fields.headline: D-Day for market merger
fields.standfirst: London stock exchange must cement German deal
fields.trailText: London Stock Exchange officials are due to meet today in a make or break attempt to unite the exchange with its German rival.
fields.body:
London Stock Exchange officials are due to meet today in a make or break attempt to unite the exchange with its German rival.

Negotiations between the London exchange and the Deutsche Borse of Germany are understood to have been successfully concluded and one City source said last night that it was now up to London to cement the deal.

Assuming executives at the London exchange are able to agree among themselves on terms the union is expected to be announced next week, in time for the May 4 deadline imposed by the Germans.

The deal is understood to be structured around the creation of a new company, with the two exchanges taking an equal stake. Nasdaq, the high-tech stock market in the US, which was thought to have been involved in three-way talks, is not expected to be included at this stage but may be invited to join the alliance in the coming weeks.

The German exchange is expected to delay its plans for an initial public offering. May 4 was set as the deadline for the talks because this was the day the exchange was due to issue its prospectus.

London is in the process of demutualising to become a privately-owned company, enabling it to take a 50% stake in the new company.

The London exchange has persuaded the Deutsche Borse to exclude its clearing business interests from the negotiations which, if included, would have given the German exchange a larger stake in any combined company. That raised the prospect of the London exchange being criticised of selling out to the newer German exchange, which has been more successful than London in developing a market for high technology stocks.

The move to create a new exchange, which will probably be headed by the Frankfurt exchange's chief executive Werner Seifert, is expected to be interpreted by the Paris Bourse as a sign that it is being frozen out of any pan-European alliance. The Paris exchange has already attempted to forge a European market through a merger with the Dutch and Belgian stock exchanges. It also indicated it would like to do a deal with London, the busiest centre for share trading in Europe.

webTitle: Record AT&T offering helps shake off Dow jitters

fields.headline: Record AT&T offering helps shake off Dow jitters
fields.trailText: AT&T, the telecommunications group, shrugged off most of the jitters that hit the US stock market yesterday with a flotation that raised $10.6bn (£6.6bn) - more money in the United States than ever before.
fields.body:
AT&T, the telecommunications group, shrugged off most of the jitters that hit the US stock market yesterday with a flotation that raised $10.6bn (£6.6bn) - more money in the United States than ever before.

By lunchtime, shares of AT&T Wireless Group were 7% above their opening price at $31. By contrast, the Dow Jones Industrial Average of blue-chip stocks was trading down about 1% as investors reacted nervously to evidence that wages had increased faster than at any time since 1989.

The economic data increased fears that the US central bank will raise interest rates when it meets next month.

In such an atmosphere, analysts said that the AT&T offering had performed well, even though the percentage increase was some way below that achieved by other, smaller initial public offerings. The Nasdaq composite index opened sharply lower before moving higher by midday. Investor behaviour suggested that the technology stocks in the Nasdaq, which have been hard hit in the past month, could better withstand higher interest rates than the blue chips in the Dow.

The cause of yesterday's concern was the latest publication of the Employment Cost Index by the labour department. This indicator revealed that the pay and benefits of US workers rose by a higher-than-expected 1.4% in the first quarter of this year, the fastest pace in more than 10 years.

"This undoubtedly raises the risk of a 50-basis point rate hike next month," said Ian Shepherdson, chief US economist at High Frequency Economics.

webTitle: Blue blood fund courts new rich

fields.headline: Blue blood fund courts new rich
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The City's most blue-blooded firm, Cazenove, is planning to court the nouveau riche though a new £250m private equity fund which will invest in the burgeoning technology, media, telecommunications and internet sectors.
fields.body:
The City's most blue-blooded firm, Cazenove, is planning to court the nouveau riche though a new £250m private equity fund which will invest in the burgeoning technology, media, telecommunications and internet sectors.

The Cazenove New Europe Access Fund will be managed by a new business division headed by Tod Bensen, a partner of the firm who has been running its global equity capital markets for five years.

Mr Benson, the chief executive of the new division, Cazenove Private Equity, said the fund would not invest in risky start-up companies but inject finance into them when they were looking for the second or third round of investment.

The fund already has £200m of funding from Cazenove and from outside investors.

The next £50m will be raised in the coming months. Employees at Cazenove, one of the last investment banking partnerships, will be offered the chance to invest in the fund.

Mr Bensen said he believed there was a "lot of money to be made" by companies with the capacity to help traditional companies adopt to the world of online commerce.

fields.headline: Wunderkind and co
fields.standfirst:
Julian Joseph
Wigmore Hall
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Julian Joseph
Wigmore Hall
Rating: ***
fields.body:
He is known for the talent in his fingers, but Julian Joseph is surprisingly vocal. He sings; he broadcasts; and now he's putting the finishing touches to a stage routine which incorporates jokes (very bad) and tributes (hyperbolic).

His wunderkind reputation preceded him, as did prolonged and enthusiastic rounds of applause at every juncture. For the music at least, it was earned.

Joseph's regular collaborators were there: Orlando Le Fleming on bass and Adam Salkeld on guitar. Guest soloist was George Coleman, who, along with his saxophone, shared glory days with BB King, Max Roach, Miles Davis and Lionel Hampton; these days he has taken to appearing with Joseph, a former Branford Marsalis protege and in his early 30s, still the great (black) hope of British jazz.

It was a glowing team, but at first the sparks refused to ignite. In a trio-only tribute to the Duke, Candlelight Supper, Moonlight Affair, Joseph's piano seemed too strident for the self-effacing guitar and gentle bass. Coming in with his own composition, You Mean So Much to Me, Coleman added a new buoyancy and crispness, setting swathes of bright melody against buzzy repetitions, but his full-bodied fluency still found itself a little flat at the top of the range.

Salkeld, a quiet hero with an unshowy style, provided a background often too reverberative and glassy to rival Joseph's assertive, opaque flights. No matter: by the time the band had rippled through the jaunty Nat King Cole ballad You're Looking at Me, one sensed a shift in gear and a new readiness to attack, gearing up with a catchy bass heartbeat.

The palette of piano tones remained light and sweet until the first set came to a close, when Benny Golson's Blues March saw Joseph become more animated, allowing smoothness to give way to some deliberate, obtuse melodic ideas to surface and stretch. Salkeld followed suit, his rhythm guitar-stopping lending friction and building tension.

Enja, which launched the second set, was another terrific number, with Coleman alternately needle-sharp and shimmery, and Joseph inventively improvising on a vamp better known as the 007 theme. That gave way to a more fragmented undertow, pierced by some agile right-hand work by Joseph, and full of flourishes. But despite the neat, flavoursome endings, some tunes - like Uncle Frank, another Coleman composition with a calypso feel - rambled on into clumsiness.

fields.headline: Too many old voices
fields.standfirst:
David Gray
Manchester University
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
David Gray
Manchester University
Rating: **
fields.body:
If you've seen the film This Year's Love, starring Kathy Burke, then you should already be familiar with David Gray. As well as writing and singing the title track, Gray appeared as the leader of the band featuring Burke's dubious vocal talents. Thankfully, Gray's own credentials are more impressive.

Songs from the film appeared on the London-based, Irish singer-songwriter's fourth album, White Ladder. First available on his own label, iHt, in the autumn of 1998, this collection of carefully-crafted ballads has already sold over 100,000 copies and has just been re-released, yet in England, until the film, Gray remained relatively unknown.

What was immediately apparent about this near capacity gig was the the reach and control of Gray's voice. Soulful and stadium-strong, at times it was redolent of Richard Ashcroft or a young Bob Dylan, and Gray was particularly adept at trailing his "woohs" and snarling his "naaahs" with an affecting gravelly intonation.

Gray and his supporting musicians went through the album with such conspicuous glee that you wondered whether they were trying a little too hard to please. In addition to his black shirt with its country and western white trim, Gray wore a smile which hung from his ears all night, while the drummer, perhaps overshadowed by the drum machine, chose to give a good impression of someone who has taken one disco-biscuit too many.

Although earnest, well-structured compositions such as My Oh My, White Ladder, and Babylon provided a solid background for Gray's fulsome vocals, the music tended to lack incisiveness. This wasn't helped by the additional percussion on tape which created the uneasy situation of an authentic singer-songwriter being backed by a karaoke-like synthetic sound. It is possible to combine the two effectively, as the bouncy bassline of Please Forgive Me, an Ibiza favourite, proved, but for the most part it felt like unnecessary gimmickry.

We're Not Right, Sail Away, and Silver Lining were sung with feeling, even though, as their titles suggest, the lyrics sometimes head for the innocuous or the sentimental. It's ideal listening for the post-club comedown, or for a balmy summer evening, and the band struggled to make it work live.

On For Century Ends, from his first album, Gray sounded like Mike Scott from the Waterboys, while for the last of three encores, he came across somewhere between Morrisons Jim and Van. Gray certainly has the voice, but now he must make it his own.

fields.headline: Mobile phones auction nets £22bn
fields.trailText: Canadian telecoms company Telesystem International Wireless in partnership with Hong Kong conglomerate Hutchison Whampoa yesterday emerged as the new player in Britain's mobile phone industry after the government auction for licences finally ground to a halt.
fields.body:
Canadian telecoms company Telesystem International Wireless in partnership with Hong Kong conglomerate Hutchison Whampoa yesterday emerged as the new player in Britain's mobile phone industry after the government auction for licences finally ground to a halt.

The consortium will join the four existing network operators, Vodafone, BT Cellnet, Orange and One2One, which all avoided the unthinkable and secured licences to run next generation mobile phones.

The historic auction was decided after cable company NTL dropped from the running yesterday morning with the combined bids on the table totalling an astonishing £22.48bn.

The auction started almost eight weeks ago, has been through 150 rounds of bidding and outstripped government hopes of raising around £3bn.

The existing network operators breathed a sigh of relief as the downside of not winning and being excluded from offering multimedia services would have been enormous. "This was a high stakes game," said BT chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield.

Canning Fok, the Hutchison group managing director who stewarded the launch of Orange in 1994, said he expected the new business to win 4m customers - around 20% market share - and break even within five years.

He estimated that the cost of building the network would add a further £5bn to the £4.4bn price of securing the licence.

The next generation networks, otherwise known as universal mobile telecommunications systems (UMTS), will allow operators to offer high-speed internet access and video phones. The licences are for 20 years.

"This is something totally new," Mr Fok said. "UMTS will totally change people's lives and this business will be more valuable than anything we have done before."

In a complicated arrangement TIW will own the licence and the network but will sell airtime wholesale to an operating company 90.1% owned by Hutchison. TIW will own 9.9% of the operating company which has not yet been named.

Vodafone won licence B, which offers the most capacity available to an existing network with a £5.96bn bid. BT secured licence C for £4.03bn, One2One is paying £4bn for licence D and Orange is paying £4.09bn for licence E.

Spectrum for the original mobile phone licences was handed out by beauty parade with a minimal charge to cover administration costs.

Mr Fok said Hutchison, whose role in the bid only emerged a few weeks ago, had deliberately hidden behind TIW so as not to prejudice Vodafone-AirTouch's takeover of Mannesmann in which it held a 10% stake.

"At the time of registering in January, Hutchison's strategy in Europe was through Mannesmann," he said. "At that time Mannesmann was under siege and if we had registered for a new licence in the UK it would have sent out the wrong signal - that we were a seller. [Staying hidden] helped us to maximise value in the takeover contest."

The result gives Hutchison a second bite at the British mobile phone market after it made a near £20bn profit from the sale of Orange last year to Mannesmann.

NTL cracked on Tuesday when the company asked for a time out in the auction. Some analysts are speculating that France Telecom, which was bankrolling the NTL bid, may have decided it would be more economical to mount a takeover bid for Orange.

Winners will have to pay half the sums up front with an option to defer the rest over the life of the licences.

The winners

BT Cellnet

BT Cellnet has been the perennial also ran in Britain's mobile phone market, trailing the leader Vodafone.

The business was launched in 1983 with British Telecom owning 60% and Securicor 40%, a situation forced on BT by regulators concerned the company would dominate the nascent market. After the restriction was lifted BT paid £3.15bn for the stake last year.

The network's profits have continued to lag Vodafone's domestic business. Its underperformace is a constant thorn in the group's side. At the end of last year BT Cellnet had 7m subscribers. BT Cellnet is expected to be given a separate stock market listing.

TIW

When the 13 bidders lined up for the auction of next generation mobile phone licences eight weeks ago, few people would have put their money on little-known Telesystem International Wireless.

Yet the Montreal-based company yesterday saw off competition from higher-profile candidates Virgin, MCI WorldCom, Global Crossing and NTL.

The business was founded as a paging company in 1994 by Charles Sirois. It moved swiftly into mobile phones and now claims to have 2.7m subscribers across Asia, Brazil and Europe in both conventional cellular and digital radio services.

In Britain it owns 78% of Dolphin Telecom, which runs a digital radio service aimed at the business community.

Digital radio, which has yet to be adopted on a wide scale, can act like a walkie-talkie in private networks as well as a conventional mobile phone. It can also handle high speed data and is aimed at mobile workforces such as sales people.

In addition to its digital radio service, Dolphin has over 300,000 subscribers across six European countries on analogue radio access such as those used by taxi services.

TIW is a regular participant in beauty parades held for conventional mobile phone licences and recently partnered British Telecom in a failed bid to run a network in Hungary.

In January Hutchison Whampoa, which is partnering TIW in its mobile venture in Britain, took a 5% stake in the Canadian operator.

One2One

The smallest of the four networks in Britain, One2One, launched in 1993 as a venture between Cable & Wireless and American telecoms firm US West.

The company was the first digital network in Britain but in its early years suffered from a series of marketing gaffes - including free weekend and evening calls, which led to consumers not using them at any other time.

In recent years its performance has improved and the originally limited network, which now covers 98% of the population, has just over 5m customers.

The For Sale sign was hoisted over One2One last year. Germany's Deutsche Telekom agreed a deal to buy it for £8.4bn.

Vodafone AirTouch

Vodafone last year overtook BT as Britain's biggest telecoms company after merging with US company AirTouch. It hasn't looked back since.

A rapid succession of deals by the chief executive, Chris Gent, has seen the formation of a US-wide joint venture and the ground-breaking takeover of Germany's Mannesmann.

The company was created by Racal Electronics and runs the biggest network in Britain.

Launched on January 1 1985, the network had 7.9m subscribers in this country by the end of last year.

It has interests in 24 countries across five continents and has a market capitalisation of £171bn.

Orange

Orange was the last network to launch in Britain but is widely held to have reshaped the way the industry does business.

The company launched in 1994 and was the first network to develop a strong consumer brand. It now has over 6m customers.

At launch the business was 65% owned by Hong Kong conglomerate Hutchison Whampoa, 5% by Barclays Bank and 30% by British Aerospace.

Orange joined the stock market in 1996 and last year was sold to Mannesmann, the German telecoms and industrial group for £20bn. The deal triggered the acquisition of Mannesmann by Vodafone and Orange's future ownership is again in question.

fields.headline: Hegemony broken
fields.standfirst:
London Philharmonic Orchestra/Kent Nagano
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
London Philharmonic Orchestra/Kent Nagano
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
When postwar French music was dominated by the hegemony of Messiaen and Boulez, a distinctive but less radical creative voice like Henri Dutilleux's tended to be disregarded. But with Messiaen gone and the old orthodoxies crumbled away, Dutilleux's elegantly crafted and subtly coloured music has come into its own. Now 84, he has been the London Philharmonic's "composer in focus" this season, and he was in the audience at the Festival Hall on Wednesday when Kent Nagano and the orchestra, with the cellist Lynn Harrell, played one of his best known and most impressive scores, Tout un monde lointain, written in 1970 for Rostropovich.

The title comes from Baudelaire, and each of the five continuous movements carries an epigraph from the poet as well. It is music of suggestion rather than explicit programmatic content, in which the cello sings a series of enigmatic songs, some of them passionate, some of them introspective, while the orchestra adds its own commentary. The colouring and the voicing of the music is always unmistakably French - Dutilleux's fastidious orchestration has a Ravelian sureness about it - and it is bound together with thematic and harmonic threads that run almost unheard through all the movements.

Harrell delivered the solo part with great command, and obvious relish; he made the considerable technical challenges look almost negligible. And Nagano is an expert in marshalling the forces in a score like this, applying all the colours in the right proportion, bringing perspective to the textures, getting the rhythmic patterning exactly right.

Nagano began with the third of Beethoven's Leonora Overtures, using an over-sized orchestra (10 cellos) yet producing a performance that on its own slightly raucous terms was highly effective. He ended with Prokofiev's Fifth Symphony, in a performance that unfolded perfectly naturally and in which he was constantly on the lookout for a dark undertow to the balletic surfaces of the music, sometimes managing to find one.

fields.headline: Virgin Direct under review
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Virgin boss Sir Richard Branson is reviewing the structure of the loss-making Virgin Direct financial services, raising speculation that the City-shy businessman could be planning a £1bn flotation.
fields.body:
Virgin boss Sir Richard Branson is reviewing the structure of the loss-making Virgin Direct financial services, raising speculation that the City-shy businessman could be planning a £1bn flotation.

Sir Richard has instructed Goldman Sachs, his bankers, to discuss all possible options for Virgin Direct with Merrill Lynch, the investment banking adviser to AMP, the Australian insurance group which owns 50% of Virgin Direct.

At the centre of the talks is the issue of whether the assets of Virgin Direct should be injected into Virgin.com, the umbrella company for all Virgin's internet activities.

Aside from financial services this includes Virgin's stake in trainline.com, the ticket booking service, and plans for selling other services online.

It is understood that AMP is being the offered the opportunity to exchange its stake in Virgin Direct for a share in Virgin.com.

No official valuation has been made for Virgin Direct but sources close to the group indicate it could be worth as much as £1bn after the summer launch of Virgin-money.com, an independent advice service.

The Virgin Direct talks are likely to raise speculation that AMP, which is facing management difficults in Australia, may use the talks as an opportunity to realise the value of its investment through a flotation or trade sale.

A Virgin spokesman insisted last night, however, that a float was not on the agenda.

"But the business is going very well," he said. "There are discussions with the other shareholder as to whether this company will become part of Virgin.com or whether its future lies elsewhere".

Set up five years ago, Virgin Direct has yet to make money for either of its shareholders but is understood to be on course to break even this year.

At the start of the year Rowan Gormley, the founder of the ground-breaking business, was replaced as chief executive by Mark Lund, the former managing director of Henderson Investors, which is part of AMP's extensive stable in the UK.

Virgin Direct has a subsidiary, Virgin One, which is 50% owned by Royal Bank Scotland - although the Scottish bank is not thought to be involved in the talks.

Mr Lund was said to have been brought in with a mandate to turn Virgin Direct's losses into a profit. The orginal plan was for it to turn a profit within five years with an option for flotation by 2003.

fields.headline: Euro sinks to new low
fields.standfirst: European Central Bank raises rates to fend off inflationary pressure
fields.trailText: The impotence of Europe's policymakers to prop up the ailing single currency was demonstrated yesterday when the euro plunged to new record lows against the dollar within hours of the European Central Bank's decision to raise interest rates.
fields.body:
The impotence of Europe's policymakers to prop up the ailing single currency was demonstrated yesterday when the euro plunged to new record lows against the dollar within hours of the European Central Bank's decision to raise interest rates.

The rate rise was seen by analysts as an attempt to bolster the ailing currency but as ECB policymakers repeated their view that the euro will strengthen as European growth picks up, the single currency shed more than a cent against the dollar, taking it below 91 cents for the first time.

"It's a euro weakness story yet again," said Audrey Childe-Freeman, European economist at CIBC World Markets. "The market was trading more cautiously before the ECB just in case we got a surprise move and once a 25 basis point rate hike was out of the way people just carried on selling euros."

In a statement explaining its decision to raise interest rates to 3.75%, the European Central Bank said it was concerned strong credit growth and the weakening currency might push up inflation. Bundesbank president Ernst Welteke said the rise had been necessary to avoid the need for a heftier rate rise later.

"I see a higher rate of growth in the eurozone than in the US and when that happens the euro's external value will rise," he said. "That is the reason why it is always possible to talk about the euro's potential."

However, on the foreign exchange markets yesterday, the euro's potential seemed to be entirely downward. It closed in London at 57.86 cents against the pound, its lowest ever level, equivalent to around 3.37 German marks, a 14-year high.

After tumbling to a record 90.89 cents against the dollar, it closed at 91.15 cents in London, more than a cent lower than its previous close.

Analysts said the European Central Bank had had little choice but to increase rates. If they had done nothing, the market would have interpreted it as a signal the bank was not concerned about the euro and would have dumped the currency.

"The expectations in the market were so pronounced that they didn't have much choice," said Eckhard Schulte of Industrial Bank of Japan.

However, the 0.25% rise was not enough to restore faith in the bank's support for the euro.

"This kind of hike is not going to stop the rut on the euro," said David Brown, chief economist at Bear Stearns in London. "They should have gone for half point hike."

But other analysts said a larger rate rise would have smacked of panic.

The euro has floundered in recent days at historic lows but analysts say there is little the central bank can do to restore faith in the euro as US economic growth roars past Europe's budding revival.

Mr Schulte said the bank had made a mistake by saying in its statement that the single currency's exchange rate did not reflect economic fundamentals.

"I don't think the ECB should generate this expectation of a rising currency soon, because they cannot manage it," he said. "The ECB has generated the expectation of a rising euro for many months and it didn't happen. And that of course means that to some extent the central bank is losing credibility."

webTitle: BMW snub for rival Rover offer

fields.headline: BMW snub for rival Rover offer
fields.standfirst:
Venture capital firm labelled 'industrial locusts' as it prepares to finalise deal with German car maker
Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The German car maker, BMW, yesterday cleared the way for the takeover of Rover by venture capitalists by rejecting union demands for serious consideration to be given to a rival offer from the Phoenix consortium.
fields.body:
The German car maker, BMW, yesterday cleared the way for the takeover of Rover by venture capitalists by rejecting union demands for serious consideration to be given to a rival offer from the Phoenix consortium.

BMW said Phoenix had failed to provide details of its financial backing, and so there was "no basis for entering negotiations" with it. The company made plain that the way was now open for Alchemy Partners, a London-based venture capital firm, to wrap up its bid for Rover within days.

The BMW brush-off angered union leaders who believe that the West Midlands businessmen behind the Phoenix offer would have saved thousands more car industry jobs than Alchemy.

John Edmonds, the general secretary of the GMB general workers' union, accused BMW of handing Rover to "asset strippers" by deciding to end talks with John Towers, the former Rover executive, who led the Phoenix bid.

"It is becoming increasingly apparent that BMW has never had any intention of seriously considering the Phoenix bid," Mr Edmonds said.

"Their only desire has been to cut and run. In doing so, they have abandoned thousands of skilled and dedicated workers to the tender mercies of the Alchemy asset strippers."

Mr Edmonds launched the most scathing attack yet on Alchemy, branding the firm "industrial locusts" and attacking its record. "So much of what they touch turns to dust rather than gold. If, as it would seem, Alchemy are to take over Longbridge, ministers must do everything to protect the jobs and rights of workers that remain."

Phoenix had won the support of ministers and unions because it intended to maintain Rover as a volume car producer. This would have involved fewer redundancies than Alchemy's plan to turn Rover into a low volume maker of MG cars.

Tony Woodley, chief car industry negotiator for the transport and general workers' union, said that BMW shareholders should ask why there was "an indecent haste to sell" which could cost them hundreds of millions of pounds.

Members of the Towers consortium maintained that the rival offer was still "alive" and they hoped that a deadline for reaching a deal could be extended to next week. Roger Lyons, general secretary of the Manufacturing, Science and Finance union, called on BMW to extend the deadline "to allow Phoenix to put its case, which in our view is better for the British economy, the West Midlands and Rover workers."

Alchemy said it still hoped to reach a deal in the next few days. A spokesman said: "It looks like the period of uncertainty is nearing an end, which must be good news."

The BMW statement said that the Towers team had not provided details of the financial backing, which "does not constitute a basis for entering negotiations".

The statement added: "The negotiations with Alchemy Partners will continue in a straightforward manner."

Mr Woodley confirmed that unions were planning legal action at the lack of consultation over the decision to sell Rover. The challenge could cost BMW shareholders hundreds of millions of pounds, he warned.

BMW yesterday denied reports that it planned to make at least 200,000 vehicles at the Rover Cowley plant, which it is retaining.

Tata, the Indian conglomerate with interests including car making and Tetley tea, also dismissed reports that it was considering a bid for Rover.

fields.headline: Red handed
fields.standfirst: The man who had pornography sent to him at work
fields.trailText: Brief encounters: The employment lawyer and the man who had pornography sent to him at work.
fields.body:
I recognise Steve when I enter the applicant's waiting room by the defeated curve to his shoulders and (more conclusively) by the bright blue ring binder gripped on his knee. I have an identical one in my wheelie bag. Inside is page after page of photocopied material, each page densely black with photographs. Lipsticked mouths rendered black and smeared against shock white faces, the deep black smudge of crotches.

In this age of internet porn, Steve was receiving the old-fashioned stuff at work, videos (which fortunately don't photocopy) and reams of accompanying advertising material for more videos and the clumsy hardware of sexual fanatasy - artificial vaginas, inflatable mice (?) that kind of thing.

We are here, in the face of this humiliating tome put together by Steve's former employer, because we say the employer acted hastily in dismissing Steve, didn't take into account Steve's twenty years with the company, didn't consider Steve's mitigating circumstances.

Me: "So Steve, let's run through what you're saying about the mitigating circumstances."
Steve: "Well, the point I was making to them was that my wife and I had not been getting on and I couldn't send for this stuff to come to the house. She was always opening my mail. She'd have killed me."

An unspoken dismal "aha" passes between us. Steve looks at his knees.

When we get into the tribunal, the employer's counsel is determined to make the tribunal panel look at the pitiful horror in the ringbinder in detail "so you can see why my clients were so concerned at what might have happened had a female employee opened one of these packages" (none ever did).

The chairman, a sedate and courtly old veteran of these battles, turns the pages politely with an empty expression, hardly blinks at Barracks Buttholes: "Well, yes, we can certainly see that the material is pornographic". At one stage I notice the female wingmember wiping her hand on her jacket, as if the papers were somehow saturated with virtual emissions.

It is the other wingmember I really worry about - an excitable and red-faced union man I've come across before. I can see as we thumb through the tired variations - teeny sex, old ladies, lesbians, three-ways, pregnant women - that he is bursting to say something. "Eeehm, just as a matter of interest.."

The room holds its breath.

He carries on, "I'm, eeehm, just wondering, what is "double anal"..."

The room waits in horror.

The chair bends over to him and whispers urgently. Red-face crumples irritably: "Well, perhaps it's not relevant to the issues in this case. I was just wondering..."

We all relax, except Steve who has been laid bare before the tribunal, for no end, as I think he finally realised this morning in the waiting room.

The tribunal decides against Steve in a relatively uncensorious fashion. There seems to be a tacit agreement that he has suffered enough. We can all go home and forget about Planet Mammary.

Am still puzzled myself about double anal. But please don't write in to explain.

webTitle: Barcelona thrown out of next season's Spanish Cup

fields.headline: Barcelona thrown out of next season's Spanish Cup
fields.trailText: The decision, by the Spanish Football Federation's Competitions Committee, follows the club's refusal to play Atletico Madrid on Monday in the second leg of their Cup semi-final at the Nou Camp.
fields.body:
Barcelona have been thrown out of next season's Spanish Cup.

The decision, by the Spanish Football Federation's Competitions Committee, follows the club's refusal to play Atletico Madrid on Monday in the second leg of their Cup semi-final at the Nou Camp.

The Catalan giants, who lost the first leg 3-0, claimed they were unable to field a team of professionals because of an injury crisis and international call-ups.

webTitle: Olsen turns to Burton for inspiration

fields.headline: Olsen turns to Burton for inspiration
fields.trailText: Egil Olsen's fragile grasp on Wimbledon's managerial hot seat appeared to weaken further yesterday when the club unveiled their new assistant manager Terry Burton.
fields.body:
Egil Olsen's fragile grasp on Wimbledon's managerial hot seat appeared to weaken further yesterday when the club unveiled their new assistant manager Terry Burton.

Burton was Joe Kinnear's right-hand man before becoming academy director on Olsen's arrival and the move, reportedly made at the behest of the club's senior players, appears to isolate Olsen, something that Burton was predictably keen to deny. "The spirit in training has been excellent and everyone is 100% behind the manager," he said.

This, however, is not the signal that has been coming from the dressing room. Many of the most influential players have been linked with moves away from the club, including Neil Sullivan, who will be available on a free transfer, Jason Euell, John Hartson, Ben Thatcher, Michael Hughes and Carl Cort.

Cort said this week: "If the players are less confident in the formation and have no confidence in the manager they will not perform well. I'm having to think about my career, and if we go down I'll think even deeper."

Olsen had hinted that Burton's appointment might be a stopgap measure. "The main reason for Terry's appointment is the situation we are in," he said. "After a lot of defeats you need to do something and that's what we have done. It's a positive decision and it could be good." He added: "I don't believe the things that Carl Cort is reported to have said. I have not seen the English papers but you cannot trust the tabloids. It is not true at all."

Burton said: "I don't see this as a short-term appointment, but who knows what will happen in football?"

With Sunday's crucial relegation decider at Bradford looming, Olsen has strangely decided to take a few days off to collect an award in Norway.

"The Norwegian FA's highest honour is their gold award, which has gone to only three or four people before Egil," said the first-team coach Lars Tjernaas. "In nine years he took Norway from a land of eskimos to the No2 international team in the world. Normally the award goes to ex-presidents who are about 176 years old."

If Olsen should leave, one suggested replacement is Aage Hareide, the first Norwegian to play in England when he moved to Manchester City in 1983. "That's news to me," he said when told of the speculation. He is currently managing Brondby, whom he joined in January after winning the Swedish league title with Helsingborg last year. He previously worked at the Norwegian club Molde with Bjorn Gjelsten, now Wimbledon's co-owner.

webTitle: No sun, but the Don shines on

fields.headline: No sun, but the Don shines on
fields.trailText: A historic opening day for the two-tier County Championship falls victim to the rain. Frank Keating is thankful for Don Bradman's adventures at New Road to ponder over on a soggy afternoon.
fields.body:
Summer for real at last and, hurrah, the cricket season proper was unveiled yesterday as all around the expectant land the timeless certainty was hymned in unison: "This is the year, for sure, of Mal Loye, Vikram Solanki and Owais Shah."

Ah, lovely cricket... By religious rite, the most romantic packed their hampers and headed, of course, for Worcester, the game's ageless green paddock. Serious history was on offer there yesterday, for this summer the venerable County Championship - unified in sickness and in health for over a century - has been split into two divisions, and six matches were on the card to celebrate. Where would history's first ball be bowled?

Oh, soggy day... By my reckoning, Worcester was the third match abandoned without a ball bowled, following Bristol and Trent Bridge. Then Taunton and Canterbury threw in the towel and only Derby remained, marooned in squelchy hope, before a final cloudburst mocked their dopey optimism. The only action was the comings and goings of men in white coats and the only news came from those jocular acolytes of foredoom, the radio weather-forecasters.

When the first ball of the new era is actually bowled, there will be none of the elitism of football's Premiership. Not when the Second Division could put out Allan Donald, Glenn McGrath and Shoaib Akhtar as an opening attack, and an all-Australian top six of the two Matts, Elliott and Hayden, followed by Justin Langer, Stuart Law, Michael Bevan and Ian Harvey.

So much for Australians rubbishing our championship. They are quite happy to make money and hay in it, aren't they? The rains over Worcester even forced the usually monosyllabic McGrath to publicly utter a bit more than he has been wont. He looked up at the pewtery skies and then down at his interviewer with the pitying gaze he usually reserves for batsmen - but he wouldn't be drawn on his previous snidey slants on English domestic cricket. He'd have been over here anyway, he said, showing his new son James to the in-laws. Glenn married Jane from the Cotswolds after last year's World Cup had been won. And the world said: "Let's hope she cheers him up a bit."

It was a far more famous Australian, of course, who founded the time-immemorial romance of Worcester as a shrine for cricket's opening day. In 1929 the South Africans had begun their tour at New Road. That winter, Lord's asked if any county wanted to be first-up against the 1930 Australians. Only Worcester said: "Sure."

So 21-year-old Don Bradman announced himself with 236. In 1934 the little fellow came back to get his April eye in with 206; in 1938 down by the Severn he made 258; and when, in the opener of 1948, he made only 107 the local Worcester Evening News trumpeted THE DON FAILS AT LAST.

Seventy years ago, on Saturday April 26, the newly arrived Australians watched the Wembley Cup final (Arsenal 2, Huddersfield 0). The tyro Bradman left at half-time and took a train to Leeds where he was met by, and stayed overnight with, the bluff bat manufacturer William Sykes. Four days later, after his glistening 236 at Worcester, Bradman wrote in his diary: "I felt well after getting a start and my new Sykes bat was excellent."

Three score and ten years later, the Evening News story was of a computer boffin who has analysed the Bradman backlift and proved with 16 electronic sensors and images reproduced at 240-per-second why the Don was the best. As if cricket didn't know already... It was something to read, I suppose, on opening day in the rain.

And the world said: "Let's hope she cheers him up a bit." It was a far more famous Australian, of course, who founded the time-immemorial romance of Worcester as a shrine for cricket's opening day. In 1929 the South Africans had begun their tour at New Road. That winter, Lord's asked if any county wanted to be first-up against the 1930 Australians. Only Worcester said: "Sure." So 21-year-old Don Bradman announced himself with 236. In 1934 the little fellow came back to get his April eye in with 206; in 1938 down by the Severn he made 258; and when, in the opener of 1948, he made only 107 the local Worcester Evening News trumpeted THE DON FAILS AT LAST. Seventy years ago, on Saturday April 26, the newly arrived Australians watched the Wembley Cup final (Arsenal 2, Huddersfield 0). The tyro Bradman left at half-time and took a train to Leeds where he was met by, and stayed overnight with, the bluff bat manufacturer William Sykes. Four days later, after his glistening 236 at Worcester, Bradman wrote in his diary: "I felt well after getting a start and my new Sykes bat was excellent." Three score and ten years later, the Evening News story was of a computer boffin who has analysed the Bradman backlift and proved with 16 electronic sensors and images reproduced at 240-per-second why the Don was the best. As if cricket didn't know already... It was something to read, I suppose, on opening day in the rain.

webTitle: Headley's return held back by back

fields.headline: Headley's return held back by back
fields.trailText: The first day of the new two- division County Championship presented a familiar scene: no play because of rain, and concerns over the fitness of Dean Headley.
fields.body:
The first day of the new two-division County Championship presented a familiar scene: no play because of rain, and concerns over the fitness of Dean Headley.

Headley injured his lower back in a practice match two weeks ago and has not bowled since. More worryingly for the player, one of the 12 to have been awarded a central contract by England, is that the injury is in the same area as the one that restricted his participation in the winter tour of South Africa to 10 balls.

An England and Wales Cricket Board press release revealed that Headley had resumed training after scans had uncovered "no major problems". But until he tests it in practice this weekend, no one will be any the wiser.

Duncan Fletcher, the England coach, was at Canterbury yesterday as part of his mission to explain to county coaches how central contracts will work. "The problem with back injuries is that you could bowl for six years or could last six balls," he said. "It's not like a broken arm. With a back injury you never know."

Headley, who has only Kent's four-day game against the Zimbabweans starting on Wednesday to prove his fitness before the first test, said: "I'm following the advice I've been given. I just have to go along with it."

webTitle: Lewis camp call for meeting notes to be made public

fields.headline: Lewis camp call for meeting notes to be made public
fields.trailText: 8.00pm update Chris Lewis' agent has called for notes taken during a vital meeting between his client and the English Cricket Board to be made public.
fields.body:
Chris Lewis' agent has called for notes taken during a vital meeting between his client and the English Cricket Board to be made public.

And he added that the ECB didn't ask Lewis to name the three men who the Leicestershire all-rounder had been told had received money for fixing matches until a fortnight ago. Lewis was today criticised by ECB chairman Lord MacLaurin after it was revealed that there was insufficient evidence to press ahead with an investigation into match-fixing among the England side.

In a strongly-worded letter to the counties refuting Lewis' claims, the ECB said they had taken no action after being furnished with the names of three England players which he claimed sports promoter Ashim Kheterpal had told him had taken money to influence matches.

Lewis was hauled before the ECB two weeks ago after revealing details of the allegations in a paid newspaper article.

He has since been booed while appearing for Leicestershire in a Benson & Hedges game against Lancashire at Old Trafford this week and agent Gareth James is concerned that his player is being made a scapegoat.

"It doesn't make sense," said James, barely able to control his emotions at today's events. "As soon as Chris was approached, he went straight to the ECB and now we are having to read a complete re-invention of our meeting with them.

"At the time, it was agreed between myself, Chris and Simon Pack at the ECB, that it wouldn't be any use revealing the names of the three people involved because there was no proof and the whole thing had probably been invented by Kheterpal anyway.

"Then a couple of weeks after that, Chris was contacted by someone at the ECB who said he should go to the police, which he did.

"At no stage during that time did the ECB ever ask for the names of the three England players - if they had Chris would have supplied them.

"Either Lord MacLaurin has been completely misled - or I hate to think of the other option."

James also rejected MacLaurin's assertion that there was no independent witness at the initial meeting between Lewis and the ECB who could recollect the precise nature of the conversation. "Simon Pack was took a padful of notes and I would like to see them," he said. "The gloves are off in this case because Chris has done everything right, yet he is the one getting the stick.

"I have no problem with the findings of the inquiry but it amazes me that it took so long to reach adecision because the only information the ECB didn't have before was the names of the three players - and that was because they never asked for them."

The day's dramatic events began with the ECB issuing a statement through Gerard Elias QC, chairman of their disciplinary committee, clearing England players past and present of any involvement of match-fixing.

Their response to Lewis' allegations, however, was far more forthright with MacLaurin stressing: "I'm satisfied there is no foundation whatsoever in the idea that those involved at the Board were not interested in the information that was made available by Chris Lewis.

"To suggest that the Board did not seek to establish immediately from Chris Lewis the names of the England players allegedly involved as soon as this information was divulged is unbelievable."

MacLaurin also claimed there was "no truth" in accusations of a cover-up and dismissed allegations that the Board leaked the story as "unrealistic and untrue" and claimed only six Board members knew of the story including himself, chief executive Tim Lamb, International Teams Director Simon Pack and chairman of selectors David Graveney.

"For the Board to have leaked details of this case would only have served to undermine the very investigation which it had instigated," insisted MacLaurin. "The allegations are utterly refuted and I hope this will lay to rest any suspicion that the Board has acted improperly."

But having dismissed all of Lewis' revelations, MacLaurin has stopped short of implementing disciplinary action against him for bringing the game into disrepute and urged cricket followers to allow him to continue with his career.

"We have no reason to take action against him," explained MacLaurin. "He came to us and it showed a lot of guts to come forward - we don't wish to discourage anybody coming to us with information that may be important.

"We also have no reason to be embarrassed. We dealt with situation entirely properly and, if we had our time over again, we would deal with it in exactly the same fashion.

He added: "It's very sad for a sportsman like Chris to put up with jeers from the fans - he should now be allowed to continue his career."

fields.headline: Van Nistelrooy deal collapses
fields.trailText: 7.30pm update Both clubs have pulled the plug on the deal after PSV would not agree to United's extra fitness tests on van Nistelrooy's injured knee.
fields.body:
Ruud van Nistelrooy's record £18.5million transfer to Manchester United from PSV Eindhoven has collapsed.

Both clubs pulled the plug on the deal after PSV would not agree to United's extra fitness tests on van Nistelrooy's injured knee.

United wanted the Dutch international striker to prove his fitness in a match before they would complete the transfer. However PSV refused to agree to this condition and the on-off deal has been shelved indefinitely.

United claim they still want to sign van Nistelrooy and they may revive the transfer when he makes his comeback and proves he has fully recovered from his medial ligament injury.

In a statement the club said: "Manchester United is very disappointed that the transfer of Ruud van Nistelrooy from PSV Eindhoven cannot proceed at this present time. As reported on Tuesday, April 25, 2000, further tests were necessary for Manchester United to proceed with the transfer.

"The discussions that have been held between all the parties failed to reach agreement as to the extent of these tests and as a result of this difference in opinion, we cannot proceed at this present time.

"Manchester United wish Ruud every success with his rehabilitation programme and will continue to monitor the situation very closely in order to achieve our desire to make him a Manchester United player."

PSV president Harry van Raay and van Nistelrooy met today and refused to agree to United's extra conditions. Van Nistelrooy had stayed in Manchester for an extra 24 hours to carry out additional tests and the pair did not want any further delay to the deal, which would have been a British record.

Van Raay said: "There is, at this moment, a difference of opinion which cannot be resolved today. Maybe in the future but I don't know. The question is whether the knee is stable or not stable and if it's not stable there may be a problem.

"He has recovered very well, better than even our doctor expected but, even when he is recovering well and the knee is stable, he does not seem able to do what the doctors of Manchester United feel is necessary to fulfil their medical tests."

Van Raay claimed the transfer could yet go through, but he also hinted that he may sell van Nistelrooy to another club unless United change their position.

"I respect the position of Manchester United and Manchester United say they can understand the position of PSV and Ruud van Nistelrooy," he said on SkySports. "I have the problem that if Ruud van Nistelrooy is leaving PSV I need a replacement striker and my preference is to resolve situation in the course of the next week.

"We will discuss it further and I will not have contacts with any other group during that process. That is not my way of doing business. Next week there will be a meeting again between Man Utd and PSV.

"It would not be fair to talk with other possible candidates at this stage as Manchester United is a neat and fair club. If we come to conclusion that a transfer is not possible then there could be other clubs involved."

PSV spokesman Pedro Salazar-Hewitt claimed van Nistelrooy was opposed to United's extra fitness checks because he feared they might jeopardise his recovery.

"They are some conditions which have been requested by the United medical staff and he doesn't agree with them from his own principles because they are going to put in danger his rehabilitation," he said.

"Ruud van Nistelrooy still wants to play for Manchester United and it's not that there's any change in his feelings towards the club, the manager - Mr Ferguson - the chairman or anybody there.

"It's just about the medical difference of opinion. That's why we are at this impasse."

Salazar-Hewitt claims van Nistelrooy is recovering well from the medial ligament injury he suffered seven weeks ago. The club had hoped to have him back in action for their final league match against NEC Nijmegen on May 14.

However Salazar-Hewitt claimed no date had been pencilled in for the 23-year-old's comeback. "I can't tell you when he will be back because you can never put a deadline on injuries like this," he said. Van Nistelrooy, himself, is keen to return to fully fitness but respects United's standpoint.

He said: "My rehabilitation process is most important for me. I want to get fit and play as soon as possible.

"Both parties have respect for each others feelings. Manchester United is a great club and I have a good feeling about the club and the people around the club."

The van Nistelrooy transfer saga has been one long embarrassment for United from the moment Van Raay angered the Reds by prematurely announcing the deal last Thursday night. United boss Sir Alex Ferguson was furious and his mood worsened when van Nistelrooy held a press conference on Friday before the deal had been completed.

Then there were the farcical scenes on Tuesday when van Nistelrooy was turned away from Old Trafford and his press conference aborted after he failed a fitness test on his knee. United said then that the deal was only on hold while they carried out extra tests, but it is clear now that it is highly unlikely that the transfer will ever be completed.

webTitle: Gooners to continue good work at Goodison

fields.headline: Gooners to continue good work at Goodison
fields.standfirst: Mike Hodgkinson, our man with one eye on rugby league trends now the summer's fast approaching, points out the best bets in a difficult week
fields.trailText: Mike Hodgkinson, our man with one eye on rugby league trends now the summer's fast approaching, points out the best bets in a difficult week.
fields.body:
Things get a bit tricky round this time of year, with all those tooth-and-nail relegation/promotion dogfights which bear a closer resemblance to cup ties than to league fixtures. There are also the 'feet-up' teams stranded in mid-table who, if football were racing, could be hauled in front of the stewards under the non-triers rules. Fortunately, the shrewd and eagle-eyed punter can still find small pockets of value, especially when it comes to wins away from home.

You might like to consider the following for inclusion in your weekend accumulators. Arsenal have won their last five against Everton, and are unbeaten at Goodison over their seven most recent visits. A late-season surge is customary for the Gunners under Arsene Wenger, who will be encouraged by the fact that four of Walter Smith's senior players were involved in midweek international duty - Don Hutchison, Richard Dunne, Abel Xavier and David Weir. In addition, American striker Joe Max Moore has ligament damage and will not start.

Now Mark Hughes is a Toffee expect fireworks if he turns out on Saturday - Sparky had a habit of mixing it with Arsenal during his days with Manchester United and could be taking an early shower if he's feeling feisty. If anyone offers you attractive odds on a red card for the Welsh manager, snap them up.

One division below, there's money to be made at Selhurst Park where Blackburn face hosts Crystal Palace. The Rovers held Charlton at home on Monday, on the back of a point away to Grimsby - which would have been three were it not for the goalkeeping heroics of the Mariners' Danny Coyne. Palace, meanwhile, were suffering at the hands of Birmingham and appear to have lost the plot at home. In fact, they haven't won at Selhurst Park since the turn of the century.

Blackburn boss Graeme Souness will get the best out of his players before the season's end, perhaps by reminding them that the Rovers' last two visits to the Eagles have produced wins. No point bucking a fruitful trend.

Easter Monday saw Colchester go down to Wrexham in Division Two, and the U's should be ripe for the picking now they are clear of trouble at the foot of the division. Bristol City can benefit. The Robins followed their weekend defeat in the Bristol derby with a draw against relegation battlers Oxford and will be hoping to finish their season in style after a disappointing recent run. They've certainly got enough in hand to turn things round at Layer Road.

In Division Three, Brighton travel to Gay Meadow. Hosts Shrewsbury are now bottom, have nicked only two wins in 23 games and even though they're desperate - and may well play above themselves - are likely to find the Seagulls too tough. The Shrews have been living up to their timid rodent of a nickname all season and Monday's defeat at Halifax will not have done their confidence any good at all.

Finally, Southampton have lost only one out of 29 at home to Leicester. You can't argue with that kind of history, so if you want a home banker look no further.

Suggested bets
Everton v Arsenal - away win
Crystal Palace v Blackburn - away win
Colchester v Bristol City - away win
Shrewsbury v Brighton - away win
Southampton v Leicester - home win.

fields.headline: Welsh cabinet secrecy dropped
fields.trailText: Rhodri Morgan, the new first secretary for Wales, yesterday broke new ground by publishing minutes of the Welsh assembly cabinet and in the process revealed he is fighting the Treasury to keep control of all the proceeds raised in Wales from the proposed tobacco tax.
fields.body:
Rhodri Morgan, the new first secretary for Wales, yesterday broke new ground by publishing minutes of the Welsh assembly cabinet and in the process revealed he is fighting the Treasury to keep control of all the proceeds raised in Wales from the proposed tobacco tax.

The three pages of minutes, a victory for freedom of information campaigners, also reveal concern about leaks and premature press coverage of job announcements. If the leaks continued "then there could be a damaging effect upon potential future investment and all the agencies concerned needed to respect the investor's wishes on the handling of announcements", the minutes state.

The minutes cover a cabinet meeting on March 13 and are said to be a full account except for issues of commercial confidentiality.

The minutes of the British cabinet are kept secret for 30 years and the home secretary, Jack Straw, is still under pressure from peers to make further concessions over his much-criticised freedom of information bill.

The director of the Campaign for Freedom of Information, Maurice Frankel, praised Mr Morgan. "The minutes reveal business-like, practical and sometimes mundane discussions and suggest that the traditional secrecy in this area may have more to do with protecting mystique than real secrets or highly sensitive discussions.

"The public can be told what is going on without bringing the process of government to its knees."

The minutes were published on the internet in English and Welsh as part of Mr Morgan's drive to make the assembly one of the most open governments in Europe.

Mr Morgan wants all assembly information, including advice to ministers from civil servants, to be made publicly available unless there is an overwhelming reason not to disclose.

The minutes also reveal that Mr Morgan is considering setting up a separate honours awards system, perhaps on St David's day, to recognise the good works undertaken by Welsh men and women. The cabinet is also to discuss the controversial issue of councillors' allowances. There has been criticism in Wales over the level of payments.

The minutes hint at a battle with the Treasury ahead when they state: "The cabinet agreed that a percentage of the revenue from the proposed tobacco tax should come to Wales as part of the Welsh block so that the assembly could determine how it should be spent."

The minutes also reveal that Mr Morgan is considering setting up a separate honours awards system, perhaps on St David's day, to recognise the good works undertaken by Welsh men and women. The cabinet is also to discuss the controversial issue of councillors' allowances. There has been criticism in Wales over the level of payments. The minutes hint at a battle with the Treasury ahead when they state: "The cabinet agreed that a percentage of the revenue from the proposed tobacco tax should come to Wales as part of the Welsh block so that the assembly could determine how it should be spent."

fields.headline: The right to education
fields.trailText: When you have spent years earning next to no money helping children without textbooks to learn in schools without roofs, it can be galling to hear politicians and bureaucrats claim no new resources are needed for education.
fields.body:
When you have spent years earning next to no money helping children without textbooks to learn in schools without roofs, it can be galling to hear politicians and bureaucrats claim no new resources are needed for education.

Take Charles, the director of a small Benin non-governmental group (NGO) working with impoverished rural children. "This conference is unbelievable. This hotel costs $200 a night," he said.

"That would pay for dozens of children to go to school for years. What is the world community trying to tell us? The message they are giving is that education is something for the elites and the rich to decide on. They say they want non-government groups to be here, but we feel very excluded."

Manvi Shrivastav, who works with the poorest of her Nepalese people to claim their right to education, said of the conference organisers: "They are spending so much money which is not going to change the life of even one of the poor. I don't feel the conference is for us. They don't see the NGOs as important."

Officially, of course, the UN bodies and most governments say that no progress in education is possible without the non-government groups. The international development secretary, Clare Short, will today echo Kofi Annan's speech when she says that "education targets cannot be reached without grassroots groups keeping governments in check and urging faster progress".

"We are the ones at the grassroots level in touch with the real needs of people. We are the ones coming up with ideas and solutions, yet we are treated like outsiders," said Robert Mensah of the Ghanaian National Education Campaign.

"They say we are essential for democracy, but they allow no democracy when they make decisions which affect us and the people we represent."

The anger of the NGOs is liable to spill over. Yesterday, the Global Campaign for Education, which represents thousands of NGOs and teachers working in education and de velopment in 180 countries, debated whether to boycott the main conference.

It narrowly decided against, but last night leading NGOs were threatening to withdraw from the committee which will draft the action plan which is expected to emerge from the conference tomorrow night.

"We do not want to be part of a system that delivers only hot air and broken promises," said an Oxfam spokesman.

The NGOs believe that governments and international bodies are effectively bankrupt of ideas and have engineered a situation over many years that is keeping the poorest from education. As the crisis in world education deepens, they argue that NGOs must be brought right into the consultative process.

"Governments and world bodies are having to rethink," said Kailash Sathyarthi, who set up the Global March Against Child Labour which brought together 7m people and 14,000 NGOs in 1998.

"Unesco and the world community has not delivered its education promises in the last decade. The whole process is unaccountable. NGOs are traditionally not militant, but increasingly we feel we are defending education itself."

He and others argue that the only way to stop the rot is for civil society to wrest power back from the economic and political elites who control it.

As at Seattle, but less visibly, huge new coalitions of un likely bedfellows are forming to put pressure on governments to change their educational priorities. They include churches, environmentalists, linguists, teachers' unions, development groups from rich and poor countries and anti-poverty campaigners.

"A real shift is happening," said an Indian ActionAid worker. "NGOs are no longer just doing the government's work for them. They are beginning to really put forward the voice of people."

Regina Mosokotwa, of the Forum for African Women Educationalists in Zambia, said: "At the moment only government decides what is spent on education, but civil society now wants a say. As the situation in our schools worsens, there is a recognition that things must change, and that civil society has the answers."

webTitle: Girls will not be forgotten, Annan pledges

fields.headline: Girls will not be forgotten, Annan pledges
fields.standfirst:
Aid agencies furious as world leaders shun launch of education summit

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, yesterday formally opened the World Education Forum in Dakar, and accused politicians of failing children and ignoring human rights.
fields.body:
The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, yesterday formally opened the World Education Forum in Dakar, and accused politicians of failing children and ignoring human rights.

The ceremony itself, at the lavish Meridien Hotel, added weight to the belief that senior politicians ignore the educational needs of the poorest people. Just three government leaders - none from the richest countries - were present, and most of the invited world statesmen failed to arrive.

And, while representatives from grassroots groups from all over the world clamoured to attend the opening, and thousands of children and teachers demonstrated outside, Mr Annan launched the conference in front of a crowd of mostly junior ministers, diplomats and bureaucrats.

"It is shameful," said one woman who was denied entry despite representing a coalition of more than 400 non-governmental groups covering more than 2m teachers.

Mr Annan, who could barely hide his frustration, told the conference that "125m children, 880m adults and a quarter of a billion children working in hazardous or unhealthy conditions ... are being denied a fundamental human right spelt out in international instruments their governments have signed on to".

He added that "the communities where they live are being denied a future labour force of healthy, literate and employable citizens, they are being denied the foundations for development and a future place in the global economy. They are being denied the future itself." To the annoyance of some governments, Mr Annan concentrated on the need to give girls an elementary education and restore their human rights.

"Of the more than 110m children who should be in school and who are not, two-thirds are girls. For them, the denial of human rights has struck twice over. They are also denied the equal rights of men and women.

"The first step is for societies to recognise that educating girls is not an option, but a necessity. It is a long-term investment ... and a tool for preventing conflict. It is the most cost-effective form of defence spending."

Announcing a UN initiative to educate girls, he said he hoped that a plan of action would be in place within a year to provide education for all. "We will help countries free up funds for girls' education by advising them and assisting them [with] policy and education reform and on debt relief," he said.

Mr Annan specifically endorsed the Global Action Plan, a non-governmental initiative from Oxfam, ActionAid and development groups in 180 countries which is gathering strength in Dakar.

There is a growing realisation within governments, the UN and financial institutions that unless elements of the plan are adopted by the conference, Dakar will be condemned as just another talking shop which achieves nothing and the UN system will be further discredited.

The action plan will be further endorsed today when the head of the World Bank, James Wolfensohn, announces a fast-track initiative to bring education to everyone in some countries within a few years.

Mr Wolfensohn intends to throw the bank's resources behind countries which agree to put education at the heart of development and which come up with plans to work with non-governmental groups and the private sector.

No country with a viable action plan will be held back by a lack of financial or technical resources, he is expected to tell the conference.

However, the bank is treading on politically delicate ground, and is expected to be accused of muscling in on traditional UN territory and upsetting some major donors who do not accept that new money is available or needed.

webTitle: Van Nistelrooy deal hanging in the balance

fields.headline: Van Nistelrooy deal hanging in the balance
fields.trailText: Ruud van Nistelrooy's record £18.5m transfer is hanging in the balance after the striker and PSV Eindhoven refused to meet Manchester United's demands that he must make his comeback from his medial ligament injury before the deal goes through.
fields.body:
Ruud van Nistelrooy's record £18.5m transfer is hanging in the balance after the striker and PSV Eindhoven refused to meet Manchester United's demands that he must make his comeback from his medial ligament injury before the deal goes through.

PSV and van Nistelrooy are unhappy with this condition and the Dutch club claim the transfer has hit an "impasse".

PSV spokesman Pedro Salazar-Hewitt said: "PSV and Ruud van Nistelrooy cannot agree to the additional conditions which Manchester United have requested for the completion of the transfer of Ruud to Manchester at this moment.

"Ruud does not agree to these conditions because they will put in danger his rehabilitation at this moment. He just wants to get on with his rehabilitation and he has been doing very well. At this moment the transfer is at an impasse."

PSV have pencilled in his comeback for their final league match of the season against NEC Nijmegen on May 14 and United want to see him come through the game before they write out a cheque for £18.5m.

Van Nistelrooy is disappointed that the deal remains in limbo, but he is confident he will prove his fitness to United in three weeks' time.

PSV held a meeting with van Nistelrooy and his agent Roger Linse this afternoon. They wanted the deal completed as soon as possible to allow them to concentrate on the search for van Nistelrooy's replacement.

Salazar-Hewitt claimed PSV had told United about their position, although the Old Trafford club have refused to comment all day.

"We have always been in contact with Manchester United throughout and we are on very good speaking terms with Manchester United," he said.

"Ruud van Nistelrooy still wants to play for Manchester United and it's not that there's any change in his feelings towards the club, the manager, Mr Ferguson, the chairman or anybody there. It's just about the medical difference of opinion.

"Ruud van Nistelrooy doesn't want to talk about the details of these extra conditions. They are some conditions which have been requested by the United medical staff and he doesn't agree with them from his own principles because they are going to put in danger his rehabilitation. That's all he wants to say at the moment."

webTitle: ECB describe Lewis match-fixing claims as 'unbelievable'

fields.headline: ECB describe Lewis match-fixing claims as 'unbelievable'
fields.trailText: England players have been cleared of allegations of match-fixing by an ECB inquiry, which was set up following the revelations by Chris Lewis in the News of the World.
fields.body:
The English Cricket Board have described Chris Lewis' claims that they failed to investigate his match-fixing claims last year as 'unbelievable'. Lewis made the allegation earlier this month when he confirmed an approach from an Indian businessman to fix the outcome of a Test between England and New Zealand last summer.

"It is clear that the investigation, carried out in close conjunction with the CID and involving the ICC, has found no evidence to sustain the allegations made last year that England players, past or present, had played any part in match-fixing," explained ECB chairman Lord MacLaurin.

"Although none of us has derived any pleasure from the fact of the investigation, we can take comfort from its findings."

However, MacLaurin then rounded on Lewis for making what he believes are clearly unfounded allegations, which have twice been made the front pages of the newspapers.

"I owe it to everyone associated with the game to answer the criticisms that have been levelled at the board," he said. "I am satisfied that there is no foundation whatsoever in the idea that those involved at the board were not interested in the information that was made available by Chris Lewis when he first reported the matter on August 3 1999.

"To suggest that the board did not seek to establish immediately from Chris Lewis the names of the England players allegedly involved as soon as this information was divulged is unbelievable."

MacLaurin admitted there was no independent witness to the initial meeting with Lewis and that his reluctance to name the guilty men was understandable. "There is no truth in the allegation that the ECB did nothing about the information it had received or that there has been some form of cover-up," said MacLaurin.

"Lewis was made aware of the importance that the board attached to sharing the information with the ICC (and later with the police), although records make clear Lewis' reluctance for this to happen. "Further time was given for Lewis to ponder this point in the hope that he would change his mind - but he did not."

MacLaurin completely rejected the notion that the ECB were behind the initial story being leaked, claiming it would have undermined the inquiry which had been launched subsequent to Lewis' initial allegations.

"The information provided by Lewis was handled on a strictly need-to-know basis with only a very small number of senior officials being aware - myself, chief executive Tim Lamb, international teams director Simon Pack, former director of corporate affairs Richard Peel, chairman of the disciplinary standing committee Gerard Elias and England chairman of selectors David Graveney. "The allegations are utterly refuted."

webTitle: Lockerbie judge rejects trial delay plea

fields.headline: Lockerbie judge rejects trial delay plea
fields.trailText: The trial of two Libyans accused of the Lockerbie bombing will go ahead in Holland as planned on May 3, the trial judge ruled today.
fields.body:
The trial of two Libyans accused of the Lockerbie bombing will go ahead in Holland as planned on May 3, the trial judge ruled today.

The presiding judge, Lord Ranald Sutherland rejected a prosecution request for an eight-week postponement to give more time to assess the evidence, at a hearing in the specially constructed court house at Camp Zeist, Holland.

Lord Sutherland based his decision on the fact that Abdel Basset al-Megrahi and Al-Amin Khalifa Fahima had already been in custody for more than 400 days - an unprecedented length of time under Scottish law, which is the terms on which the unique case is being heard. "I am not satisfied that a postponement is necessary," he said.

Prosecutors in the trial applied for postponement of the much-anticipated case on Tuesday, claiming that they had not been given sufficient access to lists of defence witnesses and evidence. Last Thursday, the defence said they would be calling 119 witnesses, most of whom are from Libya, although others are scattered across Malta, Sweden, Germany and the United States.

At a pre-trial hearing, lawyers for the accused revealed plans to try to prove that others were responsible for the bombing of the Boeing 747 over the Scottish village of Lockerbie which killed 270 people.

Under a deal brokered by the United Nations last year, Libya handed over the two men to stand trial in the Netherlands under Scottish law at a former US military base ceded to Britain for the trial.

Shortly before Christmas last year the defence was granted a postponement to prepare the case.

Jim Swire, head of UK Families Flight 103, said that any further postponement would be unwelcome, but that if it improved the quality of the defence or prosecution, they would accept the judge's decision.

fields.trailText: THE TRANSFER OF GREG VAN RUSEDSKI - PLAY!
fields.body:
THE TRANSFER OF GREG VAN RUSEDSKI - PLAY!

"My knees are fine. My knees have recovered. I am certain the tests will prove it." That's a booming serve from van Rusedski. 15-0 to Manchester United.

"I am just not match-fit yet." The £19m-rated Dutch striker follows up with a lovely volley. 30-0.

"I know from the surgeon and the doctors that there is not a serious problem." PSV president Harry Van Raay, desperate for some money to sign Pierre van Hooijdonk as a replacement, dispatches a crisp winner from the net despite rumours that van Rusedski has failed a second medical. 40-0 and the transfer looks on.

"If Manchester United make a problem of all this I will take van Rusedski back to PSV Eindhoven immediately." Van Raay suddenly remembers that they've already lost striker Luc Nilis to Aston Villa. A lovely backhand drive. 40-15.

"In fact, I would love to take him back. The fans never wanted to lose him, and neither did we." Oh, I say! Van Raay makes it 40-30, organises a quick meeting to sort this farce out, and PSV are right back in it.

"We are going to talk to Greg and our doctor and his manager. Then we can say something about the situation." PSV spokesman Pedro Salazar-Hewitt makes it deuce with a wonderful passing shot. This game could go either way!
