Liverpool may not have enjoyed the success of rivals Manchester United in recent years, but they certainly know how to maintain a stellar media profile. The papers may be full of the Old Trafford club's attempt to throw billions after Dutch strikers, English defenders and Italian goalkeepers, but the team of the Eighties can still generate massive interest. Can't they?

Today, Gerard Houllier told a massed throng of reporters, hold on, the bloke from the Liverpool web site, that £3m reserve defender Rigobert Song is "not for sale" to Marseille or Paris St Germain. "I will say this about the English press," he told an empty room. "They are very consistent. First it was Jamie Redknapp and Robbie Fowler, then it was Titi Camara and now it is Rigobert Song." We think he's talking about unfounded transfer speculation, but we can't recall reading any of it so don't quote us on that.

Houllier's message is clear - he wants to keep his team together. "Alex Ferguson has said that the longer his team remains together the more it will grow up together and, consequently, the better it will become. My own hasn't even played 30 games together yet." So more years of pain lie ahead for Liverpool fans, although Houllier thinks that a title may not be beyond them in "two or three years". Hmm. KEX KICKS

After Cameroonian age-falsifier Roger Milla decided to wiggle his hips and thrust his pelvis at the nearest corner flag during Italia 90, the 'quirky' goal celebration soon became as much a part of football as the post-match booze-up and having a Sky Sports dolly bird on the arm. But not perhaps for much longer.

Earlier today a court in Tehran slapped a six-month ban on 19-year-old Mohsen Rassuli for taking off his shirt and pulling down his shorts after his extra-time goal which gave Saipa a 1-0 win over Pas in the Tehran derby. In fairness to Rassuli, it was his first-team debut - and he was wearing briefs - but his pleas for clemency didn't cut the cous-cous in a country where Islamic laws are strictly observed.

"It was his first-ever appearance for the team and he scored a very crucial goal. He could not control himself," said his coach Mailikohan, leaving a window of double-entendre opportunity you could drive a Benny Hill-sized truck through.

While some may rue the demise of Bebeto's swaying baby, Maradona's drug-fuelled demotic camera stare and Aylesbury United's 'hilarious' duck walk, stuffy traditionalists like the Fiver will be quietly rejoicing. It can't be long before for there's a return to good old days when a goal was celebrated by a sensual hug and kiss.

THE RUMOUR MILL

webTitle: Telford family lose faith in justice

fields.headline: Telford family lose faith in justice
fields.standfirst:
Brother fears police will never win conviction for double 'killing'Race issues in the UK: special report
Stephen Lawrence: special report
fields.trailText: Clifton McGowan, the brother of one of the two black men found hanged in Telford, admitted yesterday that it might be impossible to charge and convict the racists who, he says, were responsible for double murder.
fields.body:
Clifton McGowan, the brother of one of the two black men found hanged in Telford, admitted yesterday that it might be impossible to charge and convict the racists who, he says, were responsible for double murder.

In an exclusive interview with the Guardian, Mr McGowan said the police effort may have come too late and that detectives were still trying to "fob them off" with excuses.

"On a scale of one to 10, I would say the chances of finding and convicting the murderers is minus 5, especially when you consider the track record of the police so far. It is a very, very long shot.

"But nothing else will be acceptable to the family. I am hopeful the truth will come out one day, but it might take years."

Mr McGowan said he blamed the West Mercia force for the death of his 20-year-old nephew Jason who was found hanging from iron railings on New Year's Day, six months after his uncle Harold "Errol" McGowan, 34, was found dead. Both men had suffered racial abuse and death threats in the months before they died.

Clifton McGowan offered fresh evidence to support the family's claim that the police were too quick to dismiss Errol's death as suicide.

"Six to eight weeks after he died a white man gave a statement to the police in which he named the men who had killed Errol. He said to the police 'I know who killed Errol'.

"Before he gave the statement he was threatened that if he ever told anyone what he knew then he would end up the same way as Errol.

"Jason approached him and persuaded him to speak up. I cannot give you his name and I have never spoken about this before. You would've thought that this would have been investigated properly by the police but it wasn't.

"Two weeks later this man's house was raided. The police said they'd had a tip-off he was hiding stolen goods, but he wasn't. I'm not sure whether the police have re-interviewed him since. I have not been told."

West Mercia police last night said they had been given several names of racists who had allegedly been harassing Errol but could not confirm the details.

Mr McGowan, who has been at the forefront of the campaign to have the deaths re-investigated, was also withering about Jack Straw, saying the home secretary had not been in touch with the family since a meeting at the beginning of March despite a pledge that he would get back to them swiftly.

Since January the chief constable of West Mercia, Peter Hampson, has apologised for the way his officers "reached premature conclusions" over the deaths and ordered a further inquiry run by Detective Superintendent Mel Shore.

With the support of the solicitor Imran Khan, who acts for the family of Stephen Lawrence, the McGowans have also secured an overseeing role for Scotland Yard's racial and violent crimes task force headed by Deputy Assistant Commissioner John Grieve.

Mr Grieve has said the deaths are being investigated "on the presumption of foul play". He defined foul play as including murder, manslaughter, complicity in another person's suicide and obstructing the coroner.

Although both Errol and Jason were the victims of racial abuse before they died, whether they were murdered or not remains far from clear.

Errol, a father of three, was found hanged from a door knob by the flex of an iron on July 2 last year.

He had complained about racist abuse from men he had turned away from the pub where he worked as a doorman, and had talked about leaving Telford for good.

But there were no marks or bruises on his body and there appeared to be no evidence that he was drugged. Jason is known to have been deeply disturbed by the death. He began investigating the circumstances and found he was being targeted for similar abuse.

He was found hanging by his belt from railings near the pub where hours earlier he had been celebrating millennium eve. There were no marks or bruises on his body.

Talk of a Combat 18 cell operating in Telford has been dismissed by the police and Searchlight, the anti-fascist magazine which monitors far right activity.

Clifton McGowan accepts there is a huge difference between racial abuse and cold-blooded murder. But he is convinced that Errol would not have taken his own life.

They were very close and he believes his brother would have "poured his heart out to me" if he had felt really depressed.

"I believe Errol was trapped in the house by more than one person. The police say there was no sign of a struggle but there are ways of immobilising people.

"And I blame the police for Jason's death. He was trying to do their job for them."

He described how he received a call on his mobile phone last December. The voice said "McGowan? If you lot don't back off this Errol thing, one of you will pay."

Mr McGowan added: "On January 1 they carried out their threat. Jason was finding things out. People were pointing the finger at certain people. Something was happening, that's for sure. He was getting very close.

"If the police convict people of racist offences for what happened to Errol before he died, that will not be consolation. I want to see them catch the men who murdered Errol and Jason."

Mr McGowan believes the current investigation will end up with the family being fobbed off with excuses.

"The police will say they can not do anything because it is too late. They will say they do not have enough clues to work on because it has been such a long time since Errol died. I think the clues are still there and it's a matter of pulling them all together.

"People will not speak up when they are concerned for their own safety. In time, things will move on and slowly the information will come out. The truth will become transparent.

"The police have their own mindset. They are patronising us in a way hoping that we will go away and that media interest will slow down so they can get out of the spotlight.

"I am not going to give up, no matter how long it takes. I'm going to keep on asking the questions they don't want to answer."

fields.headline: Click the vote
fields.standfirst: Is there anything behind the government's bluster about e-government? asks  Patrick Barkham
fields.trailText: Is there anything behind the government's bluster about e-government? asks Patrick Barkham
fields.body:
Go online and you can choose your ideal London mayor in fantasy mayoral games or even join a poll on what sex Cherie and Tony Blair's baby should be, and who your favourite member of Steps is. But, in Britain, actual online voting remains a fantasy.

Nevertheless, the government's grandiose gestures towards developing "e-government" are being backed by several important experiments next Thursday, which could encourage a move to real online voting.

For the first time in Britain, electronic voting and counting will be introduced in several local elections, including Bury and Salford, as part of a series of pilot schemes permitted by the government's new Representation of the People Act. Eighty electronic polling stations will also be installed in all the wards in Stratford on Avon's district council elections, allowing the electorate to vote via a key-pad, with a reassuringly similar layout to a traditional ballot paper.

In London's mayoral election, Milton Keynes-based firm DRS Data & Research Services will count the ballot electronically, having successfully established electronic counts in proportional representation elections in Norway and Bosnia.

The reason for adopting the electronic system in the mayoral election is purely pragmatic, says a Department of the Environment spokeswoman. With four different votes and a complex PR system, calculating it manually would have taken days.

"People are used to having a result the next morning - and they'll have one," she says.

If the results are delivered without a hitch by early morning, it will add credibility to the electronic experiment. For, while this electronic tinkering hardly sounds momentous, Britain's electoral etiquette has hardly changed in 100 years.

The Electoral Reform Society (ERS) is pleased the government is edging forward slowly. "We welcome the pilots. It is something we've been advocating for years," says Keith Hathaway, chairman of ERS's electronic voting commission.

The US got there first. Politicians turned to the net after grappling with the problem of encouraging political participation - in 1996, only 49.08% of the electorate voted in the presidential election, with time constraints the single biggest reason Americans didn't vote.

In January, Alaskan Republicans could cast their votes for the presidential primaries online through VoteHere.net. But despite the obvious benefits of internet voting in remote areas, just 35 of the 4,500 voters chose the online option.

The reaction has not been as lukewarm elsewhere. In March, Democratic primary elections held on the internet in Arizona increased turnout by 622%. There were some technical hitches as Election.com's servers crashed, and the Voting Integrity Project unsuccessfully tried to get an injunction against the process on the grounds that it excluded minorities and the poor. But Dogonvillage.com, a grassroots internet community for connecting black people, claims that in areas where its "digital hit squad" targeted black voters, turnout rose by more than 1,000%.

The Arizona election was conducted on PCs. Entranet, a small British company, recently demonstrated an online voting system to the British government's IT unit, which works across platforms, with voting via digital interactive TV, Wap (wireless application protocol) phones and PDAs (personal digital assistants).

Entranet has designed and built secure online transaction systems for the Co-operative Bank and the Woolwich. Its chief technology officer Dharmesh Mistry claims its pin and user name voting system is "more secure than a ballot card". It also ensures the information flow is one-way, so no big brother can tell who voted for who.

The security problems of online voting are "not insurmountable" says ERS's Alex Folkes. He favours an intranet system of online voting, linking up electronic polling stations on an internal computer network, rather than a genuinely "online" voting system which people can access anywhere. Electronic polling stations linked on an intranet could produce a quick result and would enable booths to be easily moved to more voter-friendly locations, such as supermarkets.

But he worries that unsupervised online voting could compromise the democratic principle of a secret ballot. "At the moment only one person is allowed into polling booths except in very special circumstances, safeguarding people from coercion. Online, who knows how many people are telling the person who is actually voting how to vote?"

Mistry accepts that online voting places "a responsibility on the voter to vote secretly", but argues it is the same as a cashpoint. "You wouldn't show people your pin number. You take that responsibility with cash and you should do the same with information."

He also claims that online voting could increase access. Voting through the TV could help housebound old people and the disabled vote, while Entranet also demonstrated electronic translation technology that would enhance the participation of people whose first language is not English.

Online voting has a wide application, for shareholders and trade unions as well as citizens. The government's step-by-step approach gets the approval of the ERS, as it helps increase internet access for the "information poor".

As Foulks says: "I don't think we are going to get a wonderful all-singing all-dancing online election yet, especially as less than one in five currently have internet access."

fields.standfirst: Read Frank Dobson's online debate in full
fields.trailText: Despite warnings that negative campaigning could be costing him votes, Labour's candidate Frank Dobson continued to raise the spectre of Ken Livingstone becoming a frivolous, high-spending mayor of London.
fields.body:
Despite warnings that negative campaigning could be costing him votes, Labour's candidate Frank Dobson continued to raise the spectre of Ken Livingstone becoming a frivolous, high-spending mayor of London.

On the day the latest ICM poll put Mr Livingstone on 51%, with Mr Dobson slipping one point to just 14%, the Labour candidate told Guardian Unlimited users he didn't believe the independent contender "will be a serious and accountable mayor of London".

In an online debate, Mr Dobson claimed Mr Livingstone "would levy a congestion charge even if there was no other transport for Londoners to use" and warned of the former Labour MP's desire to raise corporation tax and use bonds to fund the tube. "I think saying to Londoners beware the cost of Livingstone borders on being an understatement," he insisted.

Reacting to his 34-point lead over second placed Steven Norris, Mr Livingstone said: "It is clear that Labour's negative campaigning and confrontational approach have damaged its standing."

"The latest opinion poll makes clear that voters will have a straight choice between my proposal for a safe, modernised tube system within the public sector, or Steve Norris's alternative of a completely privatised Underground."

In today's debate, Mr Dobson maintained that his policy of public-private partnership for the tube would be qualified by a tough promise to vet all private bids "using a panel independent of government, London underground or any contractors to advise what would be the best deal for Londoners". If they recommended that PPP should not be used, Mr Dobson said that would be "tough luck on the government's plans".

In the wake of the ICM survey for London's Evening Standard showing Mr Dobson had lost more ground to Mr Norris, in second place on 17%, Mr Dobson openly contemplated life after the May 4 election. "In the event of me not being elected I will be the member of parliament for Holborn and St Pancras, as I have been for the last 20 years," he said.

If the ICM poll findings are replicated in the election, one week today, Mr Livingstone will win outright. If he polls less than 50%, as his campaign believes is most likely, the second choices of all the beaten candidates will be redistributed among the top two to find an overall winner.

Today's poll suggests that Mr Norris could claim second place and earn his place in the second choice "play-off" against Mr Livingstone.

webTitle: AOL/Time Warner deal 'a threat to free speech'

fields.headline: AOL/Time Warner deal 'a threat to free speech'
fields.standfirst:
Time Warner/AOL merger: special report
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: US consumer and public interest groups called for regulators to block the proposed merger of America Online and Time Warner yesterday because of fears about the company's dominance of media and internet services.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson in New York and  Andrew Osborn in Brussels
fields.body:
US consumer and public interest groups called for regulators to block the proposed merger of America Online and Time Warner yesterday because of fears about the company's dominance of media and internet services.

A coalition of advocacy groups said yesterday that the merger - which would unite the world's leading internet service provider with one of its biggest media groups - would hamper competition, lead to higher prices and stifle free speech.

They called on the Federal Communications Commission to withhold approval of the deal unless AOL and Time Warner "significantly restructure" the merger.

The call came in a joint statement from the Consumers Union, the Consumer Federation of America, Media Access Project and the Center for Media Education.

They said regulators should act before the industry was overwhelmed by a handful of groups including AOL Time Warner and AT&T, which recently bought Media One.

Jeff Chester, executive director of the Center for Media Education, said: "They will wield tremendous power in the marketplace of ideas - with the ability to shape the future of the internet and other digital media.

"The FCC can no longer afford to watch this parade of media giants march by without enacting the necessary safeguards to ensure open, fair, and competitive access." The merger had the potential to "transform broadband internet into a gated and branded community".

Rival media and internet groups, including Walt Disney as well as smaller companies, have also expressed their concerns about the proposed tie-up. Two instant messaging companies, ICast and Tribal Voice, accused AOL of "monopolistic behaviour".

AOL and Time Warner, which argue that the deal will benefit consumers by improving choice, are expected to file their own submission next month. A decision is unlikely before September.

Meanwhile in Brussels, MCI WorldCom's plans to join forces with Sprint were dealt a severe blow yesterday after the European Commission voiced "serious competition concerns" over the £80bn merger plan.

Competition commissioner Mario Monti said that a statement of objections would be issued in the next few days.

The commission's main concerns - which originally prompted its investigation - are that the new entity would dominate the internet backbone and the supply of global telecoms services to multinationals. It is now thought unlikely to approve the merger unless the companies offer new concessions.

The two have already signalled their willingness to sell off Sprint's internet backbone division but that is not thought to go far enough.

Sources familiar with the deal believe MCI WorldCom may now have to consider disposing of its UUNet internet business, something which it has so far refused to contemplate. The two companies are expected to ask for a hearing to argue their case before the commission's deadline for a decision on July 12.

webTitle: How much can you pay for...

fields.headline: How much can you pay for...
fields.standfirst: ...a toilet brush
fields.trailText: ...a toilet brush.
fields.body:
If you like the idea of scrubbing your lavatory with a 24-carat gold-plated toilet brush, look no further than the Zodiac range of precious metal toilet products at Harrods. The Zodiac brush has plastic bristles and a clean-cut design. It is heavy and shiny and, if you bend down, you can see your face in it. The whole experience will set you back a clean £275.

Once you've started, you might as well finish. Try a rectangular 24-carat gold-plated tissue box for £159, or an ear bud holder for £82.95. When you're done, you can throw your tissues and cotton buds into the 24-carat gold-plated bathroom pedal bin, priced £449.

Alternatively, there's the gold-plated wire soap dish for £42.95, the gold toothbrush holder for £70 or the crystal liquid soap dispenser with a slither of gold-plated stripes for just £74.95.

Finally, try a chrome and gold-plated toilet roll holder from the Dina range for a mere £124.95. Call Harrods on 020-7730 1234.

If you can't afford it, but want to make a statement, try the Conran Shop on 020-7589 7401). They do a small metal toilet brush for just £69.

fields.headline: Cybershopping
fields.standfirst: Contact lenses
fields.trailText: Contact lenses
fields.body:
The legal requirements surrounding the sale of contact lenses in the UK are complex, but the number of UK-based companies selling online - with registered opticians to supervise sales - is growing. To order, you need an up-to-date prescription and to have had your eyes checked by a professional.

www.2eyes.co.uk launched earlier this month and claims to be up to 50% cheaper than the high street; they'll refund the difference if you find cheaper lenses elsewhere. You can only order disposable lenses but solutions should be available soon. To order, just click the lenses button on the home page, and fill in the information requested, including details of your lens specification, and the name and phone number of your optician, who will be asked to verify the prescription. Delivered is usually within five working days.

www.irisonline.co.uk also launched this month with a wider selection of lenses and solutions. If you can't find your lenses on the site, send them an email and they will source them for you. Prices here tend to be around 35% cheaper than the high street and customers are required to send a copy of their prescription. All deliveries in the UK are free; daily and monthly disposables are dispatched the same day, and other lenses within 24 hours.

www.postoptics.co.uk has a search engine to save you trawling through the lists of lenses and solutions and ww.directlenses.com delivers free in the UK and will remind you when you are due for a checkup.

helen.brooks@ theguardian.com

webTitle: Heseltine: farewell to the leader the Tories never had

fields.headline: Heseltine: farewell to the leader the Tories never had
fields.standfirst: Guardian columnist David McKie profiles one of the most conspicuous and extravagantly gifted members of this parliament. This is an extract from a longer article that will appear on Guardian Unlimited tomorrow
fields.trailText: The political landscape is littered with the remains of men who might have been prime minister but who, for any number of reasons failed to make it. Michael Heseltine, who today announced his intention to give up his Commons seat at the next election, is one of the most conspicuous and extravagantly gifted members of this assembly. He never made prime minister; he never made party leader; and yet even despite this defeat of ambition, Heseltine will be better and more vividly remembered than some who got to the very top: John Major, for instance, who beat him to the job he most coveted but with so much less swagger and style and sense of occasion; and vision.
fields.body:
The political landscape is littered with the remains of men who might have been prime minister but who, for any number of reasons failed to make it. Michael Heseltine, who today announced his intention to give up his Commons seat at the next election, is one of the most conspicuous and extravagantly gifted members of this assembly. He never made prime minister; he never made party leader; and yet even despite this defeat of ambition, Heseltine will be better and more vividly remembered than some who got to the very top: John Major, for instance, who beat him to the job he most coveted but with so much less swagger and style and sense of occasion; and vision.

Michael Heseltine's annual conference speech was one of the greatest treats of the political season. Many who came to scoff ended up mesmerised. Learned - but entertaining - excursions into Victorian history or the wars of old Europe, for instance, put there not just for their colour and spice but because they chimed in with essential themes, of which the most prominent always were industry, the state of our inner cities, and Europe.

From the mid-seventies on, when he first established himself as a platform hero, every Heseltine speech had an excitingly dangerous tang of a leadership bid about it. The programme would say he was there to reply to the party's debate on industry, or the environment, or whatever department or shadow department was then in his charge. But once he was going, the whole agenda of politics, at home and abroad, was there for his taking. These were not the compartmentalised thoughts of a mere head of department, but the settled enthusiasms and commitments of a man who meant to be boss.

Nor were these the only dramas. There was Heseltine in a flak jacket, a suitably military figure to have charge of defence. There was Heseltine the friend of the great city in trouble, despatched to Liverpool after the riots. Then there was Westland: that rare occasion, the resignation of a cabinet officer on a matter of principle. The principle on which he resigned - the conduct of government - was certainly involved: but so too was his personal commitment to Europe; his sense of himself; his ambition.

He was out of the party hierarchy for seven years, at the end of which he emerged, even more dramatically, as Margaret Thatcher's assassin.

After that, he was, for a swath of his party, that traitor: the outcast who had slain the queen. He bided his time, serving John Major faithfully (though without disguising his hope that he might yet land the top job himself) and helped shore him up when vicious critics were out for his blood. And for all the venom against him, he came tantalisingly close to winning the leadership when Major resigned.

What did for him then was ill health. The television pictures which showed him being borne home, haggard and ashen, made it clear that the game might be up.

And now he is going. Wherever he goes after this - the Lords is a clear possibility even though many Tories would not wish to see him there - he will have the time and the freedom, given good luck with his health, to bring his crusading passion to a cause which clearly has desperate need of it.

webTitle: Zimbabwe police get new powers to crack down on dissent

fields.headline: Zimbabwe police get new powers to crack down on dissent
fields.standfirst: Cook to offer £36m carrot at Zimbabwe talks
fields.trailText: Police in Zimbabwe are to use special powers to crack down on escalating violence by restricting the activities of political parties.
fields.body:
Police in Zimbabwe are to use special powers to crack down on escalating violence by restricting the activities of political parties.

Commissioner Augustine Chihuri said police had invoked an act giving them the power to restrict the movement of party supporters and ban public gatherings that threatened law and order.

"In short, it is illegal to ferry supporters to meetings, public gatherings or processions unless such events are being officiated by presidents of political parties," Mr Chihuri said.

At least 14 people - farmers, farm workers and opposition supporters - have been killed in nine weeks of increasing political tension in the country. The violence has escalated with the approach of parliamentary elections and the invasion of hundreds of white-owned farms by self-styled war veterans.

Mr Chihuri said president Robert Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party and the opposition Movement for Democratic Change were equally to blame for the political violence that has killed at least seven MDC supporters in recent weeks.

Meanwhile, foreign secretary Robin Cook will dangle the prospect of an extra £36m in aid for Zimbabwe's land reform programme in the hope of a breakthrough at today's talks with ministers from the Mugabe government.

"If they are willing to be genuine partners in this project, we are willing to help - not only by contributing ourselves but also by taking the lead in the international community," Mr Cook said before the London meeting.

He emphasised that Britain would be firm in its demands, saying: "I would like to achieve an agreement, I would like to achieve a basis on which the violence can end, the violence to farmers can stop and the economy of Zimbabwe can start to be reconstructed.

"We are ready, we are willing to help, we always have been willing to help with land reform, but we are not going to appease."

Today's meeting seeks to defuse the crisis precipitated by the Zimbabwean government-sponsored occupation of white-owned farms in the former British colony. At least 14 people - including farmers, labourers and opposition members - have died in two months of violence. The Zimbabwean ministers will raise Mr Mugabe's demand that Britain pay for land he plans to take from white farmers for redistribution to blacks.

Britain has said it is prepared to dispense aid to Harare provided the government restores order. Britain wants the squatters - self-styled veterans of the 1970s guerrilla war against white minority rule - to leave the land they have occupied and insists that the Zimbabwean government pay fair prices for farms it wants to acquire for redistribution. Mr Cook said: "We hope the first meeting will lay the foundation of a broad agreement of what needs to be done and at what pace."

Mr Cook will also emphasise the importance of holding elections by the constitutional deadline of August. This demand is unlikely to please Mr Mugabe, who has instigated the occupation of white farms by veterans from the war for independence as a desperate bid to hang on to power.

Mr Mugabe says Britain has a moral responsibility because of its colonial history to pay for land transfers. However, Mr Cook insisted that Britain could not be held wholly responsibly for the legacy of colonialism.

"President Mugabe has been in power for 20 years and he cannot now turn round after those 20 years and say that what is wrong with the economy is the fault of Britain because it was in power over 20 years ago," he said.

Britain funded a land redistribution programme in the 1980s but stopped in the 1990s, saying the project was being used to benefit Mr Mugabe's cronies and government supporters. British aid to Zimbabwe, most of it currently channelled through non-governmental organisations, has fallen from £17m two years ago to £12m this year.

Anxious to ensure a smooth start to the talks, Britain and the EU yesterday denied a German newspaper report that they were preparing military assistance to evacuate whites from Zimbabwe if violence escalated.

"We have a range of contingency plans for situations across the world which are constantly updated, but we have no specific plans for military involvement in Zimbabwe," a British defence official said.

webTitle: Rebel coalition escalates Sudan's civil war

fields.headline: Rebel coalition escalates Sudan's civil war
fields.trailText: The ground at Makit is torn up by the treads of two T-54 tanks. There was a pitched battle here a few hours ago, but soldiers are nowhere in sight now. Government troops penetrated guerrilla-held positions for several hours, but left when the rebels attacked their unprotected rear. It was the kind of cat-and-mouse encounter typical of Sudan's quickly spreading revolt.
fields.byline: By Dan Connell outside Kassala, Sudan
fields.body:
The ground at Makit is torn up by the treads of two T-54 tanks. There was a pitched battle here a few hours ago, but soldiers are nowhere in sight now. Government troops penetrated guerrilla-held positions for several hours, but left when the rebels attacked their unprotected rear. It was the kind of cat-and-mouse encounter typical of Sudan's quickly spreading revolt.

At the same time as the fighting here, opposition forces captured the town of Hameshkoreb, 100km to the northwest, in a stunning show of force that seemed to catch Khartoum off-guard.

Sudan's barren northeastern corner, bounded on one side by Eritrea and on the other by the Red Sea, is the latest battlefront in the country's civil war, which was once confined to the south.

Because of this area's strategic importance - threatening the country's vital road and rail links to the coast, its new oil pipeline and other key economic installations - the outcome of this protracted war may eventually be decided here.

Both sides are gearing up for heavy fighting during the coming months, while they manoeuvre for political leverage in competing peace initiatives. The government's goal is to push the rebels across the border into Eritrea and then seal off the frontier. Opposition forces are hoping to carve out an enclave from which to launch attacks throughout the north. A tour of their mountain bases suggests that they will be hard to dislodge.

The rebels are building a network of camouflaged supply depots, training facilities and military camps in a warren of volcanic hills where the government's superior armour and aircraft are ineffective. They also have mobile units of their own, using captured military vehicles and converted pick-up trucks.

This is changing a regional contest between north and south into a national revolt that could threaten the Islamist regime that seized power in Sudan in 1989.

Intermittent civil war has racked Sudan almost from the moment it gained its independence from Britain and Egypt in 1956. Much of its southern third is now under the control of the Sudan People's Liberation Movement (SPLM), which also holds pockets of territory in central and eastern Sudan, in the Nuba mountains and the Inghessina hills.

But in the northeast, the SPLM is only one of seven opposition armies. The others run the political gamut: from the traditional Islamic sect-based movements shouldered aside by the ruling National Islamic Front to the Communist party and a new group led by disaffected military officers, the Sudan Alliance Forces.

Until recently these disparate forces had managed little more than sporadic ambushes and small surprise attacks, often fleeing east into Eritrea when pursued. Today they are fighting for the first time under a single command, and their increased effectiveness is readily apparent.

This was accomplished after two events which, at first, appeared to be setbacks. Last year, following Eritrea's border war with Ethiopia, relations between Asmara and Khartoum thawed. As a result the National Democratic Alliance - a coalition of Sudanese opposition groups - was ordered to close its bases in Eritrea and move into Sudan.

This led rebel leaders to agree to combine their forces in one division under a unified command structure. The SPLM augmented these forces by redeploying almost 8,000 soldiers from the south to what it calls the "eastern front".

Also, last month, the largest northern group in the NDA coalition, the Umma party of the ousted former prime minister, Sadiq al-Mahdi, left the coalition, saying that it would challenge the Islamist government of General Omar al-Bashir from within.

Many here view the defection as a blessing after years of internal wrangling that paralysed the NDA. A spurt of armed actions has doubled the size of "liberated" territory in recent weeks.

Now what started as a conflict between the Arabised, Islamic north and the non-Muslim African south is becoming a fight between a fundamentalist Islamic movement at the centre and a diverse alliance challenging it from the periphery.

Up to 2m people have died from causes related to war and famine since the fighting resumed in 1983 after a decade-long truce. What is at stake is the country's identity: whether it is to be strictly Arab-Islamic or loosely multi-ethnic and secular - and whether it can exist as one or the other within a single national boundary.

The potential for the fighting to spill over into a wider regional conflict has triggered a flurry of diplomatic activity. Two initiatives - one promoted by Libya and Egypt, the other by members of the East Africa-based Intergovernmental Authority for Development - are on the table. Neither one has reached the stage of serious negotiations. The SPLM's leader, John Garang, is calling for the consolidation of the two initiatives. So far the government has declined to do so, preferring to deal with the opposition parties one at a time.

Under these circumstances it is likely that fighting will intensify in one of the worst drought-affected areas of Sudan. Many civilians are trekking to refugee camps in Eritrea, which are taking the place of the opposition military bases dismantled just months ago.

webTitle: Softbank deal gives ailing Body Shop shares a lift

fields.headline: Softbank deal gives ailing Body Shop shares a lift
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Body Shop, the cosmetics retailer, yesterday attempted to inject some dot.com sparkle into its flagging share price by announcing an e-commerce joint venture with Japanese internet investment company Softbank.
fields.body:
Body Shop, the cosmetics retailer, yesterday attempted to inject some dot.com sparkle into its flagging share price by announcing an e-commerce joint venture with Japanese internet investment company Softbank.

Chief executive Patrick Gournay, speaking after announcing a 29% rise in full year profits to £31.5m, said the initiative was a precursor to a "dramatic" expansion of the Body Shop brand that would see it provide other products and services to a global market. Around 70 new stores are likely to be opened in the coming year.

The new venture on which shareholders will pin many of their hopes for recovery, Body Shop Digital, will have the ex clusive worldwide rights to develop the Body Brand online. It will be 59% owned by Body Shop, with Softbank Venture Capital providing all initial investment costs in return for a 24% stake. The remaining equity will be held in employee stock option plans.

Mr Gournay said: "Softbank manages 150 e-commerce businesses worldwide and clearly knows the industry inside out."

Anita Roddick, the chain's founder, would figure widely on a portal which was likely to focus on well-being products, lifestyle and community sites, Mr Gournay said. Analysts believe Body Shop may also offer eco-friendly travel and investment services.

Several British internet companies such as ClickMango.com and ThinkNatural.com, have al ready moved into the natural products and health and beauty space but Mr Gournay denied Body Shop would struggle to catch up.

"We have a very strong brand, a strong branded product line, distribution and experience," he said. "New net companies in this market do not. Add in the expertise, resources and networking opportunities provided by Softbank and we will have a very exciting presence."

Body Shop was a star stock in the early 1990s when the shares changed hands at more than 350p but have been underperformers since.

Mr Gournay has instigated a radical restructuring programme in an attempt to arrest the decline.

Body Shop shares rose 8.5p yesterday to 114p.

fields.headline: Frank Dobson, live online
fields.standfirst: The Labour candidate answers your questions
fields.trailText: The Labour candidate answers your questions
fields.body:
How is Mr Dobson going to deal with spiralling house rental prices in the capital?
Rory Cook
There is a two-tier housing problem in London - what might be described as traditional problem of people who are homeless or nowhere decent to live, and the relatively new problem of people who are being priced out of London by the increase in house prices and rents. I have been pressing for changes in both law and practice to try to deal with this new problem. In his Green Paper on housing, John Prescott accepted my idea of free or low interest loans for people like new police officers, teachers, nurses and social workers. I also believe we need far bigger "planning gain" to provide more affordable housing and a real effort to involve housing associations and councils to become the tennants of disused residential space above high street shops. This would provide extra housing and a steady and reliable income for the shop keepers. Hugo Young named Ken Livingstone as the 'postmodern' candidate. I concur with his analysis. Livingstone is post-politics, post-argument - he is little more than a lefto 'cheeky-chappy'. Nevertheless I am concerned that New Labour has not made more of this. If Ken, the likely victor, is post-politics, what does this say for the whole position of the London mayor? Is the position inherently apolitical? Is it a red-herring where accountability is dissipated, but has since spun out of Tony's control? Or can it rejuvenate debate in a demoralised capital?
Yours etc., Seven7of9
I don't know when Ken Livingstone is post-modern but I do not believe that he will be a serious and accountable mayor of London. My principle concern is that while the well off. well informed and trendy will be well able to look after their own interests whatever the mayor does poor people living in deprived areas where they need better healthcare, better housing, more and better jobs and a huge reduction in crime and disorder will suffer. Do you support the introduction of mayors in other cities? If so, what should be different about the campaigns and candidates? Can the London model be transported to, say, Liverpool?
I support the introduction of executive mayors in other English cities if that is what local people want. They will of course have very different powers and duties than the mayor of London because the new arrangements for the government of London are intended to provide a London-wide authority with strategic powers and duties over a limited range of topics. It might well be that a mayor of Birmingham or Liverpool may have some executive responsibility for all the services provided by those cities, not just a strategic position. I am not a Livingstone supporter, but I have to ask whether you do not think that the planned poster campaign, based on the line "Beware the costs of Livingstone", is far too reminiscent of the Tories' campaign throughout the '80s and early '90s against planned Labour tax increases?
Jacques Warren, Magdalen College, Oxford
My principal concerns about the cost of Ken Livingstone's policies have been two-fold. Firstly, he has made it clear time and again, given the opportunity, he would levy a congestion charge even if there was no other transport for Londoners to use, he favours an additional corporation tax for London and other additional taxes to be levied to be levied on London residents and businesses. This could only raise the cost of providing jobs in London which is already sufficiently high to put off some employers and potential employers. In addition he favours financing the renewal of the tube system by the issue of a bond which would have to be underwritten by Londoners. In view of the record of London Underground investment projects the prospects of having to find huge additional sums to pay for cost overruns is more of a certainty than a risk. The Jubilee line extension, which is still not complete, though two years late, has cost £1.5bn more than the original estimate. Had it been financed by a London bond, Londoners would now be having to find the additional £1.5bn - equal to £500 per family. The estimated cost of doing up the tube is £8bn, cost overruns on the same scale as the Jubilee line extension would add £6bn to that cost. All of which would have to be met from fare increases or London local taxation. With dosh on that scale at risk I think saying to Londoners beware the cost of Livingstone borders on being an understatement. In the event of you not being elected, do you plan to go back to your job in Health?
In the event of me not being elected I will be the member of parliament for Holborn and St Pancras, as I have been for the last 20 years. Most people interested in politics would be delighted just to represent that seat and I certainly am. How would Mr Dobson answer the charge that his first priority always seems to be obedience to the party leadership rather than to reflect the views of Londoners?
His policies seem to be too often pre-determined by decisions made at cabinet level (e.g. John Prescott's decision on tube financing). How can Londoners be assured that Mr Dobson will be make the views of Londoners heard even when they conflict with existing government policy?
 My first priority as mayor of London would be to represent the interests of Londoners. Until last October, when I announced my decision to stand, virtually every political correspondent in the news media used to portray me as an old Labour cuckoo in the New Labour nest - a person with a mind of my own. I do have a mind of my own and I try to learn from experience. My experience as health secretary involved launching the biggest programme of hospital building in the history of the NHS with 19 hospitals financed through public private partnerships as well as some financed with public capital. Up to then the history of hospital building had been characterised by scandalous delays and huge cost overruns. One of the 19 PFI projects is a month behind - all the rest are on time or ahead of schedule and if there are any cost overruns the private consortium involved will pick up the tab. I believe that it is sensible to test out such an approach to modernising the tube. After all the Docklands light railway extension, which was a PPP, was completed early and to price but I have made clear that as mayor I would vet all the bids using a panel independent of government, London underground or any contractors to advise what would be the best deal for Londoners. The odds are that it would be a PPP but if it wasn't tough luck on the governments plans.

Following on from the electoral college which chose you as the Labour candidate is the winner of your proposed London lottery going to be the person/people with the least numbers?
Matthew Simpson
Ho ho. What a wit. I am proposing a London lottery which would raise £50m a year to be spent on projects designed to make London a better place. Under my scheme, Londoners would decide how the money is spent. There is evidence that more people would buy tickets for such a lottery of they knew the money was going towards what they believed were good causes. All the other candidates are opposed to this sensible proposition.

What will you do to for London's cyclists? How will you encourage people to cycle and how will you make it safer?
The present arrangements for cycling in London are a dangerous half-way house. I would complete and probably extend the cycle network so that cycling would become much safer. Because I believe pedestrians should be safe, improvements for cyclists should be matched in unlawful cycling on pavements, which is a cause of accidents especially for elderly pedestrians.

In today's Guardian, an article about Susan Kramer suggests that she believes that Mr Dobson has been unclear about his policy on congestion charging:
"He [Frank Dobson] had troops out at a busy junction yesterday, telling motorists Mr Livingstone would cost them money without mentioning that his own policy is different only in nuance."
What are the differences in policy?
Asher Jacobsberg
Susan Kramer and Ken Livingstone are both in favour of introducing congestion charges to pressure drivers to get out of their cars and travel on the tube instead. The tube is full already so that would be bad for the drivers who changed to public transport and even worse for existing users of our overcrowded tube. Both of them say they want to cut car use by 15% but introducing a congestion charge just for the central area would only achieve a minute reduction because most traffic in London doesn't go into the centre. To achieve even a 10% reduction would require a £10 charge in the centre, a £5 charge anywhere inside the north and south circular roads and additional charges in crowded high streets. Therefore costing as much as £300 a month for people in outer London.

None of the mayoral candidates have said anything of note about London's arts.
Why is it of such a low priority? I don't want to vote for a mayor who doesn't rate as important such a vital part of London life. What would you do to improve accessibility to and awareness of the many and varied performances that are available around the capital? I heard someone (sorry can't remember who) talking about a 'London card' which would give residents can get reduced price access to e.g. museums, theatres. What do you think of that?
I have not been giving low priority to the arts. I believe theatres, parks, museums, concert halls, cinemas, all contribute to civilised living in London and that civilised living is a major attraction for companies from abroad to invest in London. I am committed to improving access to the arts and to encouraging local and community arts I have a track record on this from when on the Camden council when we had a major arts festival and also introduced very successfully large numbers of local neighbourhood festivals.

Thank you for your interest. Vote Labour.

Frank

fields.headline: Union-backed Rover bid in jeopardy
fields.trailText: German car giant BMW today dealt a blow to the hopes of a rival consortium trying to buy Rover when it told workers that the bid was "still not financially backed".
fields.body:
German car giant BMW today dealt a blow to the hopes of a rival consortium trying to buy Rover when it told workers that the bid was "still not financially backed".

The firm said that the consortium, led by former Rover executive John Towers, had not provided the financial backing being sought by BMW. Officials said that this did "not constitute a basis for entering negotiations" with the Towers team.

A statement issued by BMW from its Munich headquarters said: "The negotiations with Alchemy Partners will continue in a straightforward manner."

Alchemy, the venture capitalist firm bidding to buy most of Rover, had earlier expressed optimism that a deal could be reached within days. However, supporters of the Towers consortium, known as Phoenix, believed that the rival bid was under serious consideration and that a final decision on the sale of Rover could be delayed until next week.

The new BMW statement is a blow to unions, who were backing the Towers consortium. A delegation of workers from the Longbridge factory in Birmingham had travelled to Munich to petition BMW to give the Towers team more time to put together its bid.

The BMW statement was headed: Phoenix Bid still not financially backed, and read: "On the occasion of a visit, a delegation of the British unions has turned over a petition demanding to sincerely consider the bid of the consortium of the former Rover head John Towers.

"During this visit BMW made clear that despite a demand of BMW the financial backing by the consortium has not been provided yet. On the occasion of the visit of the unions, BMW has once again repeated this fact and pointed out that this does not constitute a basis for entering negotiations with the Phoenix consortium.

"The negotiations with Alchemy Partners will continue in a straightforward manner."

fields.trailText: Conservative leader William Hague today paid tribute to Michael Heseltine after the former deputy prime minister announced he is to stand down from parliament at the next general election.
fields.body:
Conservative leader William Hague today paid tribute to Michael Heseltine after the former deputy prime minister announced he is to stand down from parliament at the next general election.

Brushing aside the two men's differences over Europe, and Mr Heseltine's unorthodox announcement of his retirement on Radio 4's Today programme, Mr Hague said: "I think we should pay tribute to an immensely distinguished politician and minister, with great achievements in defence, and particularly in the regeneration of the Docklands, and the tremendous work he did on Merseyside.

"We have had a disagreement over Europe, but we haven't had many other disagreements. We have had very good personal relations and we have not let the disagreement over one matter create bad relations."

Announcing his retirement this morning, Mr Heseltine said: "When a man's got to go, he's got to go." He said he had told the chairman of his constituency association at Henley, Oxfordshire of his decision yesterday.

Mr Heseltine, a former Tory leadership contender, said he did not want to stay on the backbenches and, in what may be interpreted as a snub, he said he had not warned or consulted Mr Hague before announcing his Commons retirement.

The former deputy prime minister, who first entered the Commons 34 years ago as MP for Tavistock, said there were "a number of reasons" for his departure. "I'm really a rather very active sort of person and I'm not given to being a sort of backbench guy waiting for the whips' instructions," he said. "I'm now chairman of the Haymarket Publishing Group, which is a very exciting company which is expanding worldwide. And I just know that my own association needs a younger guy to get in there and do what I did in Tavistock in the sixties."

Mr Heseltine - dubbed Tarzan - famously walked out of Margaret Thatcher's cabinet, sparking the Westland crisis, but rose to become deputy prime minister under her successor, John Major. "I know that I will never serve in another Conservative government and I'm just not that good at sitting around."

He stressed that he had not had any disagreements with Mr Hague, apart from over Europe, and did not feel left behind by the party. Explaining his decision, he said there were things he wanted to do "which are not compatible with being lobby fodder in the House of Commons. It's not fair to deceive my constituents to pretend that I am doing a full-time job for them when I am not."

But he confirmed he had not told the Tory leader of his decision. "No I haven't told William. I will do so. To be honest about it, I felt that I wanted this to be something that came new, that there was no risk of any leaks."

Howard Green, Mr Heseltine's Henley constituency chairman, said today: "It's always somewhat emotional when a major personality like Michael, who has represented this constituency for so long, steps down. He has been an MP for 34 years and has represented us for 26 years.

"Michael has served his constituents loyally and effectively. He was an outstanding front bench spokesman for our party for over 30 years and for two decades he brought the party to its feet at annual conferences with his attacks on socialist policies."

webTitle: The swinging career of a man called Tarzan

fields.headline: The swinging career of a man called Tarzan
fields.trailText: In the 1950s Michael Heseltine mapped out his life on the back of an envelope. He divided his future into decades and wrote in each where his political career would have reached. Against the 1990s he simply wrote: "Downing Street".
fields.body:
In the 1950s Michael Heseltine mapped out his life on the back of an envelope. He divided his future into decades and wrote in each where his political career would have reached. Against the 1990s he simply wrote: "Downing Street".

But it never happened. Despite his challenge to Margaret Thatcher in November 1990, John Major became her successor. Mr Heseltine ends his career as the one of the most prominent and outspoken politicians of the 1980s and 1990s who never quite made it to the highest office.

The golden years

On the up: Elected MP for Tavistock (and later Henley) in 1966, Heseltine first made his mark in parliament as opposition transport spokesman in 1969. When Edward Heath took the Conservatives to power in the 1970 general election Heseltine took a series of ministerial posts that culminated in his 1972 appointment as minister for aerospace and shipping. Margaret Thatcher made him environment secretary in 1979 and he climbed to secretary of state for defence in 1983.

The chop: Heseltine, then trade secretary, stormed out of Thatcher's cabinet (without even the courtesies of an exchange of resignation letters) in 1986 over the Westland helicopter crisis.

The attempted coup: After four years on the backbenches (where he was a vocal critic of the poll tax) he forced Thatcher to resign, by polling 152 votes to her 204. Though she had won the majority of votes it was insufficient for her to win the first ballot outright and she stepped down in favour of her chancellor, John Major. Major was everything that Heseltine was not: modest, patient, benign, hugely unexciting and prime minister for the next six and a half years.

The return to power: Heseltine came back into government as environment secretary. Although his ambition for the top job never deserted him, the heart attack he suffered in Venice in June 1993 ended any hope that he would get there. When Major resigned the leadership in 1995 to face challenger John Redwood at the ballot box Heseltine's loyal support won him the title of deputy prime minister until the Tories ignominious defeat in May 1997.

Opposition: After suffering further heart trouble, Heseltine immediately ruled himself out of the running to succeed John Major and took his seat on the backbenches. He was particularly critical of William Hague's decision to rule out joining the euro for the next two parliaments and went as far as to join Tony Blair on a pro-European platform in October 1999. Heseltine was also one of the few senior opposition MPs who supported the millennium dome. He found a role as special adviser to Peter Mandelson while the dome was under construction.

Retirement: Heseltine announced his exit from parliament at the next election without first informing Hague or the party hierarchy. "I'm not given to being a sort of backbench guy waiting for the whips' instructions," he said.

webTitle: Third time unlucky for shuttle Atlantis

fields.headline: Third time unlucky for shuttle Atlantis
fields.standfirst:
Nasa Human Spaceflight
Mission STS-101: the crew
fields.trailText: Nasa scrubbed the launch of the space shuttle Atlantis for the third straight day on Wednesday and may not be able to try again to dock with and repair the International Space Station until mid-May.
fields.body:
Nasa scrubbed the launch of the space shuttle Atlantis for the third straight day on Wednesday and may not be able to try again to dock with and repair the International Space Station until mid-May.

Although high winds at the Kennedy Space Centre were responsible for grounding the shuttle on Monday and Tuesday, it was rain and heavy crosswinds at emergency landing sites in Spain and North Africa that caused Wednesday's cancellation.

"We were there, we were ready, and the weather just didn't cooperate," launch director Dave King said.

It was the first time in the shuttle program's history that Nasa had tried to launch three days in a row.

Still waiting in space for the seven Atlantis astronauts are the first components of the $60 billion International Space Station. The structure is losing orbit at a rate of about 1-1/2 miles a week because a long-overdue Russian service module, dubbed Zvezda, cannot be launched until summer.

When Atlantis eventually docks with the station, shuttle commander James Halsell and pilot Scott Horowitz will use the shuttle's thrusters to boost the station's orbit to 250 miles above Earth, where it will wait for Zvezda, which carries enough fuel for the station to maintain that orbit.

King said Atlantis could be ready to go again in as little as three days. Conflicts with commercial and other unmanned launches from the neighbouring Cape Canaveral Air Force Station make it more likely that the shuttle will be launched sometime between May 3 and 18.

Nasa maintains three emergency landing sites in Spain and Morocco in case a space shuttle must abort its flight soon after launch but with enough height and speed to make it across the Atlantic Ocean.

On Wednesday it was raining on the runways at Moron and Zaragoza, Spain. At Ben Guerir, Morocco, the flight team was hoping a 16-knot crosswind would change direction and allow a landing.

But with everyone from security guards to Nasa Administrator Dan Goldin eyeing clocks and watches, time ran out on that option.

The astronauts took the latest delay in stride.

"We think all three attempts were the right thing to do," Halsell said. "We'll be ready to go again as soon as the team is."

In the past, whenever the launch team at the Kennedy Space Centre has needed three launch attempts because of weather or technical problems, a delay of at least 48 hours was built into the schedule to give the launch teams some rest.

Nasa did not think that would be necessary this time. The afternoon launch times had not kept the teams working late into the night, and there were none of the unscheduled holds in the countdown that can extend workdays by hours.

The slowly decaying orbit of the space station was something the station's designers had not anticipated. A recent cycle of intense solar activity has caused Earth's atmosphere to expand, and although it remains thin where the space station orbits, there has been enough atmospheric drag on the station to accelerate the orbital decay experienced by all satellites.

The space station is being built by a international partnership led by the United States and Russia. When completed, it will house a crew of seven and sprawl over an area the size of two American football fields.

In the shuttle's cargo bay are more than 2,000 pounds (900 kg) of supplies for the station waiting to be transferred.

During docked operations, spacewalking astronauts will make repairs to the outside of the station and finish work on a Russian-built construction boom begun on an earlier mission.

Inside the station, the crew will replace four of six batteries that have been overtaxed by months of operations without support from the large solar power array that will arrive with Zvezda.

Besides Halsell and Horowitz, the crew is made up of spacewalkers Jeffrey Williams and Jim Voss, mission specialists Mary Ellen Weber and Susan Helms, and Russian cosmonaut Yuri Usachev.

The astronauts were expected to return to the astronaut training facility at the Johnson Space Centre in Houston on Wednesday night.

The first three-member crew to take up residence in the space station is scheduled to be launched in October. Construction and operation is the responsibility of a partnership linking the United States, Russia, Japan, Canada and the 14 nations that belong to the European Space Agency.

fields.headline: John Hurt - part two
fields.standfirst: On directors and directing, plus questions from the audience
fields.trailText: Part two of the John Hurt interview at BFI Southbank
fields.body:
GA: You've said in interviews in the past that you like it when a director has given you the green light to invent.

JH: When actors come and see me and I ask if they had a good day, and they say: "Well yes, but the director is just not directing me", I say: "Well, aren't you pleased?" Christ, what luxury. I don't know what they mean by that, I don't know if they think you turn up and you haven't done any thinking at all, that would be so strange. You must have something in your imagination that you are able to offer. And if the director says: "I like the way that's going," and fans the flames well that's fantastic, you feel a terrific freedom and then you start working with a director rather than for one and that's when things begin to cook, that's when things happen.

GA: And has that desire to invent ever led you into great conflict with any directors?

JH: No conflict that I didn't win. I remember there was a bit of a conflict with Herbie Wise when we'd come back from a rather good lunch. And we were feeling particularly inventive. And I climbed into bed with my grandmother and thought that this would really be a rather good idea and Herbie was getting slightly worried about how far it was going. But after many conversations and discussions we said, Well, how far can Caligula go?, and the answer was pretty much as far as possible. And so that did remain in it. No, I'm being facetious in a sense. When you're really working well with a director then you can be as outrageous as you like and so can he. And there's no worry about it.

GA: Do you actually have a favourite film or any favourite memories from working on a movie?

JH: Well I have lots of favourite memories but I can't say that I have a favourite film. I have favourite parts which are not in particularly successful films. I have to say that although it's now a highly regarded film among film-goers, The Hit was not a particular success, and for me it's a favourite film as a piece of cinema and a favourite role. When you feel you've achieved something on cinema, which is not just creating a part but making it fit into a cinematic understanding. It's difficult to say because they're all so different, it's like saying what's your favourite director. I couldn't possibly begin to tell you that because I've been very fortunate, I've worked with people from Fred Zinnemann, John Houston, through to Richard Fleischer, all of those boys from Hollywood and so on and Sam Peckinpah and then the Mike Radfords... I've been incredibly lucky with the directors I've worked with. You don't realise it at the time it's just in retrospect if you look back you think Jeez, when I saw that CV it nearly frightened the life out of me. I thought: "That's not bad for an old drunk."

GA: Have you ever been tempted to direct a movie yourself?

JH: Funny you should say that. I have been tempted. And finally I capitulated to the temptation. As Oscar Wilde says, the best way to deal with temptation is to give in to it. I'm not going to say what it is because it is not announced as yet, we're in the very early stages, but I have acquired a very good book indeed which I think will make a rather wonderful film. And my friends have persuaded me that instead of talking about film all the time, I'd better put it into practice.

GA: Do you have any unfulfilled ambitions apart from so far, not having directed?

JH: It would be difficult to have any unfulfilled ambitions because I don't have any ambitions. I've never been that kind of performer. As I said, when I first started, I literally said to myself: "Would I be prepared to stick it out in repertory for the rest of my life?" and I'd said yes. Anything that has happened to me better or more than that is the way the world has treated me and the way things have gone. I never had any ambition to be a star, or whatever it is called, and I'm still embarrassed at the word. I just wanted to act as well as I could act. I'm sounding really goody two shoes now! But that's the truth. I haven't had ambitions. I never had the ambition to play Hamlet, if I had come across it and it had been offered me in the right circumstances I'm sure I would've said yes, but I love being surprised by doing things that I'd never think of playing.

GA: You've worked a lot in either low budget or independent film-making. Do you have a natural sympathy for that sort of stuff?

JH: Again, you don't realise it is happening at the time. If you get an offer to do a film and you get excited by it and then you realise that it's an independent film... and the time it didn't really worry me. Now of course I can look back. It's quite a dangerous career move to go wilfully on making films that may not find a distributor. It's quite a dangerous way to go. In which case I've lived quite a dangerous life. But I didn't live it in any knowledge of the danger at the time. It's just when you look back at it and you think: "Ah yes, really what I should've been doing is going over and licking a few arses in Hollywood," and getting on with it there. But I've never been very good at that and I've never been particularly good at selling myself in that way, thank God one has agents to do that, and I've been very fortunate in having good ones. And in the independent market, I have to say that more than in the studio market I've found things which have interested me and the sort of things that I like making.

I think it's a dreadful shame personally that one is not able to go to a studio with a piece like Love and Death on Long Island, for instance, and say, Why don't we make this? There certainly was a time when that was possible. And I think Alec Guinness, in terms of the mainstream English films, was one of the really fortunate actors in film. He was breaking new ground as well, but he was doing it in a mainstream way, which I think is more difficult now, because the mainstream has dumbed down considerably.

GA: Has there ever been any actor who has been an inspiration for you?

JH: An inspiration, yes. I just mentioned him, Alec Guinness, without question. Because Alec - though I never worked with him and only met him on a few occasions, because he was so shy and I was even shyer so hardly a word was spoken, but to me, what he so successfully did... he broke ground as a performer, he was able to marry the tradition of British theatre and take it to the cinema and make it work. And I think he was the first person really to play so many characters both leading and supporting and be visually different and thinking differently and realising that the camera can actually photograph thought. So he was a huge inspiration to me. The first thing I ever saw of him was Oliver Twist and I will never, ever, couldn't possible forget 20 images I can think of straight off of his Fagin.

GA: You've been described more than once as a brave actor. Would you agree with that assessment?

JH: One is always shy of such compliments and also you think of knights in shining armour, don't you? Brave... I was actually having a conversation with friends of mine and I said: "They keep talking about brave. What have I done that's been particularly brave?" And they said: "You've got to remember that in Hollywood, if you are say, glamorous, and you scrape your hair back into a bun, that is considered to be brave." And the penny dropped.

Questions from the audience

Q: What has been your most emotionally draining role, either on stage or screen?

JH: Physically draining, I can understand. Emotionally draining, you never quite know, because if you're really into what doing at the time there is always, whether it be screen or stage, such a buzz of electricity that you really don't know whether you're drained or not and it isn't until you eat, or something like that, that you collapse with tiredness. But emotionally draining... I've got such a poor memory I go back very little distance. If you're doing it right, I don't think you can get more draining than Krapp's Last Tape, quite honestly. It's an extraordinarily intense little piece and you're on your own, too, which I've never done before. I say you're on your own, but of course you're not, you're with yourself but only 30 years younger. But only on tape, of course. But as I say, when you come off, you get such a buzz, such a thrill if it's gone well, that you forget about being emotionally drained.

Q: Are there any characters left you want to do? And who do you see when you look in the mirror?

JH: I've no idea who I am anymore. But I cease to be confused about it and frankly I'm not too worried. I'm motoring towards the end of it all in the most enjoyable way and does it really matter if I know who I am? I don't think it does, no. I do see a flicker.

Q: You've been extraordinarily modest about your work and tributes that have been paid to you. Who made you aware, if anybody, of the wonderful gift of your voice?

JH: You know what they used to say? You know how to ruin a young actor? You say: "You know you've got a wonderful voice." My voice has been blamed on Guinness and on Gauloises and all sorts of things like that but I'm here to tell you that it's a family voice entirely. My voice is the same timbre as my brothers, except of course that he's more Cambridge, and my father had exactly the same voice only he, of course, was a bit more north country. But the timbre of the voice is a family thing. I'm not being modest I'm being very grateful. I do love working vocally.

GA: Didn't you once do a film in which you were a bag lady, it was a version of Romeo and Juliet and the cast was almost completely feline?

JH: I am discovered, yes. That's one of those. That came up and I thought it was so bizarre. Armando Acosta was the American director. He had all sorts of people in Belgium who had all given up their salaries, I didn't know this at the time, and they decided to do a production almost entirely with cats. And he would go on at great length saying: "You just want to watch that cat. It is so stunning, the cat that is playing Juliet." And I thought, I've got to go in for this ride. This can't be anything but interesting. I didn't ask him why he wanted me to be a boatwoman. I think he felt that I had some great and deep spirituality that was going to fill the role. And obviously he felt that I was going to have some great affinity with cats, too. When one actually jumped off the boat and into the canal and wasn't able to swim, he found there was a very deep significance in this. I did suggest to him that it was not a good idea. It was a fairly extraordinary film.

GA: Did you see the film?

JH: Yes I did. He put it on with a full philharmonic orchestra in capitals of the world. And I did go to one in Brussels. It was the most bizarre evening. You got people coming out and literally saying: "Well that tabby cat really was very special."

Q: How did you find working with Michael Cimino on Heaven's Gate?

JH: Do you want to be here all night? I found it a difficult film because I can't bear that sort of indulgence and also it was at a time in my life when I couldn't treat it with a sense of humour. Obviously I was still holding onto the idea that you could control the indulgences of this business, which of course you couldn't. It was a very difficult experience all together. And I was working with a lot of people who'd worked together before and thought that it would be a very powerful film. It was not an easy time for anybody and it brought a studio to its knees.

Q: Were you aware while filming Alien just how startling that Alien moment would be when the special effects were installed?

JH: I think we were all hoped that it would be startling in terms of the film. I don't think anybody realised that it was going to become a kind of classic moment, because I don't think you do realise these things. I don't suppose Bogart realised it when he said: "Play it again Sam." These things happen by accident. It was all shot in a moment. I know I'm going to get asked this so I may as well tell you now. The rest of the cast did know roughly what was going to happen but they did not know that there were going to be explosive caps on it so that the blood would fly everywhere, all over everybody else. They might have guessed something was going to happen because Ridley didn't normally use, in a scene as tight as that, five cameras. And there were five cameras rolling. It worked - he got it in one.

GA: You once said in an interview that sci-fi is the most tedious thing for an actor.

JH: Oh, the most boring thing to do. It's endless waiting around. It's great fun for the director because he's playing with all the toys and he's going up and down and round tracks and then saying: "No, I don't think that works, let's put the track over here." By which stage you've been made up since eight in the morning and you don't do anything for one day, or the next day, or the next day, and it begins to get tedious. There's not a lot of acting to be done in it. I mean, there's a bit of "bleuaarghbrooohhh..." but that's one morning out of fourteen weeks.

Q: How closely do you keep to the original with the film version of Krapp?
