fields.bodyText: GA: You've said in interviews in the past that you like it when a director has given you the green light to invent. JH: When actors come and see me and I ask if they had a good day, and they say: "Well yes, but the director is just not directing me", I say: "Well, aren't you pleased?" Christ, what luxury. I don't know what they mean by that, I don't know if they think you turn up and you haven't done any thinking at all, that would be so strange. You must have something in your imagination that you are able to offer. And if the director says: "I like the way that's going," and fans the flames well that's fantastic, you feel a terrific freedom and then you start working with a director rather than for one and that's when things begin to cook, that's when things happen. GA: And has that desire to invent ever led you into great conflict with any directors? JH: No conflict that I didn't win. I remember there was a bit of a conflict with Herbie Wise when we'd come back from a rather good lunch. And we were feeling particularly inventive. And I climbed into bed with my grandmother and thought that this would really be a rather good idea and Herbie was getting slightly worried about how far it was going. But after many conversations and discussions we said, Well, how far can Caligula go?, and the answer was pretty much as far as possible. And so that did remain in it. No, I'm being facetious in a sense. When you're really working well with a director then you can be as outrageous as you like and so can he. And there's no worry about it. GA: Do you actually have a favourite film or any favourite memories from working on a movie? JH: Well I have lots of favourite memories but I can't say that I have a favourite film. I have favourite parts which are not in particularly successful films. I have to say that although it's now a highly regarded film among film-goers, The Hit was not a particular success, and for me it's a favourite film as a piece of cinema and a favourite role. When you feel you've achieved something on cinema, which is not just creating a part but making it fit into a cinematic understanding. It's difficult to say because they're all so different, it's like saying what's your favourite director. I couldn't possibly begin to tell you that because I've been very fortunate, I've worked with people from Fred Zinnemann, John Houston, through to Richard Fleischer, all of those boys from Hollywood and so on and Sam Peckinpah and then the Mike Radfords... I've been incredibly lucky with the directors I've worked with. You don't realise it at the time it's just in retrospect if you look back you think Jeez, when I saw that CV it nearly frightened the life out of me. I thought: "That's not bad for an old drunk." fields.headline: The lost picture show
fields.standfirst: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest author Ken Kesey had had the foresight to take a movie camera with him on his legendary 60s journey across America. The footage has now been released
fields.trailText: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest author Ken Kesey had had the foresight to take a movie camera with him on his legendary 60s journey across America. The footage has now been released
fields.body:
It's the perfect present for the unreconstructed ageing hippy in your life. After 36 years, Ken Kesey has finally finished Intrepid Traveler And His Merry Band of Pranksters Look For A Kool Place, the film account of the original Merry Pranksters bus ride across the US in 1964. Actually, that's not strictly accurate. The 56-minute video that Kesey's selling in hand-painted boxes is only Episode One, with another nine or so threatened. And Kesey himself didn't actually finish it: it needed his son and fellow Prankster Ken Babbs' son - and their knowledge of the digital age - to make sense of the family legacy.

When Kesey and friends set off on that first hippy odyssey, making a film was always the plan. Like Andy Warhol, they knew that life was meaningless until you saw it on screen. That's the most annoying thing about the DV camera twitch in The Blair Witch Project and American Beauty: it's as if people weren't doing this 40 or 50 years ago. However, it certainly wasn't as easy then.

The Pranksters failed to figure out that if they were powering their tape recorder using the bus engine, it would suffer from speed surges. Which, more or less, is the explanation for why it's taken three and a half decades to get the sound and vision in sync.

Kesey says the film was inspired by Fellini, Godard and Bergman. That would be the missing Bergman film filmed by an amateur cameraman, consisting of many hours of incoherent, wasted mumbling. And the confrontations between Kesey's freaks and the staid populace of America to jolly things along. But the core problem with Intrepid Traveler remains: there's nothing duller than other people on drugs. Sure, once in a while one of your friends will do something so catastrophically stupid that you'll be able to abuse them for days afterwards, but for the most part illegal narcotics convince the taker that they've just been given a great surge of wit or wisdom. Heads, you get someone on coke telling you all about themselves. Tails, you get that girl who dropped a tab and is experiencing an enlightenment too glorious to relate, but which expresses itself as a twisted and rather disturbing expression on her face. And a total inability to communicate.

Which might explain one of the great ironies of the whole Kesey thing: that the Pranksters owe their fame to an utter straight - Tom Wolfe. Kesey, after all, was one of the most promising writers in the US. He'd bought the bus with the profits from the decidedly non-psychedelic One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest. And the Pranksters were on their way to New York to attend the launch of Kesey's second novel, Sometimes A Great Notion. But gurudom - or simply too many drugs - effectively finished him off as a writer, leaving Wolfe to chronicle it all. Even Kesey disciples refer you to The Electric Kool Aid Acid Test before you tackle Kesey's "screenplay" about the same period, The Further Inquiry.

Wolfe liked and admired Kesey but he was an outsider. Despite the misleading impression given on the cover of several editions of the book, Wolfe never took the Acid Test - he left that to his friend Hunter Thompson, who introduced Kesey to the Hell's Angels. Wolfe's book ends with the failure of Kesey's Acid Test Graduation. As the mass of young hippies newly arrived in San Francisco walk out on them, Kesey and Babbs sing a song whose refrain is "We blew it!" (this is a couple of years before Easy Rider). Presumably, Kesey disciples manage to read around that bit.

Intrepid Traveler does have a value for cultural historians, or those with the patience to sit through the eventual 10-hour collection. The Merry Pranksters were a true vanguard movement: they did 1967 in 1964. But important doesn't mean good. The Grateful Dead were conceived as the Acid Test house band. The Day-Glo-splattered bus was the forerunner to every camper van splattered in wretched homemade art. And the great attempt to forge a new American left, based on the experience of the Civil Rights Movement, spluttered out when Kesey and Tim Leary and the Beatles convinced the kids to blow their minds instead. One of the key scenes in The Electric Kool Aid Acid Test comes when the Pranksters have been invited to a 15,000-strong Vietnam Day Committee demonstration in Oakland.

Kesey - a big patriot and John Wayne fan - thought that marching to oppose the war was a bit square. The Pranksters were already on another plane, anyway. So Kesey just mocked the other speakers and played Home On The Range on his harmonica, smug in the knowledge that he'd out-radicalled the radicals.

Now he sits around and wonders why the world didn't change. "We thought that by this time there would be LSD given in classes in college. And you would study for it and prepare for it, you would have somebody there who would help you through it; you would know what to sing, where to be, how to stand out among the trees."

As someone once said, never trust a hippy.

 Intrepid Traveler And His Merry Band of Pranksters Look For A Kool Place ($29) can be ordered from: www.intrepidtrips.com

Kesey, after all, was one of the most promising writers in the US. He'd bought the bus with the profits from the decidedly non-psychedelic One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest. And the Pranksters were on their way to New York to attend the launch of Kesey's second novel, Sometimes A Great Notion. But gurudom - or simply too many drugs - effectively finished him off as a writer, leaving Wolfe to chronicle it all. Even Kesey disciples refer you to The Electric Kool Aid Acid Test before you tackle Kesey's "screenplay" about the same period, The Further Inquiry. Wolfe liked and admired Kesey but he was an outsider. Despite the misleading impression given on the cover of several editions of the book, Wolfe never took the Acid Test - he left that to his friend Hunter Thompson, who introduced Kesey to the Hell's Angels. Wolfe's book ends with the failure of Kesey's Acid Test Graduation. As the mass of young hippies newly arrived in San Francisco walk out on them, Kesey and Babbs sing a song whose refrain is "We blew it!" (this is a couple of years before Easy Rider). Presumably, Kesey disciples manage to read around that bit. Intrepid Traveler does have a value for cultural historians, or those with the patience to sit through the eventual 10-hour collection. The Merry Pranksters were a true vanguard movement: they did 1967 in 1964. But important doesn't mean good. The Grateful Dead were conceived as the Acid Test house band. The Day-Glo-splattered bus was the forerunner to every camper van splattered in wretched homemade art. And the great attempt to forge a new American left, based on the experience of the Civil Rights Movement, spluttered out when Kesey and Tim Leary and the Beatles convinced the kids to blow their minds instead. One of the key scenes in The Electric Kool Aid Acid Test comes when the Pranksters have been invited to a 15,000-strong Vietnam Day Committee demonstration in Oakland. Kesey - a big patriot and John Wayne fan - thought that marching to oppose the war was a bit square. The Pranksters were already on another plane, anyway. So Kesey just mocked the other speakers and played Home On The Range on his harmonica, smug in the knowledge that he'd out-radicalled the radicals. Now he sits around and wonders why the world didn't change. "We thought that by this time there would be LSD given in classes in college. And you would study for it and prepare for it, you would have somebody there who would help you through it; you would know what to sing, where to be, how to stand out among the trees." As someone once said, never trust a hippy.  Intrepid Traveler And His Merry Band of Pranksters Look For A Kool Place ($29) can be ordered from: www.intrepidtrips.com

fields.headline: The universe
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about the flat and infinite expanse on the net
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about the flat and infinite expanse on the net.
fields.body:
1. After telling us the world was round and we were descended from apes, scientists have dropped another bombshell: now they say the universe is flat.

2. Until now, many of us may have supposed that the infinite and expanding cosmos does anything other than keep on the straight and narrow.

3. And we would be in good company. Albert Einstein first proposed the theory of a curved (non-Elucidian) universe in the theory of general relativity.

4. He suggested that lines which appear straight are curved, and that light travels in an arc. The opposing "flat" theory says simply that the cosmos follows the kind of mathematical geometry that you learn at school.

5. Scientists making a detailed study of the cosmic microwave background - an afterglow of ancient radiation left over from the big bang - have made precise geometrical measurements of space.

6. They say the cosmos grew from a tiny subatomic region a split second after the big bang: the enormous explosion would have stretched the geometry of space until it was flat.

7. The structure and evolution of the universe is an area of huge scientific debate and interest.

8. The Hubble telescope has helped to explore it further, but until recently scientists were at a loss to explain why the cosmos was seemingly younger than many of the stars it contained.

9. And there are other mysteries to elucidate: is the universe really a "multiverse"? Where does space come from? How can an infinite universe have a beginning in time?

10. Finally, the big one: are we alone? Some say we're not, but faced with the mind-bending complexities of modern astrophysics, don't you rather wish we were?

fields.headline: Malkovich invests in Cardiff Hotel
fields.trailText: John Malkovich, star of Dangerous Liaisons, The Portrait of a Lady and, of course, Being John Malkovich, has put some of his fortune into a middle-range 81-bedroom hotel in central Cardiff called The Big Sleep
fields.body:
John Malkovich, star of Dangerous Liaisons, The Portrait of a Lady and, of course, Being John Malkovich, has put some of his fortune into a middle-range 81-bedroom hotel in central Cardiff called The Big Sleep.

"I think the thing about investments is that they are always dangerous," Malkovich, who already owns a house in the south of France as well as property in Portugal, said yesterday in the Welsh capital. "You always have to be prepared to lose your investment, but I do not see the point in doing something like this unless I am interested."

Malkovich owns the hotel with two friends, interior designer Cosmo Fry and Lulu Anderson. "Cosmo has a fantastic sense of style and I love what he has done with the rooms," the actor said.

"John's very interested in design. He designed all the furniture at his house in France and he is interested in the interior design of the hotel," said Anderson.

webTitle: Lakis punishes Irish as Greeks enjoy a gift

fields.headline: Lakis punishes Irish as Greeks enjoy a gift
fields.standfirst:
Republic of Ireland 0
Greece 1 Lakis 15
fields.trailText: A single goal by the AEK Athens man Vassilios Lakis after only 15 minutes was enough to give Greece a scarcely deserved victory over a vastly understrength Republic of Ireland side last night.
fields.body:
A single goal by the AEK Athens man Vassilios Lakis after only 15 minutes was enough to give Greece a scarcely deserved victory over a vastly understrength Republic of Ireland side last night.

The Greeks, in the same group as England in the forthcoming World Cup qualifiers, put the emphasis on defence as they won their third game in a row to frustrate the Dublin crowd of 23,157.

Barry Quinn was a surprise starter in a makeshift Irish side which included the new caps Steve Finnan and Richard Dunne. However, Kevin Kilbane soon produced several dangerous crosses and they almost scored when Quinn's 25-yard shot flew wide and David Connolly failed to add the finishing touch.

But Greece scored against the run of play when a long ball from Vassilios Tsartas found Lakis on the right. Stepping past Steve Staunton's challenge, Lakis fired home a shot from 20 yards which swerved past an uncertain Shay Given.

"We're disappointed to lose but after so many people said it would be a farce, a Mickey Mouse match, after we lost so many experienced players, I don't think it turned out that way," said the Irish manager Mick McCarthy.

They had several chances to equalise. Newcastle's Nikos Dabizas blocked a long-range effort from Mark Kinsella and on 28 minutes Dunne produced a perfect cross, but Kilbane's weak header was pushed away by a diving goalkeeper Antonios Nikopolidis.

Quinn also went close before his game ended on a sour note when he went off with a suspected fractured ankle after a clash with Ilias Poursanidis. His replacement Rory Delap was promptly fouled by Dabizas, and in the closing moments Connolly wriggled his way through only for Nikopolidis to hang on at the second attempt.

The Irish offensive continued after the break, with Kinsella and Finnan both going close. Greece, by contrast, rarely looked threatening and they were living dangerously when an Alan Mahon cross set up a close-range header for Kinsella which was somehow pushed away by Nikopolidis.

Republic of Ireland (4-4-2): Given (Newcastle United; Kiely , Charlton, h-t); Cunningham (Wimbledon), Dunne (Everton), Breen (Coventry), Staunton (Liverpool); Finnan (Fulham; Doherty , Tottenham, 71min), Kinsella (Charlton), Quinn (Coventry; Delap , Derby, 34), Kilbane (Sunderland); Keane (Coventry), Connolly (Excelsior; Mahon , Tranmere, 54).

Greece (5-4-1): Nikopolidis ; Basinas ( Goumas , 74), Amanatidis , Ouzounidis , Dabizas , Venetidis ; Lakis ( Zikos , 63), Tsartas ( Kiparissis , 56), Poursanidis , Georgiadis ( Niniadis , 86); Liberopoulos ( Nalitzis , 88).

Referee : H Dallas (Scotland).

webTitle: Taking Gard in the Rose and Crown

fields.headline: Taking Gard in the Rose and Crown
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing questions? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: I am a publican in Somerset, and ex-Somerset keeper Trevor Gard is one of my regulars. He has my barman and me engrossed for hours with his tales, but is strangely reluctant to remember any of his own stats! Can you tell us his career record? asks Darren Hepburn from the Rose and Crown
fields.body:
I am a publican in Somerset, and ex-Somerset keeper Trevor Gard is one of my regulars. He has my barman and me engrossed for hours with his tales, but is strangely reluctant to remember any of his own stats! Can you tell us his career record? asks Darren Hepburn from the Rose and Crown

Gard played 112 matches for Somerset between 1976 and 1989, although he wasn't a regular first-teamer until Derek Taylor retired in 1982. He scored 1389 runs at an average of 13.75, and made 178 catches and 39 stumpings. He made two half-centuries in first-class cricket: 51 not out against the Indian tourists at Taunton in 1979, and 51 v Glamorgan at Swansea in 1983. Perhaps his finest hour was in the 1983 NatWest Trophy final at Lord's - I remember two lightning legside stumpings to send back Chris Cowdrey (for 0) and Derek Aslett of Kent. Somerset went on to win that match by 24 runs.

Has any player been given out more than once for obstructing the field in first-class cricket? asks Toby Cox

The unlucky man was Thomas Straw, a Worcestershire wicketkeeper, who managed to get out in this odd fashion twice, in 1899 and 1901, both times against Warwickshire. Oddly, each time he was out obstructing the field he was dismissed by Frank Field for a duck in the second innings. Wisden is curiously silent about both incidents - and the 1960 edition also fails to give Straw an obituary after he died in 1959.

I believe England once made around 600 chasing 650 or something like that in a Test. When was this? asks Sumedh Pathak

This was the famous "Timeless Test" on England's 1938-39 tour of South Africa. It was the final Test of the series, at Durban, and with England 1-0 up it was decided to play the match out to a finish. It lasted ten days, one of which was rained off. England were set 696 to win, and had reached 654 for 5 (Bill Edrich 219, Wally Hammond 140, Paul Gibb 120) by the end of the tenth day. Unfortunately, the England team then had to leave to catch the train to reach their boat home, so the match was drawn anyway. The general view was that it had been a pointless exercise, and there have been no timeless Tests since (all Tests in Australia between 1881-82 and 1946-47 were played out to a finish). Nowadays travel and administrative constraints would make the prospect of such matches even more unattractive. Since 1950 Tests in England have been scheduled to last five days (with the occasional six-dayer to round off a series if a decider was needed).

I am having an argument with my father about when Chris Lewis last played for England. Can you help? asks Deborah Brown

His last appearances to date came in the one-day internationals against South Africa at the start of their tour of England in 1998. He played in the first two, at The Oval and Old Trafford, but was left out for the final match. Lewis's last Test was against Pakistan at The Oval in 1996, during which he was famously late one morning after his car had a puncture and he had mislaid the free mobile phone the England sponsors had given to each player.

Can you confirm the England team which played Australia at Lord's in 1997, including anyone who was called up but didn't play? asks Tony Hortopp

The team that played was Mike Atherton, Mark Butcher, Nasser Hussain, Alec Stewart, Graham Thorpe, John Crawley, Mark Ealham, Robert Croft, Darren Gough, Andy Caddick and Devon Malcolm. Phil Tufnell and Adam Hollioake were left out of the chosen 13, and Ashley Cowan of Essex was added to the squad to soak up some Test-match atmosphere. "Soak up" was appropriate: little more than two days' play was possible in a soggy draw, although Glenn McGrath found time to demolish England (77 all out) with 8 for 38.

Could you please settle a bet between two of my work colleagues: has anyone ever scored 200 in a one-day international? asks Paul Stenhouse

No man has done it (the highest score is Saeed Anwar's 194 for Pakistan v India at Chennai in 1996-97) - but a woman has. Belinda Clark, Australia's captain, cracked 229 in 157 balls against Denmark at Bombay during the women's World Cup in December 1997.

What was the story behind the dead sparrow that's in the Lord's museum? asks Nicky Farr

The incident happened in 1936, during the MCC v Cambridge University match at Lord's. Jahangir Khan of Cambridge (the father of Majid, who later captained Pakistan) was bowling to Tom Pearce on the third day. Pearce played forward, then someone noticed that the bails had been disturbed, and a fielder spotted a dead sparrow lying by the stumps. Pearce was given not out and batted on, and later the bird was stuffed for the Lord's museum. The Times correspondent wrote that "the sparrow had chosen to commit suicide in an altruistic attempt to save TN Pearce's wicket". Tim Rice's book "Treasures of Lord's" adds that "Both ball and bird were declared dead."

I was intrigued to read last week's question about cricket in Philadelphia. It might interest the person asking to know that cricket is still being played in the area. Haverford College maintains a team, and their ground is also used by my own club, the British Officers Cricket Club. Superb facilities are also available at the Philadelphia, Germantown and Merion Cricket Clubs as well (although these revert to the more financially rewarding game of tennis from late May to September). All four venues will be used shortly for the Philadelphia Cricket Festival, which features 12 teams from as far afield as California, New York, Canada and the UK. So while not perhaps in the same class as yesteryear, cricket is by no means dead in this part of the world. More information can be found on our website at www.bocccricket.com, writes Angus Dawe

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

We regret that not all questions can be answered and that personal correspondence can only sometimes be entered into

fields.headline: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Pierce Brosnan to marry, more medical drama for Noah Wyle, Lars Von Trier plans completion of Kingdom trilogy, plus James Coburn, Annette Bening and Brad Pitt on the casting couch
fields.body:
 Pierce Brosnan, aka Mr James Bond, is set to marry his girlfriend, ex-journalist Keely Shaye-Smith, in a private ceremony in Ireland next month. At the age of 47, the Irish star is set to tie the knot a second time after losing his first wife, Cassandra Harris, to cancer in 1991. He is currently working on John Boorman's Tailor of Panama, adapted from a John Le Carr&#233 spy thriller.

 Warner Bros has acquired the rights to Michael Palmer's bestselling medical thriller The Patient for the production company headed by ER star Noah Wyle. It tells the story of a neurosurgeon responsible for refining a robot that can perform brain surgery who is taken hostage by a terrorist. Wyle and his stepfather, industry veteran Jim Katz, the principals of Warner Bros-based Wyle/Katz Co, will produce the project. It has not been revealed whether Wyle will take a role in the film.

 Danish Dogme director Lars Von Trier, whose latest film Dancer In The Dark - starring BjÖrk and Catherine Deneuve - is reckoned by some to be one of the highlights of the forthcoming Cannes festival, will direct the last episode of the cult Kingdom TV series. The third instalment in the mad trilogy, composed of 1994's The Kingdom and the 1997 sequel The Kingdom 2, is best described as a crazy cross between The Sixth Sense and ER.

Casting couch

 Hollywood legend James Coburn has signed to star opposite Rob Lowe in Proximity, a $6m project for action producer Joel Silver. To be directed by Scott Ziehl (''Broken Vessels''), it is a darker take on The Fugitive in which a prisoner (Lowe) must break out of jail in order to dodge a hit placed on him by a sinister organisation. Coburn will play the leader of the covert operation. Shooting begins in June in Cleveland.

 Annette Bening is being tipped by Variety as Fox Searchlight's top choice to play the role of Judy Garland in the forthcoming biopic Rainbow's End of the star's troubled life. Although whether she'll be fully recovered from having Warren Beatty's fourth child earlier this month remains to be seen.

 Blond babe Brad Pitt is reportedly in negotiations to star alongside the older-generation hunk Robert Redford in the government conspiracy thriller Spy Game. He would be playing a CIA trainee to Redford's retiring agent who gives a helping hand when Pitt is captured by Chinese forces. The Dutchman Mike van Diem is slated to direct the film, which would be his first English-speaking project. It is set for a late summer/early autumn release.

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner.
fields.body:
Voucher ploy

One of the more ingenious ploys of big businesses? Customer complains about poor service - and is appeased with vouchers valid only for transactions with said company. British Airways lost Donald Rimes's wife's luggage en route for Kenya, and it was only regained nine days into the 12-day trip. When Rimes complained, he was given 600 air miles and £70 worth of flight retail goods - both only valid for BA flights.

 This policy is practised by several airlines and rail operators, but, says BA, it should not have applied in the Rimes case. "It was a simple human error," says a spokeswoman. "We have now issued the customer with cash compensation."

Flighty response

Joanne Lyons of Perth and George Wormald of Hertfordshire received nothing from Ryanair after their respective flights were cancelled. Lyons' flight to Glasgow was cancelled following the Korean airline crash at Stansted last December and she was told to write in for her refund. Two months and three letters later, all she'd received from the company was a letter telling her she had to return her unused tickets first. Wormald and two friends had been due to fly to Glasgow in October and his flight was also cancelled, but he too has heard nothing, despite tireless correspondence on his part.

I've had innumerable crude faxes from companies ranging from car dealers to a firm of heavies offering to harass my debtors. Beddington Infants' School in Sutton has been suffering a similar plague. Businesses have to register with the fax preference service on 0845 0700702 to have their details deleted from databases. Householders can get advice on 0845 703 4599 or complain to the Data Protection Commissioner on 01625 545 745.

National disgrace

Pamela Jones of Buxton and her husband found that they could save £150 a month by switching their mortgage account to the Northern Rock Building Society - then were told the deal only applied to UK citizens. As Jones is an American she did not qualify, even though she's been married to a Briton and has lived here for 17 years.

"We lend on our normal terms to those who have operated under a work permit for four years, then obtain permanent residence status," says a spokesman. "We are reminding our branches, mortgage advisors and underwriters of this."

Nancy Robertson, a pensioner in Harrow, ordered a PC from Mesh Computers. The despatch date was postponed, then it failed to turn up on the new delivery date. After many phone calls, Mesh agreed to put it in a taxi. It failed to arrive. A week later she did receive the PC but it crashed almost immediately. Phone calls and letters to technical support had no effect until, finally, an engineer told her it must be a software problem and he couldn't help. fields.headline: Anna's Oscars
fields.standfirst: To celebrate her second year of solving Guardian readers' problems,  Anna Tims  awards gongs to those companies that have done the most to keep her postbag full
fields.trailText: To celebrate her second year of solving Guardian readers' problems, Anna Tims awards gongs to those companies that have done the most to keep her postbag full.
fields.body:
It's been two years since Consumer volunteered to take on those modern bogeymen - customer service centres and automated helplines - on behalf of our long-suffering readers. To mark the anniversary it seems only fair to credit those companies who have, by their unorthodox interpretations of customer care, kept Dear Anna going. Your letters have, as always, been many and varied, ranging from the bizarre (with apologies to the gentleman who sought help for his genital rash) to the heart-breaking, but, it seems, our fragmenting nation remains united by our hatred for three indispensables: computers, telecoms and the privatised gas industry.

You are evidently a technologically adventurous lot, judging from your wrangles with high street electrical giants, but computers - which represented the largest slice of complaints last year - have slipped to third place, perhaps due to the launch of digital television, which has helped put the telecoms industry at the top of this year's list. Laments in this category accounted for just under a third of all the letters we received, and half of that number concerned mobile phones. Unsurprisingly, recently published figures show that these tiny contraptions, designed to smooth life's path, are now up there with second-hand car dealers and double-glazing salesmen when it comes to complaints.

The problem is not so much the quality of the product, but the attitude of the customer services. If you're lucky enough to get through, that is. The man hours spent by most of you listening to Vivaldi on automated helplines would suffice to build a millennium dome for Manchester. Telecommunications giants, it seems, are not too hot at communicating.

Another familiar bugbear is the privatised utilities. As myriad new gas companies do battle for custom, more and more of you have outed yourselves as ETs (erroneous transfers), poached without your knowledge by a rival gas company or left in limbo between two suppliers. And while some of you have had to face down debt collection agencies over bills from suppliers you've never heard of, others are struggling to get a bill out of anyone at all. British Gas, being the largest of them, is not unnaturally the favourite enemy, accounting for 6% of our total postbag (1% up on last year).

Trailing behind is the iniquitous world of insurance (6% of complaints) and mail order (9%).

More unexpected is the small number of complaints about our train services, although Virgin must be congratulated on achieving 56% of rail gripes. Possibly we have become too resigned to late and cancelled trains to bother raising our voices. Most of the complaints we did receive concerned the bizarre routines required to book through tickets on the privatised system. Not even the rail operators seem entirely sure of what is valid where and one reader's £1,200 season ticket turned out to be valid solely on a train that didn't exist. "I saw a copy of the routing guide once and got the fright of my life," a spokesman from the Association of Train Operators told us recently.

Finally, Ikea and the Dixons Group deserve a little mention all of their own for providing 1.5% and 2% of our mailbag respectively. Keep up the good work, chaps - we'll ensure you see your name in lights!

The One You Most Love to Hate:

Despite its best efforts, poor British Gas has been usurped this year by the truly spectacular achievements of Cable & Wireless. Its phantom phone lines, vanishing engineers, impenetrable automated queuing systems and unforgettable customer services account for 10% of your complaints. C&W has admitted that "there have been some problems and are trying to do something about it".

The Most Prolific Newcomer:

Few of us had heard of 1st Line at the beginning of last year. Now 5% of our correspondents have received its won't-take-no-for-an-answer cold-calls, inviting them to accept a free trial mobile. Then comes the fun; unsanctioned direct debit instructions, unexpected fees, and more aggressive hard sell when they try to break free. 1st Line have printed apologies in five national tabloids for problems arising from "incredible demand".

The Biggest Blip:

The car hire company Hire For Lower burst into our consciousness last summer when 2% of our year's mailbag highlighted cliff-hanging waits for rental documents that often turned out to be invalid or incomplete when presented at check-in desks. In response, the firm promised to triple its customer services (to three) and the complaints dried up.

The Biggest Climbdown:

And the winner is Virgin Holidays. Its constantly changing flight and hotel schedules jeopardised the nuptials of two couples who'd booked a double wedding package in Antigua. Virgin declared itself powerless, but when Consumer protested, Virgin offered to charter a special plane for the wedding party to help get them home.

The Favourite Excuse:

"It was the computers' fault." (All companies.) An invaluable blame deflector when official letters threaten blameless customers (and non-customers) with debt collection agencies, close/open accounts without warning, or when charges are debited in tripli cate from the wrong account. Also handy for the non-delivery of orders, the non-arrival of technicians and the non-call-back from customer services.

The Most Surreal Excuse:

Step forward Cable & Wireless who told Barbara Smoker of Bromley that her new phone line had been mistakenly installed at her neighbour's house because her neighbour had the same name as herself (not that this stopped C&W sending the bills to Smoker). In an attempt to make amends, good old C&W, having previously confused Smoker's address with her neighbour's, switched them round and gave her neighbour Smoker's address. Thus Smoker received a change-of-name form intended for the neighbour, which the latter couldn't fill out because she never had been called Barbara Smoker.

The Creakiest Customer Services:

Hooray once more for British Gas, which eventually compensated G Rigby three years after messing up his central heating system.

The Best Example of Bureaucratic Logic:

It would be a shame not to give Ikea its moment of well-deserved glory. Several readers, who checked before setting out that certain large items were in stock, drove across country to find them unavailable. The goods were, in fact, on a top shelf, reachable only by a fork lift. Could they be fetched down? Too dangerous; can only be done overnight. Could they be fetched overnight and put aside? No, we don't take overnight orders. Could extra numbers be brought down to meet demand? Sorry, the computer only allows two at a time. If you want three you'll have to make two trips.

The Most Effective Vanishing Act:

The Wrought Iron Bed Factory which, having promised to waft its customers to cut-price dream land, left them sleepless after disappearing in August 1999 with thousands of pounds worth of orders unfulfilled. A sign at the shop said, "On holiday, back on August 31", but when Consumer went to welcome back the staff, there was nobody there. Consumer has had no news of them since.

The Most Bashful Sales Team:

Surprise, surprise, it's those unassuming double-glazing salesmen again. This time at Highgrove Windows based in Kent. Not that they admit to that. "Why are you being so pushy?" demanded the telephonist on Consumer's fourth attempt to establish the company's whereabouts. "I don't know where we're based," ventured another. When Consumer caught the managing director unawares on his mobile, he was overcome with sudden earache and had to ring off.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All the mooted moves
fields.trailText: All the mooted moves.
fields.body:
Manchester United striker Andy Cole has been linked with a switch to Fiorentina as part of a swap deal with Viola goalkeeper Francesco Toldo, according to Teamtalk. The Italian club reportedly prefer the option of selling Toldo to United rather than another Serie A side. But with the keeper rated at a staggering £15m, United are reportedly considering the option of sacrificing the £12m-rated Cole in part-exchange.

Emmanuel Petit has sparked an £8m transfer scramble by revealing he may quit Highbury after next month's Uefa Cup final, reports the Daily Mirror. Internazionale and Real Madrid are both keen on the 29-year-old Frenchman.

West Ham are set to complete the £4m signing of on-loan striker Frederic Kanoute, according to The Express. "We now have an agreement in place for Frederic to join us," said Hammers boss Harry Redknapp. "It should all be finalised over the next few days." But the club may have to sell Marc-Vivien Foe, who has been linked with a host of French clubs, to finance the deal.

Tore Andre Flo says he is flattered with reports linking him with a move to Dutch giants PSV Eindhoven - but he is happy with Chelsea, reports Planet Football. Speaking prior to Norway's international friendly with Belgium on Wednesday night, Flo said: "I have read everywhere that I don't like PSV, but I have never been approached by any Dutch team. It is true that I would prefer to stay in England and I like it at Chelsea, but I'm flattered that PSV shows interest. When they want a talk, I will certainly be positive to them."

David O'Leary has targeted 19 year-old Brann Bergen defender Erlend Hanstveit after the player impressed against Leeds in a recent friendly, reports Planet Football.

fields.headline: George Cukor: The Philadelphia Story
fields.trailText: Considering the talkative nature of the film, it moves marvellously and the performances would be very hard to beat because they are based on the wit of character rather than lines
fields.body:
George Cukor has often been called a pre-eminent director of women. And that he was, like certain other gay film-makers. Katharine Hepburn, Greta Garbo, Ingrid Bergman and Judy Garland could testify to that. It would be more accurate, however, to cast him as a film-maker who paid particular attention to performance and relationships.

Cukor had just about the longest continuous career of any major director who worked within the mainstream. He survived Hollywood's often cavalier treatment of original talent, including the blow of being fired by David Selznick a few days into the shoot of Gone With the Wind after coaching Vivien Leigh. When you look at the sort of movies he might have been asked to direct now were he still at work, you long for the wit, humanity and the sense of style evinced by such classics as The Philadelphia Story.

The film is not, perhaps, the funniest romantic comedy ever made. Cukor attempted to pitch Donald Ogden Stewart and Waldo Salt's adaptation of the Philip Barry play into the realms of ironic social significance, by suggesting that it isn't only the rich who have vices and the poor who have virtue. But considering the talkative nature of the film, it moves marvellously and the performances would be very hard to beat because they are based on the wit of character rather than lines.

In the silent opening sequence, Cary Grant, as Hepburn's former husband, is thrown out of the front door of her wealthy parents' ritzy home in Philadelphia. When Hepburn, soon to be married to a less dissolute lover, appears, she breaks one of his favourite golf clubs, throws them after him and slams the door. Grant doesn't give up and rings the doorbell again. When Hepburn answers, he pushes her in the face.

This perfectly timed sequence tells us everything. Admittedly we are in a sense primed, since the two stars had appeared before as antagonists, notably in Cukor's Sylvia Scarlett and in Howard Hawks's Bringing up Baby. And Hepburn's furious reaction turned to advantage the reputation she had acquired as arrogant and mannish, and thus box office poison.

Hepburn had starred in the play on Broadway; she acquired the movie rights and sold them to MGM with the proviso that she was the star and had the choice of director and co-stars. It seems extraordinary now that she had left Hollywood in high dudgeon before this film, feeling totally unappreciated by the public. But this was the 30s, when woman stars were liked for their vulnerability rather than their independence.

Cukor's skill at using her negative image and turning it round so successfully - the film was a huge hit - was typical of the man. Like Hawks, he was able to make the very best of good material.

Cukor has often been attacked for his obedience to the studio system, his insistance on not interfering with the values of a screenplay and the commercial appeal of his films. He could be pedestrian (witness My Fair Lady). But at his best he showed how good the studio system could be. He had taste, style and humanity. And his films look better now than they ever did because of it.

fields.headline: Producer of top musicals dies
fields.trailText: David Merrick, the American film and stage producer whose credits include the celebrated 1974 film version of The Great Gatsby, has died aged 88.
fields.body:
David Merrick, the American film and stage producer whose credits include the celebrated 1974 film version of The Great Gatsby, has died aged 88.

Merrick, whose theatre career spanned four decades, died in his sleep at a London rest home on Tuesday, said a spokesman from the David Merrick Arts Foundation. Among his 70 major stage productions were the hugely successful Hello Dolly!, 42nd Street and Gypsy. In 1983, Merrick, who had homes in London, New York and Paris, suffered a severe stroke which affected his speech and left him unable to carry on actively as a producer. The spokesman said Merrick recently moved into the London rest home as his health faltered and he became more frail.

The producer's body was being flown out yesterday to New York, accompanied by his wife and former business partner, Natalie Lloyd-Merrick, 46. He leaves two daughters from previous marriages, Cecilia Anne, of New Jersey, and Marguerite, of New York.

Merrick, born David Margulois in St Louis, Missouri, won numerous Tony awards, with Hello Dolly! picking up 10 alone in 1964, as well as a host of other accolades.

Jerry Herman, who wrote the score for Hello Dolly!, last night said: "He really understood the word 'entertainment' like nobody else I have ever worked with. Without a doubt, he truly was the greatest producer of the old-fashioned musical."

Merrick, whose theatre career spanned four decades, died in his sleep at a London rest home on Tuesday, said a spokesman from the David Merrick Arts Foundation. Among his 70 major stage productions were the hugely successful Hello Dolly!, 42nd Street and Gypsy. In 1983, Merrick, who had homes in London, New York and Paris, suffered a severe stroke which affected his speech and left him unable to carry on actively as a producer. The spokesman said Merrick recently moved into the London rest home as his health faltered and he became more frail. The producer's body was being flown out yesterday to New York, accompanied by his wife and former business partner, Natalie Lloyd-Merrick, 46. He leaves two daughters from previous marriages, Cecilia Anne, of New Jersey, and Marguerite, of New York. Merrick, born David Margulois in St Louis, Missouri, won numerous Tony awards, with Hello Dolly! picking up 10 alone in 1964, as well as a host of other accolades. Jerry Herman, who wrote the score for Hello Dolly!, last night said: "He really understood the word 'entertainment' like nobody else I have ever worked with. Without a doubt, he truly was the greatest producer of the old-fashioned musical."

fields.headline: United rely on scouts' honour
fields.standfirst: Ferguson had Van Nistelrooy watched 40 times in six years before making his move
fields.trailText: Ferguson had Van Nistelrooy watched 40 times in six years before making his £18.5m move.
fields.body:
From all the headlines in the past few days, you might imagine that Martin Edwards had picked up Ruud van Nistelrooy on impulse, forgotten to tell his manager about it and waved aside protests that he should get the bloke's knee looked at because he had been out for seven weeks.

In reality the pending deal is the culmination of one of the most sophisticated purchasing operations in Britain. No matter what impression the rickety United PR machine might produce, everyone who mattered at the club would have known about the deal and they would all have wanted it done.

The process that led the Premiership champions to agree to pay £18.5m for the 23-year-old PSV Eindhoven striker was meticulous, stretched back six years and involved hundreds of hours of video footage, countless phone calls, thousands of air miles and 40 personal evaluations by Sir Alex Ferguson and his staff who travelled to watch him play.

Years of competing in European competition have helped Ferguson build an extensive network of contacts around the continent. They, and an insatiable appetite for satellite television and video viewing, keep the United manager abreast of emerging talent all over the globe. He first became aware of Van Nistelrooy's burgeoning talents when the striker was only 17 and playing with the Dutch second division side Den Bosch.

Ferguson utilised the foot soldiers among an extensive scouting network that is headed by the chief scout, and former United assistant, Mick Brown and Ferguson's own brother Martin, who carries the title "overseas scout". United also have numerous part- and full-time scouts in Britain and three full-time overseas scouts, two of them based in France and Sweden.

About three years ago Martin Ferguson, who served as assistant manager with Hibernian and St Mirren before linking up with his brother, drew up his first dossier on a player who was gaining the attention of the big Dutch clubs, including the then PSV manager Bobby Robson.

Robson kept the United manager informed about the striker's development after signing him from Den Bosch, recommending him as a United star of the future. By 1998 Martin was urging his brother to think seriously about signing Van Nistelrooy.

The reports and videos continued to pile up on Ferguson's desk and Robson, bumping into Martin Ferguson on one of his visits to PSV this season, urged him to recommend an immediate move.

 Fiorentina's goalkeeper Francesco Toldo has said that he will leave the Italian club at the end of the season and that Manchester United are one of the favourites to sign him.  Sir Bobby Charlton last night handed the European Cup over to the safekeeping of the city of Paris where this year's final will be played on May 24.

webTitle: British make a showing at Cannes

fields.headline: British make a showing at Cannes
fields.trailText: Three British offerings are among the 24 films to be screened at the Directors Fortnight, a sideshow to Cannes' main selection at the International Film Festival, running May 10-23, it was revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Three British offerings are among the 24 films to be screened at the Directors Fortnight, a sideshow to Cannes' main selection at the International Film Festival, running May 10-23, it was revealed yesterday.

The first is Purely Belter, a comedy by Mark Herman (of Brassed Off fame) about two kids on the lookout for money to buy football tickets.

Dancer, a film starring Julie Walters, has been selected as the fortnight's closing film. Set in northern England in the 70s, it is the story of a poor boy who wants to be a ballet dancer and marks the feature film directorial debut of Stephen Daldry, until recently artistic director of the Royal Court Theatre.

Finally, Simon Cellan Jones' Some Voices will also represent British hopes - the director is best known in this country for his work on TV series Our Friends in the North.

There will also be a tribute to the recently departed French art-house director Robert Bresson, whose works include L'Argent and the scandalous Les Dames du Bois de Boulogne, among other gems.

A new prize will also be up for grabs at the festival this year: The European Commission is offering an award of around £20,000 to European producers of a first movie made with EU funding, in an attempt to stave off the threat posed by Hollywood to European film-making. For a five year period, starting in 2000, they have allocated almost 400 million euros under the EU Media Plus programme to help with the distribution and promotion of European films. The prize will be presented to a European producer by Vivian Reding, the commissioner for culture and audiovisual media, on May 19, at the end of the Producers Fortnight.

The complete list of Fortnight films is:

 L'Affaire Marcorelle, dir. Serge Le Péron (France)

 Peppermint Candy, dir. Lee Chang-Dong (South Korea)
 La Captive, dir. Chantal Akerman (France/Belgium)

 La Chambre Obscure, dir. Marie-Christine Questerbert (France)

 Cuba Feliz, dir. Karim Dridi (France)

 Dancer, dir. Stephen Daldry (UK)

 Downtown 81, dir. Edo Bertoglio (US)

 Faîtes comme si je n'étais pas là, dir. Olivier Jahan (France/Italy)

 Les Fantômes des Trois Madeleines, dir. Guylaine Dionne (Canada)

 Koroshi, dir. Masahiro Kobayashi (Japan)

 Girlfight, dir. Karyn Kusama (US)

 The Werckmeister Harmonies, dir. Béla Tarr (Hungary)

 Die Unberuhrbare, dir. Oskar Roehler (Germany)

 Lumumba, dir. Raoul Peck (France/Belgium/Haiti)

 Mallboy, dir. Vincent Giarrusso (Australia)

 Shadow of the Vampire, dir. E Elias Merhige (US)

 Pane e Tulipani (Bread and Tulips), dir. Silvio Soldini (Italy/Switzerland)

 Petite Chérie, dir. Anne Villacèque (France)

 Purely Belter, dir. Mark Herman (UK)

 Le Secret, dir. Virginie Wagon (France)

 Some Voices, dir. Simon Cellan Jones (UK)

 Summer or 27 Missing Kisses, dir. Nana Djordjadze (Germany/Georgia)

 Tout va bien, on s'en va, dir. Claude Mouriéras (France)

 A Time for the Rapture of Horse, dir. Bahman Ghobadi (Iran)

fields.headline: Swiss watch Germany falling
fields.standfirst: Germany 1 Kirsten 84 Switzerland 1 H Yakin 33
fields.trailText: Writing off Germany in a major tournament is traditionally a treacherous pastime. And most of those who do are roundly ignored in the safe knowledge that, come the semi-finals or final, the Germans will still be there. Unloved and undramatic, but still there. When the person writing off their chances is Franz Beckenbauer, however, the reaction is somewhat different.
fields.body:
Writing off Germany in a major tournament is traditionally a treacherous pastime. And most of those who do are roundly ignored in the safe knowledge that, come the semi-finals or final, the Germans will still be there. Unloved and undramatic, but still there. When the person writing off their chances is Franz Beckenbauer, however, the reaction is somewhat different.

"Our football is at rock bottom," he said. "This team has only average players, manual labourers really. We have never been so badly off."

The former national manager is far from the only German to be overcome by a nauseating dread that the nation that invented Schadenfreude is on the brink of discovering how uncomfortable it can be on the receiving end.

Amid a smouldering backdrop of dressing-room discontent, Germany have lost to Scotland, Turkey, Holland, Brazil and the United States (twice) since their thoroughly uninspiring effort in the last World Cup to leave their coach Erich Ribbeck commenting they were "on a par with Albania and Moldova".

For long spells here last night that did not look like an exaggeration as German pride took another pummelling at home to Switzerland - ranked No54 in the world and falling - when most of the talk among a near-capacity crowd concerned absent friends.

Jens Jeremies was dropped for rating German team spirit as "miserable", but the ostracised Bayern Munich midfielder has been far from alone in offering such an assessment.

Markus Babbel has spoken in defence of his colleague and only the intervention of the German association president Egidius Braun prevented Thomas Hässler from ending his international career this month.

The Bayern manager Uli Höness has accused the 63-year-old Ribbeck of being unable to control his players, and the German media are awash with rumours that Jeremies and Oliver Bierhoff gave the half-time team talk during the recent defeat in Holland as the manager skulked in the corner.

"Every problem is dealt with in a naive, ridiculous and short-sighted manner," said Germany's 1974 World Cup winner Paul Breitner. "Since the last World Cup there has been a lot of talking but nothing has been learned."

Ribbeck was dubbed Sir Erich when he was appointed (ahead of Breitner) 20 months ago but the public perception is that the man behind the smart suit and polite demeanour is hopelessly out of his depth.

"For most people, Jeremies was just putting into words what they were seeing themselves," said Christoph Biermann, chief football writer of the Suddeutsche Zeitung. "Most people don't expect the national team to win anything. If they drop out of Euro 2000 at the first stage nobody would be too shocked. There would be outrage, of course, but no shock."

The deep-rooted problem is a chronic lack of facilities, which is suffocating the development of young players. Though the Freiburg winger Tobias Willi and the Hertha Berlin midfielder Sebastian Deisler have recently reached the top, the conveyor belt of young talent appears to have come off its runners.

Ribbeck's Euro 2000 squad will probably incorporate at least eight players over the age of 30, the leaden-footed Lothar Matthäus, now 39 and playing for the New York/New Jersey MetroStars, taking the role of Captain Mainwaring.

According to Beckenbauer, the former World Cup-winning captain, standards have been declining for a decade. "The Dutch, for example, are better trained," he said. "We Germans are trailing the top European countries." And a few of the lesser lights as well, judging by the opening 84 minutes here.

Germany were limping towards their first defeat to Switzerland since 1956 when the recalled goalkeeper Jens Lehmann allowed Hakan Yakin's tame shot to squirm out of his butterfingers.

Ulf Kirsten, one of six substitutes, salvaged a shred of dignity six minutes from the end but even that required the referee to miss a foul on the Swiss goalkeeper Pascal Zuberbühler, and at the end an atmosphere more suited to a library was split by derisory whistles.

Germany may not be quaking in their boots about the impending tete-a-tete with England, but on this evidence Kevin Keegan need not have bad dreams either.

Germany (3-5-2): Lehmann; Babbel ( Worns , 35min), Wosz ( Rink , h-t), Linke; Rehmer ( Neuville , 68), Ballack, Scholl ( Hamann , 24min), Matthäus, Ziege ( Bode , 20); Preetz ( Kirsten , h-t), Bierhoff.

Switzerland (4-4-2): Zuberbühler; Haas, M Yakin, Müller, Mazzarelli; Cantaluppi ( Jeanneret , 88), Vogel, Sforza, Buhlmann ( Gerber , 82); Sesa, H Yakin ( Rey , 69).

Referee: M Norman (Sweden).

fields.headline: The Bard's biggest fan
fields.standfirst: Gregory Doran, the director tipped as the next boss at the RSC, talks to  Michael Billington
fields.trailText: Gregory Doran has lately become a jet-setting director. By the time the less-than-flattering reviews of his Stratford As You Like It appeared last month, he was already in Tokyo to supervise the transfer of his triumphant Royal Shakespeare Company Macbeth. "As the Stratford reviews were faxed through," he says, "I felt like committing hara-kiri. I'd also done five shows in 15 months and felt knackered. Then a fax arrived from the Stratford company simply saying, of the critics, 'Fuck 'em.' "
fields.body:
Gregory Doran has lately become a jet-setting director. By the time the less-than-flattering reviews of his Stratford As You Like It appeared last month, he was already in Tokyo to supervise the transfer of his triumphant Royal Shakespeare Company Macbeth. "As the Stratford reviews were faxed through," he says, "I felt like committing hara-kiri. I'd also done five shows in 15 months and felt knackered. Then a fax arrived from the Stratford company simply saying, of the critics, 'Fuck 'em.' "

For Doran As You Like It was a hiccup in a run of success with the RSC. He first worked with the company as an actor in 1987, when he met his partner, Antony Sher - there's an oft-told story of how, playing Solanio, he one night described Sher's Shylock as "the most impenetrable cur that ever slept with [instead of kept with] men." Now Doran, who is in his early 40s, has emerged from Sher's shadow to become a highly prized RSC associate director, often tipped as Adrian Noble's eventual successor - an idea he politely squashes.

Although Doran and Sher have thriving separate careers, they have worked together four times - on a South African Titus Andronicus plus Cyrano de Bergerac, The Winter's Tale and Macbeth for the RSC. Is there ever a danger of he and Sher pre-empting the rehearsal process by sorting out problems at home.

"I don't think so. For a start we're complete opposites. Tony's a pessimist and I'm an optimist. He has a dark, brooding African spirit whereas I have a soft, greyly monotonous English quality. I'm maybe calmer in temperament than he is. But also we're quite rigorous about how we work together. When we did Titus in South Africa we took the work home with us and I began to feel I needed my own space. Now we ration our discussions so that with Macbeth [now on at the Old Vic] I probably talked in advance as much to Harriet Walter as I did to Tony. Having been a spear-carrier at Stratford, I also feel Shakespeare's plays only work when you get a total investment from the whole company."

Some ideas, however, have to start with the director. And one of Doran's most brilliant in Macbeth is to begin the play in pitch darkness. "That evolved," he says, "from directing Peter Shaffer's Black Comedy. I insisted on an absolute blackout for the opening scene which meant turning off all the exit lights. On the Guildford first night I was standing at the back and a man rushed past me in panic saying, 'I've got to get out.' Another night I heard a strange gurgling sound and discovered it was a deaf person suffering from total sensory deprivation. It alerted me to how quickly you could remove people from the simple things they require to keep a sense of equilibrium.

"It's also absolutely right for Macbeth, which taps into all our primal instincts, though initially I made the mistake of having the witches' voices on amplifiers that flew out over the audience. It was too tricksy."

But why does Macbeth so often fail? In my lifetime, I've seen only a handful of successful productions: Trevor Nunn's Other Place version in 1976, Ninagawa's Japanese elegy in 1986 and now Doran's intimate RSC production. "I suspect," he says, "people normally start back to front with it. They start with the theatricality of the witches or the supernatural. The first three or four scenes also go by in a rush of generalised war. In fact, what's happening is absolutely specific. There's an attempted coup d'etat. Maybe Macbeth fights as hard as he does not to re-establish Duncan but to ensure that Cawdor does not become king. But if Cawdor can rebel, why can't he? We felt that the Macbeths seize their opportunity and that the witches are simply observers. I said to Tony one day: imagine someone stops you in the street and predicts you'll win an Oscar. Your agent then phones up to say you've been nominated. Do you rely on a chance prediction or do you get out to Hollywood and do all the promotion? In terms of Macbeth, it's the coincidence of the witches' prophecy rather than the malign purpose of it that strikes one."

If Doran hit the mark dead centre with Macbeth, he is widely perceived to have missed it with As You Like It. But he still believes strongly in the central idea: of Arden as a forest of the mind that becomes an extension of the tapestry Rosalind is working on and that is filled with her own vivacity and imagination. He also laughs off the notion that the rough reviews have lengthened the odds against his ever taking over the RSC.

"Is it my ambition to run the RSC? I don't think so. The job isn't up for grabs so it's not an issue. My sole desire is to direct the plays I want to do. I want to direct an Othello in The Swan with Tony as Iago. And I'd like to do a new version of the Morte d'Arthur for Stratford since I feel it deals with the matter of England."

This summer, however, he's taking a break from the RSC to direct the York Mystery plays in York Minster. Since he was born in Yorkshire, educated at Preston Catholic College and had an uncle who was a Benedectine abbot, he seems the right man for the job. But his own catholicism lapsed when it came into conflict with his sexuality, and anyway he sees the Mysteries as expressions of civic pride rather than openly didactic works. He even relishes the prospect of working with 200 amateur actors. "I was auditioning the other day and a man came up to me and said 'I'm not good at coming in on time and I can't learn lines but I could shout "Crucify him! Crucify him!" if push came to shove.' So he's in. But what I hope to combine is the highly competitive nature of the original Guild shows with Christian iconography. I'm no longer actively religious but, as Sartre said, 'We have a God-shaped hole in our consciousness which we've never learned to fill.' I undoubtedly have one in mine. Most of the time it's filled by Shakespeare who I passionately believe was a Catholic."

Given his lifelong Bardolatry, high intelligence and persuasive temperament, Doran is clearly a strong future contender for the Stratford throne. Whether the gentle but far-from-grey Greg also has the naked, Macbeth-like ambition to take over the toughest job in British theatre is something time alone will reveal.

 Macbeth is at the Young Vic, London SE1 (020-7928 6363), till June 3.

I insisted on an absolute blackout for the opening scene which meant turning off all the exit lights. On the Guildford first night I was standing at the back and a man rushed past me in panic saying, 'I've got to get out.' Another night I heard a strange gurgling sound and discovered it was a deaf person suffering from total sensory deprivation. It alerted me to how quickly you could remove people from the simple things they require to keep a sense of equilibrium. "It's also absolutely right for Macbeth, which taps into all our primal instincts, though initially I made the mistake of having the witches' voices on amplifiers that flew out over the audience. It was too tricksy." But why does Macbeth so often fail? In my lifetime, I've seen only a handful of successful productions: Trevor Nunn's Other Place version in 1976, Ninagawa's Japanese elegy in 1986 and now Doran's intimate RSC production. "I suspect," he says, "people normally start back to front with it. They start with the theatricality of the witches or the supernatural. The first three or four scenes also go by in a rush of generalised war. In fact, what's happening is absolutely specific. There's an attempted coup d'etat. Maybe Macbeth fights as hard as he does not to re-establish Duncan but to ensure that Cawdor does not become king. But if Cawdor can rebel, why can't he? We felt that the Macbeths seize their opportunity and that the witches are simply observers. I said to Tony one day: imagine someone stops you in the street and predicts you'll win an Oscar. Your agent then phones up to say you've been nominated. Do you rely on a chance prediction or do you get out to Hollywood and do all the promotion? In terms of Macbeth, it's the coincidence of the witches' prophecy rather than the malign purpose of it that strikes one." If Doran hit the mark dead centre with Macbeth, he is widely perceived to have missed it with As You Like It. But he still believes strongly in the central idea: of Arden as a forest of the mind that becomes an extension of the tapestry Rosalind is working on and that is filled with her own vivacity and imagination. He also laughs off the notion that the rough reviews have lengthened the odds against his ever taking over the RSC. "Is it my ambition to run the RSC? I don't think so. The job isn't up for grabs so it's not an issue. My sole desire is to direct the plays I want to do. I want to direct an Othello in The Swan with Tony as Iago. And I'd like to do a new version of the Morte d'Arthur for Stratford since I feel it deals with the matter of England." This summer, however, he's taking a break from the RSC to direct the York Mystery plays in York Minster. Since he was born in Yorkshire, educated at Preston Catholic College and had an uncle who was a Benedectine abbot, he seems the right man for the job. But his own catholicism lapsed when it came into conflict with his sexuality, and anyway he sees the Mysteries as expressions of civic pride rather than openly didactic works. He even relishes the prospect of working with 200 amateur actors. "I was auditioning the other day and a man came up to me and said 'I'm not good at coming in on time and I can't learn lines but I could shout "Crucify him! Crucify him!" if push came to shove.' So he's in. But what I hope to combine is the highly competitive nature of the original Guild shows with Christian iconography. I'm no longer actively religious but, as Sartre said, 'We have a God-shaped hole in our consciousness which we've never learned to fill.' I undoubtedly have one in mine. Most of the time it's filled by Shakespeare who I passionately believe was a Catholic." Given his lifelong Bardolatry, high intelligence and persuasive temperament, Doran is clearly a strong future contender for the Stratford throne. Whether the gentle but far-from-grey Greg also has the naked, Macbeth-like ambition to take over the toughest job in British theatre is something time alone will reveal.  Macbeth is at the Young Vic, London SE1 (020-7928 6363), till June 3.

webTitle: Scots put squeeze on the orange

fields.headline: Scots put squeeze on the orange
fields.standfirst: Holland 0 Scotland 0
fields.trailText: Scotland showed that their capacity to raise their game against the best remains undiminished as they more than held their own at the Gelredome.
fields.body:
Scotland showed that their capacity to raise their game against the best remains undiminished as they more than held their own at the Gelredome.

Neil Sullivan made the save of the game when it mattered, Don Hutchison hit the woodwork and a patchwork side proved that the fear that Europeans have for the fighting Scottish spirit is justified. Holland, obviously practising for Euro 2000, were jeered at the end.

Scotland's manager Craig Brown picked out the Wimbledon goalkeeper as worthy of special praise. In the 64th minute, after Andre Ooijer had crossed to the substitute Patrick Kluivert, Sullivan dropped to his knees and somehow blocked the shot that would have won the game. Instead, Scotland rode easily to the finish and greater credit.

"In the last year he has had shut-outs in Germany and England, now in Holland," said Brown. "We are beginning to take him for granted to be rated highly, and he's such a big, open and modest man as well. He does us proud."

Enthusiasm over the result must be tempered. The Dutch manager Frank Rijkaard effectively picked his second string for sparring practice, and four substitutions in the second half confirmed that he was more interested in forthcoming matches than the result on the night. But Scotland still had to face a testing examination on and off the field.

Arnhem's Gelredome may be off the international beaten track but the stadium is magnificent, with 30,000 seats beneath a retractable roof, which was closed and enabled the noise to bounce around as if in bedlam.

And everything was orange. It was as if Holland were making a clear statement that no one, England included, would be taking away the Euro 2000 trophy this summer if it was down to some of the most committed fans in the world.

Scotland expected to be on the back foot , even if four of the Barcelona squad who beat Chelsea in the Champions League quarter-finals were left on the bench. With Dennis Bergkamp giving early indications that his finishing could be of the highest class, Brown must have wondered what was about to happen. Instead, with Matt Elliott and David Weir standing firm in the middle of the defence, it was the Dutch spirit which began to wilt.

Indeed, in the 42nd minute Scotland were a fraction away from taking the lead. After an Edgar Davids pass had been intercepted, Neil McCann flexed his legs on the left and struck a tempting cross that hung in the air to beat the defence. Hutchison, arriving at the far post, headed strongly but, with Edwin van der Sar beaten, the ball struck the post.

Some 13 minutes from the end Sullivan again denied Kluivert and such was Brown's confidence that for the last few minutes he was able even to throw on a fringe player in Brian O'Neil in order to give the defender a cap.

By that time Rijkaard realised that his record of interminable draws over the past two years was not to be improved, and the tartan army departed happy.

 Two Scotland fans, one wearing a Hitler mask, were put on the return ferry to Newcastle yesterday after giving Nazi salutes on arrival at the Dutch port of IJmuiden. Four other fans had been refused entry and flown back to Britain on Tuesday for disrupting public order after fighting broke out on the 12-hour crossing.

Holland (4-4-2): Van der Sar; Ooijer, Konterman, De Boer, Numan; Makaay ( Talan, 60min), Bosvelt, Davids, Overmars ( Zenden , h-t ); Hasselbaink ( Van Hooijdonk , 67), Bergkamp ( Kluivert , h-t).

Scotland (4-4-2): Sullivan (Wimbledon); Dailly (Blackburn; O'Neil , VfL Wolfsburg, 84), Elliott (Leicester), Weir (Everton) , Ritchie (Bolton); McNamara (Celtic; Burchill , Celtic, 67), Lambert (Celtic), Burley (Derby; Durrant , Kilmarnock, h-t), McCann (Rangers); Hutchison (Everton), Dodds (Rangers).

Referee: H Stramp (Germany).

fields.headline: Explorations in hypertext
fields.standfirst: Karlin Lillington looks at the hypertext revolution and what it means for literature
fields.trailText: Karlin Lillington looks at the hypertext revolution and what it means for literature. Plus: the best hypertext links
fields.body:
When Apple decided to supply a copy of a little program called Hypercard on all Macintosh computers back in the 80s, it prepared the way for what would become the web's most distinctive feature, hypertext. It also unknowingly launched a small literary revolution.

Hypertext is the bone and muscle of the web, the crucial element that lets people move through cyberspace rather than sit looking at a static image on a screen. Click with a mouse on a bit of hypertext (which can be a letter, a word, or a chunk of text), and you're whisked off to whatever is linked to it. But hypertext existed well before the web, and Hypercard introduced hundreds of thousands of people to the concept.

Hypercard enabled people to connect information by association rather than in the more structured sequence of a written document. Users could create "stacks" of virtual notecards (hypercards) on a subject, and create links between cards (hyperlinking them). A reader - or, more appropriately, an explorer - could go literally anywhere, in any direction through the stack.

Hypercard gave ordinary computer users the physical embodiment of one of the most startling insights of Vannevar Bush, science advisor to Franklin D Roosevelt, who wrote a prescient essay in 1945 called As We May Think (archived at www.isg.sfu.ca/~duchier/misc/vbush). In it, he imagined the Memex, an electromechanical device much like a modern day PC, which could store information and allow it to be recalled in wayward but sensible patterns. The human mind, he argued, works not by creating hierarchies of information but by "association. With one item in its grasp, it snaps instantly to the next. In accordance with some intricate web of trails carried by the cells of the brain."

By 1972 computer pioneer Ted Nelson was exploring this concept on computers and had coined the word hypertext. When in the early 90s Tim Berners-Lee mated the visual world of Hypercard and hypertext and the interactive connections of the internet, a powerful new hybrid, the world wide web, was born. But well before the web was conceived, writers had begun experimenting with Hypercard and soon seized upon the artistic possibilities of hypertext. What if one could read in a non-linear way, enabling - or, some would argue, forcing - the reader to create a new reading of a poem or story every time one ventured into it?

Soon a program for writing hypertext was on the market, which allowed writers to structure a work by deciding how text would unfold to a reader. To read a hypertext, a reader moves between screens of text called lexias. A lexia can contain one or many links - usually an interactive word or phrase - to other lexias. Sometimes a certain lexia cannot be revealed until a reader has read other lexias first. Reading becomes a fluid experience - and a highly uncertain, unstable one. With the advent of the web, writers quickly moved to creating works online as well as on disk, and a wide variety of work can be perused from your desktop. Disk-based works tend to have more structural complexity, however.

Hypertext proponents say that hypertext enables a writer (and reader) to break free of the rigid, linear format of the print book. They point to Sterne with Tristram Shandy, Woolf with To The Lighthouse, and Joyce with Ulysses, as authors who struggled to do this in print. Hypertext, they argue, pushes literature into places it has been trying to go for decades.

Critics say hypertext is a lot of complex and pointless literary nonsense, merely a vehicle for testing out the pet theories of convoluted postmodern theorists like Roland Barthes and Jacques Derrida. But their longstanding complaint that it's annoying to read a work on a computer may have to be abandoned with the availability of new, small reading devices.

One of the best places to delve into hypertext is at the site of its leading publisher, Eastgate. Publisher Mark Bernstein is both a devotee, writer and essayist and nurtures a range of writers, sells hypertext works and critical writings about it, and has extensive links to essays, online hypertext and more. While there, have a look at Twelve Blue by Michael Joyce, who wrote the haunting Afternoon, A Story, considered a hypertext classic.

One of the more extravagant online hypertext works is Mark Amerika's Grammatron while a wide range of texts reside at www.turbulence.org. You can even view James Joyce in hypertext at www.mpx.com.

Non-fiction works abound as well: try the Dictionary of Sensibility, www.engl.virginia.edu/~enec981/dictionary, or Singing In The Rain: a Hypertextual Reading.

Poetry has also proved popular as an online hypertext format. Visit the Electronic Poetry Center, Ubuweb, or Rice, a suite of poems about Vietnam, www.idaspoetics.com.au/rice/riceheading.html.

A recent edition of online zine Feed featured an essay on hypertext by writer and critic Robert Coover, with links to previous Feed discussions on the topic, www.feedmag.comdocument/do291_master.html. If by now you are appalled, entranced or outraged by hypertext, jump into the continuing online discussion that follows the essay.
