webTitle: Inzaghi strikes late to crack Portugal

fields.headline: Inzaghi strikes late to crack Portugal
fields.standfirst: Italy 2 Inzaghi 75, Totti 88 Portugal 0
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan will not have been fooled by the result in Reggio Calabria last night, where Italy won the match but for much of it were outplayed by Portugal, England's first opponents in the European Championship. Italy took their chances in the last quarter-hour but Portugal are entitled to feel short-changed.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan will not have been fooled by the result in Reggio Calabria last night, where Italy won the match but for much of it were outplayed by Portugal, England's first opponents in the European Championship. Italy took their chances in the last quarter-hour but Portugal are entitled to feel short-changed.

After a promising start by Italy the Portuguese appeared to be cruising towards a goalless draw when they were caught out by a 75th-minute free-kick which saw Luigi Di Biagio and Gianluca Zambrotta combine to send in Filippo Inzaghi.

The goal prompted a swift reaction and Figo almost equalised when, having burst through on goal, he was brought down by the keeper Francesco Toldo, who was fortunate not to concede a penalty.

Until Italy's second goal it was practically one-way traffic towards their goal. But Portugal's keenness for the equaliser betrayed them as Stefano Fiore sent in Francesco Totti for a counter-attacking goal in the 88th minute with a simple pass from his own half.

Italy might have begun the game with plenty of enthusiasm but the first real chance went to Portugal after seven minutes when the Deportivo striker Pauleta set up Sergio Conceicao, who missed not once but twice as Toldo's first save rebounded to his feet. But Conceicao has never been a deadly marksman, as the Lazio fans know too well.

Two minutes later Italy proved that Portugal, for all their technical bravura, are vulnerable when attacked down the flank. Zambrotta made good ground, leaving Costa and Dimas in his wake before reaching the byline to set up Fiore for a chance which was shot against a post with Quim well beaten.

The initial pattern continued throughout the first half, with Italy making the running but with their goalkeeper rather busier than Portugal's, having to deal with two fine efforts from Bento, then Figo.

Portugal's ability to slow the game down to their own subtle rhythm will not have been lost on the England coach, who may feel that his team will do a better job than Italy in pressuring and cutting down the space on a side often considered Europe's Brazilians.

Italy (3-5-2): Toldo (Fiorentina); Cannavaro (Parma), Nesta (Lazio), Iuliano (Juventus); Zambrotta (Juventus), Albertini (Milan; Di Biagio, Internazionale, h-t; Ambrosini, Milan, 89), Conte (Juventus; Di Francesco, Roma, 77), Pessotto (Juventus), Fiore (Udinese); Delvecchio (Roma; Totti, Roma, h-t), F Inzaghi (Juventus).

Portugal (4-5-1): Quim (Braga) ; Xavier (Everton), Jorge Costa (Porto), Couto (Lazio), Dimas (Fenerbahce); Conceicao (Lazio), Paulo Sousa (Parma), Bento (Oviedo), Rui Costa (Fiorentina; Joao Pinto , Benfica, 70), Figo (Barcelona); Pauleta (Deportivo La Coruna; Sa Pinto, Real Sociedad, 61min).

Referee: E Zammit (Malta).

webTitle: C4 to show banned sex scenes on web

fields.headline: C4 to show banned sex scenes on web
fields.trailText: Channel 4's movie channel is to screen explicit sex scenes on the internet to highlight the strict rules which restrict what can be shown on television.
fields.body:
Channel 4's movie channel is to screen explicit sex scenes on the internet to highlight the strict rules which restrict what can be shown on television.

FilmFour will show a doctored version of The Idiots, which caused controversy when it was given a cinema certificate, on its subscription channel. But it will "webcast" the most controversial scenes, uncut, on its website.

The channel denied yesterday that it was deliberately courting prurient viewers, insisting that it wanted a rational debate on what it believes are anomalous rules.

The Idiots centres on a group of middle class friends who try to shock and provoke "normal" society by pretending to be mentally handicapped. It features penetrative sex. The British Board of Film Classification allowed explicit scenes in the cinema version because its target audience was art house cinemagoers who would understand the context. But broadcasters cannot show erect penises or penetrative sex on television - even on subscription digital chan nels which have "parental lock" facilities available to viewers. A FilmFour spokesman said: "We believe the FilmFour audience is intelligent enough to make choices about what they should watch. We disagree with the discrepancies that exist between what can be broadcast on television and seen on video and believe the viewers should be allowed to make their own choices."

The Idiots, which is being screened on FilmFour on May 5, will be shown by Channel 4 later in the year.

The FilmFour website (www.filmfour.com) is to host an online debate on the issues of censorship as well as screening the scenes.

 The first digital television channel dedicated solely to the arts is to be launched within the year. Artsworld will offer news and reviews covering a wide range of visual and performing arts, including music, film, literature and dance. The service, a collaboration between investors including the Guardian Media Group and British Sky Broadcasting, will be available throughout Britain and Ireland exclusively to Sky Digital subscribers.

We disagree with the discrepancies that exist between what can be broadcast on television and seen on video and believe the viewers should be allowed to make their own choices." The Idiots, which is being screened on FilmFour on May 5, will be shown by Channel 4 later in the year. The FilmFour website (www.filmfour.com) is to host an online debate on the issues of censorship as well as screening the scenes.  The first digital television channel dedicated solely to the arts is to be launched within the year. Artsworld will offer news and reviews covering a wide range of visual and performing arts, including music, film, literature and dance. The service, a collaboration between investors including the Guardian Media Group and British Sky Broadcasting, will be available throughout Britain and Ireland exclusively to Sky Digital subscribers.

webTitle: Hungary's Horvath breaks hearts in Belfast

fields.headline: Hungary's Horvath breaks hearts in Belfast
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland 0 Hungary 1 Horvath 61
fields.trailText: A sodden pitch and 24 hours of soaking rain threw a wet blanket over both the quality of play and the 9,140 crowd, but there was much to encourage the fledgling Northern Ireland manager Sammy McIlroy last night before Ferenc Horvath, a striker whose pace troubled the Irish defence all night, scored his country's first goal in four matches.
fields.body:
A sodden pitch and 24 hours of soaking rain threw a wet blanket over both the quality of play and the 9,140 crowd, but there was much to encourage the fledgling Northern Ireland manager Sammy McIlroy last night before Ferenc Horvath, a striker whose pace troubled the Irish defence all night, scored his country's first goal in four matches.

McIlroy's men showed grit and honest endeavour but against a far from accomplished side - seeded fourth in their World Cup qualifying group - their lack of experience was sorely exposed.

Northern Ireland's World Cup qualifiers start in September, with a final home warm-up against Yugoslavia now arranged for August 16, and McIlroy will be looking for David Healy to turn his potential into goals by then.

The Manchester United striker, currently on loan to Port Vale, made an early impact and should have scored after 11 minutes when he collected Neil Lennon's pass, only to angle his shot wide. Earlier he tested the goalkeeper Gabor Kiraly, now with Hertha Berlin, with a header from Michael Hughes's corner.

Danny Griffin, the St Johnstone defender likely to join an English club soon, came to Northern Ireland's rescue when he blocked Horvath's shot only two yards from the line, and the Hungary left-back Csaba Feher was just off target with a lob from the edge of the box.

Hungary's first direct attempt came on 42 minutes when Feher, from 18 yards out, rifled a shot through a gap. But the Fulham goalkeeper Maik Taylor was well positioned.

Healy might have scored right on half-time. Lennon began the move with a through- ball to Danny Sonner and the Sheffield Wednesday midfielder's back-heel found Healy, but Kiraly blocked with his legs.

The stalemate did not last long after the interval, though, Horvath crashing a right-foot shot into the corner after picking up Sandor Preisinger's through-ball on 61 minutes and cutting inside the substitute Mark Williams, on for the hamstrung Gerry Taggart.

Referee : C Richards (Wales).

webTitle: Hagi shrugs off heavy weather over the Black Sea

fields.headline: Hagi shrugs off heavy weather over the Black Sea
fields.trailText: International round-up
fields.body:
Romania, who provide the opposition for England in their final Euro 2000 group game, made heavy weather of getting on top of Cyprus in a friendly played in the Black Sea port of Constanta last night but eventually won 2-0.

It was a particularly memorable evening for Gheorghe Hagi, the local hero who provided much of Romania's attacking verve and in whose honour the stadium had been renamed.

More than 20,000 fans were present to witness the occasion and it was Hagi, winning his 121st cap, who knocked in a free-kick which set up Adrian Mutu for the opening goal after 58 minutes. Ionel Ganea then went close but eventually found the target after being upended in the area; Hagi, the usual penalty taker, handed the job to the Universitatea Craiova striker.

At Stade de France the World Cup holders were given a scare by Slovenia, going two behind after eight minutes. However, David Trezeguet equalised after 63 minutes, Laurent Blanc made it 2-2 and Trezeguet bundled in the winner deep in injury-time.

Gert Verheyen scored twice to give Belgium a 2-0 win over Norway in Oslo. The home side dominated the first half and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer missed three chances; he did not appear for the second period. But Verheyen turned the game in the 55th minute and added a second just before the final whistle. "We weren't as aggressive as we should have been," said Solskjaer.

In Moscow Yegor Titov and Valery Karpin scored second-half goals to give Russia a 2-0 win against the United States in the first game between them to be played on Russian soil.

Sweden defeated Denmark 1-0 in Copenhagan, Kaiserslautern's striker Joergen Pettersson joining the small but expanding ranks of those who have beaten the Danish keeper Peter Schmeichel with a lob.

Bayern Munich's president Franz Beckenbauer was in Sofia to receive an honorary doctorate and went on to watch the friendly between Bulgaria and Ukraine. "I haven't come with an offer for [Andrei] Shevchenko, who is definitely a high-class player," he said. The Milan striker's 54th-minute header duly won the game for Ukraine.

webTitle: Van Nistelrooy sweats over new deadline

fields.headline: Van Nistelrooy sweats over new deadline
fields.standfirst: Dutch striker asked to return in three weeks for a further examination
fields.trailText: Dutch striker asked to return in three weeks for a further examination.
fields.body:
Manchester United's desire to install Ruud van Nistelrooy as the most expensive player in British football history will have to wait until after a third series of tests next month.

The 23-year-old Dutch international striker returned to the Netherlands last night after being told that he must confirm his complete recovery from his right-knee injury before completing his £18.5m transfer from PSV Eindhoven.

He will spend the next three weeks receiving intensive treatment on the damaged medial ligaments before returning to Old Trafford to undergo a further medical examination.

Although United have imposed a news blackout after their embarrassment on Tuesday when Van Nistelrooy's move to Old Trafford was put on hold only an hour before he was due to be unveiled at a press conference, the Premiership champions have been forced to inform the player and his club that the deal cannot yet be ratified.

Van Nistelrooy yesterday underwent a series of scans, x-rays and examinations at a private hospital in Cheadle, Cheshire, but United's medical experts and insurers were clearly dissatisfied with the findings and have insisted that he returns for further checks before a final decision is made.

His failure to negotiate a series of straightforward physical tests at the same hospital on Tuesday afternoon had left his move to the wealthiest football club in the world in the balance, along with a five-year contract worth £42,000 a week.

Van Nistelrooy has not kicked a ball in anger since damaging medial ligaments in falling awkwardly during a friendly game against the Danish club Silkeborg on March 6. The injury has been regarded by his Dutch club as serious but not career-threatening and he should be available for this summer's European championship finals in his home country and Belgium.

"Of course United want to be 150% sure about the knee; we fully understand that and we have no problem at all with that," said PSV's spokesman Pedro Salazar Hewitt. "We are confident that everything is going to be fine. His recovery is on schedule."

Yesterday the PSV club doctor, Kees Rein van der Hoogenband, also travelled to Manchester in the hope of allaying United's fears.

When, a fortnight ago, the United chairman Martin Edwards agreed to meet PSV's asking price for a player who had also been coveted by Arsenal and Chelsea, he was fully aware of the injury. Having been assured by PSV's medical specialists that a full recovery was only four or five weeks away, he concluded the £18.5m deal with the proviso that a formal public announcement would be delayed until the end of the season when Van Nistelrooy would have been in a position to pass his medical without fuss.

But no sooner was the ink dry on the agreement than PSV leaked the news to a Dutch television station, and Van Nistelrooy's would-be employers in Manchester were yesterday still ruing that breach of confidence which precipitated one of the most embarrassing episodes in Old Trafford's recent history.

With Van Nistelrooy appearing at a press conference at lunch-time on the day after the news leak, United had no option but to bring him to England to tie up the loose ends.

Meanwhile United's manager Sir Alex Ferguson will return to work this morning, after a short break in the Spanish sunshine, to begin the process that will lead to the departure this summer of one of his strikers.

Having been informed by Edwards that he must sacrifice Andy Cole or Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, Ferguson may attempt to put together a package designed to lure the England centre-back Sol Campbell away from Tottenham. The manager's determination to pair Campbell with Jaap Stam is such that he may be prepared to offer either striker in a package deal which would also see Tottenham receive a cash adjustment of some £4m.

Teddy Sheringham is expected to leave Old Trafford on a free transfer under the Bosman ruling, with West Ham and Charlton keen to return him to London.

webTitle: Student, 19, charged with assault and taking Germaine Greer captive

fields.headline: Student, 19, charged with assault and taking Germaine Greer captive
fields.trailText: A 19-year-old female student has been charged with assault and unlawful imprisonment of Germaine Greer, the academic and feminist icon
fields.body:
A 19-year-old female student has been charged with assault and unlawful imprisonment of Germaine Greer, the academic and feminist icon.

The student, believed to be from Nottingham, was arrested at Ms Greer's home in Great Chesterford, near Saffron Walden in Essex, on Monday evening after police received a call alerting them that the writer was being held at the property against her will.

Last night police refused to name the student, who was questioned by detectives before being bailed to appear before magistrates in Harlow on May 4, charged with unlawful imprisonment and as sault occasioning actual bodily harm.

Ms Greer, who is professor of comparative literature at Warwick university, was unavailable for comment.

A spokeswoman at her London agent, Gillon and Aitken, who was unaware of the incident, said the author was speaking at the Galway Literary festival in Ireland, where she was promoting the paperback version of her latest book, The Whole Woman.

A spokesman for Essex police said: "At about 6.30pm on April 24 an incident occurred at a residential premises in Walden Road, Great Chesterford, where a resident was held against her will. As a result a 19-year-old female was arrested and has been charged."

Police refused to give any information on the nature of the assault or injuries sustained by Ms Greer, or the length of time she was allegedly held captive.

The academic and author became a household name in the 1970s after the publication of her groundbreaking book, The Female Eunuch, which was considered the bible of feminism.

Last night Ms Greer's £500,000 Georgian house was empty.

Born in Australia and educated at Melbourne and Oxford universities, she lives alone at the property with her two standard poodles, Molly and Margo, and her cats.

It is not the first time Ms Greer has found herself troubled by unwelcome visitors to her home.

In 1994, writing in the Big Issue Magazine, she issued an open invitation to homeless people to come and live in her rambling farmhouse.

The first person to take up the offer was a Mail on Sunday reporter, masquerading as a homeless person, who subsequently wrote a three-page diary of his three-day stay.

She has also been involved in a number of heated disputes with other feminist writers, most notably her infamous spat with Suzanne Moore, whom she described in personal and unflattering terms.

fields.headline: Bright lights for 'shabby' Wales
fields.trailText: In the shadow of a Welsh mountain cowers the remains of a disused lead mine, its dilapidated outbuildings and piles of scree a bleak reminder of the country's industrial past.
fields.body:
In the shadow of a Welsh mountain cowers the remains of a disused lead mine, its dilapidated outbuildings and piles of scree a bleak reminder of the country's industrial past.

A few miles to the south-west, stands a shabby row of miners' terraced houses; while, some 80 miles further south, the ghostly ruins of a once-booming iron works totter against the sky.

The images - from Cwmystwyth, Pontrhydfendigaid and Ynyscedwyn, in Powys and Ceredigion - contrast starkly with the dramatic and picturesque beauty more commonly associated with the principality, and point instead to the grim reality of rural deprivation and despair.

Yet, in the wake of the highly-successful British films Trainspotting and Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels - both of which relied on the gritty backdrops - such views are now being used to tempt movie moguls to the country.

Instead of relying on stock images of the Brecon Beacons or the Elan Valley, the Mid Wales Film Commission has included the likes of the disused mines, shabby houses and even a 1960s bungalow in a glossy brochure aimed at film directors.

The decision to include the sites among the 350 on offer seemed natural to Mike Wallwork, the commissioner.

"The inquiries we get are for a whole range of different locations and directors are just as likely to want to shoot a scene in an old mine or shabby terrace as they are on a stunning Welsh mountainside," he said. "Yes, mid Wales has some stunning landscapes - we've just had Martin Clunes filming for ITV in the Elan valley - but less attractive locations have just as much appeal."

The commissioner added that filming in gritty, industrial locations was not a new phenomenon in Wales: the 1959 classic Tiger Bay was filmed in the Cardiff docks, while many scenes for the 1996 cult film Twin Town were filmed around a rundown caravan in front of Port Talbot oil refinery.

But he added: "In television, in particular, directors are increasingly searching for less picturesque settings."

As for those who live in such areas, they welcomed the thought of Hollywood descending.

"We'd definitely welcome being put on the map," said Steven Earey, the landlord of the Red Lion, at Pontrhydfendigaid, the isolated village on the edge of the Cambrian mountains chosen by the commission for its miners' terraces. "But, I wouldn't say our village was the least bit shabby."

fields.headline: Broadband
fields.standfirst: BT has just announced broadband internet access is coming to Britain. We look at what that means for internet users and whether it will it be any good.
fields.trailText: BT has just announced broadband internet access is coming to Britain. We look at what that means for internet users and whether it will it be any good.
fields.body:
What is broadband?
Broadband is short for "wide bandwidth". It is the capacity to send huge quantities of information over phone lines, cables and wireless connections, giving users high-speed internet access and making it easier to send video and audio material over the internet. Conventional internet access down a phone line to a UK home is slow, narrow bandwidth.

What is BT offering?
Through its BTopenworld subsidiary, BT will offer broadband internet access to UK home users and businesses in July. After a small box is installed in your house, you will be able to get internet access about 10 times faster than with a good modem, connect more than one PC to the internet, and continue to use the phone while you are online. The old system of dialling up also ends, as broadband gives a continuous connection.

How does it work?
BT's broadband uses asymmetrical digital subscriber line (ADSL) technology. ADSL enables more data to travel down ordinary phone lines or cables - a far cheaper option than installing completely new cables. It is called asymmetrical because information can travel far quicker down the line to a consumer than it can if a consumer wants to send information back up the line. As most people use the internet to download rather than upload information, they probably won't notice the asymmetry.

How much does it cost?
BTopenworld does not charge for calls, billing customers a fixed fee for unlimited access. Home users will pay £39.99 a month for the line and a £150 connection fee (free if you sign up before June 30). This is more expensive than the latest unmetered deals for conventional internet access offered by companies such as NTL and AltaVista, but you get a faster service for your money.

What are the drawbacks?
 Not everyone in Britain can sign up for the service. Currently, only 26% of the UK will have access to BT's ADSL network. BT says one in three UK households and businesses will be within range by its July launch, covering London, Birmingham, Manchester, Edinburgh, Cambridge, Oxford, Brighton and 20 other cities.

 The ADSL lines offered by BT are still not quick enough to enable home users to watch video over the internet. BT hopes to upgrade speeds by the autumn, but even then the US, which has had ADSL technology since 1998, has far faster lines.

 The asymmetric nature of ADSL makes a mockery of claims that the internet is truly "interactive". John Naughton argues that it doesn't bother corporations that consumers cannot send large amounts of information back up the lines because "they don't care about the punters sending anything back - except their credit card numbers". ADSL keeps the consumer passive rather than empowering them to use the high-speed technology to, for instance, serve up their own websites from home instead of paying an ISP.

Could BT do better?
The European Commission says BT has been too slow to open up its telephone network to competitors wanting to offer similar broadband services. The British government has required that BT update and open up its network by 2001. Its competitors will be able to install their own ADSL equipment in local exchanges to gain access to the local loop.

What are the alternatives?
Other service providers, such as the UK market leader Freeserve, are trying out the technology and are bound to offer equivalent ADSL services as soon as they can. But there are other ways of getting broadband internet access with and without ADSL technology.

 ADSL through your television
Probably the most advanced way of getting broadband services this way is through Kingston Interactive Television's ADSL network. Launched in January, it provides video on demand, conventional multi-channel television services and full internet access for £14.99 a month. The disadvantage? You have to live in Hull.

 Cable TV internet
Cable companies Cable & Wireless and Telewest both provide a "walled garden", ie a restricted selection of 40-odd websites specially adapted for TV. Their cable modems also provide email services and enough bandwidth to offer video on demand. Although fast, cable is not available to everyone in the UK. For serious internet users, this kind of restricted TV internet is no substitute for full access via a PC. Cable modems also slow down the more individual users are connected to them - a bit like the conventional "narrow band" internet we are used to, which becomes congested at peak times.

 Fibre-optic cable
This technology offers the most potent form of broadband, with the capacity to transfer three hours of TV pictures down the wire in less than a second. However, fibre-optic requires the installation of new cables for the whole country - too expensive to happen in the immediate future then.

 Wireless
Wireless broadband services are one of the best hopes for cheap, fast internet access. Switzerland, Finland, Portugal, Spain, Ireland and Germany have already auctioned off parts of their spectrum for such services and, alongside the auction of third-generation mobile phones, the UK government is now planning the lucrative sale of 10-year licences for airwaves. Operators could bypass BT and cable companies, but their services will be primarily aimed at businesses and, once again, their speed will depend on the number of customers using the system at the same time.

fields.bodyText: What is broadband? Broadband is short for "wide bandwidth". It is the capacity to send huge quantities of information over phone lines, cables and wireless connections, giving users high-speed internet access and making it easier to send video and audio material over the internet. Conventional internet access down a phone line to a UK home is slow, narrow bandwidth. What is BT offering? Through its BTopenworld subsidiary, BT will offer broadband internet access to UK home users and businesses in July. After a small box is installed in your house, you will be able to get internet access about 10 times faster than with a good modem, connect more than one PC to the internet, and continue to use the phone while you are online. The old system of dialling up also ends, as broadband gives a continuous connection. How does it work? BT's broadband uses asymmetrical digital subscriber line (ADSL) technology. ADSL enables more data to travel down ordinary phone lines or cables - a far cheaper option than installing completely new cables. It is called asymmetrical because information can travel far quicker down the line to a consumer than it can if a consumer wants to send information back up the line. As most people use the internet to download rather than upload information, they probably won't notice the asymmetry. How much does it cost? BTopenworld does not charge for calls, billing customers a fixed fee for unlimited access. Home users will pay £39.99 a month for the line and a £150 connection fee (free if you sign up before June 30). This is more expensive than the latest unmetered deals for conventional internet access offered by companies such as NTL and AltaVista, but you get a faster service for your money. What are the drawbacks?  Not everyone in Britain can sign up for the service. Currently, only 26% of the UK will have access to BT's ADSL network. BT says one in three UK households and businesses will be within range by its July launch, covering London, Birmingham, Manchester, Edinburgh, Cambridge, Oxford, Brighton and 20 other cities.  The ADSL lines offered by BT are still not quick enough to enable home users to watch video over the internet. BT hopes to upgrade speeds by the autumn, but even then the US, which has had ADSL technology since 1998, has far faster lines.  The asymmetric nature of ADSL makes a mockery of claims that the internet is truly "interactive". John Naughton argues that it doesn't bother corporations that consumers cannot send large amounts of information back up the lines because "they don't care about the punters sending anything back - except their credit card numbers". ADSL keeps the consumer passive rather than empowering them to use the high-speed technology to, for instance, serve up their own websites from home instead of paying an ISP. Could BT do better? The European Commission says BT has been too slow to open up its telephone network to competitors wanting to offer similar broadband services. The British government has required that BT update and open up its network by 2001. Its competitors will be able to install their own ADSL equipment in local exchanges to gain access to the local loop. What are the alternatives? Other service providers, such as the UK market leader Freeserve, are trying out the technology and are bound to offer equivalent ADSL services as soon as they can. But there are other ways of getting broadband internet access with and without ADSL technology.  ADSL through your television Probably the most advanced way of getting broadband services this way is through Kingston Interactive Television's ADSL network. Launched in January, it provides video on demand, conventional multi-channel television services and full internet access for £14.99 a month. The disadvantage? You have to live in Hull.  Cable TV internet Cable companies Cable & Wireless and Telewest both provide a "walled garden", ie a restricted selection of 40-odd websites specially adapted for TV. Their cable modems also provide email services and enough bandwidth to offer video on demand. Although fast, cable is not available to everyone in the UK. For serious internet users, this kind of restricted TV internet is no substitute for full access via a PC. Cable modems also slow down the more individual users are connected to them - a bit like the conventional "narrow band" internet we are used to, which becomes congested at peak times.  Fibre-optic cable This technology offers the most potent form of broadband, with the capacity to transfer three hours of TV pictures down the wire in less than a second. However, fibre-optic requires the installation of new cables for the whole country - too expensive to happen in the immediate future then.  Wireless Wireless broadband services are one of the best hopes for cheap, fast internet access. Switzerland, Finland, Portugal, Spain, Ireland and Germany have already auctioned off parts of their spectrum for such services and, alongside the auction of third-generation mobile phones, the UK government is now planning the lucrative sale of 10-year licences for airwaves. webTitle: Living in the shadow of the dollar

fields.headline: Living in the shadow of the dollar
fields.trailText: How low can the euro go? Throughout its short life - coming up to 16 months - the question has dogged Europe's single currency. Mark Milner, deputy financial editor, on the currency's unhappy brief and unstable existence.
fields.body:
How low can the euro go? Throughout its short life - coming up to 16 months - the question has dogged Europe's single currency. The trouble for the policy makers at the European Central Bank is that no-one has yet come up with an answer. Today the currency slumped to fresh lows on the foreign exchanges despite a rise in interest rates by the ECB.

Since its launch at the beginning of last year the euro has lost a fifth of its value against the dollar and a similar amount against the Japanese yen - the heavy weights of the global currency markets which the euro was meant to rival.

When it was launched the euro bought $1.16. Parity - where one euro bought one dollar - was deemed unthinkable. Today, however, one euro is worth just over 91 cents.

Part of the problem is that the euro was launched on a wave of optimism. Investors wanted to hold the new currency. Arguably the exchange rate at which it was floated was too high. Initial declines can be attributed to an unwinding of that initial euphoria.

But the real reason for the euro's parlous plight is the fundamental difference between the US and euro-zone economies. The euro does not exist in a vacuum. Its international value reflects not so much what the world's financial community thinks about the single currency but more about how it compares with other currencies. You cannot just sell euros. You have to buy something else.

The problem for the euro is that throughout its life there has been a very attractive something else - the dollar. The reason is that the US economy has performed better than that of the euro-zone. Wall Street (until the recent shake-out among high-tech stocks) has soared, interest rates are higher than in Europe yet inflation (always a turn-off for investors) appears to remain under control. One reason for today's fall in the euro is that analysts are concerned yesterday's ECB rate rise should have been greater to meet the threat of inflation in the euro-zone.

All that has made assets (shares and bonds) denominated in dollars more attractive. The more people want US assets, the more dollars they have to buy to get them, the more the dollar goes up. To an extent the euro has suffered against the yen for similar reasons as investors have bought into the Japanese stock market in anticipation of the economic recovery there - though perversely their appetite for yen assets has pushed the Japanese currency - threatening the upturn they are buying into.

There are underlying concerns too that the economies in the euro-zone are too highly regulated, too inflexible and that employment costs are too high.

Britain, which exercised its right not to join the single currency - even though it met the main criteria for monetary union - has been caught in the turbulence. Its value against the dollar has change relatively little in the last 16 months (around 8 cents) - but as the euro has plunged against the greenback, so it has fallen against the pound.

That has given British exporters a massive headache as they have had to slash profit margins or be priced out of markets by euro-zone competitors. Imports from the single currency bloc have also become cheaper, giving domestic suppliers a headache, too. The problem of the "strong" pound has been most graphically illustrated by what is happening in the UK car industry, but runs much wider than a single sector of Britain's manufacturing base.

webTitle: Teacher and cousin fly in to Elian

fields.headline: Teacher and cousin fly in to Elian
fields.standfirst:
Miami relatives still denied access to US farm hideaway

The Elian Gonzalez case: special report
fields.trailText: Elian Gonzalez was due to be reunited yesterday with his Cuban cousin and his former kindergarten teacher who were being flown from Havana with special US visas to keep the six-year-old shipwreck survivor company while the courts and the US Congress decide his future.
fields.body:
Elian Gonzalez was due to be reunited yesterday with his Cuban cousin and his former kindergarten teacher who were being flown from Havana with special US visas to keep the six-year-old shipwreck survivor company while the courts and the US Congress decide his future.

The two visitors flew from Cuba through Mexico and were due to stay with Elian and his father, Juan Miguel, at their new temporary home, a secluded and well-guarded Maryland farm, to which they were moved under US Marshal protection on Tuesday. Visas have also been granted to four of Elian's schoolfriends from Cardenas, his hometown in Cuba.

"There's an understanding that he's going to be here for quite some time," James Rubin, the state department spokesman, said. "A young six-year-old ... needs to have someone to play with."

Joan Brown Campbell, the head of the National Council of Churches, said: "It's probably as close as we can do, given the fact that normal for him would be to be back in his own town, in his own home, own bed, own school, own neighbourhood."

Elian's Miami relatives, who looked after Elian for nearly five months after his shipwreck in November and who fought government efforts to return him to his father, are unlikely to gain access to the Maryland farm.

Mr Gonzalez has so far refused to see them, and a child psychiatrist assigned by the government to interview Elian recommended that the two branches of the family reconcile their differences first.

According to the justice department, Paulina Kernberg, of the Cornell university medical college, reported that Elian is "doing very well, is playful and interactive and displays a sense of belonging to a close family unit." Carole Florman, the justice department spokeswoman said: "The doctor found that he teases his father and helps to take care of his brother and plays what she called "the proud big brother role."

He was given green toy guns to play with to see how he reacted to them in the wake of Saturday's armed raid on his Miami relatives' home from which he was seized and returned to his father.

"The doctor said he played with them regularly like a normal six-year-old boy and at the end picked them up with his other toys and put them in his toy box," Ms Florman said.

"He drew a picture of Juan Miguel as a strong, sturdy man standing on top of a mountain - a sign he looks up to his father as a protector."

Elian's two Cuban visitors, his cousin, Yasmany Valentin, 10, and his teacher, Agueda Miranda, left Havana at dawn on a commercial flight to Mexico where they were due to take a connecting flight to Washington.

In an interview broadcast on Wednesday, Ricardo Alarcon, a senior Communist Party official responsible for US relations, said Elian needed his teacher, cousin and schoolmates "to create the minimum atmosphere necessary to allow him really to recover from these horrible months".

Meanwhile, the government maintained its defence of its raid on the Miami house. Maria Cardona, a spokes woman for the immigration and naturalisation service, said the federal agents identified themselves and asked for cooperation "but they did not get it despite the family's promise to just open the door peacefully if we came to get Elian. The agents said the crowd around the house was extremely aggressive and hostile."

Referring to a widely published photograph of a border patrol agent pointing a gun in the general direction of a clearly terrified Elian, Ms Cardona said the agent had "made a specific decision to keep the safety lock on because he feared he would encounter a physical struggle and didn't want the gun to go off accidentally."

fields.headline: Clashes as Pinochet hearing begins
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Amid clashes between foes and followers of Augusto Pinochet, a court in Santiago yesterday began hearings to decide whether the former dictator will be stripped of his immunity to stand trial on human rights charges.
fields.body:
Amid clashes between foes and followers of Augusto Pinochet, a court in Santiago yesterday began hearings to decide whether the former dictator will be stripped of his immunity to stand trial on human rights charges.

Police sealed off the old court building in the centre of the Chilean capital and traffic was suspended.

The anti-Pinochet demonstrators, including members of leftwing groups and human rights organisations, gathered at one end of the building. They carried photographs of victims of the Pinochet regime and signs demanding the trial of the former ruler.

The Pinochet followers were confined by police at the opposing corner, with their posters featuring pictures of the smiling retired general.

As the 21 judges of the Santiago court of appeal met behind closed doors, sporadic clashes erupted outside. Police were seen arresting several demonstrators.

The judges heard a lengthy report by the investigator Juan Guzman, who formally requested the lifting of Gen Pinochet's congressional immunity so he can face trial. Gen Pinochet has immunity as a senator-for-life, a post he created for himself in the constitution written by his regime.

After listening to the report, the judges were to hear tomorrow and Friday arguments by the lawyers for Gen Pinochet and the plaintiffs.

The judges did not immediately rule on a request by Gen Pinochet's defence lawyer that medical tests be ordered to determine whether the 84-year-old is fit enough to stand trial.

The proceedings could decide whether he will face charges on one of the most notorious cases of rights abuses during his regime - the so called "caravan of death".

The caravan was a group of military officers who toured several Chilean cities by helicopter soon after the 1973 coup led by Gen Pinochet, dragging political prisoners from jail and executing them. Seventy-five people were killed.

Seven members of the caravan are indicted, including a general once close to Gen Pinochet. The plaintiffs claim the members of the caravan acted on Gen Pinochet's orders.

The situation of the embattled former strongman has caused concern within the army, which he commanded for 25 years.

Retired General Rafael Villarroel, once deputy commander under Gen Pinochet, called the legal action against his former boss "an insult to the entire armed forces".

But President Ricardo Lagos yesterday said there should be no reason for concern.

"Chile is calm, because its institutions are doing what they have to do," Mr Lagos said. "The courts are doing their job, and as we have told the world, everybody in Chile, the humble and the powerful, is subject to the courts.

"What is starting today is a pre-trial, and I am sure whatever the ruling by the courts will be accepted by everybody."

Mr Lagos said he discussed the situation with the army commander, General Ricardo Izurieta, the night before, stressing that the case is entirely in the hands of the courts.

Gen Pinochet returned home last month after being held in Britain for 16 months. Doctors here determined he was physically and mentally unfit for trial.

fields.headline: Priest snubs cohabiting widow
fields.trailText: A feud between an Italian priest and a widowed parishoner ended in a showdown at the altar and trouble for the Roman Catholic church when he refused her Communion for cohabiting with a man.
fields.body:
A feud between an Italian priest and a widowed parishoner ended in a showdown at the altar and trouble for the Roman Catholic church when he refused her Communion for cohabiting with a man.

Fr Claudio Menichetti, 84, shocked his congregation by denouncing the 68-year-old widow as an adulterer just as she opened her mouth to receive the eucharist. The repercussions of his act are rippling beyond the hamlet of Benano, near Orvieto in central Italy.

Cardinal Ersilio Tonini has thrown his support behind the priest amid condemnation of what is seen as the Roman Catholic church's inconsistent policing of modern mores.

The parishioner, who has not been named, moved to Rome and fell in love with another man after her husband died 26 years ago. They live together but never married. She returned to Benano to attend mass with friends on Easter Sunday and queued for Communion. When it was her turn, Fr Menichetti withheld the host and explained his motive.

"It is true," he said later, "I denied her communion for religious reasons. That woman is living with a man without having tied the bond of marriage."

It emerged that the two had clashed 41 years ago, when she turned up for her wedding wearing a sleeveless dress and he sent her home for a jacket.

The parishioner said she thought it was permissible to receive Communion even while technically living in sin. But Cardinal Tonini, 85, insisted: "Matrimony is a sacrament fundamental to Christian life. It is written in the gospels so do not expect the church to change the rules."

There was uproar in Sicily recently when an 80-year-old priest refused to hear the first confession of an 11-year-old boy with Down's syndrome, saying that the boy did not know the difference between good and evil.

webTitle: Sri Lanka troops retreat after Tamils kill 200

fields.headline: Sri Lanka troops retreat after Tamils kill 200
fields.trailText: Sri Lankan military chiefs say they are reinforcing new front lines on the northern Jaffna peninsula following one of the worst defeats in the war against the rebel Tamil Tigers.
fields.body:
Sri Lankan military chiefs say they are reinforcing new front lines on the northern Jaffna peninsula following one of the worst defeats in the war against the rebel Tamil Tigers.

There are fears that civilians could be trapped if the Tigers continue their offensive.

The defence ministry says more than 200 troops were killed on Saturday as thousands of soldiers under artillery and mortar fire beat a hasty retreat from the sprawling Elephant Pass base, which guards the entrance to the peninsula. Other sources said the casualties were much greater.

"We are now consolidating our positions, that is all, we have not decided on anything else," the army spokesman, Brigadier Palitha Fernando, said.

"There have been some bombing missions but we will monitor terrorist transmissions to see what has been hit."

Sri Lankans have been shocked at both the loss of the base and the scale of casualties. State radio has issued calls for more blood donors, concerts and festivals have been cancelled and cabinet members have agreed to donate a month's salary to the war effort.

Military leaders have been defending themselves against accusations that the past five months of heavy fighting should have prepared them for the Tigers' attack.

"We had to have a timely decision when to pull of out Elephant Pass - there was a possibility of it being surrounded and it would be very difficult to maintain a force there," said the army commander, General Srilal Weerasoriya. "It was better to save the force than get them caught up."

He denied persistent reports that some soldiers had been suffering from dehydration as the main water supply was located in a nearby base at Iyakachchi, which had been taken earlier.

The peninsula is reported to be relatively quiet as both sides fortify their new positions. It is expected that the Tigers will try to fulfil a long-term pledge by making a serious effort to retake the rest of the peninsula. The town of Jaffna was at the centre of their mini state until the army retook it at the end of 1995, followed by the rest of the peninsula in the following months.

The peninsula is at the heart of the Tigers' claim for a homeland for the minority Tamil community in the north and east and its capture would strengthen their position in any upcoming peace talks.

There is concern that civilians in Jaffna could be in danger if the fighting continues, as the new front lines are thought to be within artillery range of populated areas.

It has been suggested that the Tigers could call for civilians to evacuate to allow them to shell the area, following a similar incident last year in the town of Vavuniya, which was held by the government.

Sri Lankan leaders have tried to hide the scale of the defeat by censoring the media. The defence ministry only admitted that it had "readjusted the defence line" some 12 hours after the Tigers claimed victory.

Newspaper articles have large sections cut out and the government's director of information has attacked the BBC and CNN for reporting the Tigers' claims that more than 1,000 soldiers were killed.

President Chandrika Kumaratunga, who was blinded in one eye in a suicide bomb attack in December, is abroad undergoing medical treatment. Her usually high profile deputy defence minister, Anuruddha Ratwatte, has been quoted as telling a meeting that "we have to accept both victories and setbacks" but has not yet made any official statements.

The leader of the opposition, Ranil Wickremesinghe, has called for Ms Kumaratunga to return and to appear before parliament to outline the government's plans.

"No one is in charge of the defence of Sri Lanka when all this is happening," he said. "The government must come up with a concrete plan to ensure the rest of the camps are defended."

The opposition leader said that as far as he knew the proposed peace talks between the government and Tamil Tigers, being brokered by the Norwegians, were going ahead. But he warned that the Tigers had considerably strengthened their hand because of their latest success.

"We had to have a timely decision when to pull of out Elephant Pass - there was a possibility of it being surrounded and it would be very difficult to maintain a force there," said the army commander, General Srilal Weerasoriya. "It was better to save the force than get them caught up." He denied persistent reports that some soldiers had been suffering from dehydration as the main water supply was located in a nearby base at Iyakachchi, which had been taken earlier. The peninsula is reported to be relatively quiet as both sides fortify their new positions. It is expected that the Tigers will try to fulfil a long-term pledge by making a serious effort to retake the rest of the peninsula. The town of Jaffna was at the centre of their mini state until the army retook it at the end of 1995, followed by the rest of the peninsula in the following months. The peninsula is at the heart of the Tigers' claim for a homeland for the minority Tamil community in the north and east and its capture would strengthen their position in any upcoming peace talks. There is concern that civilians in Jaffna could be in danger if the fighting continues, as the new front lines are thought to be within artillery range of populated areas. It has been suggested that the Tigers could call for civilians to evacuate to allow them to shell the area, following a similar incident last year in the town of Vavuniya, which was held by the government. Sri Lankan leaders have tried to hide the scale of the defeat by censoring the media. The defence ministry only admitted that it had "readjusted the defence line" some 12 hours after the Tigers claimed victory. Newspaper articles have large sections cut out and the government's director of information has attacked the BBC and CNN for reporting the Tigers' claims that more than 1,000 soldiers were killed. President Chandrika Kumaratunga, who was blinded in one eye in a suicide bomb attack in December, is abroad undergoing medical treatment. Her usually high profile deputy defence minister, Anuruddha Ratwatte, has been quoted as telling a meeting that "we have to accept both victories and setbacks" but has not yet made any official statements. The leader of the opposition, Ranil Wickremesinghe, has called for Ms Kumaratunga to return and to appear before parliament to outline the government's plans. "No one is in charge of the defence of Sri Lanka when all this is happening," he said. "The government must come up with a concrete plan to ensure the rest of the camps are defended." The opposition leader said that as far as he knew the proposed peace talks between the government and Tamil Tigers, being brokered by the Norwegians, were going ahead. But he warned that the Tigers had considerably strengthened their hand because of their latest success.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Violence kills 16 in Kashmir
fields.body:
Violence kills 16 in Kashmir

Sixteen people, including eight Indian security police, were killed in shootouts and an explosion in the state of Kashmir, police said yesterday.

They said that at least five border police died and two others were wounded when an explosive device went off near the border outpost of Gharana in Ranbir Singh Pora on Tuesday.

In a separate incident, gunmen shot dead four members of a family in Goigam village in Tangmarg. Nine others died in shootouts in the restive Himalayan state.
Reuters, Srinagar

Guilty verdict in 'dirty war' trial

The national court handed down a guilty verdict in Spain's second "dirty war" trial yesterday, sentencing five former security force members, including a civil guard general, for their part in the torture and murder of two suspected Basque separatists in 1983.

The verdict bolstered allegations that a dirty war was waged in the 1980s against Basque separatists and was sponsored by the Socialist governments of Felipe Gonzalez.
AP, Spain

Chinese police smash sex ring

Chinese police have smashed a crime ring that abducted at least 105 women and girls and forced them into prostitution, the China Police Daily said yesterday.

Girls as young as 12 from poor villages in the southwestern province of Yunnan were tricked by false job offers and shipped to southern Guangdong to work in brothels, it said. Police arrested 77 people for their involvement in the ring.
Reuters, Beijing

Four charged over disco fire

Swedish prosecutors charged four Iranian immigrants yesterday with deliberately starting a fire in a disco that killed 63 youngsters and injured 250.

Three men aged 19 and one 21-year-old will go on trial on May 3 in Gothenburg - scene of the blaze on October 29, 1998.

Most of the victims were immigrant teenagers.
Reuters, Stockholm

US on alert for deadly virus

Federal health officials are working with 17 states to prevent an outbreak of the West Nile Virus, which last year killed seven people in New York. Officials fear that birds from the northeast may have spread the virus when they migrated south for the winter. Humans are infected via mosquito bites.
AP, Maryland.

Kidnap gang to free hostages

Police in the Philippines said yesterday that a gang which kidnapped 21 people from a diving resort at Sipadan island on Sunday night would soon free two Malaysians who are Muslims.

The armed gang is a mix of former Muslim rebels and members of kidnap-for-ransom groups. Reports from the Philippines said the 21 people seized at gunpoint were safe, and that police were combing the southern tip of the Philippines where it is believed they are being held.
AP, Semporna

US on alert for deadly virus

Federal health officials are working with 17 states to prevent an outbreak of the West Nile virus, which last year killed seven people in New York. Officials fear that birds from the northeast migrating south for the winter may have spread the virus. Humans are infected by mosquitos.
AP, Maryland.

Nuclear leak claims life

A second plant worker died this morning after being exposed to a massive amount of radiation last September in Japan's worst nuclear accident ever.

Masato Shinohara, 40, was one of three workers exposed to heavy doses of radiation. Another died in December as a result of the accident at a uranium processing plant in Tokaimura, 90 miles northeast of Tokyo.
Reuters, Tokyo

fields.headline: Italian cabinet in instant trouble
fields.trailText: The new Italian government decided to postpone its maiden cabinet meeting because the health minister, a cancer specialist, refused to break a prior engagement with a patient.
fields.body:
The new Italian government decided to postpone its maiden cabinet meeting because the health minister, a cancer specialist, refused to break a prior engagement with a patient.

Euphoria at taking office turned to mortification when Umberto Veronesi, 74, headed for Rome airport and returned to his day-job in a Milan hospital.

Fixed grins and assurances that the cabinet will meet today instead were greeted with derision. Italy's 58th government since the second world war, cobbled together from nine centre-left parties, is enduring a difficult birth.

The swearing-in ceremony, which Dr Veronesi managed to catch, had an empty brocaded chair where the would-be minister for European Affairs was supposed to sit. Edo Ronchi of the Greens had quit hours earlier in pique at not being offered another stint as environment minister.

The new prime minister, Giuliano Amato, failed to find a replacement and the Greens are threatening to stay out of the cabinet altogether, a potential death sentence for a government with a wafer-thin majority.

Mr Amato, the former treasury minister, was supposed to whittle down the number of cabinet seats from an unwieldy 25 to 21 but ended up with 24 to placate allies demanding jobs.

Mr Amato took office after the centre-left hounded Massimo D'Alema, following a crushing defeat in regional elections. His government must now pass votes of confidence tomorrow while facing fierce opposition from the centre-right, which hopes to force an early general election.

It was expected to win by a wide margin in the senate but face difficulties in the 630-seat chamber of deputies, where Mr Amato commands 318-320 seats - just enough, if no supporters defect. Two coalition deputies are ill and a handful have left their allegiance unclear.

One predecessor, Romano Prodi, unexpectedly lost his job by one vote when a deputy stayed at home to breast-feed her baby.

fields.headline: National roundup
fields.trailText: Milton bust wrenched from plinth
fields.body:
Milton bust wrenched from plinth

A rare replica bust of the poet John Milton has been stolen from a museum dedicated to his life and work.

Police launched an investigation yesterday after the bust was wrenched from its plinth in the garden of Milton's Cottage in Chalfont St Giles, south Buckinghamshire, last week.

A Thames valley police spokeswoman said the bust might have been taken while the museum was open. "The bust has an enormous value and we believe the thieves were aware of this.

"It is one of only 10 replicas made from the original, which is at the British Museum."

The museum's curator, Edward Dawson, said: "It is disgraceful. John Milton is a lovely Englishman everybody wants to pay their respects to."

He added: "It is made from a special material that resembles white alabaster and marble ... we are not prepared to give a replacement value for it because it could only help the thieves with their negotiations."

Sex bias solicitors disciplined

Two solicitor brothers who sacked a legal executive after she became pregnant so as to avoid maternity payments were each fined £2,500 yesterday by their professional body, the Law Society, and ordered to pay £1,177.24 costs.

One brother, Philip Stephenson, 51, had told Claire Dowson: "May I remind you, you chose to get pregnant before you were here for two years," a solicitors' disciplinary tribunal in central London was told.

An employment tribunal in Newcastle upon Tyne in April 1998 awarded her nearly £13,000 for sex discrimination and unfair dismissal. At that hearing Mr Stephenson admitted saying to her in June 1997: "I am giving you notice today before you clock up job protection." She had worked for him and his brother Ian, 44, at Darling and Stephensons in Darlington since September 1995.

Yesterday the brothers admitted "misinterpreting" employment law.

Roger Field, for the brothers, argued they had tried to avoid maternity payments legitimately. He drew "the same distinction between tax avoidance and tax evasion".

Singer serenades inquest

One of the irrepressible Beverley Sisters brought an inquest to a stunned silence yesterday when she burst into song from the witness box.

Joy Wright was giving evidence at Hornsey coroners court, north London, at the inquest of her late uncle, Leonard Miles, who was found dead from hypothermia at his home in Southgate in February.

She was describing how "Lenny", who was 92, spurred bus passengers into song on his way back from a pub shortly before his death, and sang Franz Lehar's words "You are my heart's desire and where you are I long to be".

Coroner William Dolman told her: "I have sat as coroner at this court since 1974 and this is the first time in my life I have heard music sung to the court by a witness. Thank you." She responded: "It's not half as good as Uncle Lenny's rendition!"

Verdict: misadventure.

Store of memories: where Beatles' first record deal was won

The former Beatles producer Sir George Martin yesterday unveiled a plaque to record the role a record store played in bringing the band to fame.

The HMV shop in Oxford Street, London, which is to close on Saturday, was instrumental in winning a record deal for the band.

It was a visit to the shop in 1962 by the Beatles' manager, Brian Epstein, that set wheels in motion for a deal with Parlophone Records.

Sir George said: "If he hadn't come in here, I would never have heard them - who knows what might have happened?"

Epstein had unsuccessfully touted his recordings of the "Fab Four" around London. But while visiting the store he was persuaded to transfer his demo tapes of the Beatles on to discs in the shop's studio to make it easier for people to play them.

The music caught the ear of engineer Jim Foy, and he referred Epstein to music publisher Sid Colman, who was based upstairs in the same building.

The store, opened in 1921 by Sir Edward Elgar, is being closed in favour of a new shop across the road.

Trust gets first woman director

The National Trust yesterday committed itself to a higher profile and a more political future in announcing the appointment of its youngest, and first woman, director general, Fiona Reynolds.

Ms Reynolds, 42, will next January 1 move to the trust from the Cabinet Office, where she is director of the women's unit.

She was director of the countryside charity, the CPRE, from 1992 to 1998.

The National Trust is an immensely wealthy charity, and the largest conservation charity in Europe. In recent years it has quietly been moving away from its cosy image as the purveyor of afternoon teas at beautifully preserved Georgian country houses.

The present director general, Martin Drury, has led the trust into some controversial decisions, including the ban on stag hunting across trust land, and surprising new purchases, including a small terraced house which was Paul McCartney's home in Liverpool. It is now one of the trust's most popular properties, usually booked out weeks in advance.

Anger at charge for GM protest

Backbench MPs have accused the government of restricting freedom of speech by charging people for the right to oppose the sale of new genetically modified seeds to farmers.

About 250 individuals and organisations, including some MPs, have paid up to £90 to register objections with ministers under rarely used procedures which will lead to the first public local hearings into the new technology.

Nick Brown, agriculture minister, is prepared to give Aventis, makers of Chardon LL, a type of GM maize used for animal feed, permission to use the seed commercially after technical committees passed it as safe. The company has promised it will wait until the end of government-sponsored field trials in 2002 before doing so, even if it passes all legal hurdles.

But Liberal Democrat and Labour MPs are angry that the process is even under way when the point of field trials is to find whether GM crops will affect the environment - and 23 MPs have signed a Commons early day motion to raise the issue.
James Meikle

Constable art thieves jailed

Two car dealers caught trying to sell a £1m pair of Constable art works stolen from the Victoria and Albert Museum were jailed yesterday.

Kevin Gande, 34, from Laindon, Essex, and Kevin Jones, 38, from Bow, east London, were given four years at Isleworth crown court, south-west London, after admitting handling stolen goods.

Jones was also sentenced to two years to run consecu tively for possession of a loaded firearm and possession of ammunition.

The works - Dedham, Lock and Mill (from 1810-1815) and Sketch for Valley Farm (from 1835) - were taken from a vault at the museum in November 1998 but were not missed until another museum asked to borrow them months later.

Detectives from the national crime squad were tipped off that Gande and Jones were involved and mounted a surveillance operation.

They were arrested by undercover officers while trying to sell the works at a hotel in west London in January.

Roads in worst state for 20 years

Road users in England and Wales face the worst conditions since records began more than 20 years ago, new figures revealed yesterday.

The government's annual road maintenance survey showed that conditions deteriorated during the last year with increasing incidences of potholes and crumbling verges rendering one in every 20 miles of motorway in urgent need of repair.

Transport ministers blamed the decline on under-investment during the last years of Tory government.

But motoring groups and opposition MPs said the figures highlighted Labour's failure to fulfil its promise of making road repair a priority.

Jonathan Bullock, of the British Road Federation, said worsening road conditions would inevitably lead to a rise in the number of accidents.

"The government has not achieved its objective of halting the decline, let alone restoring conditions to an acceptable level. As road users try to travel around the country they will find more potholes, broken road edges and slippery roads.
Barry McIntyre

webTitle: School 'sin bins' to tackle violent pupils

fields.headline: School 'sin bins' to tackle violent pupils
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Hundreds of school "sin bins" are to be opened in the next two years, the government will announce today, in a package to prevent violent and abusive pupils from disrupting their classmates' education.
fields.body:
Hundreds of school "sin bins" are to be opened in the next two years, the government will announce today, in a package to prevent violent and abusive pupils from disrupting their classmates' education.

Among the new measures are plans for an army of "learning mentors" - school staff who will patrol corridors and playgrounds armed with pagers to assist teachers in trouble.

David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, will reveal the plans this morning to teachers attending the annual conference of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers in Llandudno, north Wales.

But he will face calls from the organisation - the second largest teaching union - to "get real" about the growing problems for teachers of dealing with violent classroom thugs and demands to deal with problem pupils in self-contained units well away from school premises.

At the moment, there are only 420 so-called "sin bins", or school-based learning support units in England and Wales, which have been set up by local education authorities. But Mr Blunkett wants to more than double this to 1,000 by 2002.

As well as announcing plans to set up an extra 200 units in innercity areas, the programme will be extended to rural schools.

He will also make it clear to teachers that he does not expect any school to keep a troublemaker in class if there is a serious risk to staff and other pupils.

Mr Blunkett will announce targets to extend teaching hours in the units, which can offer pupils as little as 10 hours a week. The schools have also been given the go-ahead to employ 800 "learning mentors".

Government sources said yesterday that the expansion of the units within schools would give heads more flexibility when dealing with troublesome youngsters.

As the pupils will not be excluded from school, the government's drive to cut the number of permanently excluded pupils - currently nearly 1,300 a year - will not be undermined.

But the union's general secretary, Nigel de Gruchy, warned last night that the proposal did not go far enough because the sin bins would be on school sites, leaving the disruptive children free to hang around the gates.

Mr de Gruchy would like to see more self-contained pupil referral units - more commonly used for children who need longer-term help.

He is calling for a change in the law so that heads would still be in charge of the units on a different site and would not have to exclude their pupils.

Mr de Gruchy said: "I have said to Mr Blunkett: 'Get real.' We don't really know how difficult these youngsters can be to teach. Many come to school with weapons and under the influence of drugs."

The union is dealing with at least 10 cases a month where it is supporting members refusing to teach troublemakers still in class despite having carried out serious assaults.

Calling for a sin bin in every major town, Mr de Gruchy said: "Let's have zero tolerance of bad behaviour. Where a youngster's behaviour threatens to disrupt education, or where it affects the staff or pupils, they should be out."

The package will be funded by some of the £500m allocated in the Budget to improve school discipline over the next three years, along with cash from the standards fund.

But the shadow education secretary, Theresa May, warned the conference that the funding would probably be more "fantasy figures" from the government - money that had already been announced rather than genuinely fresh cash.

Yesterday delegates backed a motion calling for "suitable provision" for disruptive pupils to be properly provided and funded nationally, and for the government "to promote policies which recognise the rights of the vast majority of pupils to a classroom environment conducive to a good level of teaching and learning".

During the debate, delegate Jules Donaldson described a visit to a school "where the headteacher had been head-butted and it took five police to escort the pupil off the premises".

Earlier, delegates sanctioned a ballot to decide whether to press ahead with action to ease the growing burden of bureaucracy on teachers.

Any action would start with members refusing extra tasks such as chasing pupil absences, bulk photocopying, administering exams and stocktaking.

Mr de Gruchy, who condemned the National Union of Teachers' threat of a strike over performance-related pay, said his union's action would not harm pupils in any way.

Mr de Gruchy would like to see more self-contained pupil referral units - more commonly used for children who need longer-term help. He is calling for a change in the law so that heads would still be in charge of the units on a different site and would not have to exclude their pupils. Mr de Gruchy said: "I have said to Mr Blunkett: 'Get real.' We don't really know how difficult these youngsters can be to teach. Many come to school with weapons and under the influence of drugs." The union is dealing with at least 10 cases a month where it is supporting members refusing to teach troublemakers still in class despite having carried out serious assaults. Calling for a sin bin in every major town, Mr de Gruchy said: "Let's have zero tolerance of bad behaviour. Where a youngster's behaviour threatens to disrupt education, or where it affects the staff or pupils, they should be out." The package will be funded by some of the £500m allocated in the Budget to improve school discipline over the next three years, along with cash from the standards fund. But the shadow education secretary, Theresa May, warned the conference that the funding would probably be more "fantasy figures" from the government - money that had already been announced rather than genuinely fresh cash. Yesterday delegates backed a motion calling for "suitable provision" for disruptive pupils to be properly provided and funded nationally, and for the government "to promote policies which recognise the rights of the vast majority of pupils to a classroom environment conducive to a good level of teaching and learning". During the debate, delegate Jules Donaldson described a visit to a school "where the headteacher had been head-butted and it took five police to escort the pupil off the premises". Earlier, delegates sanctioned a ballot to decide whether to press ahead with action to ease the growing burden of bureaucracy on teachers. Any action would start with members refusing extra tasks such as chasing pupil absences, bulk photocopying, administering exams and stocktaking. Mr de Gruchy, who condemned the National Union of Teachers' threat of a strike over performance-related pay, said his union's action would not harm pupils in any way.
