fields.headline: Self-defence broadside backfires on Hague
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: An attempt by William Hague to exploit public anger over the Tony Martin case backfired last night when it emerged that the Tory leader had voted against a change in the law which could have allowed the Norfolk farmer to walk free.
fields.byline: Nicholas Watt, Clare Dyer  and Audrey Gillan
fields.body:
An attempt by William Hague to exploit public anger over the Tony Martin case backfired last night when it emerged that the Tory leader had voted against a change in the law which could have allowed the Norfolk farmer to walk free.

As Mr Hague was roundly condemned for demanding changes to the law on self-defence on the back of one court case, the Tories suffered further embarrassment when a former minister confirmed that the last government shelved such plans in the mid-1990s.

The Tory leader provoked an outcry yesterday when he called for greater protection to be given to people who were forced to defend their homes against intruders.

In a bid for Tory votes ahead of next week's local elections, Mr Hague said that a Conservative government would introduce a "strong presumption" in favour of the likes of Martin, who was convicted of the murder last week of a teenage burglar.

However, Mr Hague's credibility was dented when it was confirmed that he had voted against a change in the law which could have allowed Martin to walk free last week even after being convicted of murder.

As a new MP in 1991, Mr Hague voted against an amendment to the criminal justice bill which would have abolished mandatory life sentences for murder.

Lord Ackner, the former law lord who proposed the amendment, said that Martin would probably be serving a shorter sentence if his amendment had been passed because his lawyers would have been able to urge mitigating factors.

The disclosure of Mr Hague's voting record was seized on by his political opponents as a sign that yesterday's speech was a knee-jerk response to score political points ahead of the local elections.

Mr Hague suffered another blow when a former Tory minister admitted that the last government had rejected the central proposals in yesterday's speech by the Tory leader.

David Maclean, the former home office minister, said: "We looked at [the law on self defence], but we decided we had other priorities."

Another former Tory home office minister said he saw no reason to change the law. Sir Peter Lloyd said: "The law at the moment does give courts the discretion to interpret whether reasonable force was used."

His remarks were echoed by senior police officers. Crispian Strachan, chief constable of the Northumbria police, warned that Mr Hague's proposal would lead to a "serious increase in violent crime" similar to levels in the US. "

Colin Langham-Fitt, the acting assistant chief constable of Norfolk whose force handled the Martin case, said there was no need to change the law.

"There's nothing in the Martin trial or its verdict that takes away from people the right to defend themselves. I can't see how you could practically change the law without risking all sorts of miserable sad effects and uninvited consequences."

Lawyers also condemned Mr Hague's proposal. The former high court judge, Sir Michael Davies, asked on Radio 4's Today programme: "Are people going to be encouraged to have guns, to have an electric fence with killing power round their back garden, to have a pair of man-eating tigers tied up to be released if there is a burglar about?"

Labour believes that Mr Hague's speech shows that the Tories are more interested in consolidating their core vote, rather than appealing to the political centre ground.

This was voiced by Peter Bradley, head of the rural group of Labour MPs, who said Mr Hague appeared to be advocating a move to a US-style gun law which could foster a "kind of lynch mob mentality".

On Monday Ann Widde combe, the shadow home secretary, said she saw no need for a change in the law, although she insisted yesterday that she agreed with Mr Hague's speech.

 Last night further allegations of intimidation in the Tony Martin trial emerged when a caller to a local radio station claimed the jury had been stared at by people in the public gallery of the courtroom.

A producer at Radio Norfolk in Norwich telephoned a relative of a juror after a call to the station and was told that jurors had felt uncomfortable coming to and from the courtroom.

He said one juror would have preferred to have heard the evidence from behind a screen.so he could not be identified.

fields.headline: 'Curb benefits' for over-60s
fields.standfirst:
Darling backs requirement to look for work

Welfare reform: special report
fields.trailText: Men aged between 60 and 65 are to be required to look for work as a condition of receiving benefit, Alastair Darling, the cabinet's new champion of the elderly, said yesterday.
fields.body:
Men aged between 60 and 65 are to be required to look for work as a condition of receiving benefit, Alastair Darling, the cabinet's new champion of the elderly, said yesterday.

Ministers claim current exemptions mean more than 100,000 in that age group are receiving benefit but do not actively have to seek work.

They believe this sends a strong signal that the government does not really regard work as a serious option for the over-60s.

Mr Darling was speaking as the Cabinet Office published a blueprint, Winning the Generation Game, designed to bring more than 2.8m unemployed men and women aged between 50 and 65 back into the labour force.

The massive pool of unemployed reduces national output by £16bn a year and places a direct cost on the Treasury of up to £5bn, the paper says.

Mr Darling said: "Unless we do something now this country will pay a huge price. If we neglect the over-50s and continue to let this age group be written off and become unemployed, as they started to do 20 years ago, we will all suffer."

He wanted to convince the public, employers and volun tary agencies that "life begins at 50".

He said he would review the employers' code on anti-age discrimination to see if a broad new law was required. But he insisted: "You can change laws, but you also have to change people's attitudes. For 20 years employers have assumed the right thing is to get rid of the 50-year-olds and recruit 20-year-olds.

"We have got to change a culture which says it is acceptable for so many people to be retired so early."

The government will also consult on whether to raise tax breaks for occupational pensions from 50 to 55 - a move which would encourage more to stay working longer.

Mr Darling denied that the Labour cabinet with its Cool Britannia rhetoric had itself in the past implicitly run down the usefulness of the elderly.

He also insisted he was not trying to drive the voluntarily retired off the golf courses and into work.

"If people have enough money to retire at that age, that is a matter of their choice. What I am concerned about is those people who are on the golf course, but who would rather be in work.

"They fear that if they live for another 30 years their incomes are going to decline and decline. They need help. To have a whole generation of people left high and dry, the vast majority of whom are not self-sufficient, is a huge cost in terms of income foregone and taxes paid out."

Backing his claim that many of the over-50s were poor or involuntarily out of work, he pointed out that nearly three quarters of the 2.8m receive some benefit income and nearly half rely on benefits for more than half their household income.

The Cabinet Office report proposes a series of moves designed to cajole or press the economically inactive over-50s back into the workforce. Apart from a requirement to be available for work, the report also suggests partners of the unemployed be required to make themselves available for work.

All existing incapacity benefit claimants are also to be required to attend interviews to hear about opportunities to work or volunteer. At present many of them are only interviewed once every three years.

The report also suggests that the average age of employment service staff should be raised, so that the older unemployed can be given advice by people in their own age group. The government is also to review the incentives for the disabled to seek work.

fields.headline: Big draw
fields.standfirst:
Kazoo in licence deal
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Kazoo3D, the recently floated software company, is close to agreeing a licensing deal with Universal Studios for the worldwide rights to create and sell models of the cartoon characters Rocky and Bullwinkle, writes John Cassy .
fields.body:
Kazoo3D, the recently floated software company, is close to agreeing a licensing deal with Universal Studios for the worldwide rights to create and sell models of the cartoon characters Rocky and Bullwinkle, writes John Cassy .

The three-year contract will allow PC users to digitally insert 3D characters of Rocky, a squirrel, and Bull winkle, a moose, into their photographs or stationery.

Rocky and Bullwinkle are household names in the US and should become internationally known this summer when they star in a live action-animated film with Robert De Niro. Kazoo hopes to license other characters from Universal and is believed to have held similar talks with Disney.

fields.headline: Don't write off newspapers yet
fields.standfirst:
The internet won't kill off the dailies you like - it will help the good ones thrive, writes Conrad Black

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: America Online chief executive officer Steve Case told me recently that the newspaper business was "somewhere between beleaguered and dying". The high priests of the internet have been predicting the death of the newspaper for some time, often with the affected clinical indifference of the technological Darwinian.
fields.body:
America Online chief executive officer Steve Case told me recently that the newspaper business was "somewhere between beleaguered and dying". The high priests of the internet have been predicting the death of the newspaper for some time, often with the affected clinical indifference of the technological Darwinian.

Anyone of consent age in a civilised place would have to be brain dead not to recognise the power of the internet. Newspaper proprietors who fail to bridge the culture with internet developers and users are doomed to a precarious existence in a no-growth industry. But those who recognise the internet's potential, and the power of a strong newspaper franchise as a platform for internet operations, will prosper.

It is anachronistic that we should continue to be informed and entertained much as we were a century ago by the distribution through congested city streets of large quantities of newsprint, wrought from distant forests. In newspapers, as in other media, the content is important and there is considerable flexibility to accommodate the preferences of the consumer in matters of delivery. Virtually all newspapers are published on the internet now.

But there is also a false messianism in the claims of hi-tech zealots that the internet is an antidote to all evils. In this era of overwhelming cascades of information and entertainment from a proliferation of sources, the premium on the editorial function will grow, and the goodwill in the trademarks of authoritative newspapers is a tremendous asset. Properly managed, these franchises are beacons built on solid foundations. Unlike some newer media endeavours, these are not exercises in hucksterism, faddishness and financial flimflam.

Too many US and Canadian newspapers are essentially one-city monopolies, combining the arrogance and indolence that comes from an absence of direct competition with a defeatist attitude to other and newer media. Intimidated first by television, and then by the internet, too many newspaper publishers, instead of making their products more interesting and accessible and marketing them more imaginatively, have cowered behind uneconomically low cover prices.

Canada is as populated with newspapers as the US, and when we launched a new nationwide newspaper, the National Post, in late 1998, it had an electrifying effect on the Canadian media, almost immediately gaining a paid circulation of 300,000. In part, this was because the National Post took a different view than the usual soft-left Canadian media preoccupation with rather trivial distinctions between Canada and the US. But mainly its success was because of a sharper, more humorous and more crisply edited style than Canadians are accustomed to from their worthy but not overly rollicking media.

The internet probably poses a greater direct threat to television than to newspapers. When bandwidth problems are resolved in the next few years, TV and internet transmissions will have comparable picture definition and will be received on the same screens. Already internet surfing, along with the multiplication of channels, has reduced and atomised TV viewing. The number of TV viewers, according to some surveys, has declined by a greater proportion in the past two years than US daily newspaper circulation has since 1970. Yet few people are predicting the demise of television.

The concern most frequently expressed for the commercial viability of newspapers is that they will lose all their classified advertising revenue. In one sense this is true, but intelligent publishers will lose it to themselves. Already all seriously managed newspapers put their classified advertising on the net, and almost all of them in a way that interlinks with other newspapers to make regional or national networks.

Our Chicago Sun-Times offers advertisers space in the newspaper, on the web and in a speciality publication called Digital Chicago. To small businesses we offer microsites, accessible through the Sun-Times site, that greatly expand the potential reach of their advertising dollar. This service, leveraged on the goodwill in the Sun-Times' brand, will not vanish without a struggle. Advertising goes to the media where it is effective, and newspapers, operated with any tactical skill, will not lose their attraction as multimedia classified buys.

Internet portals' professed policy of posting classified advertising without charge and calling it content could be somewhat troublesome for newspapers. But either it will lead to an avalanche of unpaid advertising that would be unwieldy, as well as expensive to the service provider, or it will not catch on outside a few categories. Resourceful newspaper publishers will be able to defend most of their revenue.

The internet affords the newspaper publisher the opportunity to expand his circulation vastly, if his product is more than regionally competitive. He will be able to reduce raw material costs to the extent that people desire the newspaper on their screens rather than on newsprint. He will be able to sell access to his archives and generally increase both advertising and circulation revenue if the quality of his product is competitive. For the greater newspapers, it certainly will be.

Anyone will be able to set up on the internet and compete directly with telecasters and established internet sites. In this era of overwhelming choice, the central question is: who can attract the proverbial eyeballs? As the profusion of dot.com advertising in the Wall Street Journal Europe demonstrates, there is no better platform for launching, promoting, co-branding and joint selling with internet sites than an authoritative newspaper.

Serious newspapers will offer their loyal readers a range of internet services as varied as their content. Those that can bridge the newspaper and internet cultures will have their full share in the rise of the internet. They will retain a base of goodwill and brand loyalty that other media will rival only with great persistence and difficulty.

Already all seriously managed newspapers put their classified advertising on the net, and almost all of them in a way that interlinks with other newspapers to make regional or national networks. Our Chicago Sun-Times offers advertisers space in the newspaper, on the web and in a speciality publication called Digital Chicago. To small businesses we offer microsites, accessible through the Sun-Times site, that greatly expand the potential reach of their advertising dollar. This service, leveraged on the goodwill in the Sun-Times' brand, will not vanish without a struggle. Advertising goes to the media where it is effective, and newspapers, operated with any tactical skill, will not lose their attraction as multimedia classified buys. Internet portals' professed policy of posting classified advertising without charge and calling it content could be somewhat troublesome for newspapers. But either it will lead to an avalanche of unpaid advertising that would be unwieldy, as well as expensive to the service provider, or it will not catch on outside a few categories. Resourceful newspaper publishers will be able to defend most of their revenue. The internet affords the newspaper publisher the opportunity to expand his circulation vastly, if his product is more than regionally competitive. He will be able to reduce raw material costs to the extent that people desire the newspaper on their screens rather than on newsprint. He will be able to sell access to his archives and generally increase both advertising and circulation revenue if the quality of his product is competitive. For the greater newspapers, it certainly will be. Anyone will be able to set up on the internet and compete directly with telecasters and established internet sites. In this era of overwhelming choice, the central question is: who can attract the proverbial eyeballs? As the profusion of dot.com advertising in the Wall Street Journal Europe demonstrates, there is no better platform for launching, promoting, co-branding and joint selling with internet sites than an authoritative newspaper. Serious newspapers will offer their loyal readers a range of internet services as varied as their content. Those that can bridge the newspaper and internet cultures will have their full share in the rise of the internet. They will retain a base of goodwill and brand loyalty that other media will rival only with great persistence and difficulty. Reprinted from the Wall Street Journal © March 6, 2000. webTitle: FO denies military plan for Harare evacuation

fields.headline: FO denies military plan for Harare evacuation
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The British government denied reports circulating last night in Germany that it had plans in place for a military rapid response force to evacuate British citizens and other Europeans if the Zimbabwe crisis worsens.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill, John Hooper  in Berlin and  Andrew Meldrum  in Harare
fields.body:
The British government denied reports circulating last night in Germany that it had plans in place for a military rapid response force to evacuate British citizens and other Europeans if the Zimbabwe crisis worsens.

The Foreign Office admitted there was a contingency plan but it would not provide any details. It described the report as "alarmist" and insisted that many steps could be taken before Britain reached that stage.

But German diplomatic sources confirmed last night that a British military evacuation plan existed and that it had been drawn up in co-ordination with other EU members.

A source said: "There are logistical and operational preparations for a possible evacuation, but it is completely open and undecided whether an evacuation of German and other European citizens will be necessary and, if so, when."

"It is the British armed forces who are in preparation to take the lead in Europe on this matter. It is an entirely British operation which would be to the benefit of other European nationals."

"All the military planning is being done by the British military authorities but we are pretty sure that, as in previous similar instances, the British army would take out other Europeans too."

The respected German paper Frankfurter Allegemeine Zeitung reports today that Britain has prepared a rapid response force to be stationed in Mozambique.

The paper said Portugal and Germany had worked out escape routes through neighbouring states. South Africa, Zambia and Botswana would reportedly allow troops to use their territories.

Britain already has forces in Mozambique, part of the relief operation to help with the aftermath of the flooding.

The situation in Zimbabwe looked set to worsen last night as the leader of the Movement for Democratic Change warned that his party was being forced into retaliation against Robert Mugabe's supporters. After three more members of the opposition were beaten to death, Morgan Tsvangirai said: "The MDC will no longer sit back and watch our supporters being killed. We cannot stand by and watch while our people are being murdered."

"We shall devise a strategy to protect ourselves. We shall take this violence to their doorstep."

Two men were killed yesterday in Kariba, about 220 miles northwest of Harare. Another MDC supporter was killed in the capital on Monday night, bringing the number of party followers killed in the last three days to five.

Mr Tsvangirai accused Mr Mugabe of creating a climate of intimidation that excluded any possibility of forthcoming elections being free or fair.

"We cannot fold our arms as our members are killed. Are we to watch as police offer no protection?" asked Mr Tsvangirai. "The time has come ... for the MDC to devise strategies for our own self-protection ... We are talking of human lives that are being lost by the deliberate actions of the state."

At least 11 MDC members have been killed this month. In almost all cases, police have taken no action to arrest the perpetrators.

In the past few days Zanu-PF has switched the focus of its intimidation from white farmers to their black farm labourers and MDC supporters.

The latest killings came as Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party boycotted talks with the opposition on the farm occupations crisis. Religious leaders had invited Zanu-PF and the MDC to a meeting in a new attempt to resolve the crisis. But no representatives of Zanu-PF or the self-styled independence war veterans who have invaded hundreds of white-owned farms were at the meeting.

So far the MDC has kept a strict policy of non-violence. But Mr Tsvangirai's statement suggested that the MDC might form self-defence units prepared to battle with the gangs of Zanu-PF supporters rampaging through the country.

Mr Tsvangirai claims that the state has distributed weapons to war veterans, agents of the Central Intelli gence Organisation and other members of Zanu-PF. "We know that AK-47s were released," said Mr Tsvangirai.

His accusations come in the wake of numerous reports in recent weeks that the invaders of white-owned farms have been armed.

"We are in a state of siege here," said Mr Tsvangirai. "It is a total onslaught on innocent civilians."

In some rural areas, Zanu-PF supporters threaten anyone who might support the MDC. In Mutoko, in northeastern Zimbabwe, government supporters burn down the huts of those who support the MDC and police do nothing, according to locals.

Mr Tsvangirai asked what his party could do in this situation. "Do you want us to turn the other cheek?"

He said the MDC would "take the violence to the doorsteps of the people who have been inciting it. All those cabinet ministers, the vice-president and the MPs who are fanning the violence, they must bear the responsibility of its consequences."

fields.headline: Euronext 'not disrupting' LSE talks
fields.standfirst:
Stock market alliance denies knowledge of talks with Frankfurt

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Euronext, the three-way stock market alliance between Paris, Brussels and Amsterdam, yesterday claimed that its merger overtures to London were not aimed at disrupting negotiations between the UK exchange and Frankfurt.
fields.body:
Euronext, the three-way stock market alliance between Paris, Brussels and Amsterdam, yesterday claimed that its merger overtures to London were not aimed at disrupting negotiations between the UK exchange and Frankfurt.

Euronext confirmed yesterday that it had made a formal proposal to the London stock exchange more than two weeks ago but had not received a reply.

"We would like to make a formal presentation before the LSE's board but this has not taken place yet. We want a fair chance that our merger proposal be considered the way it should," said a spokesman.

Asked if the move could be seen as possibly disrupting the talks between London and Frankfurt, the spokesman pointed out that when the Euronext alliance proposal was announced in London last month, London institutions, including the exchange, were invited to join.

"Was there a London/Frankfurt [link-up] when Euronext was announced on March 20?" he said.

Euronext "could not think of disrupting" something which it did not know existed at the time.

Although no formal invitation had been issued to Frankfurt, the Euronext alliance was meant to be an "open" arrangement, according to the spokesman.

The London exchange declined to comment on the Euronext approach but has confirmed that it is talking to the Frankfurt exchange.

The manoeuvrings are part of an attempt to restructure share dealing within Europe. Under pressure from financial institutions, which want to be able to trade shares across borders as cheaply and efficiently as possible, established national exchanges and newer rivals are battling for position in the market for pan-European equity trading.

Several new players have already announced plans to set up systems which will provide cross border trading facilities within the next few months.

Developments in technology which allow institutional shareholders to swap blocks of shares without going through a conventional exchange are also putting pressure on the established players.

fields.headline: Cosmic watershed
fields.standfirst: Investigation of the infant universe confirms that space is flat
fields.trailText: Investigation of the infant universe confirms that space is flat
fields.body:
It took a balloon journey of more than 10 days - to a height of 120,000ft. It took a billion measurements of the sky with an instrument that could detect temperature differences of one part in 100,000. The data added up to 50,000 hours of processor calculation time.

At the end of it, the scientists were able to reveal the answer with relief. The universe was as they thought it was. Space not only looked flat, it probably was flat.

The international team had reached what one member, Mark Kamionowski of the California Institute of Technology at Pasadena, called "a watershed in modern cosmology". They had produced the first detailed map of the universe in its infancy. They had looked back in time to a moment when the universe was one 50,000th of its present age and 1,000 times smaller and hotter than it is today.

The results "represent the ultimate limit of our vision", said Andrew Lange, also of CalTech and one of the team leaders. "The enormous structures that they reveal pre-date the first star or galaxy in the universe."

The team confirmed an observation that had been a puzzle since Albert Einstein proposed that space should be curved. Space not only appeared to be flat, it had been stretched flat in the first moments of its creation.

The experiment, called Boomerang, was a balloon launched from Antarctica to measure the faintest glow in the universe: the embers of the "big bang" in which matter, time and space were all created about 15bn years ago. Then, the universe was incredibly dense and hot. Now the background temperature has cooled to about minus 270C, about 2.7 degrees above absolute zero.

Boomerang was looking for tiny variations - ripples in space - in this back ground temperature. These would provide a snapshot of what the universe must have seemed like when it was only 300,000 years old. These small variations would explain why galaxies formed into clusters, and stars into galaxies.

The instruments had to filter out the light from the stars so that the original background glow could be detected. The data, published in Nature today, show a universe in which space is flat and just dense enough to go on expanding forever, because it does not contain enough matter to collapse one day into itself and become the ultimate black hole.

Paolo deBernardis of the University of Rome La Sapienza said: "The light we have detected has travelled across the entire universe before reaching us, and we are perfectly able to distinguish it from the light generated in our own galaxy."

The scientists, from London, Italy, California, Oxford, Paris, Massachusetts and Toronto, report that data from the unmanned balloon flight match the predictions of cosmic inflation, a relatively new theory.

This proposes that in the first thousandth of a second of time, space expanded, far faster than the speed of light, from a region smaller than the nucleus of an atom to something bigger than the entire observable universe today. As atoms and stars and galaxies condensed from this "space explosion", the universe settled down to expanding, much as it still does. But the effect was to stretch space so that, unlike the stars and planets within it, it was flat - much as the Greek geometer Euclid imagined it to be 2,500 years ago.

The project began more than a decade ago with a Nasa satellite, the Cosmic Background Explorer. This year Nasa launches a second, much more sensitive, satellite to take the temperature of the sky in still finer detail.

fields.headline: Norris rejects Tory racism claim
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Elections 2000
The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Steve Norris, Tory candidate for London mayor, yesterday tried to distance himself from remarks by an aide suggesting that elements of the Conservative party were racist, sexist and homophobic.
fields.body:
Steve Norris, Tory candidate for London mayor, yesterday tried to distance himself from remarks by an aide suggesting that elements of the Conservative party were racist, sexist and homophobic.

Ceri Evans, who handles Mr Norris's media relations, said in a secretly taped conversation that their campaign was feeling detached from the "unpleasant core" of the party.

His comments are likely to have angered and embarrassed the Tory leader, William Hague, whose recent hardline comments on asylum seekers have brought accusations that he is creating a climate in which racism can flourish.

Mr Norris insisted yesterday that he had never encountered any racism within the Conservative party in 30 years as a member. "I am equally clear that the party under William Hague is as determined to root out racism as it has ever been."

He did acknowledge that his "more liberal agenda" may have upset some in the party.

Mr Evans's comments were taped by the London-based Asian television company Zee TV as he explained why Mr Norris was not prepared to make an election broadcast specifically for the channel. "His credentials on equality, the sexual agenda and race and everything are utterly impeccable," Mr Evans said.

They also "cost him dear among the rather unpleasant core of the party from which we feel increasingly detached".

Last night Mr Evans made no attempt to disown his remarks, insisting they were "absolutely incontrovertible".

fields.headline: Industrial investment still matters
fields.standfirst:
CBI figures offer gloomy warning

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The latest figures from the CBI's quarterly industrial trends survey make disturbing reading. Most alarming are those listed in the investment intentions columns. The figures for plant and machinery and buildings are way below the long-term trends which themselves are scarcely anything to write home about.
fields.body:
The latest figures from the CBI's quarterly industrial trends survey make disturbing reading. Most alarming are those listed in the investment intentions columns. The figures for plant and machinery and buildings are way below the long-term trends which themselves are scarcely anything to write home about.

The number of manufacturers who reckon it is worth investing, who can see the sort of rate of return they want, are heavily outnumbered by those who do not.

It could be argued that British manufacturers who have lived with relatively high inflation over a long period have tended to operate on what might be politely described as a defensive risk/reward ratio when it comes to investment. But while that might explain less than exciting long term investment performance it cannot explain why sentiment has suddenly fallen off a cliff.

The factors worrying industry are what manufacturers see as a rising tax burden, relatively high interest rates and - surprise, surprise - the strength of the pound. Some of this, especially the tax aspect, could be dismissed as special pleading while interest rates (raised at industry's behest) and the strength of the pound are beyond the government's direct control.

Yet the government cannot shrug off the problem by arguing that in helping to create a stable macro-economic environment it is providing the sort of background against which business can flourish and that some manufacturers at least can help themselves by seeking to push their products ranges upmarket into less price sensitive areas and then wait for the vagaries of the forex market to bring a measure of relief.

Volume car manufacturers, to take a topical example, would find it tricky suddenly to switch to niche markets, especially if they were expected to maintain employment levels at the same time.

In terms of employment, external trade and sheer wealth creation, manufacturing industry still plays a crucial part in the economy. If manufacturers are not investing now, Britain's industrial base will be that much less able to respond to an upturn, as and when one comes along. That will mean a series of inflation-inducing bottle necks, a big bulge in Britain's imports bill or a combination of the two. None of the above would be welcome to the economic policy makers. Britain's manufacturing base, reduced though it may be, is still big enough to cause trouble.

BoS bruised
On the face of it, the stock market's reaction to yesterday's Bank of Scotland's full year results looks curmudgeonly if not downright ungrateful.

Profits, lending and market share were all well up on the previous year during a period when the bank was still able to take a tidy chunk out of the cost-income ratio, pushing it down to a level that some of its rivals will envy. Hardly the sort of performance that deserves a share price markdown of more than 8%.

But then BoS is not just any bank. It was BoS that stirred the UK banking industry into frantic life with its audacious, if ultimately unsuccessful, bid for National Westminster. Having pulled that rabbit out of the hat, BoS cannot expect to go back to the mixture as before - however successful that may have been - without encountering stock market scepticism.

To an extent BoS can write off yesterday's share price fall as investors' reaction to a return to the often humdrum realities of day-to-day banking after the hurly-burly of the best British banking bid battle for years.

But only to an extent. The BoS board, now featuring some new faces, will have to show that it, too, is not suffering from a case of post-bid blues. As the BoS noted, the banking world, in the UK and elsewhere in Europe, is under close scrutiny.

The challenge for the bank is to come up with a strategy that promises the kind of performance the acquisition of NatWest would have given, but without NatWest. Judging by yesterday's response, investors may be harbouring a suspicion that it will not come from organic growth alone.

Disharmony
The shufflings among Europe's pack of stock exchanges increasingly resemble a game of musical chairs. Everyone wants to be in the right place when the music stops but they watch each other warily.

That Euronext - Paris, Amsterdam and Brussels - has made an approach to the London exchange should come as no surprise. The partners made it clear that they wanted London on board. But their courtship of the UK exchange is complicated by, and might complicate, the talks between London and Frankfurt. The best thing would be for the two alliances to get their separate acts together first and then see if a bigger deal can be done.

webTitle: New fertility treatment hope for childless

fields.headline: New fertility treatment hope for childless
fields.trailText: A breakthrough in fertility treatment may one day allow women using donated eggs to have babies that are genetically their own, but is likely to raise concerns that it could facilitate human cloning.
fields.body:
A breakthrough in fertility treatment may one day allow women using donated eggs to have babies that are genetically their own, but is likely to raise concerns that it could facilitate human cloning.

The success of a group of scientists from France, Italy and Spain in developing a technique to help the childless demonstrates how close the ethical boundary runs between the compassionate and the unacceptable in reproductive medicine.

Jan Tesarik and colleagues today describe in the journal Human Reproduction their new technique for assisting the one in 10 infertile women who cannot have children because of defects in the cytoplasm, the material around the nucleus of the egg.

Their only chance of a baby is a donated egg, fertilised with their partner's sperm, but the child that results is not a genetic relation of the mother.

In their laboratories, the European scientists have succeeded in replacing the nucleus of the donated egg with the nucleus of the egg from the patient. The child born from such a restructured egg will have almost all their DNA (except for 37 female genes which come from the cytoplasm) from their mother and father.

This is the first time scientists have successfully removed the nucleus from a human egg and replaced it with another nucleus without immediately activating the egg - triggering cell division.

The European researchers are intent only on producing an egg containing the mother's DNA which can then be fertilised with her partner's sperm to create a baby. But the technique has the potential to overcome one of the problems in human cloning, where sperm is not required but cell division is not wanted until the nuclear transfer is complete.

They used two methods - one chemical and one mechanical. In both, the new nucleus was treated with an organic compound which acted as a kind of glue.

Then it was either fused using another chemical or by being manipulated into place with a micropipette of the kind used to fertilise an egg with a single sperm.

These techniques could be used in human cloning, to fuse a cell into an egg either to grow human tissue or, in the distant but conceivable future, to create a human clone - a being identical to the person whose genetic material was inserted into the egg.

But Dr Tesarik, from the Laboratoire d'Eylau in Paris, and his colleagues point out that their only intention is to help infertile women. They intend to produce a restructured egg that can then be fertilised, so that it would contain the DNA from two human beings and not one. But because of the ethical concern in Europe over the creation of embryos, there are legal restrictions which prevent the researchers from attempting to fertilise their restructured eggs.

One of the scientists, Zolt Nagy from Italy, has recently moved to Brazil where there are no regulations, and has already succeeded in fertilising such eggs, although his work has not yet been published.

The researchers need to know, says Dr Tesarik, that any embryos produced are chromosomally normal.

fields.headline: Producer of top musicals dies
fields.trailText: David Merrick, the American film and stage producer whose credits include the celebrated 1974 film version of The Great Gatsby, has died aged 88.
fields.body:
David Merrick, the American film and stage producer whose credits include the celebrated 1974 film version of The Great Gatsby, has died aged 88.

Merrick, whose theatre career spanned four decades, died in his sleep at a London rest home on Tuesday, said a spokesman from the David Merrick Arts Foundation.

Among his 70 major stage productions were the hugely successful Hello Dolly!, 42nd Street and Gypsy.

In 1983, Merrick, who had homes in London, New York and Paris, suffered a severe stroke which affected his speech and left him unable to carry on actively as a producer.

The spokesman said Merrick recently moved into the London rest home as his health faltered and he became more frail.

The producer's body was being flown out yesterday to New York, accompanied by his wife and former business partner, Natalie Lloyd-Merrick, 46. He leaves two daughters from previous marriages, Cecilia Anne, of New Jersey, and Marguerite, of New York.

Merrick, born David Margulois in St Louis, Missouri, won numerous Tony awards, with Hello Dolly! picking up 10 alone in 1964, as well as a host of other accolades.

Jerry Herman, who wrote the score for Hello Dolly!, last night said: "He really understood the word 'entertainment' like nobody else I have ever worked with. Without a doubt, he truly was the greatest producer of the old-fashioned musical."

webTitle: Brussels says BT is delaying net revolution

fields.headline: Brussels says BT is delaying net revolution
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: British Telecom was facing embarrassment last night after the European commission said the former monopoly's efforts to open up its local network to rivals were far too slow and out of kilter with the rest of Europe.
fields.byline: Andrew Osborn  in Brussels and  Charlotte Denny
fields.body:
British Telecom was facing embarrassment last night after the European commission said the former monopoly's efforts to open up its local network to rivals were far too slow and out of kilter with the rest of Europe.

The warning came as BT announced it would offer high-speed access to the internet for home computer users and small businesses by July, a move which industry analysts said was months overdue.

The commission told BT it should give competitors access to the local loop - the final mile of cable leading to customers' homes - by the end of the year. This contradicts the UK regulator Oftel, which has given BT until July 2001 to act. Although the EC's recommendation is not legally binding, it will embarrass BT and the government, which has portrayed itself as leading the internet revolution in Europe.

Tony Blair boasted of Britain's e-commerce crede tials as recently as March at the EU's Lisbon summit. Giving competitors access to the local loop at a reasonable price is seen as crucial in encouraging a wider variety of fast internet services and in getting more people online.

The EC's recommendation coincided with BT's announcement of details of its new broadband internet service, BTopenworld. The timing of the announcement was not lost on industry insiders who claim BT has deliberately been dragging its feet on the issue of high-speed access to steal a march on its competitors.

"It will be 15 months before any other operator will be able to compete with them on this and they will have cherry-picked the most valuable parts of the market by then," one said. "They've been very clever."

Industry analysts worry that Britain is falling behind in the area of high-speed access which could stifle the development of e-commerce.

"Nothing can illustrate more clearly the UK's progression from a European leader in telecoms to a straggler. Most of the UK's major European competitors will have something in place by the end of the year, while the UK will miss that date by up to six months," another said.

A BT spokesman in Brussels declined to discuss the issue, while Oftel said that, although it was keen for BT to act as quickly as possible, preparations for network opening took time.

BTopenworld will offer consumers asymmetric digital subscriber lines (ADSL), which allows data transmission on existing copper wires so they can transfer information at up to 10 times present speed.

This should help overcome the problem of slow internet access, although the company admitted yesterday the new lines would not be fast enough to allow home users to watch video on demand and other data intensive applications.

US consumers have been surfing the net on ADSL lines for more than year at faster speeds than BT is offering.

fields.headline: Try out Judaism, bishop suggests
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: An Anglican bishop startled his colleagues yesterday by suggesting that those searching for God should try Judaism if Christianity did not appeal.
fields.body:
An Anglican bishop startled his colleagues yesterday by suggesting that those searching for God should try Judaism if Christianity did not appeal.

The Rt Rev Richard Harries, Bishop of Oxford, chose Manna, the journal of Reform Judaism, to put forward his proposal on the basis that he would rather people believe in God even if they could not believe in the divinity of Christ, his son.

The article claimed that Christian alternatives for those wishing to follow monotheism - belief in a single god - were thin on the ground, with Unitarianism virtually moribund and the Quakers having a distinctive approach "which appeals to some but not many".

The bishop said: "Looking at people's spiritual needs, I see a category of people who are naturally monotheistic and who simply cannot believe the Christian claims about Jesus but would like to have a spiritual home ... Judaism offers a traditional way of belief and behaviour that has been tried and tested for nearly 4,000 years."

Bishop Harries, 63, known as a Church of England liberal and a controversialist, is active in improving Anglican and Jewish relations and is chairman of the Council of Christians and Jews.

"He does tend to catch us on the hop. He's always up to something. We didn't know anything about this," the Rev. Richard Thomas, the bishop's press officer, admitted.

The proposal also seemed to surprise Britain's Jewish community.

Jon Sacker, spokesman for the Board of Deputies of British Jews, said: "It is not easy to become a Jew. Converts have to show commitment and understanding of the whole lifestyle and what it entails, but if anyone is genuine about wanting to become a Jew they would certainly be welcomed."

webTitle: Party of the people puts people off

fields.headline: Party of the people puts people off
fields.standfirst:
The Tories have been here before, but they have learnt nothing

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: According to one of his aides, the Conservative candidate for the London mayoralty, Steve Norris, has made a disconcerting discovery. His party has "a rather unpleasant core". Later the aide redimensioned this a little. Mr Norris's distaste, he explained, was not for the core but for the periphery - the party's far right. But this may not be as big a distinction as we are asked to believe. For as William Hague leaps aboard a Mail/Sun bandwagon which will soon be demanding canonisation for Tony Martin, we seem to be in one of those periods of Conservative history where the periphery is calling the shots and a troubled, bewildered leadership is doing as it is told.
fields.body:
According to one of his aides, the Conservative candidate for the London mayoralty, Steve Norris, has made a disconcerting discovery. His party has "a rather unpleasant core". Later the aide redimensioned this a little. Mr Norris's distaste, he explained, was not for the core but for the periphery - the party's far right. But this may not be as big a distinction as we are asked to believe. For as William Hague leaps aboard a Mail/Sun bandwagon which will soon be demanding canonisation for Tony Martin, we seem to be in one of those periods of Conservative history where the periphery is calling the shots and a troubled, bewildered leadership is doing as it is told.

The Tories have been here before. Edward Pearce's Lines of Most Resistance - the Lords, the Tories and Ireland 1886-1914*, absorbingly charts the unlovely effects of a previous surrender, when the leadership of the Conservative party was dragged more and more into making common cause with the group commonly known as ditchers. They believed the Lords must be saved from reformist meddlers partly because of its own sublime value - the essential guarantee, as Viscount Curzon declared "of the ancient balance and equipoise of our constitution". But it also had to be saved to save Ireland. The fight to preserve the Lords and the fight to preserve the union were intertwined. The union was at risk in the Commons when the Liberals were backed by the Irish, so it had to be kept alive by superior Conservative numbers in the Lords.

Pearce says at the end of the book that with the settlement (as it seemed then) of the Irish question in the treaty of 1921, an era came to an end: Stanley Baldwin, "with his instinct for conciliation, his patriotism muted to an affectionate contemplation of the Worcestershire horizon and his perfect lack of rage", put it to sleep. And yet what strikes me in this book is less the strange death of ditcher England than its survival. Some of its basic attitudes are patently still at work in the discourse of the Conservative right.

The book documents over and over again how the party of law and order in practice adopts a shamelessly picky approach to law and order; how the party which exists to preserve the balance and equipoise of the constitution cuts loose from the constitution when that is what its political interest requires. Its so-called defence of the national interest when home rule threatened included the preaching of insurrection, not to say treason. Bonar Law, as party leader, could imagine no length of resistance to which the men of Ulster could go where he would not be prepared to support them, "and in which they would not be supported by the overwhelming majority of the British people".

That was always the justification - they and the people thought as one. Even if the electorate chose to vote in a party of another persuasion, it was the Conservative party, and the Tory-dominated Lords - "the true trustees", as one typical aristocratic buffoon expressed it, "of the nation" - which best served their interests and expressed their true feelings. All governments to the left of them were somehow invalid. Lord Rosebery, a former Liberal premier turned backbench reactionary conservative warned that the implementation of Lloyd George's budget would "leave the country without a voice". It would be carried over the heads of the people by a majority in the Commons leaving the people with no more control than if they were Tartars or Lapps.

You can see in much Conservative commentary today the same set of assumptions: that the country, even when when it rejects the Conservatives at the ballot box, still thirsts for conservatism: that Conservatives remain the true trustees of the nation; that in seeking to obstruct the enactment of Labour commitments, the Conservative party acts for the real Britain (or as they more often say, as they did then, the real England). You can see it in their treatment of Tony Martin as a national hero, as if the settled view of the law that execution, official or freelance, is not a proper sentence for burglary had nothing to do with it; or in the hints they so often drop that a law to ban blood sports, being unEnglish, could legitimately be defied. (At least Hague wants to change the law, not just ignore it.) You can see it in the constant complaint that police who should be arresting burglars are too busy "persecuting" motorists, including those who fancy a drink; though motorists threaten more lives than burglars.

Much of this comes from the periphery. It finds its purest and frankest expression in the Daily Telegraph, which expresses it more robustly than most Tory politicians dare to. But again: is this still really mere periphery? Thrashing around for a lifeline, Hague has seemed increasingly ready in recent weeks to take his cue from the leader and letter writers and columnists of the Telegraph. The story of Bonar Law is the story of how a weak leader in deep political trouble was increasingly swept along by ditcher intemperance in and out of parliament. The story of William Hague seems sadly to be developing much the same way.

* Little Brown £18.99

david.mckie@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Banks defend flotation of WOL
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: World Online's advisers, ABN Amro Rothschild and Goldman Sachs, yesterday defended their handling of the internet provider's controversial flotation.
fields.body:
World Online's advisers, ABN Amro Rothschild and Goldman Sachs, yesterday defended their handling of the internet provider's controversial flotation.

The two groups said the prospectus contained all necessary detail and conformed with the rules of the Amsterdam exchange.

The two banks pledged to fight any legal action brought against them.

World Online's share price has been heavily buffeted since the company's stock market launch earlier this month - hit both by general turbulence among high-technology stocks and by news that Nina Brink, its founder and chairman, had sold a large block of her holding in the group ahead of the initial public offering.

Ms Brink has since resigned as chairman.

In a statement yesterday the banks said World Online's share price had been affected by "general downturn" in the sector but acknowledged that the impact had been "exacerbated by the negative sentiment surrounding Ms Brink's share sale".

The two banks said they had carried out a thorough review of the offer process, particularly of the details contained in the prospectus.

"We are satisfied that the prospectus accurately reflected all material information and conformed with the listing rules of the Amsterdam exchanges," the banks said.

"We have been informed that legal action may be pending. Should this be forthcoming, we will defend ourselves vigorously.

"We have full confidence in the outcome of any proceedings."

It also emerged yesterday that at one stage World Online and Baystar, the San Francisco-based company which bought part of Ms Brink's World Online stake, had threatened legal action against the Amsterdam exchange if it ordered a halt to the flotation process.

The threat was "part of the negotiations, it never came that far because at the end of the day the prospectus was in line with the exchange's rules", said a spokesman for the exchange.

Yesterday, shares in World Online closed trading the session a fraction higher at €13.30 (£7.77), which compares with an offer-for-sale price of €43.

webTitle: Dampener Storms cost Euro Disney 100,000 visitors

fields.headline: Dampener Storms cost Euro Disney 100,000 visitors
fields.trailText: Storms cost Euro Disney an estimated 1% of turnover, reducing the number of visitors by 100,000 and losing the company entrance fees, restaurant receipts and merchandising business. The average visitor spent Fr267 (£25) at the park, on the outskirts of Paris, last year.
fields.body:
Storms cost Euro Disney an estimated 1% of turnover, reducing the number of visitors by 100,000 and losing the company entrance fees, restaurant receipts and merchandising business. The average visitor spent Fr267 (£25) at the park, on the outskirts of Paris, last year.

Nonetheless, Euro Disney, which makes all its profit in the second half of the year, announced yesterday it reduced its first-half net loss by a third to €31.3m (£18.4m). Operating profit rose 43% from a year ago to €35.7m.

Euro Disney is investing Fr4bn in a new theme park nearby, tentatively named Disney Studios. Fr1.5bn of that has already been raised through a recent capital increase while Fr2.5bn is coming from a loan from state bank Caisse des Depots et Consignations.

Company chairman Gilles Pelisson said the danger of the new park cannibalising business by drawing away 10% to 15% of visitors was not a major concern.

Euro Disney forecasts that the new park will boost the site's current 12.5m visitors by up to 4.5m in 2003.

With each paying around Fr250 in entrance fees alone, that would add up to Fr1.3bn to turnover, not counting extra nights spent in on-site hotels, cash spent in restaurants and on merchandise, Mr Pelisson said.

He reported that Euro Disney had debts of Fr15bn, giving it a gearing of around 250%. However, that would fall to 150% in 2001, once Euro Disney has paid back Fr3.8bn in convertible bonds maturing in October next year, and based on a hypothetical share price of €1.20. It closed on Tuesday at €0.89.

The average visitor spent Fr267 (£25) at the park, on the outskirts of Paris, last year. Nonetheless, Euro Disney, which makes all its profit in the second half of the year, announced yesterday it reduced its first-half net loss by a third to €31.3m (£18.4m). Operating profit rose 43% from a year ago to €35.7m. Euro Disney is investing Fr4bn in a new theme park nearby, tentatively named Disney Studios. Fr1.5bn of that has already been raised through a recent capital increase while Fr2.5bn is coming from a loan from state bank Caisse des Depots et Consignations. Company chairman Gilles Pelisson said the danger of the new park cannibalising business by drawing away 10% to 15% of visitors was not a major concern. Euro Disney forecasts that the new park will boost the site's current 12.5m visitors by up to 4.5m in 2003. With each paying around Fr250 in entrance fees alone, that would add up to Fr1.3bn to turnover, not counting extra nights spent in on-site hotels, cash spent in restaurants and on merchandise, Mr Pelisson said. He reported that Euro Disney had debts of Fr15bn, giving it a gearing of around 250%. However, that would fall to 150% in 2001, once Euro Disney has paid back Fr3.8bn in convertible bonds maturing in October next year, and based on a hypothetical share price of €1.20. It closed on Tuesday at €0.89.

webTitle: Vanguard in merger talks with CeNeS

fields.headline: Vanguard in merger talks with CeNeS
fields.trailText: Vanguard Medica, the struggling biotechnology group, could be in line for a £170m merger with CeNeS Pharmaceuticals, the pain relief specialist.
fields.body:
Vanguard Medica, the struggling biotechnology group, could be in line for a £170m merger with CeNeS Pharmaceuticals, the pain relief specialist.

The two companies said last night they were in "preliminary discussions" but warned it would be several weeks before they were likely to comment further.

A deal would provide a shot in the arm for Vanguard, which suffered a blow last year when US regulators delayed approval for Frovatriptan, its migraine treatment. Shares dropped 25% when the food and drugs administration demanded more animal trials of the drug.

Since then, Vanguard has bolstered its product pipeline with a £10m purchase of Cerebrus, a research firm focusing on drugs for the central nervous system. CeNeS concentrates on a similar area and has potential treatments for schizophrenia, Parkinson's disease and strokes.

CeNeS joined the stock market last year through a reverse takeover of Core Group, a Scottish specialist in sexually transmitted diseases. CeNes is chaired by Alan Goodman, a well known biotech entrepreneur who has served on the board of Chiroscience and Peptide Therapeutics.

Vanguard's chief executive, Robert Mansfield, is likely to want a key role in any combined organisation.

webTitle: The delegates: Three critics of Britain

fields.headline: The delegates: Three critics of Britain
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Nathan Shamuyarira
fields.body:
Nathan Shamuyarira

The minister for industry and commerce and a former newspaper editor and academic.

He is widely respected and a member of the old school who was on first-name terms with African leaders such as Kenneth Kaunda and Julius Nyrere.

He has been in Mr Mugabe's cabinet since independence in 1980.

His rhetoric on the land issue has been uncompromising. Opening a parliamentary debate earlier this month, he had little comfort for the white farmers:

"Zimbabwe belongs to the indigenous people of Zimbabwe. It does not belong to any other nationality."

John Nkomo

The minister responsible for local government and housing is leading the delegation.

Making the point that he was a powerful enough figure to do business with, the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, yesterday described him as a close confidante of the president, Robert Mugabe.

He is no relation to the late Joshua Nkomo, Mr Mugabe's former comrade and rival, but he was a senior figure in Mr Nkomo's Zapu party, which was absorbed into the ruling Zanu-PF party in 1987. He is now chairman of the party.

Mr Nkomo was reported as saying he would not bring any fresh proposals to London, and has complained about British involvement in Zimbabwe. Alleging that Britain had reneged on promises to fund land reform, he said: "We would never have got to this point had the British lived up to their commitments. We would never have had any problems with Tony Blair's government had Tony Blair accepted the commitments of the previous governments."

Stan Mudenge

The foreign minister is a career diplomat who, until the present row, was best known for fudging the issue of Nigeria's expulsion from the Commonwealth in 1995.

Writing in the government-controlled Herald newspaper, Mr Mudenge said Britain was inciting political and economic instability in an effort to topple the government.

He has accused the British Foreign Office minister, Peter Hain, of "a preconceived and premeditated agenda of demonising and ostracising Zimbabwe."

fields.headline: Mercury falls at Merrill Lynch
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: Another traditional City name is being consigned to history after Merrill Lynch's decision yesterday finally to bite the bullet and eradicate the name of Mercury from its asset management operation.
fields.body:
Another traditional City name is being consigned to history after Merrill Lynch's decision yesterday finally to bite the bullet and eradicate the name of Mercury from its asset management operation.

The American investment bank said that it would make the concession that the Mercury brand could be retained for Britain's high streets. But there, it seems its use will end.

Influential pension fund managers, who have acted with their feet and withdrawn their money from Mercury's care after a period of poor performance, will now have to familiarise themselves with the name of Merrill Lynch. It will be thundering herds, as Merrill is known in the US, rather than an old-school tie City type approach.

Merrill Lynch Investment Management, as the new brand will be known, rebutted the cynics yesterday who wondered whether the new name might help to deflect from Mercury's row with the Unilever pension fund over its track record in the recent past. Pension fund trustees were not that easily fooled, Merrill said.

It argued that Mercury, run by Carol Galley who is also co-head of the bigger Merrill Lynch Investment Management, is being rebranded in the pension fund market at a time when it is finally undergoing a period of improved performance.

From sitting at the bottom of the all-important Caps league tables, it has dragged itself up towards the 20th position out of 70.

Mercury insisted yesterday that it had won new business from the British and European pension fund world to the tune of $12bn (£7.6bn) so far this year, although it acknowledged this might only make a dent in the amount it has lost during its dodgy performance years.

Jeffrey Peek, president of Merrill Lynch Investment Management, said that the entire business, which already manages $550bn, was ahead of its target to win new clients worth $120bn this year.

He described the branding exercise, on which he would not put a price, as an end and a beginning for Merrill Lynch's endeavour to build a big fund management business.

Merrill bought Mercury Asset Management, once part of SG Warburg now gobbled by the Swiss, at the end of 1997. Its stable also contains Los Angeles-based Hotchkins and Wiley.

This might help to explain why it needs to put all its operations under one name. Mr Peek said: "As a result of the rebranding we will put all our 3,600 employees under one core brand."

This, it appears, will allow them to "leverage the power, global reach and integrity of the Merrill Lynch brand". No excuse for shoddy performance then.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: An unseasonably humid day in London was reflected in a lethargic market, possibly caused in part by indecisive juniors awaiting the return of their bosses from extended Easter holidays.
fields.body:
An unseasonably humid day in London was reflected in a lethargic market, possibly caused in part by indecisive juniors awaiting the return of their bosses from extended Easter holidays.

As on Tuesday, the US gave what little leadership was around, but even the land of zero tolerance for time off was unable to sound a clear advance or retreat.

Leading shares ended weaker, near session lows after another volatile session, reversing morning gains in the afternoon under the influence of a mixed performance on Wall Street, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average giving back some recent gains while the Nasdaq index managed to hold firm.

At the close, the FTSE 100 index was 26.5 points easier at 6,256.5, just above a late low of 6,247.0 and well below its early peak at 6,342.2. The Techmark 100 index managed to hold its own, adding 94 points to 3,671.79.

Vodafone AirTouch, BP Amoco and Shell continued to be the most actively traded issues.

"Old economy" stocks generally received the cold shoulder in favour of younger ones. But even among new technology stocks the rally was selective, with "quality" blue chip issues in the vanguard and second line and small caps lagging.

Psion was once more top of the pile, extending Tuesday's gains on news that it had signed a Symbian software platform licence deal with Sony. Psion shares jumped 421p to 3,244p.

Baltimore Technologies , up 306p to 5,854p, was also helped by news: the group is set to provide managed services for leading financial e-business infrastructure group Identrus.

WPP Group remained in demand, up 66p to 1,021p as analysts prepared to upgrade their full-year forecasts in the wake of estimate-busting first quarter results. Reed Elsevier added 10.75p at 452.75p and Emap gained a further 48p at 1,241p on ongoing bid speculation.

Positive comment on its newly appointed chief executive Rod Eddington saw BA shares rise 13.5p to 319.25p, although analysts acknowledged the former Ansett head faces a tough task.

ICI attracted fresh buying, up 16.75p at 596.75p, as Deutsche Bank highlighted the stock's attractions ahead of first quarter figures. Cable & Wireless added 51p to 1,059p and BT ticked 4p higher at 1,152p as the market continued to digest its plans to launch a mass market, broadband internet portal service.

However, Vodafone AirTouch saw its earlier recovery reversed, slipping 0.75p to 278.75p.

fields.headline: Focus: Shire Pharmaceuticals
fields.trailText: Shire Pharmaceuticals has cornered the market in treating hyperactive children. Its next step is to help elderly sufferers of Alzheimer's disease.
fields.body:
Shire Pharmaceuticals has cornered the market in treating hyperactive children. Its next step is to help elderly sufferers of Alzheimer's disease.

The emerging pharmaceuticals company has high hopes for Reminyl, an Alzheimer's treatment developed from snowdrops. The product has helped double Shire's shares this year, giving the group a market capitalisation of more than £2bn.

In addition to slowing patients' deterioration, Reminyl can actually improve their language, memory and understanding of events. It has a unique dual action, targeting both the enzyme that causes Alzheimer's and the receptor it connects with in the brain.

At present the leading Alzheimer's drug is Exelon, which produces annual revenue of more than $500m for its manufacturer, Pfizer. Shire believes Reminyl could do better after its launch this year.

Shire has been one of the drugs sector's best performers since last year's merger with US rival Roberts Pharmaceuticals.

The group licenses products at an early stage from biotech companies, rather than discovering new compounds itself, and concentrates on a handful of areas - psychiatric drugs, cancer treatments and digestive prod ucts. It targets specialists rather than GPs so only needs a modest salesforce.

First-quarter figures out yesterday showed a 40% jump in underlying profits to $26.7m (£17m). US accounting conventions meant Shire had to write down the value of all its employees' share options, reducing pre-tax profits to just $3.5m, but the market was still pleased with the performance and shares rose 100p to 844p.

The US fad for prescribing drugs to disruptive teenagers generated sales of $56.9m - an increase of 70% - in its products for attention deficit disorder. Analysts have forecast earnings growth of more than 50% this year.

The company wants to make further acquisitions and has promised savage cost cuts, so it looks likely to remain a firm favourite.

fields.headline: Sagging shares force Telegraph rethink
fields.trailText: The Telegraph newspaper group is preparing a significant expansion of its interests in Britain in what could signal a major shake-up of the now-converging strands of the media industry.
fields.body:
The Telegraph newspaper group is preparing a significant expansion of its interests in Britain in what could signal a major shake-up of the now-converging strands of the media industry.

Dan Colson, the company's chief executive, revealed that the group is seeking partners in the television, cable and telecommunications industries, to expand its media base. The Telegraph's moves form part of a wider plan by Conrad Black, the Canadian media tycoon, to extend his Hollinger empire from the core business of newspaper publishing.

While emphasising that the Telegraph titles and the Spectator magazine are not up for sale, Mr Colson said that the group had been considering for some time how to respond to the challenge posed by technological developments. "The Telegraph is undoubtedly a great content provider, but we are not in television, we are not in cable and we are not in the telephone industry either."

Mr Colson said that the Telegraph group would be seeking a small number of "strategic alliances" in the UK. He did not suggest any particular partner but there is speculation that the Telegraph is interested in developing links with the Pearson group.

Frustration at Hollinger's sagging share price, coupled with the heavy cost of launching Canada's first national newspaper, are thought to have been the motivation for Mr Black's decision to put up for sale Hollinger's bedrock of local and community papers across north America, revealed on Tuesday, and to seek partners for his larger metropolitan newspaper groups. The Toronto-based Hollinger group also owns the Chicago Sun-Times, the Jerusalem Post and the National Post.

Mr Black gave an indication of his intentions last month when he told shareholders that the internet "affords the newspaper publisher the opportunity to expand circulation vastly" (see below). But he stressed that the success would happen only if the "product is more than regionally competitive".

Even before this week's announcement, Hollinger had offloaded 45 local newspapers in the US for $460m in February 1999, using the proceeds to pay off debt, and later last year it sold a further 35 local papers in America to Horizon for $43.7m. It partly offset this with the $24.5m purchase of five local newspapers in the US.

Hollinger has already hit the jackpot on at least two internet investments. Shares in Trip.com, a travel business, cost Hollinger $10m and by March were worth $52m; its $15m stake in Intelligent Investor International has shot up to a market value of $330m.

Observers believe three factors lie behind the abrupt change of direction inside the Black empire: the costs of launching the National Post; the need to jolly up the lacklustre share price and the chairman's belief that only strong, metropolitan titles will be able to reap full advantage from the online media revolution.

The Post, launched in October 1998, achieved considerable critical success and is selling 300,000 copies a day but lost $44.3m last year. Already, Post losses have been blamed for cost-trimming exercises at the Telegraph group in London.

Mr Black has described these losses as "investment in the franchise" and is frustrated at the poor share price performance. Ahead of the announcement, it stood at about C$12.10, close to its 52-week low of C$10.25 and well below the high of C$22.4.

According to the National Post, the titles up for sale include the paper with which Mr Black began his proprietorial career, the Sherbrooke Record, but it does not appear on the alphabetical list of titles on the Hollinger website.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Leighton heads Wal-Mart unit
fields.body:
Leighton heads Wal-Mart unit

Wal-Mart Stores unit Wal-Mart Germany said Asda chief executive Allan Leighton is to take on the additional responsibility of chief executive officer for the German unit.

A statement said Mr Leighton replaces Ron Tiarks, who ended his assignment as CEO of Wal-Mart Germany yesterday and will return to the US next month to assume other duties.

It said the end of Mr Tiarks' term paves the way for restructuring management of the Wal-Mart Germany and to set up a five-member European management team led by Mr Leighton.

Wellington's retreat

Dunlop Hevea, the main manufacturer of wellington boots in Britain, has ceased production after 150 years, blaming the strong pound.

The firm, which paid off 43 employees on Tuesday, attributed the shutdown to a "mounting attack from cheaper imported wellingtons".

A total of 24 employees will be kept on at the Liverpool factory running sales, customer services, finance and warehouse operations but production lines are being transferred to parent company Hevea's plant in Portugal.

Managing director Johan de Jong said: "Our sad but necessary decision, which has only been reached after detailed analysis, means that the Dunlop brand ceases production in Liverpool after 150 years.

"However, it also puts Dunlop Hevea in a better position to compete in its domestic market."

Centrica plans 800 new jobs

Centrica, the owner of British Gas, will create at least 800 jobs as part of its drive to become a telecoms company.

The group, which is putting together a package ranging from mobile phones to internet access, will have the headquarters of its phone business in Old Trafford, Manchester.

Centrica, which already employs 3,000 staff in Manchester, will move its phone business into offices next to Lancashire county cricket club.

The first 450 jobs will filled by July, with staff for call centres, sales and marketing and technical posts the first to be appointed.

Saudi oil talks near end

Saudi Arabia will announce on Sunday the results of negotiations with heads of multinational oil companies wanting to invest in downstream oil and gas operations in the country, Prince Saoud al-Feisal was reported as saying yesterday.

Prince Saoud is head of the ministerial committee negotiating with the 12 oil companies - including Exxon Mobil, Texaco, Conoco, Marathon, BP Amoco, Royal Dutch/Shell, TotalFinaElf and Eni - shortlisted for investment in the country's gas and oil resources.

The negotiations are due to end on Sunday. The prince has said that he was expecting investments of around $100bn (£63bn).

webTitle: Worker's hero and thorn in side of Mugabe

fields.headline: Worker's hero and thorn in side of Mugabe
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Morgan Tsvangirai may be an unknown quantity in Britain, but he has been a household name in Zimbabwe for years.
fields.body:
Morgan Tsvangirai may be an unknown quantity in Britain, but he has been a household name in Zimbabwe for years.

Since the early 1990s he has been the leader of the Zimbabwe Congress of Trade Unions (ZCTU), the organisation that represents the country's main labour unions.

Once a compliant organisation that took its cues from the Mugabe government, the ZCTU was transformed by Mr Tsvangirai into the leading opposition.

In 1997 and 1998 it held a series of successful national anti-government strikes which brought the country to a halt.

The strikes also brought the wrath of the Mugabe government and in December 1998 Mr Tsvangirai was beaten unconscious by a gang who attempted to throw him out of the window of his 10th floor office.

The perpetrators were identified as supporters of Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party.

Such is Mr Tsvangirai's popularity that many workers downed tools until they found out whether he would live.

Mr Tsvangirai, 49, grew up in a large family in the southern area of Buhera . He went to secondary school but when his father died he went to work in the mines to support his family. When questioned about his lack of a degree, Mr Tsvangirai shoots back with the retort: "This government has lots of people with degrees and doctorates, but they are not doing such a good job of running the country."

He became involved in union administration and rose through the ranks.

He is credited with being instrumental in forming the National Constitutional Assembly, a coalition of church groups, unions, human rights groups and other civic organisations that pressed Mr Mugabe to draw up a new constitution.

When Mr Mugabe created his own draft constitution to entrench his powers, Mr Tsvangirai led the assembly in a successful campaign to reject it.

He founded the new Movement for Democratic Change, launched in January, which draws on a wide range of Zimbabweans, black and white.
