fields.headline: No: 1624
fields.standfirst: Nefertiti
fields.trailText: Nefertiti
fields.body:
Description: Egyptian queen.

Reigned: Circa 1372-1350 BC, with her husband, the pharoah Akhenaten.

Appearance: "Heiress, Great in the Palace, Fair of Face, Adorned with the Double Plumes, Mistress of Happiness, Endowed with Favours, at hearing whose voice the King rejoices, the Chief Wife of the King, his beloved," according to one ancient eulogist.

Bit of a looker, then. Indeed, but not just a pretty face: besides helping to popularise a new religion based on worship of the sun-disk Aten, she's now a high-profile TV personality.

But she's been dead for three millennia! If you think that's any kind of obstacle to a successful career in television, you clearly haven't been watching Kilroy recently. Nefertiti TV is the name of a controversial new Egyptian channel dedicated to sex education.

Surely the land of Cleopatra needs no lessons in love? Egypt's health minister, Ismail Salam, begs to differ. A 30s population of 18m has rocketed to more than 60m today. Family planning advice, previously taboo, is much needed.

Is Nefertiti qualified? Debatable: she had at least six children herself. Clearly Akhenaten couldn't resist the way she wore those double plumes, or maybe it was something to do with her famous bust (discovered in 1914 and now in the Berlin Museum).

It's another porn channel masquerading as a 'lovers' guide', presumably? The opening schedule's full of wholesome educational chat shows, actually. As for the future, Nefertiti TV executives are keeping a sphinx-like silence.

But it won't all be sex, sex, sex? Rumours of new lifestyle shows - Changing Mausoleums, Good Morning With Isis and Osiris, that sort of thing - are unconfirmed.

Still, Egypt's religious authorities must be furious. "Islam dictates that everything must be taught scientifically," channel director Fatima Fouad insists. "This channel will leave no issue untouched and everything will be discussed bravely."

And who'll pay to advertise on Nefertiti TV? Pyramid sales schemes, perhaps?

fields.headline: Not for the squeamish
fields.standfirst: Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: Ever since his riding accident five years ago, the actor Christopher Reeve has vowed that he would one day walk again. Until the moment in November 1998 when two American teams announced that they had "immortalised" human embryonic stem cells and were growing them in laboratory dishes, it seemed a dream.
fields.body:
Ever since his riding accident five years ago, the actor Christopher Reeve has vowed that he would one day walk again. Until the moment in November 1998 when two American teams announced that they had "immortalised" human embryonic stem cells and were growing them in laboratory dishes, it seemed a dream.

Stem cell therapy sounds like the ultimate in transplant surgery. You don't commandeer someone else's tissue so that you can live, with a little help from immunosuppressant drugs. You grow your own in a dish, treat yourself and walk away, at ease with the new bit of you inside.

There are no polymer implants, no alien grafts, no synthesised drugs on prescription. Just a fresh bit of you, fashioned by the same natural machinery that took you from a single fertilised cell to a whole human being in nine months. Five years ago, it was unimaginable. Two years ago, it was just impossible. Now there are a dozen biotech companies doing research on human stem cells, taken from foetuses, embryos and adult human tissue.

With these cells, they believe they could one day offer hope for people with Alzheimer's disease and atherosclerosis, heart disease and Huntington's, macular degeneration and multiple sclerosis, strokes and spinal cord injuries.

Stem cells are life's magic cauldron: they go on providing more. Humans begin as one single cell, a fertilised egg. They end as several trillion cells, of more than 200 different kinds. The process in between is a display of evolution's wizardry. First the embryonic egg clones, and clones again and again, and with each division, the cells contain the potential for twins, or quadruplets, or octuplets and so on. Then, at some finely balanced point, the nature of the cells begins to change. Some of them become stem cells. They can no longer become a whole human, but they can become anything a human might need, launching a cascade of changes that end with teeth and toenail tissue, or nerve cells, or the inner lining of the arteries, or the tough outer skin of a foot, or the tissue of a heart valve.

If there were some way of keeping such cells alive, scientists reasoned, they might be a new weapon in the war against degenerative diseases. If there were some way of understanding how and why cells differentiate, there might be a way of turning the clock back, of making new stem cells that would replace failed tissue. And then things began to happen. In some cancers, cells can somehow turn their own clocks back, go haywire, start making the wrong tissue in the wrong place. If cells can do that in the wrong place, at the wrong time, maybe they could do it to order.

In 1996, scientists at the Roslin Institute in Scotland took an adult cell from a fully grown sheep and persuaded it go back to square one, and produced from it Dolly the clone.

And at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore in 1998 - paid for by the Geron Corporation of California - and at the University of Wisconsin, teams of scientists separately isolated and kept alive human embryo stem cells. Words like "holy grail" were used. To illustrate the possibilities, commentators seized on celebrity sufferers who might - just might - benefit. One was Muhammad Ali, with Parkinson's disease. And one was Christopher Reeve himself, who had gone from being Superman to wheelchair-bound.

Right now, a little private company called Layton BioScience in Atherton, California, is working with a neuroscientist from the Harvard Medical School to test the effect of neural stem cells in laboratory rats before possible tests in humans. Right now, Geron BioMed at the Roslin Institute is waiting for the word from the British government before it marries the technology that led to Dolly with stem cell research and opens a new pathway in medicine, towards "therapeutic cloning".

Therein lies the catch. In the US, there is no federal money for human embryo research or anything that might seem like human cloning. On the other hand, there are no restrictions on what private companies might do. In Britain, there is a government appointed body that authorises experiments with human embryos, but only to help with infertility or certain tragic inherited diseases. The US hastily banned human cloning research in the world outcry after the announcement of Dolly the sheep. And the British government - reeling at the public reaction to the idea of genetically-altered soybean - found an excuse not to authorise new research but instead to refer the whole problem to a committee led by the chief medical officer of health, Liam Donaldson. Hope, as some see it, is blocked by red tape and squeamishness.

But there is more to it than squeamishness. The first step towards such research involves experiments with human eggs, human embryos. They will be at a very early stage - just bundles of cells - but to many they will be potential humans. Their use right now is justified because the research has led not just to new life, but to desperately longed-for life. It might seem a huge step to use what some people will see as potential life to do engineering on behalf of people who have had a life, and want to enjoy an even longer one. But each day brings new ethical puzzles: today, European fertility experts report a new way of fusing human eggs to make babies possible for women whose pregnancies have failed, and this, too raises problems of embryo research.

The chances are that stem cell therapy will go ahead. The betting is also that the use of five or six-day-old embryos will only be a stage in the adventure. Just as there are not enough donor hearts to meet demand for transplant surgery, so there will not be enough donated embryos to meet the demand for therapeutic cloning. So the dream answer is to isolate the stem cells from the patient, and use them to make the new tissue that could be injected into, or stitched into, the patient. There are huge obstacles. But if the stem cell machinery can conjure up a whole human in 40 weeks from a cell the size of a full stop, then, scientists reason, it ought to be able to conjure up a new heart valve, or endothelial cells for arteries, or eliminate damage done by diabetes, or cirrhosis, or hepatitis.

And, they think, in five or 10 years, there could be human trials for stem cell therapy - for Parkinson's, and, yes, spinal cord injury. Christopher Reeve can see the future, and from where he sits, it must look good.

Tim Radford is the Guardian's science editor.
tim.radford@theguardian.com

webTitle: Cook warns Zimbabwean mission he is offering help, not appeasement

fields.headline: Cook warns Zimbabwean mission he is offering help, not appeasement
fields.standfirst:
Bilateral talks: Aid incentives tied to elections and withdrawal of squatters
Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, expressed caution yesterday about any deal when he meets a high-level delegation from Zimbabwe today against a background of continuing violence in the southern African state.
fields.body:
The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, expressed caution yesterday about any deal when he meets a high-level delegation from Zimbabwe today against a background of continuing violence in the southern African state.

Mr Cook, briefing journalists ahead of the meeting in the Locarno Room at the Foreign Office, said: "Time will tell whether the delegation is here to grandstand or to reach agreement."

The meeting is aimed at resolving the land issue and other sources of friction that have brought British-Zimbabwean relations to their lowest point for more than 20 years.

But the signs yesterday were ominous, given the gulf between the parties, especially on land reform.

Mr Cook stressed yesterday that Britain would be putting no new money on the table to help with land reform beyond the £58m package promised two years ago.

The British government is reluctant to see President Robert Mugabe rewarded for unleashing a wave of violence. "Britain is ready to help the government of Zimbabwe but we are not going to appease," Mr Cook said.

"There can be no help unless there is an end to the occupations and a start to elections."

The Zimbabwean delegation, which is made up of three cabinet ministers, is being led by John Nkomo, the housing minister and a close confidant of Mr Mugabe.

The other members of the delegation are Nathan Shamuyarira, minister for industry and commerce, and Stan Mudenge, the foreign minister.

Mr Cook said he would be looking for commitments on land reform and a promise of a free and fair election, complete with international observers.

He said: "There will be no magic solutions tomorrow. We cannot offer quick fixes. The government of Zimbabwe must be willing to enter serious dialogue and take real, practical steps.

"We are willing to help but it is their choice. We are willing to work with them, but tomorrow will prove whether they are willing to work with us."

Zimbabwe will receive £12m from the Department of International Development this year and £10m next year. Mr Cook described this as the "low scenario", the money that Zimbabwe would receive even if Mr Mugabe's government did not cooperate.

But he held out the carrot of a "high scenario" if Mr Mugabe was "willing to behave reasonably": this would see the package increased to £28m this year and £30m next year. This money, which would not be exclusively for land reform, was on offer to Zimbabwe at a special conference two years ago.

In a bigger sweetener, Mr Cook promised to help mobilise the international community to provide financial help: the European Union, the World Bank, Scandinavian countries and the US.

Britain would insist that land reforms were carried out within the rule of law, on the basis of a fair price offered to farmers for their land, and that they benefit the "rural poor and not public officials with the right connections", Mr Cook said.

"What that means in the immediate future is that the illegal occupations must be stopped before any land reform starts."

Mr Cook said it would not be sensible for him to discuss whether Britain had a reserve plan should today's talks fail.

But he seemed to be preparing the ground for this eventuality when he said that if there were no agreement, he would make it clear this was the choice of the Zimbabwe government, not Britain.

He said he thought Zimbabwe's neighbours would be unimpressed if the delegation returned home without agreement.

The likelihood is that the British government would then raise the Zimbabwean issue next Tuesday at a meeting of Commonwealth ministers in London.

fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst:
Who will be signed up to play the Sith assassin in Star Wars Episode Two?
Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Who will be signed up to play the Sith assassin in Star Wars Episode Two?
fields.body:
Brad Pitt .......................5/1

Li Lian-Jie ..................14/1

Virtual actor ................16/1

Leonardo DiCaprio .....20/1

After accusations of using ludicrous, racially caricatured voices for Episode One, you can only hope that George Lucas's Sith assassin character in the next Star Wars installation handles the kung fu stereotypes with more sensitivity. Word is that Lucasfilm is seeking a more culturally diverse cast for the next instalment of the prequel trilogy.

"This character will be bad, dirty, fast and extremely skilled in the martial arts arena," says Ladbrokes' Ed Nicholson. The popularity of Darth Maul in Episode One means that this will be a sought-after role, especially as that part is contracted to last through to Episode Three."

And if Leonardo DiCaprio doesn't get to play a grown-up Anakin Skywalker, perhaps this would appeal?

"It would do his acting good to play a monster," says Ed. "However, he simply doesn't have the characteristics to become believable."

After Fight Club, Brad Pitt (pictured) as a tough guy would be an inspired choice, Ed reckons. "He's certain to bring in the female audiences. But the cast is looking hunk-full, with Christopher Walken and Ewan McGregor already signed up. My feeling is that they may go for an unheard-of name.

"If that's the case, then I think we've found the dark horse. His name is Li Lian-Jie. He's a martial arts expert, a wu shu champion - and I'm told that, despite sounding a little unthreatening, wu shu champions are hard. He also has form in the acting world, having taken part in that epic must-see film of 1982, Once Upon A Time in China. I'm not going to argue with him."

With Lucas having just given the go-ahead digitally film Episode Two digitally, a completely virtual enemy isn't out of the question. "It would certainly cost less in catering bills, but it would probably cost 10 times more to create and activate."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Dr Strangelove | High Hopes | Blood Relatives | Body Snatchers
fields.body:
Dr Strangelove

(Stanley Kubrick, 1963)

4pm, Sky Cinema

Satirical cold war comedy at its blackest from the late Kubrick, with barking mad General Jack D Ripper (Sterling Hayden) accidentally launching a nuclear strike on the Soviet Union. Peter Sellers plays US President Merkin Muffley, desperately trying to preserve the somewhat shaken peace, as well as playing loony adviser Strangelove and RAF pilot Lionel Mandrake. George C Scott's chief of staff doesn't see what all the fuss is about: "No more than 10 or 20 million people will be killed. Tops."

High Hopes

(Mike Leigh, 1988)

8pm, FilmFour

Attempting to parody the thick-skinned detachment of the upper classes and the naff excesses of the aspirational lower-middle classes, Leigh relies on stereotypes and unbelievable situations. But the dour wit and sharp

dialogue is there, in a story about a bolshy socialist motorbike courier and his broody girlfriend, looking after his mother as she slips into senility and dealing with the upper classes as they invade their patch.

Blood Relatives

(Claude Chabrol, 1978)

12.15am, Carlton Cinema

Here's a French-Canadian co-production which transposes an Ed McBain 87th Precinct plot to Montreal. Donald Sutherland plays an enigmatic and haunted-looking cop investigating the nasty murder of a 17-year-old girl. Typical Chabrol ruminations on the charmless bourgeoisie before he recalls that this is a thriller, and cranks it up to a riveting finale.

Body Snatchers

(Abel Ferrara, 1993)

12.20am, FilmFour

Another take (after Don Siegel and Philip Kaufman) on Jack Finney's sci-fi horror novel of alien pods hatching into duplicate humans: Ferrara turns it into an allegory on the all-American family and on youthful alienation. Gabrielle Anwar is the teeny outraged at having to move to a remote army base in the deep South, and Meg Tilly and Terry Kinney are the parents so lacking in understanding that they might as well be Martians. This is intelligent, fast and pleasingly gruesome stuff.
fields.bodyText: Dr Strangelove (Stanley Kubrick, 1963) 4pm, Sky Cinema Satirical cold war comedy at its blackest from the late Kubrick, with barking mad General Jack D Ripper (Sterling Hayden) accidentally launching a nuclear strike on the Soviet Union. Peter Sellers plays US President Merkin Muffley, desperately trying to preserve the somewhat shaken peace, as well as playing loony adviser Strangelove and RAF pilot Lionel Mandrake. George C Scott's chief of staff doesn't see what all the fuss is about: "No more than 10 or 20 million people will be killed. Tops." High Hopes (Mike Leigh, 1988) 8pm, FilmFour Attempting to parody the thick-skinned detachment of the upper classes and the naff excesses of the aspirational lower-middle classes, Leigh relies on stereotypes and unbelievable situations. But the dour wit and sharp dialogue is there, in a story about a bolshy socialist motorbike courier and his broody girlfriend, looking after his mother as she slips into senility and dealing with the upper classes as they invade their patch. Blood Relatives (Claude Chabrol, 1978) 12.15am, Carlton Cinema Here's a French-Canadian co-production which transposes an Ed McBain 87th Precinct plot to Montreal. Donald Sutherland plays an enigmatic and haunted-looking cop investigating the nasty murder of a 17-year-old girl. Typical Chabrol ruminations on the charmless bourgeoisie before he recalls that this is a thriller, and cranks it up to a riveting finale. webTitle: Harvest burns as economy goes up in smoke

fields.headline: Harvest burns as economy goes up in smoke
fields.standfirst: Tobacco: The agriculture crisis threatens far more than just the farmersZimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: At the Zimbabwe tobacco auction it smells as though the world has been marinating in an ashtray. There is a dense, pungent odour hanging over an enormous hangar on the outskirts of Harare, the largest auction house in the world, where bails of tobacco leaves stand ready to be sold.
fields.body:
At the Zimbabwe tobacco auction it smells as though the world has been marinating in an ashtray. There is a dense, pungent odour hanging over an enormous hangar on the outskirts of Harare, the largest auction house in the world, where bails of tobacco leaves stand ready to be sold.

Mark Impey, the auctioneer, walks from bail to bail with sellers in tow and buyers keeping pace opposite. Amid his fluent, lyrical patter you can make out the prices he is quoting for each bail. Meanwhile the buyers keep one eye on the tobacco leaves, rubbing them between their fingers and then thrashing them against the rest of the bail. The best leaves are orange and have the feel of soft leather.

Their other eye is on Mr Impey. Without interrupting his banter he seeks a flicker of recognition from the buyers. One nods; Impey nods back. The deal is done.

The opening of the auctions should be one of the highlights of the country's economic calender. But the marketing manager of the tobacco sales floor says she is depressed.

"We are geared for business but it's almost a charade of normality," she says. Tobacco is vital to the economy. The industry is Zimbabwe's largest employer and provides its most important export, earning a third of its foreign currency.

Yet the scene yesterday was pitiful. The volume of tobacco coming into the capital is a third down on last year and the price is down by a fifth.

Political instability and a feeble economy has kept many farmers and buyers away. Many of those who should have been selling their wares yesterday have not been able to return to their farms to prepare for the auction since they were chased away by squatters.

Others have had their crops burned. With 70% interest rates on the loans they have taken out against their crops, farmers say they need a devaluation of the exchange rate, which has been kept artificially high for 15 months, if they are going to stay competitive.

This is bad news for an economy which is desperately in need of foreign currency as it haemorrhages around £600,000 a day through its involvement in the war in the Congo.

And tobacco is not the country's only problem and tobacco farmers are not those most in need. White farmers employ 65% of the workforce - it is their labourers, among the poorest paid, who will be hit hardest.

The picture of staff in the entrance of the auction room illustrates just how much of Rhodesia's racial power structure remains in place in the economy. Whites make up less than 1% of the population. But they dominate the upper echelons of the tobacco industry. The receptionists and ticket markers are all black.

Both inflation and unemployment stand at more than 50%. Tourism has been seriously affected by the images of violence beamed into homes across the globe. Tourism at Victoria Falls is down by a half on this time last year.

Only the goodwill of Zimbabwe's stable neighbour, South Africa, is keeping the country in electricity. President Mugabe cannot pay the bill.

If the South African president, Thabo Mbeki, loses patience with Mr Mugabe's reluctance to restore law and order he could turn the lights out.

But that could trigger even greater instability throughout the region. The South African rand hit a 20-month low against the US dollar last week.

Zimbabwe's other neighbours such as Zambia and Mozambique, which have far more fragile economies, could be even more adversely affected.

The parlous state of the economy provides the backdrop for much of the political violence. While voters were queueing at the polls to vote in a referendum on the constitution last month, drivers were queueing at petrol stations because of a fuel shortage.

Mr Mugabe lost - his first significant political defeat in 20 years. First economic problems helped spark political chaos; now the political turmoil is compounding economic woes.

As Rian Le Roux, head of economic research at the leading investment house in South Africa, warned: "The risk is that the political crisis will result in full-scale economic collapse."

fields.headline: The great escape
fields.trailText: Castaway 2000 | Black And Blue | Alistair McGowan's Big Impression
fields.body:
Ben and Ray are at opposite ends of the social seesaw. Ben, the picture editor of Tatler, is universally popular, perennially sunny, charming, good-looking. An all-round good egg. Well, ovoid, I suppose. Gussy Fink-Nottle would call him "old bean", and borrow a fiver until Friday. I need only say that, when all the castaways on Taransay took an antibiotic which turned their urine red, Ben's turned a beautiful upmarket blue. I think it possible that Ben is much brighter than he looks, on the grounds that he must be. Ray is a retired builder from Greater Manchester. (Have you noticed the disruptive effect of builders in Coronation Street?). He is outspoken, awkward, independent, salt of the effing earth. Ray is northern. Ben is southern. Ray is elderly. Ben is young. Ray is enmeshed in whiskers like a goat in brambles. Ben's cheeks are a baby's bottom.

The resemblance between Mr Grouser and Larry the Lamb ("Oh, Mr Grouser, sir!") in Toytown is striking. They are marooned with 34 others on the island of Taransay in Castaway 2000 (BBC1).

Last night Ray said he was leaving. In seesaw terms, this left Ben high, if not exactly dry. Taransay is in the Outer Hebrides. Winter gales lift the Atlantic and drop it on the Hebrides. I didn't even know there were such things as Force 11 gales. As Sheila put it: "Last night was like being wrecked at sea." Some of them refused to set foot on Taransay until the roofs stopped blowing off their bedrooms. Listening as they filmed their video diaries, it struck me that seals probably do not bark at all, they cough. All the castaways were making the same forlorn, honking noise. On the other hand... on a fine day... the sea's the tender blue of a bird's egg.

There had been earlier hints of discord. When one of their sheep died, Ben asked helplessly: "What do you do with a dead sheep?" Ray said: "Get it on a plate with two veg and roast potatoes." Particularly tactless since Ben had called the sheep after girls on the staff of Tatler. Perhaps that was Arabella lying there with her hooves in the air. Or Camilla. When Trish's bitch had puppies and they debated the desirability of extra dogs for days, Ray said briefly: "Should have drowned them at birth." The castaways seem to be dedicated democrats whose reaction to a comet strike would be to take a vote on it.

Among the things Ray couldn't stand were endless bloody meetings and journalists. When Padraig asked: "Why don't you adjust your behaviour?" Ray replied - very sonorously I feel - "I will not adjust to journalists." Padraig himself came under attack on Burns Night when Ray got drunk and had to be forcibly restrained ("Ray! Ray! Sit down!"). "I shouldn't," he said remorsefully the morning after, "drink whisky."

Last night Ray retired to one of the Nissen huts, known as pods, that he lived in and repulsed all efforts to wheedle him out. "Fuck me! What do you want? You're about the fucking 10th one to come here!" He emerged to stare moodily at the sea. It was like The Prisoner without the white balloons. The series made the best of a rapidly worsening job ("Find out tomorrow what really happened!").

What really happened is well documented. Ray adjusted to journalists long enough to be rescued by the Mirror, and instantly fell out with them too. No one seemed sure why he left. As Paul McCartney put it: "Why he had to go, I don't know, he wouldn't say." One theory was that his building work was unappreciated. His bridge was condemned by Health and Safety (I'm sorry to see their remit stretches so far) and the lid he was building on the toilets blew off.

Ray is, as Denis Norden once said, "one of those wild, free spirits or, as producers call them, troublemakers".

Black And Blue (ITV) is one of those irredeemably gloomy Scottish thrillers, punctuated with the steady thump of people hurtling out of tenement windows onto rain-soaked cobbles. Or off roofs. Or over cliffs. John Hannah has the high cheekbones and low spirits for Inspector Rebus, a man under a cloud. He could also play John Knox, The Teenage Years. Unless you knew Ian Rankin's readable book, the plot would be hard to follow.

In Alistair McGowan's Big Impression (BBC1) Carol Smillie, supposedly, says:"People should cheer up and be more smiley, shouldn't they, Sam?" Sam is Scottish. He says sadly: "Oh, ay. A smile does nae cost nothing. No."

fields.headline: Car workers are rightly doomed
fields.standfirst:
The government's help has merely prolonged the agony

Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The workers of the West Midlands are the victims of decades of kindness. Their vulnerability to mass redundancy is the direct result of the policies designed to save them. For the Rover plant at Longbridge, like the Ford factory at Dagenham, has been doomed for years. Both the new money the government has promised the plant and the new bid drawn up by its well-wishers amount simply to a prolongation of its agony.
fields.body:
The workers of the West Midlands are the victims of decades of kindness. Their vulnerability to mass redundancy is the direct result of the policies designed to save them. For the Rover plant at Longbridge, like the Ford factory at Dagenham, has been doomed for years. Both the new money the government has promised the plant and the new bid drawn up by its well-wishers amount simply to a prolongation of its agony.

Longbridge is still working only because the government has given it £3.5bn since 1975. By propping up car manufacturing through building roads, holding down fuel taxes and stifling the growth of public transport, it has handed the industry many billions more. Protecting car production in the face of market failure has, far from helping them, locked the people of the West Midlands into an economy which cannot sustain itself.

British car plants are doomed not only because they are slow and inefficient and suffer from the economies of scale enjoyed by bigger plants elsewhere, but also because the European car market is close to saturation. Car manufacturing can continue to grow only if the people of this and other nations are prepared to suffer ever more intractable traffic jams. We are not. The workers of Longbridge are vulnerable, in other words, because their industry is both economically and environmentally unsustainable.

The troubles at Longbridge are illustrative of a far wider problem. Instead of liberating "the extraordinary talent of the British people . . . from the forces of conservatism that so long have held them back", Tony Blair's government has systematically suppressed the future and subsidised the past. It has poured money only into those industries whose growth is limited by the carrying capacity of the environment. Since Labour came to power, for example, it has given BAe and Rolls-Royce a total of £850m to make aeroplanes, yet political pressure has been building up all over Europe to limit the number of flights and stop the construction of new airports.

Releasing more cars and planes on to the market is likely, paradoxically, only to reduce our productivity. The CBI calculates, for example, that congestion is costing Britain £15bn a year. Swedish research shows that the reading ability of 12 to 14-year-olds living under flight paths is impaired by 23%. Figures published this week by the Global Commons Institute reveal that, while global GDP has risen by 3% a year over the past four decades, economic losses caused by natural disasters have risen annually by 10%. By 2065, it calculates, the cost of climate change will outstrip the value of the entire global economy.

Technologies for which demand is booming, on the other hand, are being muzzled. As the economist Paul Ekins points out, the growth in environmental spending in the UK outperformed the rest of the economy by four times over the 90s. The global solar energy market is growing annually by 40%. Yet civil servants at the Department of Trade and Industry, captured by the oil and nuclear companies they are supposed to regulate, remain fiercely hostile towards the new technologies. Five times as much money is spent in British universities on research into oil and gas as on research into renewable power, even though oil and gas is a mature industry whose reserves are running out, while renewable energy is taking off.

As a result, Shell has decided to build its solar energy plants not in Britain but in Germany, where the government has promised to install solar panels on 100,000 homes. The massive export market it is developing will create tens of thousands of jobs. Though Britain is the windiest nation in Europe, it has offered no challenge to Denmark's bid to become the global leader in wind technology. By 2030, wind will supply 40% of Denmark's electricity, while we will be left to struggle with growing power bills and massive unemployment as oil reserves dry up and we have to import our electricity from far-sighted nations. Indeed, while it continues to prop up such 19th-century technologies as internal combustion engines and coal mining, the government is permitting the only shipyard with the capacity to build giant offshore wind turbines (Harland and Wolff in Belfast) to go to the wall.

The impending loss of thousands of jobs in the West Midlands is a great tragedy. It is also a great opportunity. Were the government to exercise a little of that vision it claims to possess in abundance, it would abandon the backward-looking policies which have compromised the future of British manufacturing and launch, instead, a genuine "knowledge-based economy". I fear, however, that the forces of conservatism are alive and well, sustained by the misguided philanthropy of the government which claims to despise them.

webTitle: Mother saves 13-year-old snared by internet man

fields.headline: Mother saves 13-year-old snared by internet man
fields.trailText: A mother yesterday told how the "boy" her 13-year-old daughter had arranged to meet through an internet chatroom turned out to be a middle-aged man - and said she believed if she had not insisted on going with her daughter "we may not still have our daughter now".
fields.body:
A mother yesterday told how the "boy" her 13-year-old daughter had arranged to meet through an internet chatroom turned out to be a middle-aged man - and said she believed if she had not insisted on going with her daughter "we may not still have our daughter now".

The woman, from Milton Keynes, Buckinghamshire - who asked not to be identified - said the man's internet deception, which he used to build up an intimate relationship with the girl without her parents' knowledge, had left her daughter devastated and destroyed dreams of her "first love".

Thames Valley police said the 47-year-old man, from north-east England, originally claimed to be 15 when he exchanged messages with the girl. Later he changed his age to 18, and asked the schoolgirl to send photographs of herself before arranging to meet her in central Milton Keynes.

Her mother said: "My daughter told us they wanted to meet. We were concerned, and insisted that if they were going to meet I would be there.

"I was also a bit worried because the man had insisted that if I was there he would drive away immediately."

She dropped off her daughter, and drove on to park her car while the girl talked to her "friend" on a mobile phone.

"I came back from the car and suddenly saw an older man talking on another mobile, and immediately thought: 'Oh my God'," she said.

"My daughter was still talking on the phone when he was waiting outside the meeting place. I knew she was talking to him when I heard him say her name and say: 'Come out and show yourself.' I was so shocked, I could not believe it."

She said she did not immediately confront the man, who she described as "middle-aged, not very well dressed", out of fear, and only did when her daughter began talking to him.

"As they were talking I went up to him. I said: 'You are not 17,' and he answered 'Yes I am', then admitted he wasn't, and I took her away immediately."

The mother said her daughter had been distraught. "She was shocked, depressed, it was absolutely terrible. It was her first love, she said she was in love."

The man was later arrested but he was not charged as police concluded no crime had been committed.

The mother said: "I think the police should be given more powers and something like this should be a crime."

Police warned parents to be vigilant about their children using internet chatrooms. There has long been concern about how the anonymity of text-based chat sites can allow paedophiles or others with ulterior motives to shelter behind assumed identities while chatting to children.

Chief Inspector Neville Pinkney, of Milton Keynes police, said the case highlighted the dangers of the internet. "This was a most disturbing case, and had it not been for the vigilance of the girl's mother, the 13-year-old could have placed herself at quite considerable risk," he said.

webTitle: Straw sees stowaways caught by port patrol

fields.headline: Straw sees stowaways caught by port patrol
fields.standfirst: The issue explained: How to claim asylum Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw could not have planned a better illustration of his new get tough measures to reduce the number of asylum seekers. During a visit to Dover yesterday the home secretary witnessed nine stowaways being caught by immigration officers during checks on vehicles arriving from the continent.
fields.body:
Jack Straw could not have planned a better illustration of his new get tough measures to reduce the number of asylum seekers. During a visit to Dover yesterday the home secretary witnessed nine stowaways being caught by immigration officers during checks on vehicles arriving from the continent.

Mr Straw was in the Kent port to see how new government measures, whereby drivers can be fined up to £2,000 for each stowaway found in their vehicles, are working.

Minutes after Mr Straw's arrival at the freight clearance centre at Dover's eastern docks, a lone stowaway, who told immigration officers he was from Kosovo, was detected by an officer using a hand-held carbon dioxide probe.

Mr Straw shook the Kosovan by the hand as he was taken off the lorry.

The bemused refugee, who was in a truck which had come from Barcelona, had been hiding in an 18in by 5ft space between two pallets when he was discovered by customs officers measuring for raised levels of carbon dioxide, indicating stowaways are on board.

About 10 minutes later a body-detector dog found eight refugees in the back of a lorry from Prague. Seven adults and a child, who had cut the security seal around the load to get on board, were taken out of the lorry.

Praising immigration officers, Mr Straw insisted Britain was meeting its international obligations but would not be a soft touch to those who sought to "profit from human traffic".

Warning drivers that they faced a £2,000 fine for each stowaway found in their lorries, Mr Straw said the message was getting through to British truckers but it was going to take a little more time with foreign drivers.

The home secretary said the government had been talking extensively with French ministers to try to improve security at Calais, as well as increasing the number of immigration staff at Dover by 30% with 133 more staff.

Since the new measures were introduced on April 3 more than 50 lorry drivers, 19 of them British, have been caught carrying asylum seekers.

fields.headline: Hide and seek
fields.standfirst:
We were promised architecture rivalling the finest in Europe for Scotland's parliament. So where is it?

Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: We were promised architecture rivalling the finest in Europe for Scotland's parliament. So where is it?
fields.body:
When the folk singer, Sheena Wellington, sang "A man's a man for a' that", Burns's great ode to egalitarianism, at the opening of the Scottish parliament last year, it was not so much a musical tribute as a statement of intent: a plea to pull together for a common aim and a promise of accessibility and accountability.

And it didn't matter that her strong, clear voice was blunted by the acoustics of Edinburgh's old Assembly Hall, the parliament's temporary home. Soon there would be a new building to symbolise the nation's pride in devolution - a striking, contemporary political campus for the foot of the Royal Mile, designed by the Catalan architect Enric Miralles.

A year on from the parliament's inception and recrimination is now the most common refrain. Recrimination for policies gone awry, for political posturing and for the demise of the building that was in some way supposed to signal the end of all that.

Now Scotland's answer to the Reichstag is a balsa wood model, so changed from its original concept that it will go back before city planners this week. It is so expensive that it will cost more than five times the original amount; some £200m. And it is so shrouded in secrecy that no one knows whose signature should be written on its base, when it will be ready or what exactly it will look like.

"We just don't know what we're getting," says Margo Macdonald, the SNP politician whose dogged determination to track the project kept the issue alive when others might have hoped it would be left well alone.

"At first, there were concerns about the money. Now I have concerns about whether or not this will be a thing of beauty to behold and add to Edinburgh's architectural heritage."

Indeed, those who have seen the latest scale model, revealed only to a select few this past week, say it looks "scrunched up", with some parts six to seven storeys high, and the distinctive upturned boat design of the original replaced by what are ominously referred to as "towers".

Earlier this month, the parliament voted to continue with the project, despite the rising costs and growing doubts over the exact role of Miralles, the Barcelona-based architect who won the international competition to create the building. He is recuperating after being taken ill in America and parliamentarians have been told that much of the responsibility now falls to his Scottish partners in the venture, the Edinburgh architects RMJM.

But Miralles does not appear to have been the hands-on presence Scots were previously led to believe. And yesterday, Ms Macdonald was drafting a letter to the parliament's presiding officer, Sir David Steel, asking who crafted the latest model and whose name could be put on the finished product. "Is Miralles the architect in this?" she asked. "And if he's not why are we paying so much for a building by someone else?" She has already been told such questions are "distasteful" given Miralles's ill-health.

RMJM say they don't talk to the press. A parliamentary spokesman first said it was never solely Enric Miralles's building, then added that it was his building but others had always been involved. He described RMJM as the design engineers, saying that this is the stage the scheme has moved to.

Meanwhile, many of those in the Scottish architectural community have reacted with horror at the unfolding saga. They say the latest plan is barely recognisable from the original; that it is far too dense and will be a disaster for what is a world heritage site. They talk of the desecration of the adjoining Queens berry House, the elegant 17th-century A-listed building, that has been saved from demolition but is to be bomb and bullet-proofed. And they fear the entire project will deal a body blow to Scottish architecture.

Hardest of all to take, however, is the lack of information forthcoming on the project. One architect has described it as Scotland's "state secret". It is a sign that the parliament, for all its fine intentions, has been unable to shake the old hands-off culture that haunted the Scottish Office in the past. Decision-making responsibilities have been cushioned from uncomfortable questions.

"This is our new parliament, our new democracy, all open and all accountable. Stuff and nonsense," says Margo Macdonald. "But what are we supposed to do as MSPs? We know people are fed up hearing about the Scottish parliament but it is such a huge amount of public money, a huge responsibility."

She's right that Scots are wearying of the saga. We were promised a development to rival the best architecture of Europe's other great cities, but many could not now care less about bricks and mortar. We had hoped for that which Sheena Wellington and Robert Burns had articulated so clearly. Accessibility. Accountability. Community. A parliament that would work with us as well as for us. But the debacle over its permanent home has exposed that there is as little a sign of that happening as there is of an inspiring new structure filling the gap at Holyrood anytime soon.

Kirsty.Scott@theguardian.com

webTitle: Hardliners in elite force 'plotting coup against Iranian president'

fields.headline: Hardliners in elite force 'plotting coup against Iranian president'
fields.standfirst: More about Iran
fields.trailText: Several commanders in Iran's Revolutionary Guards have mapped out a strategy to force reformist foes to "stay silent or pull aside" in a planning session which it is claimed could be described as a precursor to a coup against President Mohammad Khatami.
fields.body:
Several commanders in Iran's Revolutionary Guards have mapped out a strategy to force reformist foes to "stay silent or pull aside" in a planning session which it is claimed could be described as a precursor to a coup against President Mohammad Khatami.

Three senior officials of the Revolutionary Guards and their allies outlined a three-stage plan to be carried out by a "crisis committee", according to notes taken from a tape of the meeting two weeks ago, which have been made available to the Guardian.

The first stage was to close 18 newspapers. On Monday, hardliners in the judiciary issued orders to shut down 13 newspapers and journals.

The other stages include tapping leading reformers' telephones, disrupting the Tehran bazaar and seminaries to incite senior clerics, and deploying forces in the countryside to terrorise citizens and force the supporters of reform to "stay silent or pull aside".

If these steps were successful, the final stage would be to force a coup, according to the notes from the tape. "A coup on what pretext?" asked one participant. "A coup on the grounds that some [reformers] could be foreign agents or spies," replied another.

The commanders discussed how to gain the support of Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.

The Revolutionary Guards, created after the 1979 revolution to protect clerical rule, are estimated by western analysts to number about 150,000 - around a third of the armed forces. If they were to stage a coup, President Khatami would be at the mercy of Ayatollah Khamenei, who has power over the military and would be forced to take sides.

They also discussed ways to postpone the convening of a new parliament, in which reformist candidates won a plurality of seats in February's elections. It is due to hold its first session on May 28.

One man at the meeting recommended that Ayatollah Khamenei assign duties to "representatives" in the provinces so "that a sense of terror could be created".

Rumours of a coup have swept Iran since the Revolutionary Guards issued a statement on April 16, warning that they were prepared to eliminate their enemies if necessary. "The Islamic revolution is a revolution of reason and compassion. But, if necessary, the enemies will also feel the [pain] and blows in their skull, that they will forever be stopped from hatching plots and committing crimes," it said.

The Guards, responding to fears of a coup plot, issued another statement on Monday dismissing the rumours.

"Today, the word coup d'etat is a defunct word in our country. Considering the foundation that has been laid by the eminent Imam [Ayatollah Khomeini, the founder of the republic] for political management of the country, coup d'etat is a meaningless, alien and irrelevant word."

Pro-reform newspapers and government officials began warning of a shadowy "crisis committee" earlier this week.

Sobh-e Emrouz, one of the few reformist newspapers allowed to stay open, has reported the aims of the Guards and their allies in the police and the state broadcast monopoly.

webTitle: All murder is heinous, but not all murderers are alike

fields.headline: All murder is heinous, but not all murderers are alike
fields.standfirst:
Tony Martin is paying the price for the policy of mandatory life sentences

Tony Martin murder case: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Martin should never have been sentenced to life imprisonment. Punishing the Norfolk farmer in this way is an outrage. It offends any sane person's instincts about the meaning of justice. On the spectrum of heinous murders it places Martin at the same point as the Yorkshire Ripper, which is plainly unacceptable. All murderers do not weigh the same in the scales of human wickedness, yet we discover that they are equal before the law. Something very wrong is happening to a man who went too far, with a terrible result, in defending himself and his property.
fields.body:
Tony Martin should never have been sentenced to life imprisonment. Punishing the Norfolk farmer in this way is an outrage. It offends any sane person's instincts about the meaning of justice. On the spectrum of heinous murders it places Martin at the same point as the Yorkshire Ripper, which is plainly unacceptable. All murderers do not weigh the same in the scales of human wickedness, yet we discover that they are equal before the law. Something very wrong is happening to a man who went too far, with a terrible result, in defending himself and his property.

It is obvious, therefore, that politicians should be heard from. They have a duty to say what they would do not only for Martin but for others in similar situations. William Hague had a go at doing that yesterday. Very naturally there has been an outcry, and you don't have to be a Daily Mail reader to experience the indignation that produces it. But one does need to take a little care. Ends and means bear some examination. The very same political instincts that drive Mr Hague to lash out in all directions are the ones that sent Martin to jail for life. Politicians, especially Tory politicians, are accomplices before the fact of the outrage that has now occurred.

For Martin got his life sentence because the judge had no option but to impose it. Ever since the abolition of capital punishment, life has been mandatory for murder. This was the political sweetener that got rid of the gallows, a necessary reassurance to the public at that revolutionary penal moment.

But as the gallows receded, the weakness of the mandatory life sentence became clearer, precisely for the reason that it fails to distinguish between the Ripper and the farmer. By lumping all murders together, it reduces recognition of what is truly heinous, and nullifies the grades of stigma between a desperate act of domestic violence and contract murders by a professional killer.

Over the years, there has been a build-up of studies and reports with detailed argument showing that life should be a maximum and not a mandatory sentence for murder. It would not only be fairer but more effective. The Butler committee said so in 1975, the Advisory Council on the Penal System in 1978, the Criminal Law Revision Committee in 1980, the parliamentary all-party penal affairs group in 1986, a House of Lords select committee in 1989. All lord chief justices in living memory have thought that a judge was no less qualified to exercise discretion in murder cases than in others, and to determine a fixed sentence appropriate to the case - retaining life only for the very worst.

If this collective wisdom had been followed, Tony Martin would now be serving a proper and not a repugnant sentence for murder. But the wisdom was spurned by politicians. Although it acquired critical mass in the Tory years, no home secretary would listen to it. David Waddington said removing mandatory life would "greatly damage public confidence". Kenneth Baker said that all murder, whatever the circumstances, was more abhorrent than any other crime. Douglas Hurd, an aspirant reformer, said it was impossible to get away from the politics of it. None of them paid attention to their colleague, Lord Chancellor Hailsham, who scorned the mandatory life rule and what he called the "hairy heel of populism" that made it apparently untouchable.

The Martin case could be used as a unique moment to turn the hairy heel to advantage. Isn't it the best proof yet available of how mandatory life sentences can offend popular instincts? Couldn't the thorny issues of what is appropriate self-defence and what is reasonable force be dealt with, after the jury has spoken, precisely by the judicial discretion that the mandatory sentence takes away? If, as the tabloids and the Tories scream, a better balance must be struck between wicked criminals and overheated householders with a gun to hand, isn't reform of the blanket life sentence by far the most sensible way to do it?

Not to William Hague. Nor to Jack Straw - though abolishing mandatory life is another penal reform Labour once favoured but now rejects. Instead Hague finds the conventional populist appeal irresistible, and overlooks the penal failures it incessantly produced during the Thatcher-Howard years. In 1996, after all, Michael Howard produced mandatory minimum three-year sentences for persistent domestic burglars, which didn't do much good to Tony Martin. A decade of answering what Hague now righteously calls "an explosion of anger among millions of law abiding people" with explosions of anger by ranting politicians had limited success in crime-reduction, and still less in restoring to society a hard sense of the difference between right and wrong.

There are many reasons for that failure: moral decline, godless materialism, social neglect, personal indifference, a duty-free society. For vigilante-ism to be written into law, the remedy Hague comes close to proposing, is insupportable, but people must be able, within the law, to defend themselves proportionately to the threat they face. Martin had an illegal weapon, and committed a shocking crime. The issue is the context, especially the legal context, in which this should henceforth be dealt with. There are sharply contrasting possibilities.

The politicians' way is to pass sweeping laws of ever greater crudity. These are what have put Tony Martin in jail for life, and Hague wants more of them. They reject individual justice, in favour of grand statements that brush aside particulars. They may catch some serious criminals and send them down for a long time, but people of minor as well as major evil are caught in a penal regime which, more and more over the past decade, has promoted political over judicial decision-making. Life sentences, with discretion over the real time served given to the home secretary, are a burgeoning phenomenon of the British system, now extending well beyond murder. They undermine the notion of justice as a juridical not a political commodity, applying to people not to categories, addressing real lives and not tabloid furies.

The judges' way is different. The judge uses his judgment in all the circum- stances. He can look at Tony Martin and see he's not one of the Krays. Restoring his power to discriminate between one murderer and another would restore justice without imperilling social order in any way. Judges can be as hard as politicians, but aren't locked into a system that guarantees injustice. Actually, they will get their power back. As the Bulger case showed, political intervention in sentencing is beginning to seep away, because it violates the European human rights convention. This will retrieve some sanity. But not before the Martin case has sent politicians raging in the wrong direction.

They undermine the notion of justice as a juridical not a political commodity, applying to people not to categories, addressing real lives and not tabloid furies. The judges' way is different. The judge uses his judgment in all the circum- stances. He can look at Tony Martin and see he's not one of the Krays. Restoring his power to discriminate between one murderer and another would restore justice without imperilling social order in any way. Judges can be as hard as politicians, but aren't locked into a system that guarantees injustice. Actually, they will get their power back. As the Bulger case showed, political intervention in sentencing is beginning to seep away, because it violates the European human rights convention. This will retrieve some sanity. But not before the Martin case has sent politicians raging in the wrong direction. hugoyoung@compuserve.com

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Woodwards bailed
fields.body:
Woodwards bailed

Louise Woodward's parents Susan and Gary appeared in court in Chester yesterday on charges of defrauding their daughter's appeal fund after she was convicted of killing a baby in her care. They are both accused of falsely claiming $15,400 for accommodation in the US and producing a false invoice to trustees. They were bailed until July.

RSPCA award for Josie Russell

Josie Russell, who survived a hammer attack in which her mother and sister were murdered, was yesterday commended by the RSPCA for her part in the rescue of three sheep from a cliff near her home in north Wales.

Playground's solar success

A children's playground in east London yesterday became the first to sign up to a scheme in which an electricity company gives a discount to customers who generate their own solarpower. Eastern Energy and Greenpeace are promoting the scheme. Homerton Grove playground has a solar electric building.

Wellingtons factory axed

Footwear firm Dunlop Hevea is ending production of its Wellington boots in Britain with the loss of 43 jobs. The strong pound was blamed for the decision to close its plant in Walton, Liverpool, after 150 years.

Auction lot will be a snip

Bidders at a school's fundraising auction can compete for a vasectomy. Laurel Spooner, whose two younger children attend Hamilton primary in Colchester, Essex, said she would operate on the winning bidder at her surgery.

webTitle: Scots in crisis over Dewar heart op

fields.headline: Scots in crisis over Dewar heart op
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: The political future of the Scottish first minister, Donald Dewar, was thrown into severe doubt yesterday as it emerged he is to undergo major heart surgery.
fields.body:
The political future of the Scottish first minister, Donald Dewar, was thrown into severe doubt yesterday as it emerged he is to undergo major heart surgery.

In the next few weeks Mr Dewar, 62, will have a cardiac operation to replace a leaking aortic valve.

He will be out of action for around three months, leaving a political and power vacuum at the heart of the Scottish executive.

In his absence the Liberal Democrat deputy first minister, Jim Wallace, will take control of cabinet, but he will not take the title of acting first minister.

Although there was widespread concern for Mr Dewar yesterday, there was also acknowledgment that the coalition deal which brought him to power last May turns his illness from a worrying personal matter into a real political dilemma.

While Mr Wallace can, in theory, run the partnership government as Mr Dewar convalesces, this would leave the Labour majority group answering to a political master from another party.

To counter this, the enterprise minister, Henry McLeish, emerged yesterday as Mr Dewar's de facto political replacement.

No firm date has been set for the first minister's operation, which will be carried out on the NHS at Glasgow royal infirmary. But his cardiologist, Kerry-Jane Hogg, said Mr Dewar would be in hospital for 10 days, with a 12-week recovery period.

The first minister, who is divorced with two children, told reporters that he was in "good form" yesterday as he left hospital, and his spokesman, David Whitton, said later that he would return to work today in time for his question time session.

Mr Whitton said the first minister had known there was a problem with his heart for some time, but had not realised its severity until he underwent tests on Tuesday.

It has always been assumed - though never confirmed - that Mr Dewar would leave the Scottish parliament at the next election in 2003.

Mr Dewar's cardiologist stressed that he should make a full recovery from his "major but fairly routine" surgery.

However, his illness, coming on top of widely reported back problems, has sparked rumours that he will quit before the next Scottish election.

If Mr Dewar were to go, his most likely successor would be Mr McLeish.

The first minister had all but anointed the communities minister, Wendy Alexander, as his heir apparent, but her poor performance in the section 28 row has badly damaged her immediate prospects.

The only other candidates would be the finance minister, Jack McConnell, and the health minister, Susan Deacon, whose surprise star performance gives her an outside chance of replacing Mr Dewar.

But Mr Dewar is far from gone yet and when he returns to work today he will face a punishing schedule.

Taking on the full mantle of power has been difficult for Mr Dewar, who is regarded as notoriously bad at delegating, and he has been stung by personal attacks on his handling of the Scottish parliament building and on his decision to sack his former chief adviser, John Rafferty.

Although he undoubtedly retains the affection of Scotland for his "father of the nation" role, his illness will further highlight the gap in age between himself and the up and coming members of his cabinet - and the difficulties involved in presiding over coalition government.

 The furore over plans to scrap section 28 intensified yesterday as it emerged that millionaire businessman Brian Souter had found a polling society prepared to conduct his self-financed referendum.

The Stagecoach tycoon, who has vowed to spend all his money in an attempt to keep the clause, is paying polling group Vote It £1m to send out voting papers to 4m Scots. He had been turned down by the Electoral Reform Society.

The news comes as the Scottish parliament today prepares for a stormy debate on the matter.

Voting papers will be sent out to households across Scotland early next week and the result will be declared on May 30.

webTitle: The fine art of being mayor

fields.headline: The fine art of being mayor
fields.standfirst:
London is the cultural capital of the world, but what is the mayor going to do to keep it that way? Leading arts figures tell Matt Barnard their views
The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: London is the cultural capital of the world, but what is the mayor going to do to keep it that way? Leading arts figures tell Matt Barnard their views
fields.body:
Something is missing. Amid all the shouting and sniping over the London mayoral elections, debate about the arts is almost entirely absent.

It is a decidedly British anomaly. If there is anything London should be proud of it is the arts. The capital of Britain is arguably the cultural capital of Europe. The Millennium Dome notwithstanding, London boasts an unparalleled collection of cultural jewels. It is home to the flagship national companies (the Royal National Theatre, the Royal Opera); it hosts the economic powerhouse that is the West End, and the South Bank Centre, the largest arts complex in Europe; the British Film Institute is based in the capital, alongside more than 100 cinemas; while the bulk of the national collections are to be found in the city, at the ever-expanding Tate, the National Gallery, the British Library, the Victoria & Albert Museum and others.

Alongside the institutionalised creative activity, London is home to a frenetic community of artists, musicians, writers and performers, while the wider creative community stretches from the media to design and architecture. Much of the money behind Britain's burgeoning creativity - the "creative industries", as New Labourspeak once had it - is located in London. Down the road from the Houses of Parliament, the Arts Council of England sits in judgment over and dispenses money to a range of projects across the country.

With all this activity, one would imagine that the four main mayoral candidates would be rushing to cover themselves in reflected glory. Not so. Ken Livingstone harks back to his Festival of Britain childhood, when trips to the zoo were top of his cultural agenda. Frank Dobson avows, "I'm a conservative about visual art. If I can't hang it on my wall at home, I'm not interested." Steven Norris tells us that, "My radio is almost permanently tuned to Classic FM." Susan Kramer reads a lot. London's cultural life, they wail, is a super thing, if only they had more time for it.

It is to be hoped that the new mayor might make time for it, although like so much else surrounding the role of the mayor, precisely how he or she will be able to affect the cultural life of the city is not clear. The mayor is required to appoint a cultural strategy group, which will then advise him or her on the only other task they are required to carry out, which is to devise a cultural strategy. Tellingly, the mayor is not required to implement that strategy, which is probably a necessary omission as the mayor's powers are severely limited.

The only cultural institution over which the mayor will have direct control is the London Transport Museum. The mayor will be able to provide "financial or other assistance" to London's cultural institutions, though as the revenue-raising powers of the London Assembly are also limited, it is not clear where any extra money for grants could come from.

Sue Robertson, chief executive of the London Arts Board, chairs an organisation called the Cultural Strategy Partnership (CSP), which has no official relationship with the mayor, but was put together specifically to consider the issues affecting the cultural life of London and how the mayor could get involved. The CSP includes organisations such as English Heritage, the Heritage Lottery Fund, London Film Commission, the London Tourist Board and the National Lottery Charities Board.

Together, the organisations within the CSP have far more spending power than the new mayor will have for culture; even so, Robertson says that they will look to the mayor to provide leadership and direction. "We hope that the mayor will be a broker for new resources," Robertson says. "But what the mayor can really do that none of us can on our own, is link the cultural policy with other policies. I hesitate to use the phrase joined-up thinking, but there is a real opportunity to link culture with economic [planning], environmental sustainability, and transport strategies to make some sense of London."

Echoing this, there is a sense of optimism among London's arts figures that the mayor can make a positive difference. The Guardian asked a number of the capital's leading arts figures to comment on what they thought the first priority of the new mayor should be in terms of culture. The responses are set out below: almost all thought that the mayor had an important role to play in the capital's cultural life.

Name: John Tusa

Job/organisation: Managing director, Barbican Centre

Mayor's first priority: "It would be nice if the mayor realised that culture is what the world sees in London and that it needs speaking up for. If they don't, then the title of 'cultural capital of the world' will go to Paris, New York or Berlin, and they will be laughing all the way to the bank."

Name: David Gordon

Job/organisation: Secretary, Royal Academy

Mayor's first priority: "Clear up the mess that is London. I would be quite happy if they didn't come up with great thoughts on culture but created the infrastructure for a functioning city in which culture will naturally develop."

Name: Karsten Witt

Job/organisation: Chief executive, South Bank Centre (includes the Royal Festival Hall and Hayward Gallery)

Mayor's first priority: "Maintain and enhance London's position as the cultural capital of the world. As London's ambassador, the mayor must demonstrate support for and pride in London's cultural infrastructure, and help arts organisations in London to increase the diversity of audiences."

Name: Julia Peyton-Jones

Job/organisation: Director, Serpentine Gallery

Mayor's first priority: "Firstly, they should commit to free admission and access for all; secondly, they should harness the vibrancy of the London arts scene and secure its place at the heart of contemporary culture; thirdly, they should abolish art-school tuition fees."

Name: Katharine Doré

Job/organisation: Producer, Adventures in Motion Pictures

Mayor's first priority: "Bring pressure to bear on the Arts Council and the London Arts Board to continue reform; increase the funding that there is for London and make sure that the money actually gets to the artists and is not creamed off by layers and layers of bureaucracy."

Name: J Patrick Greene

Job/organisation: President, Museums Association

Mayor's first priority: "They could do a great job providing grants for local museums that really reflect their communities and provide a first step into culture for lots of people."

Name: David Barrie

Job/organisation: Director, National Art Collections Fund

Mayor's first priority: "The best thing would be if the new Mayor supported free admission to London's national museums and galleries."

Name: Nicholas Payne

Job/organisation: General director, English National Opera

Mayor's first priority: "I should like to welcome the mayor to the Coliseum so they can see what the ENO means to the people of London. The mayors of Paris, Rome and New York care about what goes on in their city's opera houses, and I should like that to be so here."

Name: Cameron Mackintosh

Job/organisation: Producer

Mayor's first priority: "He should sort out dependable, late-running public transport and create litter-and vagrant-free streets for the West End theatres and cinemas."

Name: Jennifer Edwards

Job/organisation: Director of external and strategic relations, London Arts Board

Mayor's first priority: "Social inclusion is the biggest policy issue, but the mayor will wish to do some very practical things quickly. I think the capital access card, the fund for innovation and young people's involvement in live cultural activities, could be quickly facilitated."

Name: Philip Hedley

Job/organisation: Artistic director, Theatre Royal, Stratford East

Mayor's first priority: "To put money and power in the hands of ethnic minority artists, and give them buildings to work from. The contribution black and Asian people already make is enormously valuable, but they could contribute a great deal more if they were given serious support and serious power."

Name: Peter Hall

Job/organisation: Director

Mayor's first priority: "The new mayor should recognise that support of London's great national arts institutions involves supporting scores of small, adventurous satellite organisations around the capital. The centre always needs feeding with new talent and new audiences. Thatcher and her successors, including New Labour, pretty much wrecked the wonderful group of small theatres - Greenwich, Leatherhead, Watford - which used to be the centre of new activity. The slogan of the new mayor in the arts should be, 'Think big by looking after the small.' "

fields.headline: Welsh cabinet secrecy dropped
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Wales: special report
fields.trailText: Rhodri Morgan, the new first secretary for Wales, yesterday broke new ground by publishing minutes of the Welsh assembly cabinet and in the process revealed he is fighting the Treasury to keep control of all the proceeds raised in Wales from the proposed tobacco tax.
fields.body:
Rhodri Morgan, the new first secretary for Wales, yesterday broke new ground by publishing minutes of the Welsh assembly cabinet and in the process revealed he is fighting the Treasury to keep control of all the proceeds raised in Wales from the proposed tobacco tax.

The three pages of minutes, a victory for freedom of information campaigners, also reveal concern about leaks and premature press coverage of job announcements. If the leaks continued "then there could be a damaging effect upon potential future investment and all the agencies concerned needed to respect the investor's wishes on the handling of announcements", the minutes state.

The minutes cover a cabinet meeting on March 13 and are said to be a full account except for issues of commercial confidentiality.

The minutes of the British cabinet are kept secret for 30 years and the home secretary, Jack Straw, is still under pressure from peers to make further concessions over his much-criticised freedom of information bill.

The director of the Campaign for Freedom of Information, Maurice Frankel, praised Mr Morgan. "The minutes reveal business-like, practical and sometimes mundane discussions and suggest that the traditional secrecy in this area may have more to do with protecting mystique than real secrets or highly sensitive discussions.

"The public can be told what is going on without bringing the process of government to its knees."

The minutes were published on the internet in English and Welsh as part of Mr Morgan's drive to make the assembly one of the most open governments in Europe.

Mr Morgan wants all assembly information, including advice to ministers from civil servants, to be made publicly available unless there is an overwhelming reason not to disclose.

The minutes also reveal that Mr Morgan is considering setting up a separate honours awards system, perhaps on St David's day, to recognise the good works undertaken by Welsh men and women. The cabinet is also to discuss the controversial issue of councillors' allowances. There has been criticism in Wales over the level of payments.

The minutes hint at a battle with the Treasury ahead when they state: "The cabinet agreed that a percentage of the revenue from the proposed tobacco tax should come to Wales as part of the Welsh block so that the assembly could determine how it should be spent."

webTitle: TV presenter faces jail over cancer con

fields.headline: TV presenter faces jail over cancer con
fields.trailText: Elizabeth Wagstaff, presenter of the television series Changing Rooms, was yesterday warned by a judge that she faces jail after she admitted conning colleagues out of almost £55,000 by pretending she had terminal cancer.
fields.body:
Elizabeth Wagstaff, presenter of the television series Changing Rooms, was yesterday warned by a judge that she faces jail after she admitted conning colleagues out of almost £55,000 by pretending she had terminal cancer.

The BBC1 makeover expert pleaded guilty to 14 charges of obtaining a money transfer by deception and four charges of obtaining property by deception.

Inner London crown court heard she swindled the wife of fellow host Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen out of £2,000, presenter Anna Ryder Richardson out of £500, and former Blue Peter host Mark Curry out of £1,000.

Wagstaff, of Stevenage, Hertfordshire, who admitted the charges, also took £12,000 from her former boyfriend Mark Thurgood, it was stated.

She had denied 19 charges at an earlier hearing but changed her pleas yesterday. One charge of obtaining money from Mrs Llewelyn-Bowen was allowed to lie on file.

The court heard that Wagstaff's deception of colleagues at Bazal Productions, which makes Changing Rooms for the BBC, started early last year, and that over the course of the year she conned money out of production staff including Michael Jewitt and Caroline Officer, and landscape gardener Peter Beech, who also worked on the show.

Andrew Shaw, defending, said: "Miss Wagstaff is suffering from a psychiatric disorder and further reports would indicate that she continues to suffer from that. She is continuing to receive treatment for that. The basis of mitigation will be that the long history of the disorder has directly led to the committing of these offences."

He added: "She has admitted during her interview each of the allegations and she has never disputed any aspect of the witness statements."

But Judge Quentin Campbell warned Wagstaff she faced going to prison for the offences, which involved a total of £54,150.

"I have to stress that asking for reports is no indication whatsoever that a community sentence is being considered."

The judge released Wagstaff on bail until May 22.

webTitle: Briton held in biggest seizure of ecstasy

fields.headline: Briton held in biggest seizure of ecstasy
fields.trailText: An Australian journalist and a 26-year-old British man have been arrested in north-east Italy for alleged involvement in what is believed to be the world's biggest shipment of ecstasy, Italian police said yesterday.
fields.body:
An Australian journalist and a 26-year-old British man have been arrested in north-east Italy for alleged involvement in what is believed to be the world's biggest shipment of ecstasy, Italian police said yesterday.

The men were arrested on Monday near the town of Udine and police seized a consignment of 333,000 ecstasy tablets, with a street value of around £4m.

The tablets, allegedly found in the back of the British suspect's car, were on their way from Holland to America, police said.

The Australian, a 30-year-old correspondent for an Australian newspaper, lives in Los Angeles and had allegedly flown to Italy to collect them.

"This is the largest ecstasy seizure ever carried out in Europe and perhaps in the world," officials said in a statement.

Colonel Carlo Germi, commander of the revenue guard in Udine, said the Briton was born in Bournemouth and the Australian was from Sydney.

He added that he believed the Briton had bought the drugs in Holland and held them for two months before moving them to Italy.

Trieste anti-Mafia prosecutor Federico Frezza said the arrests were part of an on-going police operation that had already led to 35 arrests for drug trafficking in Italy.

Police had tapped the mobile phone of the alleged Australian drug trafficker but still had difficulty in identifying the time and place of the drug handover because of the extreme circumspection shown by those involved.

A third man, known as Dave, allegedly coordinated the drug consignment arrangements from the United States. "He was the brains behind the operation. We don't know where he lives because he was always contacted by cellphone," Col Germi said.
