webTitle: Apology at last 500 years after Brazil's first mass, bishops admit 'sins' against Indians

fields.headline: Apology at last 500 years after Brazil's first mass, bishops admit 'sins' against Indians
fields.trailText: Five hundred years after the Portuguese celebrated their first mass in Brazil, the country's bishops gathered at Coroa Vermelha yesterday to recreate the moment when Friar Henrique de Coimbra gave thanks to God, four days after the voyagers' safe arrival.
fields.body:
Five hundred years after the Portuguese celebrated their first mass in Brazil, the country's bishops gathered at Coroa Vermelha yesterday to recreate the moment when Friar Henrique de Coimbra gave thanks to God, four days after the voyagers' safe arrival.

It will be held near the same spot where on Saturday police used clubs, tear gas and rubber bullets to break up a crowd of about 2,000 Indians from across Brazil who gathered to protest at Portugal's "invasion".

The Roman Catholic church formally apologised for "sins and errors" committed by its clergy against Indians and black people at the service near Porto Seguro, 500 miles north-east of Rio de Janeiro.

Around 15,000 people, including 300 bishops, heard the Most Rev Jayme Chemello, president of the National Brazilian Bishops' Conference, declare:

"We ask the Lord for forgiveness for the sins committed against our brothers, especially against the Indians whose rights have not always been respected. We ask forgiveness for not always having respected the dignity of our black brothers and sisters."

But Pataxo Indians, who protested at the ceremony, rejected the apology. Their spokesman, Matalaue, said: "Apologies are not enough. We want our dignity. We weren't respected 500 years ago and we continue not being respected today."

fields.headline: Helen Tomkinson
fields.standfirst: Ski racer with memories of Hitler at the Olympics
fields.trailText: The British ski racing champion, Helen Tomkinson, who has died aged 86, took part in the first Winter Olympic Games, at Garmisch-Partenkirchen in 1936, made notorious by its opening ceremony and march-past under the eye of Adolf Hitler.
fields.body:
The British ski racing champion, Helen Tomkinson, who has died aged 86, took part in the first Winter Olympic Games, at Garmisch-Partenkirchen in 1936, made notorious by its opening ceremony and march-past under the eye of Adolf Hitler.

In those days skiing as Helen Blane, Mrs Tomkinson would recall the silence in the arena as the British team marched in. The British Olympic Association could not afford uniforms. They wore ages-old team sweaters under old-fashioned peak caps and were still shivering from their long wait in the wet cold.

Police and security guards were everywhere. The huge German crowd waited breathlessly. Then the British team did what, at a lengthy meeting the previous evening, had been agreed. They put their arms out sidewise in the formal manner of the Olympic salute, but over the loudspeakers the announcer boomed, "It is the Heil Hitler salute!" and the crowd burst in to wild applause. Soon afterwards, Mrs Tomkinson recalled, came the turn of the Swiss, who performed only "eyes right," and were received in stony silence.

She was one of the British team of six and finished 25th, the event being decided on the combined result of downhill and slalom, Alpine skiing having been accepted as a discipline for the first time thanks to the lobbying of Britain's Arnold Lunn. The experience of skiing for her country convinced her she should carry on, although racers had little or no support. "In the three weeks before the Olympics it was wonderful to have training at Muerren, organised and paid for - unheard of in those days."

Mrs Tomkinson was in good company. The British had one of the strongest women's teams of the time. Esme McKinnon had won the first ever World Championship in 1931; Evie Pinching, a member of the 1936 Garmisch team, three weeks later went on to win the World Championship downhill at Innsbruck. It was a race which came to be known as the "Innsbruck Massacre." Mrs Tomkinson was one of the few to finish a course frozen to sheet ice. Men racers formed a line down the finishing straight to stop the more exhausted women racers crashing on to tree stumps.

Helen Blane began to ski at the age of 12 in Villars, Switzerland. It was a time when skiers packed long dresses and evening jackets for formal parties. Her mother, Lady Blane, was keen Helen should learn languages, and after a year in France she spent the 1934-35 winter season in Kitzbuehel, learning German and competing in the local ski club races. She was quickly good enough to make the British ladies' team, finding the money to pay for herself from work in the winter sports department of Woollands in Knightsbridge, or guiding Alpine walking tours.

Women racers in the mid-30s still wore plus fours or gabardine trousers, and raced on heavy wooden skis without release bindings. Helen Blane competed in the 1937, 1938 and 1939 World Championships at Chamonix, Engelberg and Zakopane and went on to win the Czech international championship, a title she was to hold for many years. Holding firm to her Austrian friends, she would speak to them where others, after the Anschluss, and the crushing together of Austrian and German teams, refused to do so. She also had kind words for Christl Cranz, German winner of the 1936 Olympic Alpine gold, who, she said, took good care of her team and always trained with the weakest member.

Of highly independent mind, she was guiding a Thomas Cook tour in Austria in August, 1939, when a Polish-Jewish woman in her railway carriage asked her to carry a parcel through customs into Switzerland. The woman was searched, but Helen safely brought the package through. During the war, her languages came in useful as a censorship officer and she worked for a time at Wormwood Scrubs prison before moving to Holborn.

In post-war years she became a senior technical delegate with the International Ski Federation, serving regularly on Olympic and World Championship juries, and supervising the safety of courses and rule observance. She sat on the FIS ladies' committee for 20 years, and in 1983 became only the second woman made an honorary member by that organisation. She was chairman of the Kandahar Club from 1962 to 1967 and as chair of the FIS Citadin committee from 1975 to 1983 worked assiduously for amateur racers in an increasingly professional environment.

In 1979 she was awarded an MBE. She had married Bill Tomkinson in 1940 and is survived by her two sons and two daughters, one of whom, Diana, skied with the 1960s British team.

 Helen Tomkinson, ski racer, born June 25 1913; died April 12 2000

webTitle: City makes it big as Brazil looks inwards

fields.headline: City makes it big as Brazil looks inwards
fields.trailText: Fortune seekers are flocking to a remote city which could transform Brazil's sparsely populated central savannah into a hive of agriculture, tourism and industry.
fields.body:
Fortune seekers are flocking to a remote city which could transform Brazil's sparsely populated central savannah into a hive of agriculture, tourism and industry.

Twelve years ago Palmas did not exist. Now it has a population of 160,000, making it Brazil's fastest-growing city. "It's madness. It's unprecendented," says the mayor, Odir Rocha. "We feel we are making history. In a few years Palmas will be the great metropolis of this whole area."

The city is the most striking example of Brazil's shift of gravity from its populated coast towards its backlands. The new frontier is the cerrado, a tropical savannah surrounded by the Atlantic rainforest to the east and the Amazon jungle to the north.

"We want to make the area just like the midwest is for the United States - a big producer of grains, food and energy," says Livio de Carvalho, planning secretary of Tocantins state.

The opening-up of the cerrado began in the 1950s with the construction of Brasilia, the national capital, 600 miles inland from Rio de Janeiro. Development has accelerated since the creation in 1988 of Tocantins and its capital, Palmas, 400 miles north of Brasilia.

There is construction across Palmas - workmen are building an international airport and a football stadium. It is the only city in Brazil where the telephone system is entirely digital and, according to the mayor, 98% of the population drinks treated water.

And the state is pushing forward with projects including the building of six hydroelectric dams on the Tocantins river, a railway, a waterway and new roads.

Locals believe that Tocantins can lead Brazil to a new future. Governor Jose Siqueira Campos says: "We are geographically in the centre of Brazil.

"We want to be the state that speaks for Brazil. Maybe we can't do it now but we will when the infrastructure is in place. We really feel that we are trying to put the country on a better track."

But there are fears among green groups about the cost of development. "The infrastructure projects will almost inevitably fragment the cerrado of Tocantins to a very large degree," says Professor Alexandre Araujo of Brasilia University. "The cerrado is one of the world's biodiversity hotspots."

Future prosperity is not assured. Tocantins' economy is so far almost entirely based on government spending, and there are worries about how long Palmas can sustain such high growth, since most newcomers are unskilled labourers from all over the country.

Fatima Dourado, of the Palmas Human Rights Centre, says the city is sitting on a social timebomb. "The government says 60 families arrive every day. Yet there is no system in place to receive them.

"Already 4,500 people have nowhere to stay. The state has propaganda around Brazil to attract investors, but it attracts poor people instead."

But the boom continues. Last week, Francisco Alves, a 49-year-old electrician, arrived in Palmas after a 36-hour journey from his home town.

"I came looking for work. But all I have got is promises. Palmas is OK if you want to invest, but for someone like me there is nothing."

fields.headline: Ex-rebels swap guns for guesthouses
fields.trailText: The matronly Carolina Alegria owns a guest house in San Salvador, the capital of El Salvador. She can also fire guns and use grenades.
fields.body:
The matronly Carolina Alegria owns a guest house in San Salvador, the capital of El Salvador. She can also fire guns and use grenades.

Her husband Damien runs an internet service from their hotel. But back when he was a spokesman for the guerrillas, he was the feared face of leftwing insurgency.

When El Salvador's 12-year civil war ended, combatants from the anti-government FMLN were in a perfect position to capitalise on their knowledge and open bed and breakfasts. For more than a decade they had guided foreign journalists through rebel-held territory and accommodated Europeans and Americans who came to El Salvador and Nicaragua to show solidarity with the revolutionaries.

Yet the success of these guesthouses in the capital's Boulevard de los Heroes district is presenting these Marxists turned capitalists with a serious crisis of conscience.

"We ask ourselves daily whether we are exploiting people. Making money is a dilemma for many FMLN businessmen," Mr Alegria says.

A former captain in the FMLN, Mr Alegria tried without success to make a living from selling earrings and cheese before setting up the Oasis hotel in 1993, which he has lovingly decorated with a painting of the revolutionary Che Guevara, flags and photographs of his comrades in fatigues.

But selling products from rural communities was never as lucrative as catering to western tourists and employees of the western non-governmental organisations who flocked to El Salvador at the end of the war.

Even the Mexican Zapatistas paid a good whack for their bed and board when they were in town recently.

The owner of the airy International Hotel, Tirso Canales, who is a poet as well, was once the official representative of the FMLN in Costa Rica. A framed letter from Fidel Castro complete with Cuban postmarks is proudly displayed in reception.

But revolutionary poetry does not pay the bills quite like a group of Swedish professors or Mexico's football team.

The success of a bed and breakfast owned by Rosano Calderon, a former rebel who spent most of the war in exile in Cuba, enables her fashionably dressed son to while away his weekends on the internet. "We've moved a long away from the revolution," she sighs.

The commercial success of these combatants has come to the attention of other less entrepreneurial FMLN activists. "We have been shunned by some of our comrades," admits Mr Alegria.

Also, running a bed and breakfast requires long hours. "I don't have time for political meetings any more," Mr Canales says, although he tries to fit in a chapter of Marx every morning before welcoming his high-paying guests.

The Alegrias recently enrolled in university courses, Damien in economics and Carolina in business and administration, in part to solve their intellectual dilemmas.

They chat about "adding value" to their hotel service by offering tourists the opportunity to join political discussion groups.

"It's all very well to demand an equal distribution of wealth but it's important to learn how to create that wealth," says Mr Alegria.

fields.headline: A stylish romance
fields.standfirst:
Derek Malcolm's 100 greatest movies. This week, number 65: George Cukor's The Philadelphia Story
Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Derek Malcolm's 100 greatest movies.This week, number 65: George Cukor's The Philadelphia Story
fields.body:
George Cukor has often been called a pre-eminent director of women. And that he was, like certain other gay film-makers. Katharine Hepburn, Greta Garbo, Ingrid Bergman and Judy Garland could testify to that. It would be more accurate, however, to cast him as a film-maker who paid particular attention to performance and relationships.

Cukor had just about the longest continuous career of any major director who worked within the mainstream. He survived Hollywood's often cavalier treatment of original talent, including the blow of being fired by David Selznick a few days into the shoot of Gone With the Wind after coaching Vivien Leigh. When you look at the sort of movies he might have been asked to direct now were he still at work, you long for the wit, humanity and the sense of style evinced by such classics as The Philadelphia Story.

The film is not, perhaps, the funniest romantic comedy ever made. Cukor attempted to pitch Donald Ogden Stewart and Waldo Salt's adaptation of the Philip Barry play into the realms of ironic social significance, by suggesting that it isn't only the rich who have vices and the poor who have virtue. But considering the talkative nature of the film, it moves marvellously and the performances would be very hard to beat because they are based on the wit of character rather than lines.

In the silent opening sequence, Cary Grant, as Hepburn's former husband, is thrown out of the front door of her wealthy parents' ritzy home in Philadelphia. When Hepburn, soon to be married to a less dissolute lover, appears, she breaks one of his favourite golf clubs, throws them after him and slams the door. Grant doesn't give up and rings the doorbell again. When Hepburn answers, he pushes her in the face.

This perfectly timed sequence tells us everything. Admittedly we are in a sense primed, since the two stars had appeared before as antagonists, notably in Cukor's Sylvia Scarlett and in Howard Hawks's Bringing up Baby. And Hepburn's furious reaction turned to advantage the reputation she had acquired as arrogant and mannish, and thus box office poison.

Hepburn had starred in the play on Broadway; she acquired the movie rights and sold them to MGM with the proviso that she was the star and had the choice of director and co-stars. It seems extraordinary now that she had left Hollywood in high dudgeon before this film, feeling totally unappreciated by the public. Katharine Hepburn, Greta Garbo, Ingrid Bergman and Judy Garland could testify to that. It would be more accurate, however, to cast him as a film-maker who paid particular attention to performance and relationships. Cukor had just about the longest continuous career of any major director who worked within the mainstream. He survived Hollywood's often cavalier treatment of original talent, including the blow of being fired by David Selznick a few days into the shoot of Gone With the Wind after coaching Vivien Leigh. fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.standfirst: Quotes of the week
fields.trailText: Quotes of the week
fields.body:
"I don't have a partner, I have a 'somebody' and he comes and goes. I would certainly never live with anyone again. I'm not good at it and I know I would bust it all up, so what you've got, you might as well preserve"
Honor Blackman, Hello!

"Mary Harron, a former flame of Tony Blair at Oxford University, revealed that she fell for the PM because he was 'cute' ... So where has this alpha male image of a tough leader surrounded by football-loving cronies come from? ... Could it be that Mr Blair presents one face to the ladies and another to the lads? That would explain why he keeps them separate. Men in the inner circle and women on the lower ranks"
Laura Kibby, Express

"I didn't get to be who I am without being honest. I had to include a lot of sex because sex was a lot to do with my life. We have an oversexualised culture in terms of the media, yet we're terrified of really talking about it, whether it's the menopause, or the sexual life of a woman, how we enjoy our bodies"
Cybill Shepherd on her tell-all autobiography, Cybill Disobedience, Sunday Times Magazine

"I shouldn't tell you what these are called in the States. They're fanny-packs. The behind is known as the fanny over there"
Patrick Duffy, sporting a bumbag, explains all, Evening Standard

"When I do a strip, I think that people are really testing each other's reaction. If there's a really funny, open-minded person, people become nice and create a good atmosphere. If they're all Catholic and square-minded, people become very moody and sometimes complain or shout ... I really love to do it in the tube. 'Underground' sounds really sexy"
Performance artist Natsuki Uruma, currently bringing pole dancing to tube travellers, Sleazenation

fields.headline: Kiss you, pal? Kiss off!
fields.standfirst: A new survey reveals that British men don't, er, embrace.  William Leith explains why
fields.trailText: A new survey reveals that British men don't, er, embrace.  William Leith explains why.
fields.body:
How many times have I kissed, or been kissed by, British men? I can remember a few. They have all been tense, difficult occasions. Once, at a party, I saw a man I thought was chatting up my girlfriend. If he wanted to kiss her, I told him, he'd have to kiss me first. What followed was a strange, spiky snog - half headbutt, half wrestle. We had both been drinking. We separated uneasily. I found myself not knowing what to think. Had I won? I thought so. But I think he thought he had won, too.

Another time I was kissed by a man was at Ibrox stadium in Glasgow, the home of Rangers. A neutral spectator sitting in the Celtic seats, I stood and clapped when Celtic scored an equalising goal. I didn't see the kiss coming. My kisser was an elderly man. He kissed me on the mouth, quite hard, and hugged me. It was a sort of triumphant attack. There was aggression involved. During the kiss, I realised he was kissing me legitimately - one of the only times a man is free to kiss another man is when their team scores. He had mistaken me for a Celtic fan. I went along with it. It was all right, I told myself. It was fine.

But it's not usually all right. There are few heterosexual guy-on-guy role models when it comes to kissing. The only one I can think of is the scene in Planes, Trains And Automobiles, starring Steve Martin and John Candy, in which the two big guys find themselves sharing a bed. In the morning, the half-asleep Martin cuddles his bedmate, mistaking him for a woman. When he opens his eyes, he's mortified. Martin darts out of bed and does a dance of horror, as if exorcising demons. When Candy gets out of bed, the two men, both terrified, back away from each other. To calm things down, Martin begins talking about his team, the Chicago Bears. "What about the Bears?" he shouts. Only then does Candy start to relax.

Anglo-Saxon guys find it hard to kiss each other, even when it's just a peck on the cheek. You can feel the other man's neck stiffen up when you do it. Of course, you can do it if one of you is French or Italian, or if one of you is pretending to be French or Italian. You can do it when you declare it in advance as a joke. But that's about it.

"Countries like ours which have a powerful military history tend to be a bit more inhibited," says the anthropologist Desmond Morris. So it doesn't surprise me at all that a survey published this week reveals that British men feel uncomfortable about kissing each other. Of course they do - they always have. It's going to take more than a few decades of feminism to change things.

Of 1,000 men polled by NOP, 60% said they would rather shake a man's hand than kiss him; 62% said they didn't kiss other men in case people thought they were gay; 23% of Scotsmen said they would kiss a man only if they were drunk or celebrating a sporting triumph. Perhaps most ominously, over half of Yorkshiremen were prepared to answer a male kiss with physical violence.

Why? Partly because they don't want to seem gay and partly because they don't want to seem vulnerable. When footballers, or football supporters, kiss each other, it is an act of mania, not an act of affection. It is a moment outside control. The kissing takes place at the moment of least vulnerability - when your team has scored.

Men, who also see the public kissing of women as an act of ownership, of anti-vulnerability, are naturally wary of kissing each other. What if the kissee is a Yorkshireman? It's a big risk to take. On a night out, men subtly signal their heterosexuality to each other; they narrow their eyes with approval at the entrance of an attractive woman and nod at each other with relief.

Maybe this reluctance of men to kiss each other is not such a bad thing. Gloria Steinem once wondered what if men, instead of women, had periods; she surmised that they would hang around on street corners and say things like: "Yeah, man, I'm on the rag!"

Imagine what men would be like if they stopped worrying about kissing each other. You'd hear them in pubs, boasting about it. "I got my tongue down his throat," they'd say. "He was begging for it."

fields.headline: Sobs for the boys
fields.standfirst: They scream, they moan and they've just shot a boy band into the record books.  Lucy Barrick talks to star-struck teenage girls about the pop fan phenomenon
fields.trailText: They scream, they moan and they've just shot a boy band into the record books.  Lucy Barrick talks to star-struck teenage girls about the pop fan phenomenon.
fields.body:
Ever since Elvis first swung his pelvis and the Beatles yeah yeah yeah-ed, teenage girls the world over have screamed much louder than the songs their idols have sung to them. And these days, there's no shortage of teen god material.

Latest boy band sensation Westlife are set to enter the Guinness Book of Records after their first five singles hit the charts at number one, while Stateside trio Hanson will next week release the follow-up to their eight million-selling debut album. While adults may tut at the girls' gormless adoration, or pity them for being exploited by cynical marketing men, the girls know better. Loving a boy band isn't just about screaming

Crushes of all kinds are a good preparation for proper adult relationships. Being obsessed with a fantasy figure allows girls to experience the agony and ecstasy of first love without the dangers inherent in a real relationship. This sexual angle should not be overlooked. Grown-ups won't admit it, but teen girls can get pretty lewd when discussing the objects of their affection. They might not have had their first kiss, but they know what they want to do to Boyzone.

The boys in these bands willingly turn themselves into sexual objects for the gratification of girls. The hyper-sexualisation of female teen stars - Britney, Christina, Billie - may be viewed with suspicion and their male fanbase probably contains as many 40 as 14-year-olds, but teenage girls are lusting over men left, right and centre, and no one bats an eyelid.

Claudine and Angelique, 15, and Andrea, 17, are all fans of Sisqo, singer in R&B group Dru Hill who is currently at number three with his solo hit Thong Song. They have travelled all the way from Thornton Heath in Surrey to central London to see him perform in the flesh. They're captivated by "his voice, the way he moves, his totally fit body," Andrea says. "Everything about him is fine."

Claire and Tina, both 14 and from Bedford, are "mad 5ive fans". Tina says: "Abs is so horny. I really love him."

"They're better than Westlife and Boyzone because they don't just do slow songs," Claire explains. "They've got wicked dance routines and they dress better than other bands. Most of our friends like 5ive as well. Some girls at school like weird stuff like Travis, but that's boring."

This mixture of put-on worldliness and impossible-to-disguise innocence is typical of feverish adolescent fandom. But while girls once dreamed of marrying their heart-throbs, today's fans are more savvy. Claire explains: "It says in all the magazines that most of them are too busy with work to have girlfriends, but everyone needs somebody to love them, right?"

The main accusation levelled at boy bands (apart from that they can't sing) is that they are merely tools to part young girls from their pocket money. Looking at the teen mags, the two-part CD singles with fold-out posters, the limited edition this and exclusive that, you could be forgiven for agreeing. But that would be to do these young women a disservice.

Sophie Wilson, editor of girls' magazine J17, says: "Most teenagers these days are pretty sophisticated and media-savvy. They know when they are being sold to and they know all the behind-the-scenes stuff, like Ronan Keating managing Westlife."

Liking a boy band is a conscious choice that goes beyond just thinking a member of the group is cute. For one thing, if you can get past the musical snobbery, a lot of these bands do make decent pop records.

"People like the Backstreet Boys and 5ive make great entertainment," Wilson points out. What's more: "A lot of it is to do with establishing your own identity and creating a sense of self. It's buying into a whole scene, so it affects the clothes you wear, the places you hang out, your friends."

The friendships formed around boy bands are another positive aspect of the phenomenon. Groups of girls get together to talk about the bands, listen to the music and bunk off school to wait outside Top of the Pops. But when interest in the group inevitably fades, the friendships can remain. I made a very good friend at the age of 11 because we both loved Duran Duran. While we may (secretly) still be fond of them, our friendship has been far more enduring.

"I never really consciously thought I'd marry Simon le Bon," she says now, "but a small part of me still imagined I probably would. Looking at him now, I'm quite glad I didn't!"

Today's fans are just as down to earth. Asked what will last longer, their friendship or their love of 5ive, Claire says: "I don't think I'll ever stop liking them, but my friends are more important really." Angelique adds: "I'd never do anything bad to my mates for the sake of a man, no matter if he's a singer or whatever. No question."

Being into a pop group and having a crush on a band member is something that unites generations of women. When the Take That fans of a few years ago become mothers themselves, they'll understand their daughters' obsessions. There is no difference between the girls who screamed at the Fab Four back in the 60s and the girls who love 5ive now. When I was obsessed with Duran Duran, my mother could relate to it because she and her best friend had been Animals fans. "I thought Eric Burdon was lovely," she says. "And I still play their records now."

Far from there being something weak about girls being into boy bands, it is empowering. There's a big difference between wanting to be like the Spice Girls or Billie Piper and wanting to have sex with one of the Backstreet Boys. The current crop of female pop stars don't make particularly good role models. Billie had a breakdown at 16, certain All Saints members are better known for their string of celebrity boyfriends than for their singing and the remaining Spice Girls spend most of their time bitching about Geri.

Young girls don't worry about not being good enough to date a pop star; part of them knows it's just a fantasy. But they do worry that they are not as pretty, thin or fashionable as those teeny starlets. If girls seriously looked to these women for guidance, they'd wear loads of make-up and hardly any clothes, go on weird diets and date a battalion of unsuitable older men.

Basically, they would grow up and grow boring way too soon. But if you like NSync or A1 or Point Break, you just want to go out with your girlfriends, lust over some gorgeous bloke, singalong with some good pop songs and generally have a laugh. Wilson sums it up: "The whole thing shouldn't be taken too seriously. The bottom line is that liking these bands is fun. It might just be part of growing up, but if that's true, then I'm certainly not a grown-up yet."

webTitle: IRA men back in high security jail

fields.headline: IRA men back in high security jail
fields.standfirst:
Anger as Dublin's transfer order follows escape fears

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The last 10 IRA prisoners in the Irish Republic were yesterday transferred back to Portlaoise, the country's maximum security jail, amid fears they were planning an escape attempt.
fields.body:
The last 10 IRA prisoners in the Irish Republic were yesterday transferred back to Portlaoise, the country's maximum security jail, amid fears they were planning an escape attempt.

One is Pearse McAuley, who broke out of Brixton prison in south London with a smuggled gun nine years ago.

Sinn Fein reacted furiously, and dismissed as nonsense the suggestions of a planned jailbreak. It said the development further soured the political atmosphere ahead of a push to save the Good Friday agreement, and it was seeking talks with the Irish government.

Prison officials announced the move after warder Tom Shaughnessy was held hostage on Sunday in a drunken incident at Castlerea open prison, Co Roscommon.

He was freed unharmed, but has been on sick leave since the incident.

Colleagues, who were considering strike action, were taken aback. One said the move could have "huge ramifications because their treatment is a part of the Good Friday agreement. We are genuinely surprised."

The IRA inmates had been celebrating the Easter Rising of 1916. Bottles of vodka were found in a follow-up search.

The inmates had been transferred four months ago from the strict regime at Portlaoise prison to Castlerea, then newly opened. They enjoyed considerable freedom there, living unsupervised in bungalows, and according to one report, being able to order deliveries of Chinese food. None of the 10 is entitled to early release under the agreement.

Those transferred back to Portlaoise include a man jailed earlier this month for 20 months for assault after vigilantes killed a Dublin heroin addict. Two others are also anti-drugs activists.

One of the prisoners locked the warder in a kitchen. He was said to be angry that Mr Shaughnessy, who had come to deliver a message, had failed to ask permission to enter the IRA chalet, and the warder was freed only when Kevin Walsh, the IRA's officer commanding, intervened.

Republicans said the anti-drugs activists were allowed into the IRA's accommodation for their own protection. But it is widely believed the IRA is behind a series of attacks on drugs dealers.

McAuley, serving 14 years for manslaughter, and three others were jailed last year over the shooting of detective Jerry McCabe, 53. He was killed in June 1996 during an abortive IRA robbery in Ardare, Co Limerick.

Bertie Ahern, the taoiseach, sought to quell public outrage in the Irish Republic by announcing they would not qualify for early release.

But the decision to move them to Castlerea last December was widely seen as an initial step towards reducing their sentences.

Unionist politicians lambasted Mr Ahern for hypocrisy. They compare his decision to deny early release to police killers in the republic with his insistence that RUC murderers must qualify in Northern Ireland.

But now Sinn Fein is leading criticism of him. It believes the decision to transfer the IRA men back to Portlaoise was aimed at reassuring the garda that Mr McCabe's killers will serve their sentences, and say that the breakout claims were an excuse.

They are angry, too, at the arrests this year of three IRA men on extradition warrants. One, Nessan Quinlivan, escaped from Brixton with McAuley in July 1991. All are now free on bail.

One is Pearse McAuley, who broke out of Brixton prison in south London with a smuggled gun nine years ago. Sinn Fein reacted furiously, and dismissed as nonsense the suggestions of a planned jailbreak. It said the development further soured the political atmosphere ahead of a push to save the Good Friday agreement, and it was seeking talks with the Irish government. Prison officials announced the move after warder Tom Shaughnessy was held hostage on Sunday in a drunken incident at Castlerea open prison, Co Roscommon. He was freed unharmed, but has been on sick leave since the incident. Colleagues, who were considering strike action, were taken aback. One said the move could have "huge ramifications because their treatment is a part of the Good Friday agreement. We are genuinely surprised." The IRA inmates had been celebrating the Easter Rising of 1916. Bottles of vodka were found in a follow-up search. The inmates had been transferred four months ago from the strict regime at Portlaoise prison to Castlerea, then newly opened. They enjoyed considerable freedom there, living unsupervised in bungalows, and according to one report, being able to order deliveries of Chinese food. None of the 10 is entitled to early release under the agreement. Those transferred back to Portlaoise include a man jailed earlier this month for 20 months for assault after vigilantes killed a Dublin heroin addict. Two others are also anti-drugs activists. One of the prisoners locked the warder in a kitchen. He was said to be angry that Mr Shaughnessy, who had come to deliver a message, had failed to ask permission to enter the IRA chalet, and the warder was freed only when Kevin Walsh, the IRA's officer commanding, intervened. Republicans said the anti-drugs activists were allowed into the IRA's accommodation for their own protection. But it is widely believed the IRA is behind a series of attacks on drugs dealers. McAuley, serving 14 years for manslaughter, and three others were jailed last year over the shooting of detective Jerry McCabe, 53. He was killed in June 1996 during an abortive IRA robbery in Ardare, Co Limerick. Bertie Ahern, the taoiseach, sought to quell public outrage in the Irish Republic by announcing they would not qualify for early release. But the decision to move them to Castlerea last December was widely seen as an initial step towards reducing their sentences. Unionist politicians lambasted Mr Ahern for hypocrisy. They compare his decision to deny early release to police killers in the republic with his insistence that RUC murderers must qualify in Northern Ireland. But now Sinn Fein is leading criticism of him. It believes the decision to transfer the IRA men back to Portlaoise was aimed at reassuring the garda that Mr McCabe's killers will serve their sentences, and say that the breakout claims were an excuse. They are angry, too, at the arrests this year of three IRA men on extradition warrants. One, Nessan Quinlivan, escaped from Brixton with McAuley in July 1991. All are now free on bail.

fields.headline: Opportunity knocks
fields.standfirst:
Mr Hague thinks he has spotted a life raft

Tories in opposition: special report
Tony Martin murder case: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague, to use the language of the hour, has "previous" on this topic. He has spoken before - at the last two Conservative party conferences, in fact - of the lunacy of a system which punishes the victim but not the criminal, which appears tougher on the citizen who defends his home than on the villain who breaks into it.
fields.body:
William Hague, to use the language of the hour, has "previous" on this topic. He has spoken before - at the last two Conservative party conferences, in fact - of the lunacy of a system which punishes the victim but not the criminal, which appears tougher on the citizen who defends his home than on the villain who breaks into it. This, according to the Conservative leader's aides, gives him credibility when he voices the "anger and resentment among millions of law-abiding British people" following the conviction of Tony Martin, the Norfolk farmer who shot and killed a 16-year-old intruder who broke into his home. That is what he sought to do with a tub-thumping speech in Warwickshire yesterday.

It was classic Hague: all plain-speaking and apparent common sense. Of course it would be bonkers if burglars enjoyed more rights than their victims; of course it would be wrong for citizens to feel unprotected in their own homes. He will no doubt have struck an extra chord when he called for the law on self-defence to take into account not just the actual threat to homeowners from an intruder, but the threat as they see it. Others will agree that excessive use of lethal force should not always constitute murder; sometimes it should be reduced to manslaughter. Much of that will come over as utterly sensible.

But offering a reasoned contribution to the improvement of our criminal justice system was not the object of yesterday's exercise. Instead it was a demonstration of cheap, exploitative politics at its worst. Mr Hague did not want to reduce public distrust in British justice - rather he wanted to fuel it. He sought yesterday to play to Britons' fears by exaggerating the threat that confronts us. In so doing, he gave succour to the acolytes of vigilante justice - a phenomenon far more likely to bring our legal system "close to collapse" than any of the mirage dangers conjured up by the leader of the opposition.

For, as Clare Dyer and Alan Travis make clear on our news pages, almost every one of the concerns stoked up by the Tory leader yesterday is, to use another word of our time, bogus. He complains that burglars are allowed to roam the land, despite dozens of recent convictions to their name. He chooses to ignore the fact that, since December 1999, legislation initiated by the Tories forces a burglar convicted of a third offence to serve a minimum of three years. He demands "honesty in sentencing," choosing to ignore the January 1998 edict which obliges judges to spell out the minimum sentence any convict would serve - an edict known, coincidentally, as honesty in sentencing. The Tory leader also ignores the obvious remedy for the Tony Martin problem: abolition of the mandatory life sentence for murder. That would allow judges to be lenient in cases of excessive force used for self-defence. But Mr Hague ignores that: perhaps because it would please few of the core Tory voters he needs to win over in time for next month's local elections.

For that is what all this is about. The Conservative leader is playing politics with justice. Like an American district attorney seeking to win votes by promising to electrocute a hated murderer, William Hague is exploiting a specific legal case for political gain. And, to use a word his aides are using themselves, Mr Hague has previous in this area. He has already whipped up lowest common denominator fears on asylum seekers. Now he is doing the same with the right to self-defence. Mr Hague is fast becoming the ambulance-chaser of British politics: searching for trouble, and milking it.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Costing The Earth | Evening Concert
fields.body:
The new series of Costing The Earth (9.0pm, Radio 4) opens with a campaign for a "safer" cigarette. Alex Kirby accepts that, with four million deaths a year attributable to tobacco products, safety can be no more than a relative concept. But he argues that manufacturers could do far more to exclude toxic chemicals from their product. The political difficulty, apparently, is that to produce "safe" cigarettes would implicitly acknowledge that current lines are unsafe.

In the Evening Concert (9.0pm, Classic FM) Nicholas Tresilian celebrates Sergei Prokofiev's birthday. His early and prodigious talent (an opera at the age of nine) more or less ensured Prokofiev's development as an enfant terrible amid the stifling musical orthodoxy of St Petersburg. He got away with it in the early Stalinist years but was eventually forced into a humiliating recantation of his decadent "formalism". Stalin's welcome death brought no relief, however: Prokofiev died on the same day.

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst: Joss Whedon, producer, Buffy The Vampire Slayer
fields.trailText: Joss Whedon, producer, Buffy The Vampire Slayer.
fields.body:
I've just finished shooting Buffy and Angel for the season, then I'll edit for a couple of months and work with writers on the next series.

We structure the show around what the kids are going through emotionally. The ideas have to come from our own personal lives and experience, not monster movies. People come to me with ideas for a long-lost-son plot or revenge-of-the-evil-twin story and I say, "And how did you feel when that happened to you?" And they say "Er, well it didn't..."

I'm lucky to be surrounded by intelligent writers, and eventually I'll skedaddle. But for now I still have loads of Buffy stories in my head.

I think about writing constantly. I produce the shows for 12 hours a day, five days a week and what time I have spare I tinker with writing. I write at home, at the office or in cafes. I sometimes work a 20-hour day, and when both shows are running, I do all-night sessions. Writing is a drug. I don't feel any good if I'm not doing it.

I'm about to take a vacation which I'll spend writing a comic book. It's called Fray, and it's a limited series which sets the Slayer 500 years in the future, long after Buffy is dead. I've written one issue and I'm halfway through the second. It's more fantasy-based than Buffy and I'm going to having flying cars in it - because I love them.

What I'd like to do is write a show about Winchester public school, which I attended for a while. I spent my childhood watching Monty Python and wanting to be British. Then when I got there and realised what the British really think of Americans, it made me very sad.

 The Buffy The Vampire Slayer Box Set (Season Two, Part II) is released on April 24 by 20th Century Fox Home Entertainment, £34.99.

fields.headline: Court challenge reprieves listed buildings
fields.trailText: The government is facing high court action to prevent it from demolishing a group of listed buildings in London.
fields.body:
The government is facing high court action to prevent it from demolishing a group of listed buildings in London.

The Department of the Environment, Camden council and London Underground are being asked to explain why they intended to use legislation passed by the Conservatives to speed up the Channel tunnel rail link to tear down the Victorian railway milk terminus at King's Cross for an entirely different purpose.

Normally planning permission is required to destroy listed buildings, but none was sought, so the high court has required the three "conspirators" to explain - giving the cobbled platforms, designed in a v-shape for use by horse-drawn wagons, a reprieve.

At the heart of the action is the development of 150 acres of railway land behind King's Cross and St Pancras stations.

The case against the government is that the Channel tunnel rail link legislation cannot be used to demolish buildings and start the development unless the works are associated with the link. At present there is no certainty that the second leg of the link, joining Stratford in east London to St Pancras, will ever be built, because the £2bn needed from the private sector to complete the work has not been found.

The government still claims that construction of this leg will start next year and be completed by 2007, but lawyers say that cannot justify speculative demolition of listed buildings.

The property company working with the government has signed an agreement with the joint venture developers Argent Group and St George and is pressing ahead with plans to demolish listed buildings.

Buildings at the site have repeatedly been featured in films and television shows in "atmospheric" scenes of Victorian London, and the Victorian Society wants them to be part of a World Heritage site. But they stand in the way of the government, which is the landlord, and developers: both will make money if they are torn down whether the rail link is built or not.

Under an agreement made by John Prescott with the consortium London & Continental Railways in 1998 the government gets half the money from any money-making property developments at King's Cross.

LCR is supposed to start the rail link next year but has not raised the money so far, and Railtrack, which is required to take up an option to back the scheme, will not decide whether it wants to until June.

The sticking point is the 14.25 miles of tunnel through Essex and east London required to join the rail link on its final leg from the Channel tunnel to St Pancras. The astronomical cost overruns on the underground Jubilee line extension will have frightened away most investors.

The government is prepared to back the scheme to the tune of £3.8bn, partly through a bond issue, but that leaves £2bn to be raised.

Meanwhile, the government and Camden council, which wants the area "improved", were prepared to let the developers start demolishing the milk terminus - to provide a builder's yard for contractors improving King's Cross underground ticket hall.

The high court's decision to allow a judicial review is a victory for Julien Burcher, a tenant of Stanley Buildings, a group of Victorian model workers' flats also due for demolition. Mr Burcher, who with other tenants has fought to save the area for years, said: "It is time the conspirators who want to flatten this area without justification are forced to explain their actions."

fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: Matthew Norman
fields.trailText: •It is with delight that I announce the Diary's inaugural Stephen Glover Spring Festival. Some will see the festival as an intriguing modern twist on an ancient pagan rite, the airing of old anecdote acting as a symbolic reaffirmation of vernal renewal. Others will prefer a psycho-analytic interpretation which states that, ever since his stint as Independent on Sunday editor came to so traumatic a close, Stephen has been in "denial" - using his role as a media pundit to visit on other, more lavishly talented editors than he the failings he cannot face up to in himself (a classic case of "transference").
fields.body:
It is with delight that I announce the Diary's inaugural Stephen Glover Spring Festival. Some will see the festival as an intriguing modern twist on an ancient pagan rite, the airing of old anecdote acting as a symbolic reaffirmation of vernal renewal. Others will prefer a psycho-analytic interpretation which states that, ever since his stint as Independent on Sunday editor came to so traumatic a close, Stephen has been in "denial" - using his role as a media pundit to visit on other, more lavishly talented editors than he the failings he cannot face up to in himself (a classic case of "transference").

According to this theory, Steve cannot move on until he faces up to his failure, and to help him achieve this "closure" we will be reviewing his editorship for many many weeks (more weeks, perhaps, than it lasted itself). All anecdotes are welcome, and we begin with the one about how, in order to court a younger market, he told a startled conference that the paper sorely needed a feature entitled "Whither hip hop?".

Tremendous news for anyone concerned by nuclear power. It isn't actually dangerous at all - and certainly not as dangerous as hydroelectric, which has caused thousands of deaths through flooded dams, according to an unbiased and independent lecture on power reported in BNFL News (in the small print it does mention that BNFL sponsored the lecture, but we are not here to quibble). Meanwhile, there is also news of a green award presented to the firm by Michael Meacher "for environmental excellence". Great stuff. Not much about that appalling safety scandal which forced the firm to sack most of its board, but early days. Maybe next month.

Apologies to the 15 readers whose applications for Oooh, You Amaze Me! T-shirts arrived yesterday, but as mentioned also yesterday we have sold out. But don't despair. We are considering printing some more, so we will hang on to the cheques on the off chance. For Matthew Cast, a student from Lancaster, an exception will be made, and the very last T-shirt is on its way to him - not so much because of his very nice letter, on finest A4, full of lavish praise, but rather because Matthew had the wit to send a tenner in cash, adding that if there was any change I could have a pint on him. Thanks for your note, Matthew. No need to put it through the till.

Does anyone have any information about the whereabouts of Esther and Abi Ofarim? After the failure to locate King Dong, all information on the pair behind the hit record Cinderella Rockafella especially gratefully received.

It is a mark of this column's incredible reach and influence that yesterday's item on www.ruthgledhill. com provoked a rush of hits on Times religion correspondent Ruth Gledhill's magnificent website. By late afternoon, 152 visitors had popped along to read about Ruth, her ballroom dancing, her family and her equestrian career aboard Sadie . . . a number only slightly down, I calculate, on the daily average. There is no room to explore further today, but tomorrow we will consider Ruth's familial relationship to the actor Basil Rathbone.

Readers are advised that a week today, Thursday May 4, all the planets will be aligned for the first time in 167 years. Frankly we are not sure what this means, and can't find any confirmation anywhere, but someone has rung to say it is true and that Arthur C Clarke featured it in 2001 (although obviously he was a year out), and that's good enough for us. May 4 is also the day of the London mayoral elections, which are now too boring even for this column. It is also the birthday of my colleague Kate Morris's mother Caroline. It is also the day on which a very sweet VAT woman is coming round to my house for what is termed, drolly, as a "comfort visit". Quite a day then.

fields.headline: BBC drug programme criticised
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: A Broadcasting Standards Commission ruling yesterday criticised the BBC for "glamourising and condoning" the crimes of former drug dealer Howard Marks.
fields.body:
A Broadcasting Standards Commission ruling yesterday criticised the BBC for "glamourising and condoning" the crimes of former drug dealer Howard Marks.

A viewer had complained that later drug convictions and jail terms had not been mentioned in a BBC2 Turning Point programme, aired last November, about how Mr Marks was acquitted of drug charges in 1981 after telling an Old Bailey jury he was an MI5 agent spying on IRA drug smugglers and gunrunners.

The BBC argued that the purpose of the programme was to give Mr Marks the opportunity to describe the "turning point" in his expectations, from imprisonment to freedom.

But the BSC standards panel findings state: "Although the aim of the programme may have been to highlight significant points in the lives of people from all walks of life, the style and manner of Mr Marks's contribution had tended to glamourise and condone his crime."

The BBC has conceded that the programme may have been open to misinterpretation and has since decided not to repeat the show.

Mr Marks, 54, of Kenfig Hill, near Bridgend, Mid Glamorgan, now campaigns for the legalisation of cannabis.

fields.headline: See the world, be insulted
fields.standfirst: Advice for black travellers | Stress and unisex loos | How Our Ainsley failed the US taste test
fields.trailText: Advice for black travellers | Stress and unisex loos | How Our Ainsley failed the US taste test
fields.body:
Three cheers for the website that has promised to publish honest holiday guides - the ones specially compiled for the travel industry and meant to be kept well out of the public gaze.

You can get an idea of the warts-and-all approach of the industry bible, OAG Gazetteers, from its bald advice to travellers contemplating an idyllic trip down the Nile: "Unless you are an avid collector of virulent waterborne diseases or exotic infections do not under any circumstances swim or even dip your toes in the Nile."

But while this kind of information, which will be available through Virgin.net, will doubtless help many intrepid travellers to decide where to go - or at least where not to go - it will be of little use to the black holiday-maker. I, for one, crave a little extra advice on what to expect before booking my flight. Since making the mistake of spending my hard-earned McJob wages on a trip to the Italian resort of Rimini, I have yearned for an honest guide for black travellers.

I've long been jealous of the way in which white people take for granted the ease with which they can board trans-European trains, skipping merrily from the Swiss cantons to the French Alps without a care in the world.

Increasingly, we hear about the travel industry's desire to give us more "honest" accounts of their products. Well, if they are so keen on honesty why not provide a "race-o-meter" reading to warn black Britons about what kind of treatment they are likely to encounter at their chosen destination? It could be slotted in neatly alongside those temperature gauges and "real" customer comments that often feature in brochures. Are you reading this, Thomas Cook?

In fact, why not go a step further and give it the full OAG Gazetteers treatment? For Rimini, the entry would read: "If you are a black female looking for adventure you won't be disappointed. Make the most of your holiday and you should leave with a unique insight into what it feels like to be a reviled Mafia-sponsored prostitute. The locals will take an instant dislike to you whether or not you flaunt your Englishness by speaking in a loud Bertie Wooster accent whenever in public.

"In addition, Romany travellers will quite probably hurl rotten fruit your way. The hotel staff will, more likely than not, converse about the indignity of having to serve black people. Local shopkeepers will refuse to give you your change in your hand. Finally, you will extend your Italian vocabulary by picking up plenty of regionally unique abuse."

The entry for the German provincial town of Münster, similarly, might read: "You may find your innocuous request for a Big Mac and fries will bring the entire restaurant to a complete standstill, so unaccustomed are the locals to the sight of black people eating on the premises." For Russia, meanwhile, it would usefully warn that "natives have been known to reach out to touch the faces of black visitors to see if the colour will rub off. Also expect to field requests to play with your hair." Alas, no such advice exists in the Gazetteer. Instead the book is packed with insider gems such as the tower-block hellhole that is Benidorm, the environmental disaster that is Bangkok, the flotsam that washes up on Tunisian beaches. So how then are black travellers to make informed decisions about their holiday destinations? Probably by word of mouth, as there is clearly no point ringing the French tourist board to ask about the state of race relations in Marseilles.

After Rimini, my paranoid response to any friend's holiday suggestion is: "Sounds nice, but how do they treat black people?"

In Portugal, my companion and I had to stumble on the bad news ourselves. During what was meant to be a romantic stroll along a stretch of Algarve coast, we happened across a shanty town inhabited by Angolan workers. Their unsolicited but toe-curling accounts of racist attacks cast a pall over the rest of the trip.

But it isn't just Europe where black tourists are likely to encounter at best puzzlement, at worst hatred. A black female friend of mine works as a fashion buyer and often travels to India as part of her work. The first time she arrived at her five-star Delhi hotel she watched her luggage being deliberately left on the pavement by the hotel staff while that of her white colleagues was hurriedly attended to.

So, this was business and not pleasure, but race can prove a great leveller whether you hold a Club Class ticket or turn right when you get on to a plane. There's not a lot we can do about that, but it would be nice to have a bit of warning.

Say no to new share options

As if years of having to share a toilet at home with male relatives wasn't torturous enough, now a small number of City of London companies are latching on to the revolutionary concept of unisex loos.

The hype has it that shared toilets are a sign of the trendy, modern employer. So if you're about to embark on a career, say, in the dot.com industry, you should take into consideration the fact that your regular trips to the bathroom may no longer lead to the haven of same-sex camaraderie that they used to.

This is not a trend to be encouraged. Women's loos especially should be a sanctuary, somewhere you can unhook your skirt from you knickers, conduct the odd clandestine pregnancy test and gripe about your loathsome male boss without fear of exposure.

Unisex loos represent a clear and present danger to the great tradition of spontaneous female bonding that regularly sparks up in the ladies between complete strangers. They must be fought at all costs.

US sinks Ainsley's soufflé

If, like me, you breathed a sigh of relief when that manic television cook Ainsley Harriott signed his million-dollar contract to move stateside and wow US audiences with his unique culinary black-and-white minstrel act, you will be disheartened by the following news.

Harriott looks likely to be making a return to British TV. The word is that his NBC networked show - a thrilling combination of cookery and chat - is to be cancelled due to sliding ratings. It all proved too rich for US audiences, said an NBC insider. It's not often that you find yourself admiring the viewing tastes of our friends across the Atlantic but for once it seems they are a model of discernment.

 Catherine Bennett will be back next week.

webTitle: MoD 'wastes' £40m a year on empty homes

fields.headline: MoD 'wastes' £40m a year on empty homes
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence is spending nearly £40m a year renting and maintaining 14,000 empty houses, auditors disclose today.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence is spending nearly £40m a year renting and maintaining 14,000 empty houses, auditors disclose today.

Despite this high vacancy rate, it also spent £11m last year renting private sector accommodation for 700 families.

The report by the national audit office, parliament's financial watchdog, criticises the management of the MoD's 63,000 family quarters.

Of these, 23% were vacant last year, costing the ministry £39m in wasted rent and maintenance charges. It spent a further £4m renting houses which were unavailable for families because they were being used for other purposes.

Married quarters are owned by Annington Homes and leased back to the ministry under a sale agreement accepted in 1996 by Michael Portillo, then Tory defence secretary. Its defence housing executive remains responsible for managing, maintaining and upgrading the estate.

The deal with Annington, a Japanese-led consortium, was savaged by the NAO in 1997 when it found that the MoD had wasted £139m of public money in the £1.7bn sale.

It said Mr Portillo knew from his department's own figures that over 25 to 30 years it would have paid to retain ownership, selling only quarters that were surplus.

Discounted value to the armed forces of owning their housing, plus proceeds of selling the surplus, amounted to between £77m and £139m more than the sale price, it said.

The MoD's housing stock was at the centre of further controversy last year when refugees were prevented by the Home Office from using more than 270 empty ministry houses near Cambridge on the grounds that the accommodation was too good.

Today's report says the defence housing executive acknowledged that such a high level of empty and unavailable quarters was unacceptable. It admitted planning assumptions needed improvement.

The NAO acknowledges that the MoD needs some flexibility, given the uncertainty surrounding relocation of service personnel, but not as much as the ministry says it needs.

webTitle: Dando case police find 31 possible new witnesses

fields.headline: Dando case police find 31 possible new witnesses
fields.standfirst: More on the Jill Dando case
fields.trailText: A year on from Jill Dando's death, detectives hunting her killer yesterday returned to the west London street where the television presenter was shot in the hope of finding more clues in what has become one of the great unsolved crimes.
fields.body:
A year on from Jill Dando's death, detectives hunting her killer yesterday returned to the west London street where the television presenter was shot in the hope of finding more clues in what has become one of the great unsolved crimes.

As police set up a mobile incident room on Gowan Avenue in Fulham, Scotland Yard revealed that 31 potential new witnesses had been uncovered in the past few days.

A woman who saw a man in a suit carrying a mobile phone loitering near the television presenter's home on April 26 last year, but had not contacted police, was discovered on Tuesday after being stopped by officers posted around the area as part of the operation based on the anniversary of the shooting.

Speaking yards from the scene of the crime, Detective Chief Inspector Hamish Campbell, the man who has led the year-long investigation, said it was "very frustrating" that potential witnesses had failed to contact the police voluntarily, but insisted that no one would be criticised if they came forward now.

"We do believe the case is most likely to be solved with the help of members of the public and it is very difficult to understand why this person did not come forward before.

"A lot of people think that if they didn't actually see Ms Dando being shot they have nothing to add. There is no real explanation for why they don't come forward but I can assure them, even one year on, they will not be castigated for it."

As Mr Campbell was speaking, uniformed officers and detectives were stationed at both ends and in the centre of the quiet terraced street, stopping people on their way to work and asking whether they had been questioned before.

From the moment news broke that the 37-year-old BBC presenter had been shot in the back of the head at point blank range on the doorstep of her terraced house theories have abounded as to why she was killed. They have ranged from a contract hit set up by a gangster Ms Dando helped to send to prison through her work on the Crimewatch television programme, to a Serb gunman retaliating against the Nato bombing of the state television station in Belgrade and Ms Dando's involvement with an appeal for Kosovan refugees.

But police now appear to have settled on the lone stalker theory, with Scotland Yard confirming yesterday they had identified at least 140 people people with an "unhealthy interest or obsession" with the television presenter.

Most had already been eliminated from the inquiry but some were still to be interviewed, Scotland Yard said.

fields.headline: Day of reckoning
fields.standfirst: Freed former Black Panther wins £2.8m
fields.trailText: A former leader of the Black Panther movement, Geronimo Pratt, won an estimated $4.5m (£2.8m) in an out-of-court settlement from the FBI and the Los Angeles authorities for prosecutorial misconduct in a murder trial which jailed the radical activist for 25 years, it was reported yesterday.
fields.body:
A former leader of the Black Panther movement, Geronimo Pratt, won an estimated $4.5m (£2.8m) in an out-of-court settlement from the FBI and the Los Angeles authorities for prosecutorial misconduct in a murder trial which jailed the radical activist for 25 years, it was reported yesterday.

Mr Pratt, a Vietnam veteran, always maintained that he had been framed for the shooting of a schoolteacher, Caroline Olsen, on a tennis court in Santa Monica, California, in 1968. He was sentenced in 1972, mainly due to the testimony of a police informant, Julius Butler.

The jury was never told of Mr Butler's criminal record and his links with the police, but an investigator later found his name on an index of secret informants kept by the same district attorney's office which prosecuted Mr Pratt. He finally won a retrial in 1997 when a superior court judge ruled that if jurors had known the witness's background they would not have found him guilty.

Mr Pratt said he had been in Oakland at a Black Panther meeting on the day of the murder. The FBI and police had wiretap recordings proving he was there, but had destroyed the evidence, he argued. The FBI has denied the allegations.

Yesterday's Los Angeles Times quoted sources familiar with the case as saying that the case had been settled for $4.5m, of which $2.75m would be paid by the Los Angeles city council. The federal government would pay the rest.

"It's a fair deal for everybody," Johnnie Cochran, Mr Pratt's lawyer, said.

Mrs Olsen was killed and her husband seriously wounded when two armed men robbed them of $18 and then shot them. The jury deliberated for 10 days before finding Mr Pratt guilty.

He spent the first eight years of his sentence in solitary confinement.

Since being freed, Mr Pratt has moved back to his home town, Morgan City in Louisiana, and has changed his name to Geronimo ji Jaga.

He told the Los Angeles Times that his false imprisonment was part of a FBI scheme to undermine the Black Panthers in the 1960s and 1970s.

webTitle: Priest's snub of cohabiting widow leads to uproar

fields.headline: Priest's snub of cohabiting widow leads to uproar
fields.trailText: A feud between an Italian priest and a widowed parishoner ended in a showdown at the altar and trouble for the Roman Catholic church when he refused her Communion for cohabiting with a man.
fields.body:
A feud between an Italian priest and a widowed parishoner ended in a showdown at the altar and trouble for the Roman Catholic church when he refused her Communion for cohabiting with a man.

Fr Claudio Menichetti, 84, shocked his congregation by denouncing the 68-year-old widow as an adulterer just as she opened her mouth to receive the eucharist. The repercussions of his act are rippling beyond the hamlet of Benano, near Orvieto in central Italy.

Cardinal Ersilio Tonini has thrown his support behind the priest amid condemnation of what is seen as the Roman Catholic church's inconsistent policing of modern mores.

The parishioner, who has not been named, moved to Rome and fell in love with another man after her husband died 26 years ago. They live together but never married.

She returned to Benano to attend mass with friends on Easter Sunday and queued for Communion. When it was her turn, Fr Menichetti withheld the host and explained his motive.

"It is true," he said later, "I denied her communion for religious reasons. That woman is living with a man without having tied the bond of marriage."

It emerged that the two had clashed 41 years ago, when she turned up for her wedding wearing a sleeveless dress and he sent her home for a jacket.

The parishioner said she thought it was permissible to receive Communion even while technically living in sin. But Cardinal Tonini, 85, insisted: "Matrimony is a sacrament fundamental to Christian life. It is written in the gospels so do not expect the church to change the rules."

There was uproar in Sicily recently when an 80-year-old priest refused to hear the first confession of an 11-year-old boy with Down's syndrome, saying that the boy did not know the difference between good and evil.

fields.headline: Race bias in US jailings
fields.trailText: Black teenagers in the United States are six times more likely to go to prison for their first offence than young whites, according to a report co-sponsored by the US justice department.
fields.body:
Black teenagers in the United States are six times more likely to go to prison for their first offence than young whites, according to a report co-sponsored by the US justice department.

In cases of violent crime, young blacks are nine times more likely to go to jail, the report said. The statistics confirm longstanding claims by civil rights organisations that the country's juvenile system is systematically biased.

"What is important about yesterday's report is that it has demonstrated that this is a national civil rights issue," said Nancy Gannon, of the Washington-based Coalition for Juvenile Justice.

The report, called And Justice for Some, does not explore the reasons for the racial imbalances in the system, but Ms Gannon said: "It runs from blatant racism on one end of the spectrum and on the other end it is just a systemic problem.

"The system in poor areas is just glutted with kids, who may not have an advocate and a parent who can dress them up in a tie and tell them the right way to behave in court."

The report, the most comprehensive of its kind to date, was partly financed by the justice department, and prepared by the National Council on Crime and Delinquency. It confirms on a national scale what smaller, local studies had already found.

Since 1992, 47 states have expanded their laws to punish more juveniles as adults and according to the justice department, there are between 6,000 and 8,000 inmates under the age of 18 in US adult prisons on any given day.

Teenage inmates are five times more likely to be sexually abused and eight times more likely to commit suicide in adult institutions than in specialised juvenile facilities.

Black youths represent 15% of the US under-18 population, but 26% of all under-18s arrested and 58% of the youth population in adult prisons.

A recent survey in Maryland found that young whites appearing before a juvenile court were five times more likely to be referred for psychiatric counselling than black teenagers, who more often ended up behind bars.

Proponents of tough juvenile sentencing have argued in the past that this imbalance is due to a higher crime rate among minorities, but the new report suggests that an unequal treatment by the justice system is the more important factor.

"We are faced with a very serious national civil rights issue, virtually making our system juvenile injustice," Hugh Price, the president of the National Urban League, a civil rights pressure group, said yesterday.

"The depth of the disparities is breathtaking and can only be explained by a rampant pattern in the justice system of locking young black males away.

"What it does is to take our young black males out of play before they have a chance to become productive members of society."

webTitle: Rothko's new home: spacious, great views

fields.headline: Rothko's new home: spacious, great views
fields.standfirst: It was one of the old Tate's most popular galleries. But will the new Rothko room at Bankside make the grade, asks  Jonathan Jones
fields.trailText: It was one of the old Tate's most popular galleries. But will the new Rothko room at Bankside make the grade?
fields.body:
Tate Modern is a big building and it demands big art. It cannot be a coincidence that so many British artists are suddenly inflating their ideas to colossal proportions. But the art this museum seems made for exists already, and it was made in New York half a century ago.

Abstract expressionist paintings, made to look good in skyscrapers, seem to have found a home from home high up over the Thames. There are two entrances to the Rothko room at Tate Modern, low square doorways leading into a tall rectangular room painted grey. The lighting panels mimic the sombre illumination you might get through a skylight in a basement. Here hang the nine paintings Rothko donated to the Tate in 1968-9, before his suicide in 1970.

A blood-red rectangle floats in a velvety void, a black cloud parts to expose a purple doorway. The shapes can be described like this, but the words turn to dust in your mouth. Doors, portals - maybe, but also not at all. What is unmissable is the terminal quality of these paintings. They are what you imagine the last thing you might see being like - a red retinal flash.

This was what the businessman dining at the Four Seasons restaurant would have seen if Rothko had kept to the terms of his 1958 commission for paintings to go in Manhattan's newest skyscraper, the Seagram Building, designed by Mies van der Rohe and Phillip Johnson.

Rothko, born in the Russian city of Dvinsk in 1903, came to the USA in 1913 and won a scholarship to Yale before dropping out, reportedly alienated by anti-semitism, to "starve a bit" and study art in New York. For the rest of his life he hated to leave the city. He emerged as one of the abstract expressionists in the 40s, and in the 50s he became celebrated for his big paintings with numinous rectangular panels of colour. The Seagram building job was his first big commission, and the building itself was the highpoint of 50s corporate modernism, a bronze-and-glass-fronted palace of business that was elegant, authoritative and radiated rational control of its surroundings.

Rothko went to the task with a passion, but then in 1959 returned the money and kept the paintings. A decade later he finally gave a selection of them to the Tate, on condition that they would be shown in their own room. It was a coup for the Tate, obtained by reassuring Rothko that he would get the perfect display conditions he believed no American museum would provide. The Rothko room has been a sacred part of the Tate since it opened in 1970. The display of these paintings is one of the tests by which the new museum will be judged.

The Tate has in the past portrayed Rothko as a mystic - it displayed his paintings as he insisted, in a clean, purified space that fitted in with the religious way he had come to see his art by the end of his life. I prefer the less reverential way they are displayed at Tate Modern. There has long been a tacit agreement that whatever Rothko was thinking about when he created these exalted canvases it cannot have been cocktails and steaks. He cannot have ever really intended them as restaurant murals. But in an interview with Phillip Johnson and Phyllis Lambert, daughter of the then chairman of the Seagram corporation, to be broadcast this weekend, the artist's claim that he misunderstood the commission, that he thought the canvases would be visible from a worker's canteen, is denied. They say, on the con trary, that Rothko always knew these paintings were for a restaurant.

At Tate Modern, the curators have departed from the last, chapel-like hanging of the Rothko murals at Millbank. There they were in a solitary hall. Here they have a grand, tenebrous setting, but one that can be passed through on the way to other galleries. You get vistas that combine the Rothkos with other paintings: Monet waterlilies, a De Chirico. But best of all the Rothko room at Tate Modern is high up, reached by escalators, situated just a few feet from a sweeping view of the city - a setting in the same modernist mould as the Seagram building. One that makes you see these paintings not in a religious void but playing their part in the city, as backdrops to life, backdrops that are meant to usurp the foreground, architectural decorations that subvert the architecture around them.

Abstract expressionism has had a bad press for 30 years, rejected by younger artists, and yet at Tate Modern it can be revealed as an art with a deeply ambivalent relationship with the modern world. There is no more modern artist than Pollock or Rothko and there is no contemporary installation art more subversive than the Seagram murals. No one thinks of Rothko as a joker. But in a speech about his art in 1958 he listed "wit, humour" and "irony" as requirements for art. If you accept for a moment that he really was thinking of the Seagram Building when he painted these murals, their irony becomes savage.

The architectural allusions in Rothko's murals are clear. The shapes in the paintings suggest doors, the arrangement of pillar and lintel, and most of all they replicate the shapes of Manhattan skyscrapers. But these rectangles are collapsing. Straight lines turn fuzzy. The rational space of Mies van der Rohe is being disrupted by something organic, something that presses at the walls, an irresistible flood. The skyscraper is full of blood.

 Rothko's Rooms is broadcast on BBC2, at 6.55pm on Sunday. Tate Modern, Bankside, London SE1, opens on May 12. Information: 020-7887 8008.
