fields.headline: Inglis Gundry
fields.standfirst: Composer devoted to Cornwall and opera
fields.trailText: Inglis Gundry, who has died aged 94, composed 13 operas. Their subject matter ranged from classical history to the Yugoslav partisans in the second world war. He wrote many books, including, two years ago, Composers By The Grace Of God, a study of the role of religion in the lives of great composers.
fields.body:
Inglis Gundry, who has died aged 94, composed 13 operas. Their subject matter ranged from classical history to the Yugoslav partisans in the second world war. He wrote many books, including, two years ago, Composers By The Grace Of God, a study of the role of religion in the lives of great composers.

Gundry was born in Wimbledon and lived in London, but loved Cornwall and did much to preserve Cornish folk songs and carols, editing Canow Kertnow: Songs And Dances Of Cornwall. In 1952 he was made a bard of the Cornish Gorsedd.

Gundry was of Cornish descent. He was christened an Anglican, attended a nonconformist school, and was confirmed while reading greats - classics and philosophy - at Balliol College, Oxford. He later qualified as a barrister. He also studied at the Royal College of Music with Ralph Vaughan Williams as his composition tutor, orchestration with Gordon Jacobs, and counterpoint with RO Morris.

In 1934 Gundry published his first novel. Several more were to follow.

During the second world war he served in the Royal Navy and was torpedoed while on board HMS Welshman in the Mediterranean. He later worked as music advisor to the Admiralty's education department and edited The Naval Songbook. In 1943 his orchestral suite Heyday Freedom was performed at the Proms.

In 1956 he wrote the lyrics and music of a comic opera, The Logan Rock, and presented it at the Minack Theatre on the cliffs at Porthcurno, near Land's End. Edith Coates of the Royal Opera was in the company, and the conductor was Marcus Dods.

Four years later he co-founded the Sacred Music Drama Society and conducted medieval dramas at Easter and Christmas for almost a quarter of a century. In 1960 he won Morley College's opera competition with another comic opera, The Prince Of Coxcombs. A third comic opera was A Will Of Her Own.

His final opera, Galileo, was written in 1996. For nearly 50 years he lectured on music appreciation for the Workers' Educational Association and for London, Cambridge and Surrey universities.

A non-churchgoer from his mid-20s into his mid-40s, he then became a committed Christian with, as he said, growing conviction.

He leaves a widow and two daughters.

 Inglis Gundry, composer, born May 8 1905; died April 13 2000

fields.headline: Arnold Johnson
fields.standfirst: Star of a film that reversed the dominant Hollywood image of blacks
fields.trailText: The actor Arnold Johnson, who has died aged 79, starred in the 1969 film Putney Swope. In an era when Sidney Poitier was playing a Nobel-prize-winning black Prince Charming in Guess Who's Coming To Dinner (1967), Putney Swope, a movie which came out of the New York underground, provided an alternative.
fields.body:
The actor Arnold Johnson, who has died aged 79, starred in the 1969 film Putney Swope. In an era when Sidney Poitier was playing a Nobel-prize-winning black Prince Charming in Guess Who's Coming To Dinner (1967), Putney Swope, a movie which came out of the New York underground, provided an alternative.

Written and directed by the white movie-maker Robert Downey, it told the story of an inspired takeover of a Madison Avenue advertising agency. Johnson portrayed the abrasive, arrogant Putney, accidentally elected chairman of the board. "I'm not going to rock the boat," Putney announces. "I'm going to sink it!"

Most of the white staff are replaced by armed black militants complete with afros. By the end of the film, Putney and company have sunk the boat, and revealed that some African-Americans can be just as corrupt and power-hungry as whites.

Putney Swope reversed the dominant Hollywood image of blacks. It featured a wealthy black couple who employ a lazy white maid and a black employer who turns down white job applications. In Black Hollywood (1975), African-American historian Gary Null observed that "Downey dared to treat blacks as full-fledged human beings".

Brooklyn-born, orphaned at the age of four, Johnson read drama at New York University and began his career in off-Broadway productions. He was still working in New York when he was cast as Swope. After that film Johnson went to Hollywood to play a supporting role in Shaft, the 1971 box office smash starring Richard Roundtree that helped launch the blaxploitation vogue.

His other films included Pipe Dreams (1976) - which starred singer Gladys Knight - A Hero Ain't Nothin' But A Sandwich (1977), John Schlesinger's Honky Tonk Freeway (1981), Weeds (1987), Sunset (1988), Robert Townsend's The Five Heartbeats (1991) and Menace II Society (1993).

On television, Johnson played a continuing role in the 1973-77 NBC television sitcom Sanford and Son, inspired by the BBC's Steptoe and Son. His other TV work included Family Matters, Homefront, Buddies, The Fresh Prince of Bel Air, The Jeffersons, Highway to Heaven, Amazing Stories and Matlock.

Johnson is survived by his wife, Betty Heater Johnson, three children from a previous marriage and three stepchildren.

 Arnold Johnson, actor, born 1921; died April 10 2000

fields.headline: Wayne McAllister
fields.standfirst: He designed stylish drive-ins and diners for car-crazy California of the 40s and 50s
fields.trailText: There are lots of Bob's Big Boy restaurants in California, but only one was designed by Wayne McAllister, unsung hero of United States roadside architecture, who has died after a fall aged 92. The restaurant, in Riverside Drive, Los Angeles, has been designated a California State Point of Historical Interest.
fields.body:
There are lots of Bob's Big Boy restaurants in California, but only one was designed by Wayne McAllister, unsung hero of United States roadside architecture, who has died after a fall aged 92. The restaurant, in Riverside Drive, Los Angeles, has been designated a California State Point of Historical Interest.

Built in 1949, this drive-in diner, complete with car-hop service and classic car shows on Friday evenings, is a key monument to US post-modern architecture and just the kind of building the East Coast architect Robert Venturi had in mind when he wrote his Po-Mo set-texts Complexity and Contradiction In Architecture (1966) and Learning From Las Vegas (1973), a celebration of US roadside design.

Yet where Venturi's view of this architecture was, if fond, ironic, McAllister was in earnest when he designed some of the best drive-ins, diners and dance lounges to be found in the automobile-addicted California of the 1940s and 1950s. McAllister designed for the Kentucky Fried Chicken and Pig 'n' Whistle chains as well as for Bob's Big Boy. "I just ran a modest office," he told the LA Times in a 1998 interview, "and did modest work". Yet he was one of the first architects to understand and respond to the way the car was changing American life.

Bob's Big Boy on Riverside Drive remains an unmistakeable building with its 70-ft mast topped with a pink-and-white neon logo and sweeping glass facade. Its design makes reference to the futuristic New York World's Fair pavilions of 1940 as well as to Frank Lloyd Wright's desert home and studio, Taliesin West. And of course to the bright lights of nearby Hollywood.

A later generation of Po-Mo architects paid homage to its complex, high-spirited design as well as to McAllister's rich palette of materials. Bob's Big Boy is faced in a zooty skin of mosaic tiles, mustard-coloured clapboard, glass and brick veneer and its sidewalks are made of moss green and black terrazo.

Sadly, much of McAllister's work has been discarded. The Riverside Drive restaurant was saved in 1992 through a campaign led by the architectural historian Chris Nichols, who had long been a fan of its 40s Moderne meets 50s coffee-shop design. Among the many losses along the way was the Brown Derby at Los Feliz, a highly fashionable district of LA next to Hollywood. Here McAllister's "car cafe" and dance lounge swung under a dome capped with an illuminated sign depicting a brown Derby hat. Water was pumped up over the dome to keep it cool. It must have looked a treat at night, lit up by soft neon and the lamps of voluptuous, chromed automobiles.

McAllister also designed the original El Rancho Hotel, the first of many theme resorts on the Las Vegas strip, and Sands, the club frequented by Dean Martin and Frank Sinatra. His work was finally celebrated in an exhibition of photographs and drawings curated by Nichols in 1998 at the Pacific Design Center, Los Angeles.

Taken for granted by Californians, McAllister's designs were the stuff of Hollywood nostalgia to the visitor who knew the names and works of Frank Lloyd Wright and Robert Venturi.

Wayne McAllister was born in San Diego. He dropped out of high school to take up architecture. At 20 he designed the Mexican resort of Agua Caliente, later frequented by, among others, Clark Gable, Jean Harlow and Gloria Swanson. Even then he sought inspiration in the cars that brought the stars to Agua Caliente and, later, the common motorist to the architectural fanfares of Bob's Big Boy . He was, he said later, "influenced by the automobile, not the architect". That wasn't altogether true, yet McAllister was truly the motorist's friend.

He gave up architecture in 1956, moving to Washington DC, where he was appointed vice-president of the hotel-owning Marriot Corporation. He went back west to LA in 1962 where he developed coin-operated copying machines.

He is survived by his wife Corinne, a daughter and two sons.

 Wayne McAllister, architect, born November 17 1907; died March 22 2000

fields.headline: Urban crime, rural myths
fields.trailText: Following the conviction of Tony Martin, there have been a rash of stories giving the impression of a rural crime epidemic, with householders unable to rely on the police to protect them against burglars and other criminals (Martin jury nobbling claims rejected, April 26). Figures easily available from the Home Office, paint a very different picture.
fields.body:
Following the conviction of Tony Martin, there have been a rash of stories giving the impression of a rural crime epidemic, with householders unable to rely on the police to protect them against burglars and other criminals (Martin jury nobbling claims rejected, April 26). Figures easily available from the Home Office, paint a very different picture.

Consistently, householders are far more at risk from crime in urban rather than rural areas, and this crime is far less less likely to be detected. For burglary, the British Crime Survey (a self-report study) records a rate of household burglary of 8.5% in inner-city areas in 1997. In rural areas, this figure more than halves, to 3.4%.

For individual neighbourhood types, the BCS lists rural areas as having a risk of burglary that stands at 45% the national average; the rate of risk in urban-based council areas is often 200% the national average.

Figures for notifiable offences reported to the police in 1999 show 5.7 burglaries per 1,000 households in Norfolk (Tony Martin country). In the Metropolitan Police area, this figure was 12.6 per 1,000 households.

Conversely, detection rates, taken from the 1998-99 Annual Report of Her Majesty's Chief Inspector of Constabulary, were just under 40% in Norfolk, the second highest in England. For the Metropolitan Police, burglaries were detected in around 10% of cases, the fourth lowest.

You quote four Conservative MPs as saying that people in rural areas "no longer have the confidence in the ability of the police to defend them and their property" and are "likely to be tempted to take the law into their own hands".

What, then, does this mean for the town-dweller who is more likely to be victimised and less likely to be helped by the police? The statistics quoted were obtained over the internet in around 20 minutes.
David Price
Darwin College, Cambridge dep21@hermes.cam.ac.uk

 The 16-year-old traveller who was shot dead did break into someone's home. The farmer who used the gun did commit murder. In a way both have paid tragically for a moment's madness.

The jury gave their verdict but even this was not enough. Allegations of intimidation are flying. Why not put an end to all the hypocrisy, to quote a local farmer: "They're only light-fingered pikies, Gypsies and scum."

Travellers are the only ethnic minority forced to live in camps, usually next to rubbish tips or graveyards or main roads. You can still see "no travellers" outside pubs.

Because travellers are not black or even mixed race they appear to be legitimate targets for everyone to vent their resentment on. Would the Commission for Racial Equality stay silent if this treatment was dished out to Sikhs or Asians?

The travelling community have and always will live on the fringe of the host community. They used to sell pegs and flowers, pick hops and fruit, harvest potatoes: a more back-breaking job would be hard to find.

Because of legislation, farmers cannot allow families to stay on their land, so sites were built, rents charged, electricity paid for, but when they are full the families are moved on and on. Why don't they live in houses and get a proper job? Some do and villagers hate them.

You are born a traveller as if you were born a Jew. I feel sorry for the asylum seekers bogus or otherwise. If they are herded into military camps they might realise that our country is not an easy touch: just look how we treat our own home grown travellers.
Mary Powell
National Gypsy Council

For burglary, the British Crime Survey (a self-report study) records a rate of household burglary of 8.5% in inner-city areas in 1997. In rural areas, this figure more than halves, to 3.4%. For individual neighbourhood types, the BCS lists rural areas as having a risk of burglary that stands at 45% the national average; the rate of risk in urban-based council areas is often 200% the national average. Figures for notifiable offences reported to the police in 1999 show 5.7 burglaries per 1,000 households in Norfolk (Tony Martin country). In the Metropolitan Police area, this figure was 12.6 per 1,000 households. Conversely, detection rates, taken from the 1998-99 Annual Report of Her Majesty's Chief Inspector of Constabulary, were just under 40% in Norfolk, the second highest in England. For the Metropolitan Police, burglaries were detected in around 10% of cases, the fourth lowest. You quote four Conservative MPs as saying that people in rural areas "no longer have the confidence in the ability of the police to defend them and their property" and are "likely to be tempted to take the law into their own hands". What, then, does this mean for the town-dweller who is more likely to be victimised and less likely to be helped by the police? The statistics quoted were obtained over the internet in around 20 minutes. David Price Darwin College, Cambridge dep21@hermes.cam.ac.uk  The 16-year-old traveller who was shot dead did break into someone's home. The farmer who used the gun did commit murder. In a way both have paid tragically for a moment's madness. The jury gave their verdict but even this was not enough. Allegations of intimidation are flying. Why not put an end to all the hypocrisy, to quote a local farmer: "They're only light-fingered pikies, Gypsies and scum." Travellers are the only ethnic minority forced to live in camps, usually next to rubbish tips or graveyards or main roads. You can still see "no travellers" outside pubs. Because travellers are not black or even mixed race they appear to be legitimate targets for everyone to vent their resentment on. Would the Commission for Racial Equality stay silent if this treatment was dished out to Sikhs or Asians? The travelling community have and always will live on the fringe of the host community. They used to sell pegs and flowers, pick hops and fruit, harvest potatoes: a more back-breaking job would be hard to find. Because of legislation, farmers cannot allow families to stay on their land, so sites were built, rents charged, electricity paid for, but when they are full the families are moved on and on. Why don't they live in houses and get a proper job? Some do and villagers hate them. You are born a traveller as if you were born a Jew. I feel sorry for the asylum seekers bogus or otherwise. If they are herded into military camps they might realise that our country is not an easy touch: just look how we treat our own home grown travellers. Mary Powell National Gypsy Council

fields.headline: A president's progress
fields.standfirst:
The struggle for reform in Iran intensifies

More about Iran
fields.trailText: Two months after reformers won a famous election victory, and one month before the new parliament is due to convene, hardliners within Iran's clerical establishment are struggling to thwart the tide of change. This week's banning of pro-reform newspapers and magazines smacks of desperation, for the suppression of these symbols of free speech is an act of futility.
fields.body:
Two months after reformers won a famous election victory, and one month before the new parliament is due to convene, hardliners within Iran's clerical establishment are struggling to thwart the tide of change. This week's banning of pro-reform newspapers and magazines smacks of desperation, for the suppression of these symbols of free speech is an act of futility. The Mosharekat daily, run by President Khatami's brother and leading reformer, Reza, is still in business, for now at least. As in the past, new titles will take the place of proscribed publications. Leaflets and "night letters", an Iranian samizdat , will continue to circulate. Word of mouth is an invincible foe, even for those who claim to rule by divine right. And even the most messianic mullahs must know they cannot force an entire nation, especially one as young and talkative as Iran, to shut up completely.

The conservative backlash is taking other, more vicious forms. Rumours of a coup to oust Mr Khatami have intensified, as we report today, with claims that a Revolutionary Guard "crisis committee" has been formed to seize power by stages. The unexplained shooting last month of Saeed Hajjarian, a presidential confidant, recalled the "serial killings" of dissidents and intellectuals in the late 90s. The trial on dubious espionage charges of 13 Iranian Jews, due to open next week, comes in the context of attempts to recycle the old spectre of "foreign enemies". Add to all this the jailing of journalists and the voiding of some election results by the cleric-dominated Council of Guardians and the extent of the danger facing the president is plain.

Luckily, Mr Khatami is a cool head who has been through all this before. He knows that his enemies would like nothing more than a repeat of last year's Tehran student riots as an excuse for a crackdown, even a putsch. Hence his call for calm as protests against the newspaper closures spread. Mr Khatami also knows that the clerical establishment (of which he is a part) is by no means united in its hostility. As ever in Iran, there are as many shades of opinion as there are seats in the Majlis. The supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, is said to be resistant to pressure from extremists, and firmly opposed to violence. In truth, the biggest threat to Iran's unique Islamic state comes not from reformers but from those who distort its values for their own ends. Coup plots aside, Mr Khatami is steadily winning that argument.

fields.headline: Old, but not incapable
fields.standfirst: People are being written off too early
fields.trailText: A popular image of the early retired is of an affluent group voluntarily trading income for leisure. Nothing could be further from the truth, as the report from the Cabinet Office's performance and innovation unit starkly documented yesterday. A small affluent group does exist, but the majority of people aged 50 to 65 no longer in work face serious financial problems.
fields.body:
A popular image of the early retired is of an affluent group voluntarily trading income for leisure. Nothing could be further from the truth, as the report from the Cabinet Office's performance and innovation unit starkly documented yesterday. A small affluent group does exist, but the majority of people aged 50 to 65 no longer in work face serious financial problems. For two out of three, there is nothing voluntary about their position. They are victims of prejudice, destructive "downsizing" economic policies and perverse pension incentives. Almost half receive most of their income in state benefits. One out of three people between 50 and the state retirement age - some 2.8m people - is now out work. Unemployment rates for men in this age group have risen twice as fast as in any other. Fewer than 50% are still in employment by 60, and a mere 37% by the age of 64. This waste of labour is already costing the country £3-5bn in benefits and lost taxes and an estimated £16bn in lost GDP. Without a dramatic change in attitudes, another 1m will be added to this unemployed roll by 2020.

There is no single solution. Policy-makers should note that pushing the over-50s out of the labour market does not create jobs for the young - nor does re-engaging the third generation increase youth unemployment. Economists are united on that. They also point to a looming labour shortage which the over-50s are ideally suited to meet. Ministers, and the media too should stop being so obsessed with youth. There is plenty to celebrate at the other end of the age spectrum. Half the managers of premier league football clubs are over 50. The new emphasis should be on more help to stay in work or get back to work, more flexible working, more retraining. Most important of all is an act outlawing age discrimination. This was promised in opposition. Seven industrial nations have demonstrated it works. It is time for the UK to join them.

fields.headline: David Drakakis-Smith
fields.standfirst: Influential geographer whose theoretical work was aimed at helping the urban poor
fields.trailText: David Drakakis-Smith, who has died aged 57, was one of the most highly regarded and influential geographers of his generation whose work - on urban poverty, population policy, the problems of small islands and the marginalisation of Australian Aborigines - made for a greater understanding of development issues.
fields.body:
David Drakakis-Smith, who has died aged 57, was one of the most highly regarded and influential geographers of his generation whose work - on urban poverty, population policy, the problems of small islands and the marginalisation of Australian Aborigines - made for a greater understanding of development issues.

He played a major role in developing the concept of sustainable urbanisation and its practical application, which lead to three landmark papers in the journal Urban Studies. Following a successful international workshop funded by the European Science Foundation, he intended to develop a major programme of related research in South-east Asia. While some components of this work began, notably in Singapore and Vietnam, his deteriorating health prevented him coordinating the extensive programme that he envisaged.

He had immense energy, which often placed considerable pressure on colleagues and collaborators. That energy meant that he found it extremely difficult to refuse invitations and he frequently seemed to engage in a punishing schedule of activities.

I have enduring memories of field visits to Vietnam, Singapore and the Philippines in November 1995. A great deal of effort had been devoted to arranging as many meetings as possible so, as David put it, we could "hit the ground running". The programme ran exhaustingly well until our arrival in Manila, which was suffering the worst typhoon for 35 years.

Meetings had to be cancelled; most of the buildings and trees surrounding our hotel were blowing into the sea, and the noise was deafening. Meanwhile, David curled himself up on his bed to work on the draft of a paper for Urban Studies. He could write extremely fluently under the most unlikely conditions, using the cheapest of university issue ball-point pens and posting wads of paper to his home department for typing.

His committee work was for such bodies as the Institute of British Geographers, the Royal Geographical Society and the International Geographical Union. He was firmly committed to the public responsibility of the universities, which resulted in him becoming an assessor for the Quality Assurance Association agency for higher education and the 1996 Research Assessment Exercise (RAE). He sought the latter demanding position as a result of extreme dissatisfaction with the way in which work on third world development issues, much of it interdisciplinary, seemed to have been seriously undervalued in the previous assessment exercise.

While he felt that the universities should be accountable, he became increasingly exasperated by the low pay, shortage of resources and limited esteem afforded them by successive governments. He corresponded with successive ministers responsible for overseas aid on the lack of support for the training of researchers and planners for third world work.

Given his skill as a teacher, it was not surprising to find him collaborating in the production of a series of texts for first-year students. His own contribution, The Third World City (1987) was a remarkable achievement. One of his last writing tasks was to complete an extensively revised edition.

Born in Liverpool, he studied at Aberystwyth University, both as an undergraduate and post-graduate. He was appointed assistant lecturer at the University of Glasgow in 1967 and subsequently held posts at Hong Kong, Durham, Canberra and, in 1980, at Keele. He became professor of development studies at Keele in 1988.

Visiting professorships fol lowed at Witwatersrand and Gothenborg, and in 1994 he moved to the University of Liverpool as professor of economic geography. He was then at the height of his intellectual powers, and a wide-ranging programme of work, particularly on South-east Asia and South Africa, was envisaged.

This return to his home town gave him great pleasure, not least because it facilitated more frequent visits to Liverpool Football Club. It was typical of him that when organising a demanding three-day European Science Foundation workshop at Liverpool he also arranged a tour of the trophy room and a dinner in the directors' dining room.

He is survived by his wife Angela, son Emmanuel and daughter Chloe.

 David Drakakis-Smith, development geographer, born November 18 1942; died December 19 1999

fields.headline: Straw's asylum scam
fields.trailText: The Home Office's trumpeting of a record month for decisions in asylum claims (Asylum decisions at record rate, April 26) is, at least in part, bogus. At the beginning of April law firms began to receive a new form of refusal-of-asylum letter from the secretary of state.
fields.body:
The Home Office's trumpeting of a record month for decisions in asylum claims (Asylum decisions at record rate, April 26) is, at least in part, bogus. At the beginning of April law firms began to receive a new form of refusal-of-asylum letter from the secretary of state.

Normally these "refusal letters" provide detailed reasons for refusal of a claim to asylum - the individual's grounds for claiming asylum, apparent discrepancies in the claim and the background objective evidence as perceived by the secretary of state. It is against these letters that we prepare our clients' appeals. We seek evidence to rebut the assertions made and further and better reports on the human rights situation in the client's country of origin.

The new refusal letter is a standard computer-generated letter. Although the letters state the cases have been "carefully considered", the secretary of state offers no reasons for refusal.

Legal firms have received scores of these letters. They do not vary in their content, save in the name at the top of the letter. There is no doubt in the minds of other practitioners that the secretary of state is attempting a sleight of hand. If he had "carefully considered" the claims, as he says, then he should be able to provide his reasons for refusing asylum claims.

A clear consensus of lawyers we spoke to was that this was a ruse to allow the Home Office to say they had achieved a record number of decisions. It is a basic right of any individual to be given clear reasons for a refusal of his/her asylum claim. It appears there is no abrogation of asylum-seekers' rights that is beyond the pale.
David Enright
Howe & Co, solicitors

fields.headline: Adoption: for and against
fields.trailText: The proposal that adoption should be made easier (Agencies back plans to make adoption easier, April 26), with the inevitable result that checks will be less rigorous, gives me considerable disquiet.
fields.body:
The proposal that adoption should be made easier (Agencies back plans to make adoption easier, April 26), with the inevitable result that checks will be less rigorous, gives me considerable disquiet.

I am a survivor of the second world war evacuation. Homes were wanted for city children in a hurry and we were forced into families who did not want us. Sixty years later I still have nightmares.

I was physically, mentally and emotionally abused in two out of three foster homes; the subject of benign neglect in a third. I have been scarred for life, my relationship with my parents was virtually destroyed. My family has suffered and most of my relationships have been affected by my inability to trust people

I do not know what the answer to our childcare problem is, but free and easy adoption is not it. Children are not little parcels to be sent around the country and everyone who wants to adopt is not necessarily suitable.
F Costa
Kent

 As a social worker with 12 years' experience, I welcome the government's proposals. I have often felt horrified at the culture within family placement teams where adoption is viewed with suspicion. The goal of securing suitable long-term carers is often lost whilst attempting to find an "ideal" family. Running beside this, the number of foster carers is inadequate, their recruitment is haphazard and the rate of retention is woeful. Consequently large numbers of children, a disproportionate number from ethnic minorities, are left in children's homes for long periods.
Name and address supplied

webTitle: Dogfight continues over air traffic control service

fields.headline: Dogfight continues over air traffic control service
fields.trailText: When Labour MPs receive John Prescott's letter claiming that most air traffic in Britain is handled by private firms (Prescott fights air traffic rebels, April 25), they shouldn't be worried if they find his statistics a little confusing. Air traffic controllers themselves are struggling to understand them.
fields.body:
When Labour MPs receive John Prescott's letter claiming that most air traffic in Britain is handled by private firms (Prescott fights air traffic rebels, April 25), they shouldn't be worried if they find his statistics a little confusing. Air traffic controllers themselves are struggling to understand them.

Prescott says that in 1998 1.9m movements - "more than half the total for UK airports" - occurred at airports where air traffic control is not provided by National Air Traffic Services (Nats).

First of all, "movements" are not a helpful basis for comparison, as they include private aircraft at tiny airfields, which have no air traffic control service at all. The number of passengers is far more meaningful.

According to the Civil Aviation Authority, in December last year 87% of passengers at all UK airports were handled by Nats. Of the remaining 13%, all were guided by Nats controllers during the "en route" part of their journey, ie after their initial take-off and before their final approach and landing.

Yet airport services are a minor part of Nats' work. In 1998-99, Nats earned just £73m from airport services, compared to £467m from en route services. Nats is the only provider of en route air traffic control for aircraft flying through controlled UK airspace.

Every commercial passenger flying in UK skies, whether they're travelling from London to Glasgow or from the US to Dubai, is handled by Nats. My union has never claimed that non-Nats airports like Leeds, East Midlands or Southampton are dangerous. If Prescott's accu sation was directed at IPMS, he should withdraw it.
Paul Noon
General secretary, Institute of Professionals, Managers and Specialists

 Your article repeats claims that the proposed public-private partnership (PPP) of Nats will put passenger safety at risk. As safety regulator, the CAA's position is clear: the PPP would not, indeed could not, affect the safety of air traffic control.

All aspects of air traffic control are highly regulated and controlled by law. A comprehensive system of safety locks is already in place.

None of these can be affected by a change of ownership of Nats. For example, the hours worked by air traffic controllers could not be changed by new management, or affected in any way by a change of ownership. The only way air traffic controllers could work longer hours would be if the law were changed.

PPP would mean clear separation between the provision and regulation of air traffic services. The CAA will stay in the public sector, separate and independent.

Nats would be regulated by the CAA, exactly as it currently regulates BA and the BAA and the 35 air traffic providers referred to in your article, which are already in the private sector. By bringing greater transparency, by strengthening the regulator, and by giving Nats access to investment, the PPP should in fact reinforce the UK's excellent safety record.
Sir Malcolm Field
Chairman, Civil Aviation Authority

The number of passengers is far more meaningful. According to the Civil Aviation Authority, in December last year 87% of passengers at all UK airports were handled by Nats. Of the remaining 13%, all were guided by Nats controllers during the "en route" part of their journey, ie after their initial take-off and before their final approach and landing. Yet airport services are a minor part of Nats' work. In 1998-99, Nats earned just £73m from airport services, compared to £467m from en route services. Nats is the only provider of en route air traffic control for aircraft flying through controlled UK airspace. Every commercial passenger flying in UK skies, whether they're travelling from London to Glasgow or from the US to Dubai, is handled by Nats. My union has never claimed that non-Nats airports like Leeds, East Midlands or Southampton are dangerous. If Prescott's accu sation was directed at IPMS, he should withdraw it. Paul Noon General secretary, Institute of Professionals, Managers and Specialists  Your article repeats claims that the proposed public-private partnership (PPP) of Nats will put passenger safety at risk. As safety regulator, the CAA's position is clear: the PPP would not, indeed could not, affect the safety of air traffic control. All aspects of air traffic control are highly regulated and controlled by law. A comprehensive system of safety locks is already in place. None of these can be affected by a change of ownership of Nats. For example, the hours worked by air traffic controllers could not be changed by new management, or affected in any way by a change of ownership. The only way air traffic controllers could work longer hours would be if the law were changed. PPP would mean clear separation between the provision and regulation of air traffic services. The CAA will stay in the public sector, separate and independent. Nats would be regulated by the CAA, exactly as it currently regulates BA and the BAA and the 35 air traffic providers referred to in your article, which are already in the private sector. By bringing greater transparency, by strengthening the regulator, and by giving Nats access to investment, the PPP should in fact reinforce the UK's excellent safety record. Sir Malcolm Field Chairman, Civil Aviation Authority

fields.headline: The future is blonde
fields.trailText:
I am delighted the government is beginning to realise that people of 50 are not quite ready to be put out to grass (Ministers move to woo the over-fifties, April 26). But on behalf of all my contemporaries who still consider themselves in their prime, can I gently chide you for portraying me as one of the "grey vote". My friends are blonde, some blonder than ever, or bald, but grey, never.
Hilary Patrick
Edinburgh

My friends are blonde, some blonder than ever, or bald, but grey, never.
Hilary Patrick
Edinburgh

 Please, Michele Hanson, have a heart (G2, April 24). If I am taken to hospital (I am nearly 80), I don't want to be resuscitated. Not once! What do I do? Hang a label round my neck? Had your father ever been asked?
Hans Lobstein
Brighton

 Strange you should perpetuate the class prejudices of Captain Scott's expedition by naming the three officers left at Evans Cove but not the "three sailors" (Six desperate men, G2, April 25). For the record, those brave men were George Abbott, Frank Browning and Harry Dickason.
Chris Brown
Keighley

 You refer (Injury leaves Van Nistelrooy in limbo, April 26) to the £18.5m Dutch striker's injury to "his knee". The position was made quite clear 30 years ago, when Tommy Smith complained to Bill Shankly that he had hurt his. "That's not your knee," Shankly replied. "That's Liverpool's knee."
Fritz Spiegl
Liverpool fritz@scousepress.demon.co.uk

 Both Bertrand Russell and Sir Walter Scott have used infer as a synonym for imply (see OED). And let us not forget James T Kirk, a man who would never be inclined to pedantically attack teachers in the manner of Brian Strauss (Letters, April 26).
John Eglin
London
John@eglin.net

fields.headline: Man trouble
fields.trailText: What does Bonnie Greer (No more Mr Nice Guy", G2, April 25) do for fun when not engaged in peddling male stereotypes? Is she "nice", baking cakes for the Sunday school fete, or perhaps she is a "toxic spinster", embarking on torrid affairs with the entire local rugby team?
fields.body:
What does Bonnie Greer (No more Mr Nice Guy", G2, April 25) do for fun when not engaged in peddling male stereotypes? Is she "nice", baking cakes for the Sunday school fete, or perhaps she is a "toxic spinster", embarking on torrid affairs with the entire local rugby team?

Does she seriously believe that women who waste their lives repeatedly falling for abusive trouble-makers deserve a miserable fate because they secretly crave chaos and instability?

What vulnerable women really need is sensible, rational advice. Instead they are repeatedly subjected to this sort of hysterical twaddle, perpetuating the myth that all men are either nice-but-boring-so-don't-bother or villainous-but-incredibly-glamorous-so-have-a-go.


Christine Harling & David Vinicombe
Bristol

webTitle: Blind woman to be given artificial eye

fields.headline: Blind woman to be given artificial eye
fields.trailText: Belgian scientists are preparing to fit a blind woman with an artificial eye which will link directly with the optic nerve and allow her to "see."
fields.body:
Belgian scientists are preparing to fit a blind woman with an artificial eye which will link directly with the optic nerve and allow her to "see."

If the technique works, it could restore vision to many who are blind because retinas have been damaged or destroyed.

The eye - lens and all - is like a video camera: wavelengths of optical light hit the retina and are transmitted but the information still has to be processed into a picture in the head.

The brain is the viewer that actually makes sense of the signals transmitted from the optic nerve.

For decades, researchers have believed that just as artificial aids could enable some deaf people to "hear", and implants could help throat cancer patients speak, so some mechanical device could one day enable blind people to see.

A team at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore two years ago started work on a Star Trek-style "eye chip" to bypass non-functioning eye cells and transmit signals directly to cells in the retina.

All 15 volunteers reported being able to see either spots of light, or more complex patterns.

Some patients had not seen for four decades, and were able after a while to identify the shapes of letters transmitted to them.

However, such a technique, provided that it worked well enough, could only help a small percentage of sightless people.

Scientists at the Catholic University of Louvain, according to New Scientist today, believe that a coil wrapped around the optic nerve could widen horizons for many others.

With a shift in the phase and a variation in the strength of the singals, the coil could stimulate different parts of the optic nerve, rather in the way that electron guns light up dif ferent parts of a television screen.

The signals would come from an externally fitted camera and be transmitted to the implant through a radio antenna and microchip fitted under the skin and just behind the ear.

Trials with one woman volunteer have been going on for two years.

The scientists think that success is likely to be with people who had once been sighted, and would therefore have some experience in interpreting images.

The hope is that with such a device, blind people might at least be sure of "seeing" and avoiding obstacles.

If the implant is a success, it is hoped that trials on three more patients could begin in August.

webTitle: No one cares what you did in the war Dad

fields.headline: No one cares what you did in the war Dad
fields.trailText: A quarter of a century after the fall of Saigon, the United States and Vietnam are at peace. More surprisingly, the issue that divided America as no other confict has done since the civil war has finally been laid to rest.
fields.body:
A quarter of a century after the fall of Saigon, the United States and Vietnam are at peace. More surprisingly, the issue that divided America as no other confict has done since the civil war has finally been laid to rest.

All this week, television channels, magazines and newspapers have been running anniversary reflections on the war which claimed 58,000 US lives and 2-3 million Vietnamese: the tone has been overwhelmingly conciliatory.

This year, for the first time, a presidential election will be fought between two candidates who are both from the Vietnam war generation.

Al Gore, who was an opponent of the war, is nevertheless a Vietnam veteran, though not quite as battle-hardened as he tries to imply.

George W Bush, a supporter of American policy, managed to avoid being sent to Vietnam by means which have not been satisfactorily explained.

When Bill Clinton ran for the presidency in 1992, the issue haunted him, because Mr Clinton was both an opponent of the war and a draft evader who feared to say why. For many of America's rightwing Clinton-haters, that remains at the centre of their visceral hostility.

Yet in the 2000 election, the sting of Vietnam seems to have been drawn. "What did you do in the Vietnam war?" is rarely asked and when it is it creates no scandals, even among Vietnamese- Americans.

There are far more Vietnamese refugees living in the US today than Cuban refugees. Yet in southern California, where the highest concentration of Vietnamese emigrants now live, there is little of the obsessional sort of politics which marks Florida's Cuban population.

When relations between the US and Vietnam were normalised in 1995, there was no explosion in California's Little Saigon of the kind which would break out in Florida's Little Havana under comparable circumstances in US-Cuba relations.

Nevertheless, the Vietnam war has played a subtle role in the 2000 election. Senator John McCain's unsuccessful run for the Republican nomination focused on his war record as a five-year prisoner in the so-called "Hanoi Hilton". But while banners proclaiming him an American hero won MrMcCain support among Republicans, his magnanimity about Vietnam attracted independents and Democrats who had opposed the war.

Vietnam is certainly not a resolved issue for all Americans. When a Vietnamese-American shopkeeper put up a poster of Ho Chi Minh in his Los Angeles video store last year, it provoked nightly demonstrations from refugees and war veterans until he took it down.

And when a group in New Jersey founded what is still the only Vietnam war museum in the country in 1998, they outraged war veterans by planning a section on the anti-war movement.

When the museum opened, there were no pictures of Jane Fonda, all references to US soldiers taking drugs had been removed and a video about anti-war protest was replaced with one of soldiers' stories.

Each year in late May, when Memorial Day celebrations take place in Washington, the city fills with thousands of ageing men in leather riding Harley Davidsons up and down the avenues, ostensibly as part of a campaign to bring justice and "closure" for families of the 2,000 US service personnel still listed as "missing in action" in south-east Asia, 1,500 of them in Vietnam.

The "MIA" issue casts a long shadow over US politics and public life. Last month, when William Cohen became the first US defence secretary to visit Vietnam since Melvyn Laird during the Nixon era, the public relations centrepiece of his visit was a trip to a rice field 20 miles west of Hanoi.

There an American team and more than 200 Vietnamese villagers were digging through a wartime crater for evidence that a plane shot down in May 1967 was piloted by one of the MIAs, Commander Richard Rich.

Senator John McCain returned to Vietnam for his eighth post-war visit this week and made the obligatory trip to the same rice field where the "Operation Full Accounting" unit is still at work.

In American universities, the subject which fired a generation - including many of today's college professors - has largely dropped off the curriculum.

"This new generation of students is as likely to take a course on the Peloponnesian war as the Vietnam war," says Allan Goodman, a former Georgetown University professor.

Other teachers say their students have only the vaguest knowledge of the events of the war, and understand far less about the issues involved than they do about the second world war.

As the Vietnam era slips further into the past a new iconoclasm is emerging, exemplified in Michael Lind's 1999 book Vietnam: The Necessary War. The writer, whose previous book was a critique of American conservatism, argued that the "hawks" who lost the war had nevertheless been right to believe that they had to fight international communism.

"What's interesting to me is how little is happening any more to learn the lessons of Vietnam," says analyst Richard Haass of the Brookings institution.

"I don't think there are any very clear lessons being drawn any longer about whether and when the United States is likely to get involved militarily around the world.

webTitle: No easy victory in Hanoi's war on poverty

fields.headline: No easy victory in Hanoi's war on poverty
fields.standfirst: Twenty five years after the defeat of the US, Vietnam faces its biggest challenge as it opens up to global economic competition
fields.trailText: No one mentions Vietnam's brief war with China at Thanh Thuy on the border, where local villagers from both sides can now cross freely. But the steep wooded slopes enclosing this trading market on a tributary of the Red river are still littered with mines.
fields.body:
No one mentions Vietnam's brief war with China at Thanh Thuy on the border, where local villagers from both sides can now cross freely. But the steep wooded slopes enclosing this trading market on a tributary of the Red river are still littered with mines.

"It will always be out of bounds on the mountain," said the manager of a small eating place next to the frontier gate. "It took 10 years after the 1979 war just to clear the road here."

Twenty five years after Vietnam's victory in the south against the |US-backed former Saigon regime, it feels relaxed about Washington. But the Chinese presence to the north remains, as it has done for most of Vietnam's history, a deeper-rooted concern.

While Hanoi's relations with Beijing have improved following China's 1979 invasion prompted by Vietnam's ousting of the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia, "China is still the biggest foreign policy headache," said a western ambassador in Hanoi.

"They have to manage China by strengthening their relations with the Asean countries to the south. They are at the same time fascinated and worried by China's huge economic progress."

At the Thanh Thuy border port, the traffic is virtually one way. Families return from the Chinese side with everything from eggs to rice cookers. The cheap shoes and watches sold on the Vietnamese side come from China too.

Hanoi was not prepared for the rout of the Saigon regime in 1975 and had no coherent post-war economic strategy. Recovery was also delayed by Vietnam's intervention to rescue Cambodia.

Hanoi embarked on the policy of doi moi, or transition towards a market economy, nearly 10 years after China, and has shown more hesitation since then. Despite forecasts in the mid-1990s of the country becoming a new "Asian Tiger", it is lagging behind.

Although wages are lower in Vietnam, so is productivity. Foreign investment creates five times fewer jobs in Vietnam than in China for the same sum of money

"A Chinese farmer who earns several times more than his Vietnamese counterpart pays half the price for a motorbike," said a government statistician, Dao Ngoc Lam.

This month Honda Vietnam pledged to lower its prices, admitting that it is under severe presure from Chinese competition

It is an appropriate example in a capital city where hundreds of scooters swarm like fireflies around the historic Hoan Kiem lake, as Vietnam's emerging middle class has more money to spend.

But although veteran residents lament the quickening pace of life, Hanoi is still an oasis of calm compared to other major Asian cities, including Saigon, which has become as brash and noisy as it was before the 1975 "liberation".

"We were saved by the Asian economic crisis," said a local conservationist. "It has given the government time to realise the tourist potential of the French colonial architecture and to start preserving the streets of the old town."

It has also strengthened the arguments within the ruling elite of the Vietnamese Communist party against a headlong rush into the world market.

The semi-official Vietnam Economic Review this month refers openly to a "lack of consensus in public opinion".

Even World Bank and International Monetary Fund officials now say that Vietnam is right to take its time implementing the market reforms which they pressed upon Hanoi a few years ago.

"We now understand that poverty must come first in a country where 80% still live on the land," said an aid programme manager.

"Foreign investors may be agitated by the slow pace of reform, but Vietnam is one of the best performers at poverty reduction in the developing world."

A recent assessment by the World Bank and the British Department for International Development claimed a "striking change for the better".

While 58% of the population lived below the poverty line in 1992, the poverty headcount was reduced to 37% by 1998.

Yet for too many the improvement is only marginal. Rural life is "so fragile and finely-balanced that a small misfortune will destabilise the [peasant] household for many years", said the report.

Poverty in the northern uplands and central highlands - the poorest areas of Vietnam - is evident to anyone crossing the border from China.

Peasant housing is crudely built, with walls of rough matting and roofs of thatch. There are few shops, and no cars on the road.

"The government has a four-fold programme to improve roads, schools, hospitals and electricity," said a Vietnamese technician. "There is still a very long way to go."

Rural incomes have improved, particularly in the fertile deltas, but the shift to a market economy has hit education and health and undermined traditional social values.

The removal of state subsidies means that only 61% of children finish primary school, and 39% of children under five suffer from malnutrition.

The doi moi policy has resulted in an increased number of children living on the street, more child labourers, child prostitution, an increase in trafficking in women and children, and an increasing gap in living standards between rural and urban areas.

No one denies that Vietnamese society is riven with new contradictions. "Unemployment is still sizeable," its national assembly admitted in an end-of-year resolution for the millennium.

"Social evils and crimes tend to increase, the state administrative apparatus remains cumbersome and ineffective. Corruption, bureaucracy and authoritarianism have not been curbed."

Professor Gabriel Kolko, a historian of the war and a sympathetic critic, believes that Vietnam is "drifting precariously". The government has neglected the plight of the peasants.

Other observers are more hopeful, pointing out that politics in Vietnam continues to be less divisive than in China.

"The students dislike the widespread corruption", said an experienced foreign teacher, "but they don't hate the party." And business, not the party, is now the pathway to a successful career.

Real changes may follow next year after a national party congress which is likely to see the final retirement of the old guard. A new generation in the 50-60 age group, described by one diplomat as " very impressive", will take over.

But the argument about whether to "revitalise" or privatise unprofitable state-owned industries may only be a question of semantics.

In the end, jobs will be lost and Vietnamese industry will be exposed to foreign competition.

Its leaders showed brilliant skill in winning two wars, against the French colonialists and Americans, and then fending off the Chinese in a third.

But with 50% of the population under 25 and the total increasing by 1.5m a year, their successors face a protracted war against poverty and unemployment, in a competitive global environment in which there is no easy victory.

Professor Gabriel Kolko, a historian of the war and a sympathetic critic, believes that Vietnam is "drifting precariously". The government has neglected the plight of the peasants. Other observers are more hopeful, pointing out that politics in Vietnam continues to be less divisive than in China. "The students dislike the widespread corruption", said an experienced foreign teacher, "but they don't hate the party." And business, not the party, is now the pathway to a successful career. Real changes may follow next year after a national party congress which is likely to see the final retirement of the old guard. A new generation in the 50-60 age group, described by one diplomat as " very impressive", will take over. But the argument about whether to "revitalise" or privatise unprofitable state-owned industries may only be a question of semantics. In the end, jobs will be lost and Vietnamese industry will be exposed to foreign competition. Its leaders showed brilliant skill in winning two wars, against the French colonialists and Americans, and then fending off the Chinese in a third. But with 50% of the population under 25 and the total increasing by 1.5m a year, their successors face a protracted war against poverty and unemployment, in a competitive global environment in which there is no easy victory.

fields.headline: Fate of hostages unknown
fields.trailText: Police in the Philippines said yesterday that kidnappers who abducted 21 people from a diving resort at the weekend will soon free two Malaysians who are Muslims.
fields.body:
Police in the Philippines said yesterday that kidnappers who abducted 21 people from a diving resort at the weekend will soon free two Malaysians who are Muslims.

The kidnappers are a mix of former Muslim rebels, including the extremist Abu Sayyaf, and members of kidnap-for-ransom gangs, Sulu's governor, Abdusakur Tan, said.

Police in the coastal town of Semporna, in Malaysia, said five more people were arrested yesterday, bringing to 10 the number of people under interrogation over the hostage-taking on Malaysian shores.

Reports from the Philippines said the abductors had been located and that the 21 people seized at gunpoint from Sipadan island on Sunday night were safe.

Officials said troops were being sent to secure the area around Talipao in Sulu province. The province is a sparsely populated, impoverished collection of islands at the Philippines' southern tip.

A military report said the kidnappers included 12 Malay speakers, two speakers of Tausug, a Philippine language, and one person of Caucasian appearance.

"They're safe. I can assure you of that," the Philippine military intelligence chief, Major General Jose Calimlim, said. But Malaysia's inspector-general of police, Norian Mai, said yesterday that none of those reports had been verified.

"A provincial governor may say the hostages are in Basilan, Jolo or Tawi-Tawi, but there's nothing affirmative," he told the national news agency Bernama, adding that the gunmen had yet to contact authorities with any demands.

Six men armed with AK-47s and a rocket launcher abducted the hostages and made off with them on speedboats toward Philippine waters.

The hostages included two French tourists, three Germans, two South Africans, two Finns, one Lebanese, a Filipino worker and nine Malaysians, authorities said. The 21st hostage has yet to be identified.

On Tuesday, Muslim rebels who kidnapped 27 Filipinos on the Philippine island of Basilan last month said they might be responsible for the latest crisis. Basilan and Sipadan share the Celebes sea.

webTitle: The men who came back to find peace

fields.headline: The men who came back to find peace
fields.trailText: It was not their first trip to Vietnam. The last time these greying men sat down at the Rendezvous cafe's white plastic tables they were carrying rifles in the service of their country.
fields.body:
It was not their first trip to Vietnam. The last time these greying men sat down at the Rendezvous cafe's white plastic tables they were carrying rifles in the service of their country.

Some had been stationed near the small town of Hue, the ancient capital that sits midway on Vietnam's long coastline.

Now they were back as part of a project to exorcise the ghosts that have haunted them since the war, and to build better relations between the two countries.

Horrific flashbacks and addictions to alcohol and cigarettes have left Mike Farquhar looking older than his 49 years.

A few years ago he could not have made this trip but, with his wife's encouragement, he boarded the plane in Idaho.

"Coming here this time was a whole heap better than the first time I landed in Vietnam. That was on my 18th birthday," he said.

"I always remember the songs they used to play on the radio: 'Are you going to San Francisco'."

Bob Garrison was 19 when he landed as part of the 25th infantry. He remembers the night he lost hope.

"We had a captain who wanted to make a name for himself," he said.

"We were in some open country. I remember a hill, a village and a clump of trees. We moved in and set up an ambush with claymores [anti-personnel mines]. The captain said it wasn't a dangerous area, so we got on with it.

"We waited and waited and then when we launched the ambush I saw the claymores raining back down on us.

"Charlie [the Viet Cong - Vietnamese Communist fighters] had been watching us the whole time and turned them around so we were getting hit with our own fire and we knew the power of these things. I remember it like yesterday: May 17, 1970. I lost some good friends that day."

The veterans' return trip to Vietnam was the work of one man - Walter Bacak, a former army officer who had himself been through the mill after three tours of duty in Vietnam.

He said: "I came back here on my own at first. I was having some problems with drugs and stuff and my wife persuaded me to come here to help sort out a lot of my insecurities.

"The people here were wonderful and I was starting to get things together, so I decided to start bringing other veterans over to help them to come to terms with their memories."

This is Mr Bacak's eighth trip to Vietnam. He makes two visits a year with about 17 veterans who each pay $1,675 (£1,000) to cover the costs of the trip.

He tries to keep the veterans occupied from dawn every morning so that they don't have a chance to become depressed.

"I try to get them to face their own dragons," he said.

He has had problems with a few who have begun drinking heavily immediately on arrival, but all have ended up benefiting from the trip.

The next day the latest group of veterans was to take part in an exercise Mr Bacak learned from Native American tribes.

Each veteran would be asked to write a letter to anyone he chose, alive or dead, reflecting on his feelings about the war.

At night on a hillside near Duc Pho, south of Hue, the men were to be led one by one to a bonfire and left alone to read their letters aloud, weep, and then watch them disintegrate in the flames.

An even bigger test for the veterans would be the face-to-face encounter on the hillside with a group of their North Vietnamese and Viet Cong counterparts.

"This is the part that has been tearing my guts out," Mike Farquhar said. "I just don't know if I can go through with it. It's just too much."

Evening had fallen on Hue, the cafe was beginning to fill up with travellers and the veterans were getting tired.

Mr Farquhar added: "Ask any one of us if we are afraid of death and we'll tell you the same thing. That's the last thing we're afraid of because we all died here 30 years ago."

fields.headline: Villages of the damned
fields.standfirst: Christopher Kilburn on the hazards of a world carried away by vast engineering projects
fields.trailText: Christopher Kilburn on the hazards of a world carried away by vast engineering projects
fields.body:
The 1990s have seen a blooming of dam controversies. In south east Turkey, 20,000 people are under threat from reservoir flooding by the Ilisu dam project. In northwest India, the Sardar Sarovar dam will displace hundreds of thousands from their homes in the Narmada river valley. Through Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia, there are plans for 15 dams along the Mekong that could disrupt several million.

Most staggering of all is China's Three Gorges dam across the Yangtse River. Due for completion in 2009, the dam will stretch for 2.3 kilometres, stand more than 180 metres high and, with its 26 turbines, generate the energy of nearly 20 nuclear power stations. It will be the world's largest dam and will hold back a reservoir 600km long and more than a kilometre wide. At a cost of $30bn, the spur for the Three Gorges dam is a mixture of community protection, economic development and national prestige.

The Yangtse regularly floods its banks and major overflows, such as in 1954, have killed tens of thousands and left millions homeless. The project's ambitions are to prevent such floods and to provide much-needed energy to China's rapidly industrialising south. Creation of the reservoir, however, will definitely flood the homes of two million people and disrupt water supplies to the natural floodplains on which 75 million others depend for fishing and farming.

The debate about Three Gorges is a gargantuan version of events 40 years ago in north eastern Italy. Exhausted by the second world war and eager to develop its only natural energy resource, the Italian government had sponsored a massive expansion of hydroelectric power schemes in the Alpine foothills north of Venice.

Centrepiece of the programme was the Vajont dam which, nearly 265m high, was in 1960 the highest double-arch dam in the world and a tribute to advanced engineering design. The plan was to transform the tiny Vajont river valley into a reservoir five kilometres long, at the cost of hundreds of homes. Reservoir filling began in February 1960.

Almost immediately small movements were recorded on Mount Toc, just upstream from the dam on the valley's northern flank. Such movements were at first considered normal signs of the flanks adjusting to the weight of water in the reservoir.

In October, with the reservoir less than half full, a crack two kilometres long opened high up on the face of Mount Toc. New geological studies revealed that the moving slope was not part of the original mountain, but the unstable relic of a giant landslide several thousand years old. They also revealed that the thickness of the moving mass was not restricted to surface layers but extended to more than 50m beneath. The mass was far too big to be stopped, but might it be possible to let it creep gently into the valley floor? Reservoir-filling was resumed in late 1961 after a 12-month hiatus.

The Vajont dam was a per fect showcase for Italian expertise. National pride and commercial pressure drove the project onward.

It was never completed. At 10:39 pm on October 9, 1963, 500 million tonnes of mountainside crashed into the Vajont reservoir. The collapse took less than than a minute.

A giant wave surged over the dam and, crashing to the valley floor, punched the air from the mouth of the Vajont gorge with the force of an atomic bomb. A kilometre downstream, the bars in Longarone were crowded as people from nearby villages settled down to watch Celtic play Real Madrid. Four minutes later, Longarone and 1,909 lives ceased to exist.

The Vajont tragedy has become an object lesson for engineers and geologists. Nobody had imagined that a mountain slipping at rates of less than 30 centimetres a day could have suddenly collapsed within seconds.

Forty years later, debate continues as to what actually took place. The conventional explanation is that, after two weeks of heavy rain, percolating rainwater had become trapped inside Mount Toc as water in the reservoir blocked the routes through which rainwater would normally have escaped.

Acting as a jack, the trapped water separated adjacent cracks in the old landslide until, the entire mass was able to slide into the reservoir. The "water-jack" explanation suggests that the total amount of trapped water is crucial to triggering sudden collapse, and that rock drainage can restabilise a slope by allowing the separated cracks to close as water escapes. Indeed, since the Vajont catastrophe, estimating the jacking pressure of trapped water has become fundamental to forecasting whether or not reservoir filling will destabilise a slope.

New studies of the Mount Toc collapse, however, have prompted an alternative view that the role of water is to create, and not just to separate, cracks within rock. Water readily corrodes the tips of rock cracks.

Under most circumstances, the amount of corrosion is insignificant. But when a rock is under stress, so that its existing cracks are only just stable, a small amount of corrosion may be enough to trigger a cascade of cracking, in which small cracks grow and join together to form a giant plane of failure.

Sudden collapse occurs as soon as the failure plane has been formed. Cascade-cracking has been recognised as a precursor to other abrupt and violent geological events, including earthquakes and volcanic eruptions, so it would be remarkable if the same process could not also occur in rock slopes.

Unlike crack separation, however, cascade cracking is unstoppable once it has accelerated beyond a critical rate and no amount of sudden drainage will restabilise the slope. The key point is that the safety conditions against cascade cracking are more stringent than those against crack separation by water pressure. So if cascade cracking was responsible for the collapse at Mount Toc, then current slope-stability forecasts, based only on water pressure, may prove to be inadequate when assessing the impact of new reservoirs on adjacent valley walls.

Nearly 40 years on, attempts to understand the Vajont tragedy are still yielding insights into how reservoirs can destabilise rock slopes. The new lessons must be learned quickly. The 600km of the Three Gorges reservoir will cut dozens of recent and ancient giant landslides and the superficial resemblance with Vajont is overwhelming.

Most clearly, though, Vajont shows how human pride and pressure can trigger what is later described as a natural disaster.

 Next Wednesday at 9 pm, Prof Bill McGuire investigates the Vajont tragedy and interviews survivors in his Radio 4 series Disasters In Waiting.

webTitle: Sri Lanka reeling from Tamil victory

fields.headline: Sri Lanka reeling from Tamil victory
fields.trailText: Sri Lankan military chiefs say they are reinforcing new front lines on the northern Jaffna peninsula following one of the worst defeats in the war against the rebel Tamil Tigers.
fields.body:
Sri Lankan military chiefs say they are reinforcing new front lines on the northern Jaffna peninsula following one of the worst defeats in the war against the rebel Tamil Tigers.

There are fears that civilians could be trapped if the Tigers continue their offensive.

The defence ministry says more than 200 troops were killed on Saturday as thousands of soldiers under artillery and mortar fire beat a hasty retreat from the sprawling Elephant Pass base, which guards the entrance to the peninsula. Other sources said the casualties were much greater.

"We are now consolidating our positions, that is all, we have not decided on anything else," the army spokesman, Brigadier Pallitha Fernando, said.

"There have been some bombing missions but we will monitor terrorist transmissions to see what has been hit."

Sri Lankans have been shocked at both the loss of the base and the scale of casualties. State radio has issued calls for more blood donors, festivals have been cancelled and cabinet members have agreed to donate a month's salary to the war effort.

Military leaders have been defending themselves against accusations that the past five months of heavy fighting should have prepared them for the Tigers' attack.

"We had to have a timely decision when to pull of out Elephant Pass - there was a possibility of it being surrounded and it would be very difficult to maintain a force there," said the army commander, Lieutenant Srilal Weerasoriya. "It was better to save the force than get them caught up."

He denied persistent reports that some soldiers had been suffering from dehydration as the main water supply was located in a nearby base at Iyakachchi, which had been taken earlier.

The peninsula is reported to be relatively quiet as both sides fortify their new positions. It is expected that the Tigers will try to fulfil a long-term pledge by making a serious effort to retake the rest of the peninsula. The town of Jaffna was at the centre of their mini state until the army retook it at the end of 1995.

The peninsula is at the heart of the Tigers' claim for a homeland for the minority Tamil community in the north and east and its capture would strengthen their position in any upcoming peace talks.

There is concern that civilians in Jaffna could be in danger if the fighting continues, as the new front lines are thought to be within artillery range of populated areas.

It has been suggested that the Tigers could call for civilians to evacuate to allow them to shell the area, following a similar incident last year in the town of Vavuniya, which was held by the government.

Sri Lankan leaders have tried to hide scale of the defeat through censorship of the local media. The defence ministry said it had "readjusted the defence line" some 12 hours after the Tigers claimed victory. Newspaper articles have large sections cut out and the government's director of information has attacked the BBC and CNN for reporting the Tigers' claims that more than 1,000 soldiers were killed.

President Chandrika Kumaratunga, who was blinded in one eye in a suicide bomb attack in December, is abroad undergoing medical treatment. Her usually high profile deputy defence minister, Anuruddha Ratwatte, has been quoted as telling a meeting that "we have to accept both victories and setbacks" but has not made any official statements.

The opposition leader, Ranil Wickremesinghe, has called for President Kumaratunga to return and to appear before parliament to outline government plans.

"No one is in charge of the defence of Sri Lanka when all this is happening," he said. "The government must come up with a concrete plan to ensure the rest of the camps are defended."

The opposition leader said that as far as he knew the proposed peace talks between the government and Tamil Tigers, being brokered by the Norwegians, were going ahead. But he warned that the Tigers had considerably strengthened their hand because of their latest success.

fields.headline: Designer genes for jeans
fields.standfirst: DNA says more about your clothes than a label, writes  Anne Lavery
fields.trailText: DNA says more about your clothes than a label, writes Anne Lavery
fields.body:
You own an upmarket brand of designer clothes. You have a problem: your brand is turning up in some unlikely places at half the price.

These clothes could be good imitations or one of your distributors could be conning you. How can you find out? One option is to have a tailor-made DNA tag sprayed on your products. The DNA would encode your company name, when and where the garments were made, the batch number and the distributor.

This is not science-fiction. The clothes you wear, the petrol you put in your car and even the cash you handle everyday could already be labelled with a secret DNA tag. This technology has taken Cardiff-based company Cypher Science 10 years to perfect. Originally intended to monitor oil stolen from tankers, the diverse demand for the product has taken Cypher by surprise. It now marks anything from diamonds to roof insulation.

The properties of DNA make it an extremely stable, invisible, and permanent marker in which a vast amount of information can be stored. DNA is made up of four molecules known as A, T, C and G. The order of those molecules encodes the genetic blueprint to our bodies. However, DNA is easily made artificially and the order of the molecules can be made to encode any information we choose.

When Cypher Science receives an order, it starts a computer program that designs a completely random string of DNA of about 100 molecules in length. It's a bit like the way lottery balls are chosen except that the programme ensures the string bears no similarity to any natural DNA sequence.

Cypher has not invented a code that can be translated into words like Morse code. Instead, for each commission, a computer database is created recording the entire sequence. Those 100 molecules now correspond to that particular product. The randomness of each batch of DNA makes its meaning impossible to crack. You are more likely to win the national lottery every week for a year than come up with the same strand of DNA as Cypher.

A second piece of sophisticated software then identifies two areas about 20 molecules long at either end of the DNA strand that can act as primers or "locks". It is only by having the right "keys" to these locks that the rest of the DNA sequence can be accessed.

The solution of DNA tags can be brushed on to an expensive oil painting, sprayed on to a pair of designer jeans or applied as a single drop onto a perfume carton. Sometimes phosphorescent beads, only two microns in size, are attached to the DNA strands, which if viewed through a UV microscope announce the tag's presence. Only a very small amount of the tag is needed. A thimble full can mark 1,000 tonnes of oil. Only a trace amount of DNA has to be collected when Cypher comes to test an item. Just as in our bodies DNA can copy itself over and over to make new cells, that same enzymatic process can generate thousands of copies of Cypher's DNA - if you have the right key to start the process.

When the locks and keys bind, a dye is released, signalling that the process is working. There's usually no need to sequence the DNA molecule by molecule. Looking up the key sequence in the database will find out what the rest should be and to whom the item it was taken from belongs.

DNA tags provide a powerful tool to combat parallel trading - when a distributor in a country where goods are cheap imports more than he needs, then passes the goods on to a more expensive country, to sell at a slightly higher price and pocket the difference.

"It's not illegal," says a spokesperson for UK Fashion Exports, "but it's a huge headache for brand manufacturers." For example, in Portugal a CD costs about £9, but in the UK £15. There's nothing to stop a Portuguese distributor selling CDs in the UK for £12.

Cypher Science has a run ning contract with a big perfumery in France. The company has 250 distributors, each allocated its own unique tag.

"When they get a box of perfumes they think is in the wrong market, they send us that box and we interpret the DNA to tell them which distributor it should have been," explains Alan Costain, chief executive at Cypher. The perfumery can then stop doing business with that distributor and find one more trustworthy.

Due to the covert nature of tagging, companies are reluctant to admit using such a system and Cypher usually can't divulge its clients' names. "DNA is not the only tagging system," says Costain, "but in general an awful lot of goods have got security tags on. Your Barclaycard does, your bank notes do, even share certificates."

Counterfeiting and the theft of personal goods are each very lucrative areas for black marketeers. "The market for stolen antiques is second only to arms dealing and drugs running. You are talking millions and millions of pounds a year," says Costain.

Another important line of work is tracking ships that dump waste oil at sea. In the recent oil spill off Brittany there were reports that other ships were surreptitiously adding to the slick, but no way of proving it. At the moment oil-tagging is done on a voluntary basis. If it were made mandatory, such polluters could be brought to justice.

Probably the most unusual item that Cypher has been asked to mark are Beanie Babies. "An internet auction house was concerned that with bids of up to $15,000 for one toy, people would return the Beanie Baby and tell them it was a fake," says Costain producing an innocent looking Beanie dog. "We've marked this one on the right eye and the front left paw."
